abstract: -- One gets an appalling idea of the sacrifices that have already been made to the Moloch of Rebellion, by an official return of the Surgeon-General at Richmond, who states that up to the present time one hundred thousand sick and wounded soldiers have been received in the hospitals of that city! Note that this is but one item, for other cities have received proportionate numbers, and also that this return excludes those that have been killed on the battle-field. From these examples one may form a conception of the enormous havoc that the war has made in the Southern population. It must be remembered that these losses are more palpably felt there than among our teeming masses. In the semi-feudal constitution of Southern society, each man of thousands of these was the centre of a little social system, which falls to pieces without him; and if the war were to continue very much longer the whole framework of Southern life must be rent asunder. Poor, deluded, God-forsaken people, wrecked and torn by the earthquake and the lightning of war, where weeping and wailing resounds through the land, and ashes are on every brow!
lead_paragraph: -- One gets an appalling idea of the sacrifices that have already been made to the Moloch of Rebellion, by an official return of the Surgeon-General at Richmond, who states that up to the present time one hundred thousand sick and wounded soldiers have been received in the hospitals of that city! Note that this is but one item, for other cities have received proportionate numbers, and also that this return excludes those that have been killed on the battle-field. From these examples one may form a conception of the enormous havoc that the war has made in the Southern population. It must be remembered that these losses are more palpably felt there than among our teeming masses. In the semi-feudal constitution of Southern society, each man of thousands of these was the centre of a little social system, which falls to pieces without him; and if the war were to continue very much longer the whole framework of Southern life must be rent asunder. Poor, deluded, God-forsaken people, wrecked and torn by the earthquake and the lightning of war, where weeping and wailing resounds through the land, and ashes are on every brow!

abstract: Yesterday morning a portion of Gen. SUMNER'S corps, consisting of the Fifth and Sixth Cavalry, (regulars,) and a horse battery, made a successful reconnoissance in the direction of Charlestown. The party, under the command of Major WHITING, proceeded nearly four miles, drove in the enemy's' pickets, capturing five, suffered no loss, and established the fact that the enemy are in force at Charles- town.
lead_paragraph: HARPER's FERRY, Va., Saturday, Sept. 27, 1862.

abstract: Hon. ANDREW JACKSON HAMILTON, of Texas' will address the citizens of this City to-night at the Cooper Institute, and those of Brooklyn at the Academy of Music, on Thursday night, under the auspices of the Union Defence Committee. Mr. HAMILTON formerly represented his State in the United States Congress, and was one of the most eloquent orators from the South. He was not swayed from his allegiance by the ragamuffins of his section, but firmly stood by the Union through good report and through evil report, and was on account thereof subjected to threats and indignities which would appal a man of less nerve and thorough determination. All the property he possessed was taken from him, and he escaped to the borders without shoes and nothing but rags to his back. He is now in New-York, and has been induced by several prominent citizens to speak in this City previous to proceeding to Washington.
lead_paragraph: Hon. abstract: -- The London Times, maddened that people in this country have ceased to pay the slightest heed to its impotent rant and raving on everything American, in its last article works itself into foaming frenzy, and talks about "England and France landing a hundred thousand men each, and driving back the Federal armies of invasion"! It is a characteristic of madness to play fast and loose with figures; but it is somewhat ludicrous coolly and calmly to bring these wild military maunderings into comparison with that country's actual resources.
lead_paragraph: -- The London Times, maddened that people in this country have ceased to pay the slightest heed to its impotent rant and raving on everything American, in its last article works itself into foaming frenzy, and talks about "England and France landing a hundred thousand men each, and driving back the Federal armies of invasion"! abstract: We publish on the second page of this morning's TIMES a full report of Judge TREMAIN'S speech at the Syracuse Convention, in review of GOV. SEYMOUR'S elaborate statement of his own position in the pending canvass.
lead_paragraph: We publish on the second page of this morning's TIMES a full report of Judge TREMAIN'S speech at the Syracuse Convention, in review of GOV. SEYMOUR's elaborate statement of his own position in the pending canvass. It is an able, clear and convincing document. It strips off the thin disguise of loyalty by which Gov. SEYMOUR seeks to cloak the real tendency of the canvass in which he is engaged, and lets daylight into the actual aims and objects of this formidable attempt to cripple the National Administration in the very midst of its contest with the rebellion.

abstract: Gen. HALLECK could not have made a more weighty recommendation than that in his circular to the Governors of the several States, urging them to fill the numerous vacancies in volunteer regiments now in the field, by "promoting officers, non-commissioned officers and privates, who have distinguished themselves in the field, or who have shown a capacity for military command." The power of officering the volunteer regiments is vested in the Governors of the several States; so that the Government or General-in-Chief can do no more than recommend a general policy in the matter. The Governors of some of the States allow the regiments to elect their own officers; but, generally, the State Chiefs take the matter into their own hands, and as it is utterly impossible that they should have an intimate acquaintance with each regiment, even if they desired to, it is easy to see that places which should go as rewards to merit are too often given to personal or political favorites.
lead_paragraph: Gen. abstract: No cause, however good, can enlist public sympathy, and no enterprise, however purely philanthropic, can be agitated, which bad men will not seize upon and attempt to use for their own vile and selfish purposes.
lead_paragraph: No cause, however good, can enlist public sympathy, and no enterprise, however purely philanthropic, can be agitated, which bad men will not seize upon and attempt to use for their own vile and selfish purposes. This fate, we fear, is befalling the President's purpose to establish a colony of free blacks somewhere without the limits of the United States. It is, to say the least, a decidedly suspicious circumstance that there is an evident pre-determination to make the proposed colonial experiment upon the exploded Chiriqui Grant, in Nicaragua. We have no disposition to charge upon Senator POMEROY, of Kansas, a willful design to deceive the proposed colonists, and to coin money of their blood. With his motives we have at this time nothing to do. It is certain, however, that some of his statements to the proposed colonists are grossly erroneous, and consequently none of them can be trusted. If he is not aware that he is grossly misleading those who are expected to initiate his colony, he has himself been greatly imposed upon.

abstract: REPORT. -- The official report of Gen. MCCLELLAN presents a fearful picture of life wasted at the battles of South Mountain and Antietam. The footing up of casualties on the Union side is 14,794. On the side of the rebels an estimate, somewhat forced, perhaps, and exaggerated, reaches the startling total of 30,000 men; so that by this official statement we are authorized to believe that some 45,000 men were slaughtered or disabled in that sanguinary fight. This is frightful. Men may reasonably turn from such a story, and calculate the gains that might partly compensate such losses. A victory must be carried to the per contra; immortal honor to the soldiers who fought so gallantly and to the officers who led them so bravely andhandled them so skillfully; a large number of flags, some cannon, and enough email arms to furnish a division; these figure on the Opposite side of the ledger, but are far from balancing the account. The price paid was worth infinitely more; it was worth the capture or annihilation of the rebel army. We shall be told one of these days what officer, or what difficulties of the country, or what combination of circumstances, is to be held responsible for this worst of all bargains.

abstract: The President's Emancipation proclamation contains one feature that has escaped attention in the more absorbing interest drawn around its leading edict.
lead_paragraph: The President's Emancipation proclamation contains one feature that has escaped attention in the more absorbing interest drawn around its leading edict. It is the renewal of the offer made by the President through Congress, in June last, to the Border Slave States, of a compensated Emancipation and colonization of the freed blacks. This proposition of the President received at the time of its utterance, the decided indorsement of Congress. There was an entire willingness expressed in every influential quarter to make this policy a permanent and National one, and seek through its agency a gradual, peaceful and philanthropic solution of the Slavery question in the United States.

abstract: Editorial speculates on probable length of war
snippet: Editorial speculates on probable length of war
lead_paragraph: One question must come up vary seriously before all our readers, and will be considered from various aspects, and that is, What shall be the length of this war? Are we to have a weary contest of many years, or a struggle short and desperate? It is a question seriously affecting all business arrangements, and one in which almost every member of all civilized communities has a profound interest. The conditions on which any well considered answer can be given are so various, shifting and uncertain, that it seems hardly worth while to attempt at this period a prediction or a probable estimate. Still, those conditions should be carefully considered, and some sort of conclusion may be attained.
headline: {'main': 'The Probable Length of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Probable Length of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: One of our special correspondents with the Army of the Potomac gives an account of several important reconnoissances into Virginia on Monday. Col. FARNSWORTH'S brigade of cavalry, accompanied by two batteries, crossed the river below Shepherdstown, and reconnoitred the country for a distance of five or six miles toward Win- chester the result being the discovery that the enemy still holds his position near Winchester.
lead_paragraph: One of our special correspondents with the Army of the Potomac gives an account of several important reconnoissances into Virginia on Monday. Col. FARNSWORTH's brigade of cavalry, accompanied by two batteries, crossed the river below Shepherdstown, and reconnoitred the country for a distance of five or six miles toward Winchester -- the result being the discovery that the enemy still holds his position near Winchester. A regiment of rebel cavalry was seen on the road from Shepherdstown to Martinsburgh, but a collision did not take place. On the road to Winchester, a number of the enemy's wounded were taken prisoners and paroled.

abstract: Editorial notes lack of official reports from McClellan on battles he has commanded
snippet: Editorial notes lack of official reports from McClellan on battles he has commanded
lead_paragraph: We have received several communications asking the publication of Gen. MCCLELLAN's report of the battle of Antietam. We should gladly comply with this request -- but so far as we are aware, Gen. MCCLELLAN has made no such report. He has sent to Washington a statement of the losses of his own army, and some very interesting conjectures concerning the losses of the enemy, -- and this we published yesterday. But of the battle itself, -- the disposition of troops by which it was fought, the conduct of the different divisions engaged the objects sought to be accomplished by it. and the extent to which these objects were attained, as well as the other circumstances and incidents which go to make up the history of a great engagement, he has given us no account whatever.

abstract: We give place, with some reluctance, to a letter from Washington defending Gen. HALLECK against sundry imputations, contained in an editorial of the National Intelligencer, written in the specific interest of Gen. McCLELLAN. We do not propose to enter at all into...
lead_paragraph: We give place, with some reluctance, to a letter from Washington defending Gen. HALLECK against sundry imputations, contained in an editorial of the National Intelligencer, written in the specific interest of Gen. McCLELLAN. We do not propose to enter at all into the merits of the controversy, and we publish the letter only in response to a strong appeal against the evident injustice of such an attack upon the Commander-in-Chief, made for the evident purpose of building up one of his subordinates at his expense.

abstract: editorials on difficulties caused by use
snippet: editorials on difficulties caused by use
lead_paragraph: quite time some effective steps were taken to stop the use of postage stamps as currency. They never were fit for such a purpose, though in the absolute dearth of small change they have been of some service to the business community. But currency, to answer any good end, must have some essential value. It must either be of intrinsic worth, like metal coins, or represent somebody's credit, -- that of the Government, of a corporation, or of private individuals. The only intrinsic value of these stamps consisted in the fact that they might be used to pay postage. When people took them, they thought that they could convert them into this use at least, and that so long as letters had to go by mail they would have some value, and might therefore be safely regarded as currency.

abstract: A dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN'S Headquarters, dated last evening, informs us that Gen. PLEASANTON, in the morning, crossed the Potomac at Shepherdstown, with a force of cavalry and artillery, for the purpose of making a reconnoissance in the enemy's rear.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN's Headquarters, dated last evening, informs us that Gen. PLEASANTON, in the morning, crossed the Potomac at Shepherdstown, with a force of cavalry and artillery, for the purpose of making a reconnoissance in the enemy's rear. He came up with a force of rebels near Shepherdstowns and drove them to Martinsburgh, from which place he soon shelled them, with a loss on our side of only two men wounded. Some prisoners were captured. It is now believed that very few rebel troops are at Winchester, their main force being encamped between that place and Martinsburgh.

abstract: Thanksgiving Day proclamations by Gov. Morgan; Proclamations by NYS Gov
snippet: Thanksgiving Day proclamations by Gov. Morgan; Proclamations by NYS Gov
lead_paragraph: From the depth of National affliction we come, with stricken hearts and chastened spirits, to own our dependence upon the Most High, and to render, with grateful sense, our thanksgivings for His mercies, countless in number and infinite in extent. A year fraught with the heaviest sorrow has yet, in the merciful plan of Providence, been distinguished by the most conspicuous blessings. Although it is numbered among the dark periods of history, and its sorrowful records are graven on many hearthstones, yet the precious blood shed in the cause of our country, will hallow and strengthen our love and our reverence for it and its institutions, while the bitter sorrows of the year will discipline us into humility. Whatever was passionate in the earlier period of the war has given way to a deep and subdued conviction of duty in defending the integrity of the Union. Reflection has made clear our obligations, and the issues of the momentous struggle present themselves in more definite form. Our National aims have been elevated, and our sacrifices have made us less selfish; our Government and institutions placed in jeopardy have brought us to a more just appreciation of their value. Looking beyond the wicked leaders, who have precipitated this great calamity of civil war upon us, we see that the people in arms against the Government possess the higher qualities of our national character, and though their minds have been perverted by passion and prejudice, yet on many occasions their prowess and devotion to their cause have been such as to win our respect. We are permitted to see that the war is developing the manhood of the nation; and when peace shall return, we have faith that the American Republic will be more powerful, the Government more permanent, the elements of society more perfectly blended, and the people more firmly united than ever.

abstract: A special meeting of the Board of Councilmen was held at noon, yesterday, to consider the resolution from the Aldermen, which had been laid over, in favor of paying the City bounty of $50 to all recruits enlisted since the payment of this bounty ceased, on the 24th of September, and of continuing the payment of the same until the 9th inst., the day before the draft is to take place, as ordered by the Governor. President PINCKNEY was in the Chair, and ten other members were present promptly at 12 o'clock, but it was found necessary to dispatch the Sergeant-at-arms for two more members, to make up a quorum. Two were soon found in the Clerk's office, down stairs, who immediately answered roll-call, and enabled the Board to proceed to business.

abstract: The Banner Club of Brooklyn, a political organization of much influence and strength, has invited Hon. and Major-Gen. CASSIUS M. CLAY to speak before them at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Tuesday next. Mr. CLAY, in a letter before us, has accepted the invitation, and proposes, while awaiting orders from his military superiors, to try and induce his fellow-citizens to think and do the right thing in the coming political struggle. His text will be the President's Proclamation.

abstract: The inclemency of the weather last evening did not prevent the attendance of a large audience at Continental Hall, corner of Thirty-fourth-street and Eighth-avenue, for the purpose of forwarding the election of WADSWORTH and TREMAIN.
lead_paragraph: The inclemency of the weather last evening did not prevent the attendance of a large audience at Continental Hall, corner of Thirty-fourth-street and Eighth-avenue, for the purpose of forwarding the election of WADSWORTH and TREMAIN. Mr. SAMUEL SINCLAIR called the meeting to order, and on motion of Mr. EDWARD GILBERT, Mr. P.C. BULKLEY took the chair. The exercises were commenced by Mr. GEO. N. SEYMOUR leading in the singing of the "Star Spangled Banner." Mr. GILBERT read a series of resolutions, which were adopted, cordially indorsing the Republican Union State ticket, and stigmatizing the Seymour ticket as the representative of treason in the North. Mr. SEYMOUR next sang an original song of the contrabands, called "Old Shady." There were loud calls for McDONALD to furnish another song, but that gentleman persistently declined. abstract: Editorial on Curtis report that most people of Southwest desire peace; editorial speculating on reasons for resolution
snippet: Editorial on Curtis report that most people of Southwest desire peace; editorial speculating on reasons for resolution
lead_paragraph: We do not for a moment suppose that any collusion exists between the Southern representative and the Northern "Conservatives," for we do the latter party the justice to believe that they are laboring not for the independence of the South, but for the submission of the North. They are not seeking to exalt the Confederacy, but merely to abase the Union. Mr. FOOTE, on the contrary, is earnestly bent upon achieving a complete separation of the two sections; and we interpret the conjunction of his remarkable speech at Richmond, with the scarcely less remarkable resolutions of the Democratic Convention at Albany, to mean simply and solely that the rebel leaders are sagacious enough to see the great opportunity which the action of the New-York Democracy affords them, and resolute enough to avail themselves at once.

abstract: The United States vs. The Cargo of the Schooner Sarah and Caroline. When this was called for hearing, it was found that no proof was furnished convicting the vessel of any confiscable offence, and the Court therefore suspended proceedings in the cause, and as no one had appeared in the cause for the cargo allowed the United States Attorney a year and a day within which to furnish further proof.
lead_paragraph: About two months afterward proofs in preparatorio were offered to the Court. A witness was produced, who testified that he was present at capture of vessel, which was taken by Bienville, on Dec 11, 1861, at the mouth of the St. John's River, in Florida. She was being towed out by a steamer, which dropped her on being pursued by the Bienville, when she endeavored to feet back into port, but was overhauled, about 6 P.M., when she was found deserted by her crew. She was loaded with turpentine and a few shingles. Letters were found on board her addressed to Nassau. N.P., but no papers were brought from her with the cargo to this port. The vessel was detained by the United States Flag-Officer at Beaufort, S.C.

abstract: In calling attention to this regiment, we would mention that they have been in the held for the past sixteen months, doing active duty as engineer troops with the Army of the Potomac. Their commander, Col. MURPHY, formerly of the navy and a graduate of Annapolis Naval Academy, is an experienced engineer, whose merit has been often acknowledged. This regiment is now organizing a second battalion; having some 1,200 men in the field, recruits must fall in lively, or they will be shut out Their bounties are as large as any other regiment and wages higher, viz.: $13, $17, $20, $34 per month. This is the chance for mechanics. Their recruiting-office is No. 83 Spring-street.

abstract: Editorial doubts report Confederates are raising large fleet of war steamers in Great Britain
snippet: Editorial doubts report Confederates are raising large fleet of war steamers in Great Britain
lead_paragraph: Intelligence has been received that the rebels are raising a large fleet of war steamers in England, and are constructing a steam-ram at Liverpool. Many persons may be inclined to doubt the truth of this report. From the operation of numerous causes, the rebel Government, if left to its own resources, seems in no condition to strengthen its naval arm. Already, according to official statements, fifteen millions of dollars have been wasted in the vain attempt. And the chief result in which the enterprise has culminated, is to prove that ricketly old hulls, roofed with railroad iron, and armed with a beak, are not the highest possible ideal of naval architecture in the nineteenth century. For their terrible rams, and other novel sea-monsters, have contracted an awkward habit of injuring themselves as much as their opponents, or of foundering in the most unhandsome manner, and going to the bottom when least expected. The Confederates clearly have not as yet made good their call to the empire of the sea.
headline: {'main': 'The New Rebel Fleet.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Rebel Fleet.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is pretty hard work to protect the Government against its enemies, but when, in addition, it has to be protected from its friends, the task becomes a little too much.
lead_paragraph: It is pretty hard work to protect the Government against its enemies, but -- when, in addition, it has to be protected from its friends, the task becomes a little too much. Its own agents ought, one would think, to be men who will not join the rebel raids, either upon the Territory or the Treasury of the country. Some of them, we regret to say, seem to consider the contest with the rebels as simply a race for plunder, -- and we are by no means certain that they are likely to come out last.

abstract: A lot of bids for public work were to have been opened at the street Department at noon yesterday, but the opening was postponed till next Monday, on account of the absence of the Comptroller.
lead_paragraph: -- A lot of bids for public work were to have been opened at the street Department at noon yesterday, but the opening was postponed till next Monday, on account of the absence of the Comptroller. No explanation of his absence was received from him, but it is of course understood that it was because he believes that Mr. KNAPP is legally removed from the Street Commissionership, and would not encourage him in retaining charge of the affairs of the Department. Mr. KNAPP was present and ordered the postponement. The contracts for which the bids were given, are for repairs to piers and engine houses, and for building two new engine houses. As Mr. KNAPP intends to contest his removal when a successor is appointed, and attempts to oust him from the Department, come time may elapse before the work can be put in progress.

abstract: Comptroller HAWS yesterday issued the customary circulars to the various heads of the City and County departments and bureaus, stating that the time for preparing the financial estimates for the ensuing year having arrived, he respectfully solicits from heads of departments and others estimates and statements in detail of the probable expenses of conducting the branches of the public business with which they are severally charged, for next year,...
lead_paragraph: Comptroller HAWS yesterday issued the customary circulars to the various heads of the City and County departments and bureaus, stating that the time for preparing the financial estimates for the ensuing year having arrived, he respectfully solicits from heads of departments and others estimates and statements in detail of the probable expenses of conducting the branches of the public business with which they are severally charged, for next year, which are payable from either the City or County [???]. Two forms of circulars are used, one for the City and one for the County. It is requested that the [???] to them be sent in by the 20th inst., in order that they may be made up and submitted to the Common Council and the [???] at an early day. There never was a better time for, or greater need of public economy in the City than at present, and it is hoped that the parties to whom these circulars are addressed, fully understand the stelagency the people now feel, and will act accordingly in dispensing with superfluous offices to save the City from heavy taxation. In many other ways they can cooperate with the Comptroller in economizing for the public benefit. The following is an extract from the circulars.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. Mr. FORREST made his first appearances this season on Monday in "King Lear" Of all the Shakesperian characters that he personates Lear is generally allowed to be the one in which he can be seen to the most striking advantage. Even in the time when it was thought to be the correct thing...
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- Mr. FORREST made his first appearances this season on Monday in "King Lear" Of all the Shakesperian characters that he personates Lear is generally allowed to be the one in which he can be seen to the most striking advantage. Even in the time when it was thought to be the correct thing to deny, in a comprehensive sort of way, that Mr. FORREST possessed either talent or genius for the portrayal of the higher order of dramatic passion, an exception was usually made in favor of his [???] which hostile criticism acknowledged, to be a creation of rare power, wherein the beauties far outbalanced the defects. Popular opinion has always regarded it as one of the grandest performances over beheld upon the stage -- quite sufficient, of itself, to stamp Mr. FORREST the foremost actor of his generation. Popular opinion is better than criticism, after all, inasmuch as it [???] theatres and demonstrates itself enthusiastically in applause. Mr. FORREST has found that out long ago, and he has wisely modeled his style according to the dictates of the judgment in which he finds the largest number of people concur. It is sufficient to say of Mr. FORREST's performance that it has lost none of its former attractions, though it has mellowed and improved with age. The three [???] of the unfortunate old monarch are ably represented by Madame PONISI, Miss WELLS and Mrs. GLADSTANE.

abstract: PAYMENT OF THE BOUNTY AT CAMP SCOTT.  The payment of the bounty to the troops at Camp Scott, Staten Island, has given the greatest satisfaction to the troops at present stationed there, and has inspired them with a degree of confidence in the United States Government which has had the effect of causing a great number of fresh recruits to join.
lead_paragraph: PAYMENT OF THE BOUNTY AT CAMP SCOTT. -- The payment of the bounty to the troops at Camp Scott, Staten Island, has given the greatest satisfaction to the troops at present stationed there, and has inspired them with a degree of confidence in the United States Government which has had the effect of causing a great number of fresh recruits to join the service. It is, however, to be regretted that there are found some who do not fully appreciate indulgent consideration of the Government, as many, after having received the bounty payment, have left the camp without the regular permission of the commanding officer in obtaining a pass from the proper quarter; however, this is supposed to be a kind of desire to visit their families and have the bounty with them which has been so liberally paid. This was found to be the case on Saturday last, but we apprehend that they will not long absent themselves from their different corps, but will at once return to camp, where the greatest activity seems to be going on to send a trops forward to the seat of war. Since Gen. CORCORAN took up his quarters at the camp, large numbers of new recruits have flocked in to [???] his legion, and such success has attended the raising of his Legion Brigade, that it will be drafted to the seat of was so soon as its full quota has been made up.

abstract: editorial holds Florida as most advantageous state for colonization
snippet: editorial holds Florida as most advantageous state for colonization
lead_paragraph: The subject of colonizing the blacks of the Southern States that are so rapidly becoming free through the operation of the war, is engaging very general attention, and has already led to the development of several plans of more or less merit. The Government of Denmark has applied for several thousand " contrabands," as these persons for present convenience are called; the Island of Hayti, through responsible agents, is seeking to draw a portion thither; Liberia claims, as Africa's right, all her children to be returned to her; Senator POMEROY, of Kansas, is organizing a colony, which he proposes to plant in Central America; and, now, Mr. ELI THAYER, well known for his practical philanthropy, comes forward with a proposition to make Florida, a State of our own Union, the home of the enfranchised blacks.

lead_paragraph: There is an assurance at once imposing and refrigerant in the pretences with which the Seymour Party submit to the people the petition to have the business of subduing rebellion transferred from the hands of the Administration to their own. Mr. LINCOLN's Government they say, has proved its utter inadequacy to the task. The war languishes. The country clamors for greater energy. Intrust to the National Democrats the business of enforcing the laws, and they will show how well and sternly, and speedily the thing will be done.

abstract: A meeting of the colored people of Brooklyn was held at the Bridge-street Methodist Church, on Wednesday evening, to take into consideration the President's emancipation proclamation, and other matters of interest to the colored people of the North...
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the colored people of Brooklyn was held at the Bridge-street Methodist Church, on Wednesday evening, to take into consideration the President's emancipation proclamation, and other matters of interest to the colored people of the North in the present crisis. J.W.B. SMITH was chosen Chairman, and THEODORE VOORHIS Secretary. The Chairman, on taking the Chair, said that the proclamation of the President was causing great feeling among the free colored people of the North. They had been pained to hear from his lips that they had been the cause of all this bloodshed, and that his race and theirs could never dwell together in this land on terms of equality. And what was it proposed to do with us? Why send us to Chiriqui --a place than which, if Satan himself had been sent to search, he could not have selected a worse. He objected emphatically to this proposition, for various reasons; among others, the existence of the Spanish Peon law, by which, if one of the emigrants happened to get into debt, he could be sold into Slavery for its payment. Besides, it was an extremely unhealthy colony, where no people of any race could maintain their health for two years. Of Honduras the speaker had a much more favorable idea, and he entered into a glowing description of the country, its healthful climate, its productive soil and its luxuriant vegetation. He closed by requesting the Secretary to read an editorial in yesterday's TIMES, relative to the Chiriqui colonization scheme, which, he said, met with the hearty approval of every man who had any understanding of the subject.

abstract: The colored people of this City assembled in large numbers, at 8 P.M., yesterday, in the Shiloh Church, on the corner of Marion and Prince streets, to do public honor to Capt. ROBERT SMALLS, their gallant brother, who "with his comrades, seized a rebel gunboat, resoned his family and mose of his companions from Slavery, passing six forts, reach-
lead_paragraph: The colored people of this City assembled in large numbers, at 8 P.M., yesterday, in the Shiloh Church, on the corner of Marion and Prince streets, to do public honor to Capt. ROBERT SMALLS, their gallant brother, who "with his comrades, seized a rebel gunboat, resoned his family and mose of his companions from Slavery, passing six forts, reaching the Union squadron, and presenting the Government with the trophies of his achievement." Punctually the house was crowded with the most intelligent and respectable portion of the African-Americans of the great Metropolis. The female portion of the audience was very numerous, and remarkable for every visible characteristic that adorns the sex. Neither personal attractions, taste nor dignity were wanting.

abstract: ERN UNIONISTS. -- Of those sturdy and irrepressible patriots, who ennoble their race by devotion to their country, ANDREW JACKSON HAMILTON, of Texas, should stand in the foremost rank. Rather than enjoy the honors, rewards and immunity offered as a bribe by treason, he has given up home, and friends, and wealth; and after months of danger by the way, is here at last a penniless fugitive. In old Greece, they who came with such sacred antecedents, were known as "suppliants." Their cause was holy; and king or archon who should turn away from it unhelpful, were exposed to the wrath of the Gods and the vengeful pursuit of the Furies. The cause which brought Mr. HAMILTON hither, he exposed last night at Brooklyn, and more briefly in New-York. He spoke of the sufferings of Southern Unionists; of the condition especially of his own imperial State; of the wrongs, the cruelties, the unspeakable torture suffered by his friends and neighbors; and implored the people and the Government to move at once to the rescue of those political confessors. Of the peculiar and effective eloquence of this great Southwestern orator, it is impossible to give a sufficient idea. His title to be regarded as the leading stump-speaker of Texas, and the reason why, next to HOUSTON, he was the most popular man in the State, before treason had poisoned the minds of the people, it is very easy to understand after listening to a few of his magnificent periods

abstract: COMMERCE. -- An effort was made yesterday to prevent the National War Committee from continuing its occupancy of the rooms belonging to the Chamber of Commerce. The contest in the latter body was quite spirited on the part of the exclusionists; but the Chamber, indisposed to commit itself, even by implication, to measures tending to discourage loyal efforts to sustain and perpetuate the Government, voted against the expulsion; and it now only remains for the Committee to seek accommodations elsewhere to make the transaction neat and complete in every particular. The Chamber of Commerce has vindicated its loyalty. Let the Committee vindicate its dignity.

abstract: Col. SHERRILL, of the One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Regiment, N.Y.V., who was wounded in the month at Harper's Ferry, has returned to his home in Geneva, where he will remain until his wound is healed. Col. SHERRILL was formerly a member of the State Senate, from the Tenth (Ulster) District; lived afterwards in Brooklyn, and, two or three years since, removed to Geneva, where he has a large and beautiful farm. He is a man of high character, and universally esteemed.

abstract: Two months of the operation of the Tariff Act of 1862 have passed and no diminution in the amount of duties received has yet been apparent. The estimate mark, when the last Congress was in session, that the duties could be made to reach the sum of $100,000,000 for the next fiscal year proves not to have been nearly as incorrect as many then prophecied it was. On the supposition that the new tariff would yield the above-named sum the law was framed and the Tax bill passed. The statement that under its operation the amount received would approach that sum was dorided in Congress by some members, and was thought by many to be extravagant. It appeared probable that if the war should continue, the importations would diminish, and in consequence, the receipts for duty be less instead of greater than before. It did not seem rational to believe, when the condition & the country was already unfavorable to the importation of foreign goods and merchandise, that the passage of a tariff law levying higher duties than the ones already imposed, would increase the receipts. It appeared last Spring and Summer as though the importing trade must suffer on account of the encouragement afforded domestic manufactures, and from the unsettled state of the country. But strange to say, though the nation has been and still is involved in its most gigantic war, the people seem to have plenty of money and to expend it more freely than ever in purchasing articles of foreign growth and manufacture. The receipts at our Custom-house in July were unparalleled, but for this there was a good reason, namely, that importations were increased in anticipation of the new Tariff, to take effect on the 1st of August, and that the withdrawals of goods from bond to escape the new duties were very great. It appeared evident to all then that the next month must be a dull one, that the importations must be small, and the receipts greatly inferior to those usual at that season. It did not seem in the least probable that importers would make large purchases abroad at the beginning of the operation of the new tariff, especially when they had been afforded ample opportunity to anticipate it and enter such goods as they were in need of under smaller rates. It seemed that the importations must be small till the stock already on hand should have been consumed. But when the month had passed, the official returns showed that the receipts, though inferior to those of July, were nearly $5,000,000 -- a sum larger than that received in any month of 1860 or 1861. But a reason could be assigned for this by those who believed that importations must decrease. The new tariff had been in operation only one month, and the heavy receipts might have been due to the arrival of goods shipped by owners who believed the merchandise could reach this country before the 1st of August. Falling in this, the new duties must be paid; this reason could have been assigned with some appearance of validity, but another month has passed, and instead of falling off, the receipts have been greater than in August. For September, they were about $5,300,000. There figures prove that the demand for foreign merchandise is still good, and that the community does not feel inclined to cease its expenditure for them on account of the war.
lead_paragraph: Two months of the operation of the Tariff Act of 1862 have passed and no diminution in the amount of duties received has yet been apparent. The estimate mark, when the last Congress was in session, that the duties could be made to reach the sum of $100,000,000 for the next fiscal year proves not to have been nearly as incorrect as many then prophecied it was. On the supposition that the new tariff would yield the above-named sum the law was framed and the Tax bill passed. The statement that under its operation the amount received would approach that sum was dorided in Congress by some members, and was thought by many to be extravagant. It appeared probable that if the war should continue, the importations would diminish, and in consequence, the receipts for duty be less instead of greater than before. It did not seem rational to believe, when the condition & the country was already unfavorable to the importation of foreign goods and merchandise, that the passage of a tariff law levying higher duties than the ones already imposed, would increase the receipts. It appeared last Spring and Summer as though the importing trade must suffer on account of the encouragement afforded domestic manufactures, and from the unsettled state of the country. But strange to say, though the nation has been and still is involved in its most gigantic war, the people seem to have plenty of money and to expend it more freely than ever in purchasing articles of foreign growth and manufacture. The receipts at our Custom-house in July were unparalleled, but for this there was a good reason, namely, that importations were increased in anticipation of the new Tariff, to take effect on the 1st of August, and that the withdrawals of goods from bond to escape the new duties were very great. It appeared evident to all then that the next month must be a dull one, that the importations must be small, and the receipts greatly inferior to those usual at that season. It did not seem in the least probable that importers would make large purchases abroad at the beginning of the operation of the new tariff, especially when they had been afforded ample opportunity to anticipate it and enter such goods as they were in need of under smaller rates. It seemed that the importations must be small till the stock already on hand should have been consumed. But when the month had passed, the official returns showed that the receipts, though inferior to those of July, were nearly $5,000,000 -- a sum larger than that received in any month of 1860 or 1861. But a reason could be assigned for this by those who believed that importations must decrease. The new tariff had been in operation only one month, and the heavy receipts might have been due to the arrival of goods shipped by owners who believed the merchandise could reach this country before the 1st of August. Falling in this, the new duties must be paid; this reason could have been assigned with some appearance of validity, but another month has passed, and instead of falling off, the receipts have been greater than in August. For September, they were about $5,300,000. There figures prove that the demand for foreign merchandise is still good, and that the community does not feel inclined to cease its expenditure for them on account of the war.

abstract: Yesterday, the Mayor approved the resolution, ordering an extension and continuance of the bounty term for recruits from the 24th ult. to the 9th inst. Comptroller HAWS, however, chose not to pay cut the $50 to each man so promptly as before. Having discovered that great frauas have been practiced, both...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Mayor approved the resolution, ordering an extension and continuance of the bounty term for recruits from the 24th ult. to the 9th inst. Comptroller HAWS, however, chose not to pay cut the $50 to each man so promptly as before. Having discovered that great frauas have been practiced, both her and in Brooklyn, on the special bounty funds, he is determined to exercise caution sufficient to prevent any further repetition of them, so far as this City is concerned. He has found that collusions existed between Adjutants of regiments and recruiting officers, by which men have been enlisted over and over again, and each time under a different name, and, perhaps, different dress.

abstract: Our attention has been called to a provision which we must admit has caused us some alarm, in the draft of a civil code which has been prepared by the Commissioners of the Code and submitted for examination, and we deem it our duty to call the attention of the public to it. It is found in the 115th section, which provides that "a surviving parent (or, in case of an illegitimate, the mother) of a child likely to be born, or of an unmarried child who is a minor, or incapable of taking care of his person, may by deed or will appoint a guardian of the person." Thus it will be seen that the Commissioners intimate very strongly, that under this code, the "surviving parent" "of a child likely to be born," may in some cases be the father.

abstract: An institution little known beyond a certain circle of our quieter citizens has been, for a year past, in full progress of successful operation. A most substantial and commodious building of three stories in height adjoins the Friends or Quaker Heeting-house on Rutherford-place, and is known as the Friends Seminary. It is conducted upon princi-...
lead_paragraph: An institution little known beyond a certain circle of our quieter citizens has been, for a year past, in full progress of successful operation. A most substantial and commodious building of three stories in height adjoins the Friends or Quaker Heeting-house on Rutherford-place, and is known as the Friends Seminary. It is conducted upon principles somewhat differing from those which apply in our public schools, although between them and it exist the most cordial relations. The building is subdivided into large assembling rooms with class rooms adjoining; lecture-room, with laboratory completely furnished with every apparatus for the elucidation of lectures upon the various sciences, while the main hall itself is provided with maps, charts, electrical machinery, an air pump of mammoth dimensions and a model steam engine, all of which requisites are brought to bear in teaching the young idea how to shoot. The first lecture of the season took place last night. Lecturers of ability are to be selected and invited to deliver discourse to the various departments once a fortnight. There are wardrobe rooms (models in their way) for boys and girls respectively. The sexes arc educated together, though the arrangement of the class rooms provides rows of seats from them distinct from each other.

lead_paragraph: Military matters at Governor's Island deserve attention at the present time. The troops on the Island do not amount to a large number, yet the correct attention of the officers and men to their duties is worthy of commendation. The parades are strictly attended to and the guards regularly mounted, whilst the conduct of the troops is everything that could be desired. In fact the greatest order and regularity appeal to prevail in every department of this well-regulated fortress.

abstract: We hung a white flag over our desk as a sign of suspension of our treadmill operations at our work, and, like thousands of others, paid our fare for...
lead_paragraph: We hung a white flag over our desk as a sign of suspension of our treadmill operations at our work, and, like thousands of others, paid our fare for the privilege of being transferred from the centre of our Babel to the broad walks and winding pathways of the Central Park. Having an inquisitive turn of mind at the time, we took the liberty of peeping in the doors of the grotesque and turreted building on the Fifth-avenue, called "The Arsenal," to see its contents. But there were no signs of war to be perceived. The columbiads long since disappeared, and have doubtless done good execution on Southern soil, while the flushing swords, and barking gun-dogs' and tracking rifles, have been telling their tales of terror to [???], or have become crimsoned in the strife with rebellion. But lying on one aide of the large hall, waiting to be adorned in the handsomest style, and then to dance and dash over the tippling surface of the lake, was a graceful and capacious vessel from the "Maiden City of the Sea." A Venetian [???] for the lake in the Central Park! Thought, like an argosy, carried us away to the water-paths of the ancient city, and as we floated over its lagoons, and along under the Rialto, we dreamed of the merchant princes, the noble sailors, and the charming and jewel-enriched heiresses who had, perhaps, long since, sped along the streets and in front of the magnificent palaces of Venice in that identical gondola.

abstract: The General Triennial Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church reassembled yesterday morning, at St. John's Chapel. Bishop HOPEINS, of Vermont, conducted the morning service, after which Rev. Dr. VINTON, of Trinity Church, appropriated special pews for the Bishops. Some time was spent...
lead_paragraph: The General Triennial Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church reassembled yesterday morning, at St. John's Chapel. Bishop HOPEINS, of Vermont, conducted the morning service, after which Rev. Dr. VINTON, of Trinity Church, appropriated special pews for the Bishops. Some time was spent in interchanging friendly greetings among the Bishops, clergy and laity, and at 11 1/4 o'clock the Convention was called to order by Rev. JAMES CRAIK, D.D., of Kentucky; and the Secretary, GEO. M. RANDALL, D.D., of Boston, called the roll. In answer to an inquiry, the Secretary said that only those Dioceses had been called from which certificates had been received. Mr. RUGGLES suggested that the remaining Dioceses be called; whereupon the Secretary called for delegates from Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas, Tennessee and Kansas, but from none of them was there any response.

lead_paragraph: Frederick M. Behrle vs. Austin Shermon et al. -- This is an action brought against the suretics on the official bond of Adeline C. Gunter as an executrix. The Sorrogate of Queens County issued a degree requiring the executrix Adeline C. Gunter, to pay certain sums of money to various parties, the plaintiff herein, among others. After default in the payment of such amounts, and, it is alleged, after this [???] against the sureties was brought in the Superior Court, an appeal was taken, by the executrix to the General Term of the Supreme Court. lead_paragraph: Once more the telegraph forbears to give us news. In these latter days, indeed, the magnetic messenger too often merits the stale sneer that whatever he announces as news is apt not to be true, and that whatever he brings of truth is hardly news. Silence reigns on the Potomac -- the silence, not of achievement, indeed, but of expectation -- the lull in the storm.

abstract: We publish, to-day, two communications on subjects of the first importance to our armies in the field, and, through them, to every family in the land. War is not a matter of parades and battle-fields, as the picturebooks of history and the popular feeling make it out to be. It is simple the organization of numbers of men, into a new and nomadic ...
lead_paragraph: We publish, to-day, two communications on subjects of the first importance to our armies in the field, and, through them, to every family in the land. War is not a matter of parades and battle-fields, as the picturebooks of history and the popular feeling make it out to be. It is simple the organization of numbers of men, into a new and nomadic habit of life. An army is a city composed of male citizens only, living mostly out of doors, and exposed to the severest strain upon all their resources, physical, mental and moral. How to save these men from decimation by disease, before they come under the fire of the similar hostile city against which they are moving; how to care for them after the collision has taken place; how to restore those of whom sickness and the sword may spare in the best condition to their homes and their ordinary life, -- these are great problems, in which not only they, but the whole community to which they belong, must feel the deepest interest.

abstract: The work of altering and refitting the building formerly occupied as the Merchants' Exchange, for the use of the different officers of the Customs at this port, progresses slowly. The contract for the work was entered into last Spring, and it was then thought that but little time would be required to make the changes necessary to a transfer of the Custom-house business thither.
lead_paragraph: The work of altering and refitting the building formerly occupied as the Merchants' Exchange, for the use of the different officers of the Customs at this port, progresses slowly. The contract for the work was entered into last Spring, and it was then thought that but little time would be required to make the changes necessary to a transfer of the Custom-house business thither. The changes have been more numerous, and the time required much longer than at first anticipated, so that there is little prospect that the building will be entirely ready for occupancy before the beginning of the year.

abstract: This is Sunday, and rest-day in the camps of our army. The rain, that had drenched us on yesterday, ceased late in the afternoon.

abstract: Democratic rally, 19th Ward, NYC

lead_paragraph: Mr. THOS. K. DOWNING presided in the Hall, assisted by Mr. DANIEL, GRIFFITHS, as Secretary pro tem. At 8 o'clock, the Chairman opened the proceedings by stating the objects of the organization and its present assembling, viz.: The indorsement and supporrt of Hon. HOTARIO SEYMOUR and his companions on the orthodox ticket. As he resumed his seat, vehement calls for Hon. FERNANDO WOOD resounded on all side, and Dr. J.S. BRADFORD, upon the solicitation of many bystanders, arose to state that unexpected, yet unavoidable exigencies had arisen to detain Mr. WOOD,who would, probably, be unable to be present on this occasion. The statement produced evident and marked chagrin, as Mr. WOOD's coming had been looked forward to with eager certainty. However, Dr. BRADFORD, encouraged by the cheers of the audience, went on to cheer a very warmly worded, and, assuredly very Democratic speech, in which the entire programme of both Northern and Southern extremists was reviewed and [???] In that direction, the Doctor said, there was no hope, but in the success [???] the Democracy alone [???] the salvation of this [???] tracted county. He predicted that success, and with it the restoration of the Constitution and the Union as [???] were, and the close of the National dream of war and [???]

abstract: editorials on difficulties caused by use; editorials on resulting difficulties
snippet: editorials on difficulties caused by use; editorials on resulting difficulties
lead_paragraph: MOND. -- The opposition to the Government in the North -- in other words the Democratic party -- have assured us that great exasperation would result from the publication of the President's Emancipation Proclamation in the South. Wise men ventured to question the prediction. There Was plausible reason for believing that an accessof irritation in that quarter was simply an impossibility. Popular passion had been wrought up to so extreme a pitch, that another degree of elevation was unattainable; and besides, the ignorant whites who compose the bulk of the population, had so often been assured that the sole object of the war was to free the slaves, that an official announcement to that effect, signed and sealed by ABRAHAM LINCOLN, would hardly excite a fresh emotion. There would be no sudden uprising of an outraged people, demanding resistance and vengeance. The edict would not add a soldier to the ranks, or a dollar to the vacant Treasury of the Confederation. No new armies would rush to the field to resent the assault on Southern institutions and drive back the invaders. The practical effect would be simply nil.

lead_paragraph: The publication yesterday of the address of the loyal Governors to the President, pricks the bubble which mischief-making journals had blown about their action. There is nothing whatever in it to which the most fastidious can possibly take exception. On the contrary, the object of the Conference was highly patriotic and praiseworthy, and everything said and done seems to have been well calculated to aid the Government in its contest with rebellion.

abstract: The steamship City of Washington passed Cape Race yesterday morning, and a summary of her news, which is four days later, was obtained. The news generally is not of much importance.
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Washington passed Cape Race yesterday morning, and a summary of her news, which is four days later, was obtained. The news generally is not of much importance. The American Consul at Vienna had written to GARIBALDI, asking if he would offer his assistance in the struggle in America for liberty, and had received in reply the assurance that as soon as he has recovered his liberty and health, GARIBALDI will take the first favorable opportunity to satisfy his desire to serve the great American Republic. France is said to have protested energetically against the capture of the ship La Manche, at New-Orleans. Cotton in the Liverpool market was slightly lower. Breadstuffs were quiet, and Provisions dull. Consols were quoted at 93 1/2 @93 5/8.

abstract: Julia A. Wood, Executive, vs. Benjamin F. Hunt, et al. The plaintiff, as executrix of Silas Wood, deceased, sues the defendants, who are the heirs at law of Benjamin Hunt, to set aside and have declared void the conveyance of a certain piece of
lead_paragraph: Julia A. Wood, Executive, vs. Benjamin F. Hunt, et al. -- The plaintiff, as executrix of Silas Wood, deceased, sues the defendants, who are the heirs at law of Benjamin Hunt, to set aside and have declared void the conveyance of a certain piece of property, by Hunt, Sr., to Hunt, Jr., on the ground, among others, that it was without consideration, and in fraud of creditors. On the question of consideration, the Court held that when a party receives a conveyance of land or other property from an insolvent, without actually paying, or securing the payment of any consideration, no further proof of knowledge or fraudulent intent of the grantor against his creditors is necessary, in order to charge the grantee with complicity in the fraud.

abstract: Mr. HAMILTON, of Texas. is one of the most earnest prophets the South has yet given to the Union. He has trodden the wine-press of rebel hate and bears marks of the vassalage sought to be imposed upon him. He stands
lead_paragraph: Mr. HAMILTON, of Texas. is one of the most earnest prophets the South has yet given to the Union. He has trodden the wine-press of rebel hate and bears marks of the vassalage sought to be imposed upon him. He stands before his loyal countrymen to-day a martyr to his principles, and his life saved by a miracle, as it were, of good fortune. He was dogged from his home, through the settlements and into the mountains of Texas. Five times his attempt to escape was defeated. He was the mark at which the assassin's bullet was sped. He reached the Gulf coast at last and found safety on shipboard. "The last thing I saw," he says, "on looking back from the schooner's deck to the receding shores of Texas, was the little launch full of armed men who had failed to catch me."

abstract: Editorial again notes difficulties that have arisen over use of postage stamp currency
snippet: Editorial again notes difficulties that have arisen over use of postage stamp currency
lead_paragraph: The Post-office Department has committed a great blunder, as well as a great wrong, in repudiating postage-stamps which may be "soiled or defaced," or which may "apparently have been used" to prepay postage on letters. It has no shadow of right thus to repudiate its own obligations; and it is just as great an outrage on justice and public right to repudiate a three-cent stamp as it would be to repudiate a thousand -- dollar bond. In permitting any Post-office clerk, to whom a stamp may "appear" to have been used, to return the letter or send it to the Dead Letter-office, the Department puts the whole business of the country completely at the mercy of the caprice, whim, judgment and malice of this class of persons.

abstract: A war meeting was held in the Eighteenth Ward last evening to take measures to fill up the quota of volunters of the Ward, so as to avoid a draft. Mr. JNO, A. FOSTRA, who has visited Albany at the request of the Committee of the Sixth Senatorial District, to ascertain how the draft was to be made in this City, repoted that the had had an inter
lead_paragraph: A war meeting was held in the Eighteenth Ward last evening to take measures to fill up the quota of volunters of the Ward, so as to avoid a draft. Mr. JNO, A. FOSTRA, who has visited Albany at the request of the Committee of the Sixth Senatorial District, to ascertain how the draft was to be made in this City, repoted that the had had an interview with Gov. MORGAN, who informed him that it was not yet definitely settled whether the draft would be made by Wards or Senatorial Districts or in some other manner. In answer to an inquiry from Mr. FOSTER, however, the Governor, stated that if the Eighteenth Ward raised its quota previous to the draft, no draft would be made in that Ward, and Mr. FOSTER was of the opinion from what the Governor stated, that the draft would be made by wards. The speaker said he called on Judge Advocate General ANTHON yesterday morning, who informed him that he had not as yet received any directions from the Governor as to the manner of making the draft, but he had prepared the enrollment in such a way that he could make the craft either by Wards. Senatorial Districts. Assembly Districts or even Election Districts, according as he should be ordered by the Governor. Mr. FOSTER staled that as near as could be ascertained, the quota of New-York City yet to be raised was about 4,000, and the quota of the Eighteenth Ward about 250.

abstract: -- The process of suppressing the rebellion. will inevitably throw light as it goes on upon the dark dens and the secret horrors of the slave system. We shall inevitably bring out before the world incontrovertible facts enough to make a new Key to Uncle Tom's Cabin, and any number of new speeches on the barbarisms of Slavery. One appeared in New-Orleans a short time, ago in the correspondence between Gen. BUTLER and the Superintendent of the State Penitentiary, who wrote to Gen. BUTLER, stating that by the laws of Louisiana children born in the prison for female convicts were State property, and that it had been the custom "to sell them into Slavery at the age often years, and appropriate the proceeds to purposes of State expenditure."

abstract: The old American steamer Virgin, which was raised from the lake some months since by the M.O. Roberts Company, and the engines of the steamer John Hart put into her, for service on Lake Nicaragus, went ashore on Zapater's Island, a few days since, and sunk. She is too old and rotten, it is said, to bear raising. As this is the only steamer the Company have, save one, for lake and river service, it is not presumed Mr. ROBERTS will open his line in October, if he ever intended to do so. His steamer San Juan, for the lake, arrived at San Juan del Norte a few days since. She is said to be a spacious and comfortable vessel. But very little has been done to put the transit route in order -- no repairs having been made at the large bridges.
lead_paragraph: The old American steamer Virgin, which was raised from the lake some months since by the M.O. abstract: Mr. GOTTCHALK'S CONCERTS AT IRVING HALL  A large and brilliant audience comfortably occupied  without quite filing, living Hall on Thursday even
lead_paragraph: Mr. GOTTCHALK's CONCERTS AT IRVING HALL. -- A large and brilliant audience comfortably occupied without quite filing, living Hall on Thursday evening, to hear Mr. GOTTSCHALK and several other leading musical artists in a concert of choice compositions for the voice and various instruments. The programme was selected with excellent taste and judgment, and gave general satisfaction and delight. Mr. GOTTSCHALK played three pieces on the piano in his most dashing, sparkling manner, of course receiving enthusiastic applause and demands for repetition. As a finale he performed for the first time, a burlesque on the French air, "Marlbrook," better known to the American student of harmony as "He's a jolly good fellow." This plan of finishing up with something having a dash of lively humor in it is one of the most attractive features of Mr. GOTTSCHALK's system. In the programme on Thursday were two classical works, admirably executed by Messrs. NOLL, REYER MATZKA and BERGNER, a Fantasia for the violin by Mr. THEODORE THOMAS, an exquisite cornet solo by LOUIS SCRIBNER, and singing by Mrs. JENNY KEMPTON and Mr. J.R. THOMAS. Mr. J.R. THOMAS has one of the most agreeable baritone voices that can be employed in the interpretation of chamber music, and Mrs. KEMPTON possesses a full and melodious contralto, which, with a year or two more of cultivation, may be made a valuable acquisition to the Opera. Mrs. KEMPTON made her debut on the occasion, and has reason to be gratified with her reception and success.

abstract: The resolutions of the Confederate Congress, which we publish to-day, inviting JEFFERSON DAVIS to issue a proclamation "touching the free navigation of the Mississippi and its tributaries, and the opening of the Southern markets to the inhabitants of the Northwestern States," deserve attention : not, indeed,
lead_paragraph: The resolutions of the Confederate Congress, which we publish to-day, inviting JEFFERSON DAVIS to issue a proclamation "touching the free navigation of the Mississippi and its tributaries, and the opening of the Southern markets to the inhabitants of the Northwestern States," deserve attention : not, indeed, because they are likely to result in any immediate secession of Iowa and Illinois from the despotic, clutch of the Union into the arms of the Confederacy thus temptingly opened, -- noryet because they indicate the importance to the rebel cause of the campaign now carrying on by the Seymour Democracy, -- but because they clearly illustrate the political future which the successful establishment of the seceded Confederacy would prepare for the Continent.

abstract: The Court-martial which was ordered on Governor's Island assembled again yesterday. Witnesses were examined to support the charge against Sergeant BALDWIN for striking his superior officer. Lieut,
lead_paragraph: The Court-martial which was ordered on Governor's Island assembled again yesterday. Witnesses were examined to support the charge against Sergeant BALDWIN for striking his superior officer. Lieut. SPROLE himself testified against the prisoner. In three days more it is expected the decision of the Court will be known. If the accused is proved guilty he may be shot. There are other parties to be tried when this case is over. Maj. BRUEN, of the Twelfth Infantry, U.S.A., is President of the Court.

abstract: -- Our State authorities are always getting ready to draft the militia, but the draft never comes. First, one expedient to ward it off is tried; then another. When the draft is ordered at last, the enrollment is not perfected; and one or two postponements on that account must be made. But in time, all obstacles are removed. The Government calls, the enrollment is finished, the day for drafting is fixed, bounties are proclaimed to be offered no longer. But at the eleventh hour another proclamation comes from Albany opening the recruiting stations for volunteers, this time for nine months' men, for a few days longer. All this while precious time is lost. New-York regiments in the field, reduced to skeletons of one hundred men, bring reproach on the Empire State. Is this "positively the last chance" for evading the national duty which our State authorities can avail themselves of?
lead_paragraph: -- Our State authorities are always getting ready to draft the militia, but the draft never comes. First, one expedient to ward it off is tried; then another. When the draft is ordered at last, the enrollment is not perfected; and one or two postponements on that account must be made. But in time, all obstacles are removed. The Government calls, the enrollment is finished, the day for drafting is fixed, bounties are proclaimed to be offered no longer. But at the eleventh hour another proclamation comes from Albany opening the recruiting stations for volunteers, this time for nine months' men, for a few days longer. All this while precious time is lost. New-York regiments in the field, reduced to skeletons of one hundred men, bring reproach on the Empire State. Is this "positively the last chance" for evading the national duty which our State authorities can avail themselves of?

abstract: one night only, and that a benefit, was begun and ended last evening in the most agreeable manner, with an excellent performance of BELLINI's exquisite opera "II Puritani." The prima donna was in full and sweet voice, and sang with less apparent effort and a more equable success than upon any previous appearance. The role of Elvira is not, indeed, accurately adapted to Miss PATH's peculiar qualities, but her conception of the character was more than respectable, and her vocalization threw a veil of melody over the dramatic foioles of her performance. She was well supported by Sig. BRIGNOLI in the not very exigeant role of Arturo, and by Sigs. SUSINI and AMODIO, who executed the eventful suoni la tromba with creditable emphasis, and in the case of the former artist particularly with a fine artistic feeling, which deserves the more notice from the temptation which the duo holds out to exuberant musical and dramatic clap-trap.

abstract: FOUND DROWNED. -- The body of a lad, identified as JOHN [???], was found at the foot of Partition-street yesterday morning. It appears that the deceased lost his life by falling overboard from a small boat in consequence of a collision in the bay. He was a peddler of apples, &c., and hired the boat to take him to a vessel coming [???]. Another peddler-boat came up and ran into the boat containing [???], and caused the accident. Two men named MCGLYNN and HAGGERTY have been arrested, and will be held to await the result of the Coroner's inquest.

abstract: One of the most difficult problems in the science of taxation has always been to adapt internal duties to agricultural districts. The inhabitants, in their ordinary business, have so little money passing through their hands, that direct taxation, in such cases, has  usually disappointed financial legislators. Such taxes are difficult to realize, and their collection is therefore expensive.
lead_paragraph: One of the most difficult problems in the science of taxation has always been to adapt internal duties to agricultural districts. The inhabitants, in their ordinary business, have so little money passing through their hands, that direct taxation, in such cases, has usually disappointed financial legislators. Such taxes are difficult to realize, and their collection is therefore expensive. They usually [???] much below expectation, and are inevitably attended with popular odium. Hence, it has always been found best to reach the agricultural classes of any country by indirect rather than direct impost. This principle has been adopted in our own recent tax-legislation, and in all the well-considered fiscal systems of modern Europe.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: -- Edward O. Wright, Second Lieutenant in Company H. Fifth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, (Duryea's Zouaves,) died in the Fairfax Seminary Hospital, near Alexandria, on Sept. 26, of a wound received in the second battle of Bull Run, Aug. 30. Lieut. Wright enlisted as a private in the Seventy-first Regiment, N.Y.S.M., on April 20, 1861, but as he was among those whom that corps was obliged to reject, because it was so full when it left this City for the seat of war, he enlisted, on April 22, in Duryea's Zouaves, which was then forming. During the stay of the regiment at Fort Schuyler, its encampment in the vicinity of Fortress Monroe, and at Fort Federal Hill, Baltimore, he discharged his duties with zeal and fidelity. In the battle of Big Bethel, on June 10, 1861, he bore himself with great bravery and coolness. Although he was always foremost in the succession of battles and skirmishes before Richmond in which the Zouaves won such distinction. Sergt. Wright, for his services in the ranks had been rewarded with promotion, escaped without a scratch, and for bravery displayed in the battle of Gaines' Mills he was made a Second Lieutenant. In the battle of Groveton, or Bull Run No. 2, which was fought on Aug. 30, he was wounded by a Minieball, which struck his left arm near the socket, passed through his lung and finally lodged between his shoulder blades. Could he have received immediate attention his life might have been spared, but he lay on the field until the afternoon of the next day, when the ball was extracted. After submiting to this operation he dragged himself to Centreville, where he was paroled, and thence was sent within the National lines. He was promptly taken to Fairfax Seminary Hospital, but the excellent care which he there received came too late to revive his failing energies, and he died as we have already stated, on Sept. 26. During all his sufferings, which were at times intense, he gave a striking example of patience to those around him. His company, which had become attached to him as few companies are to their commanders, will miss him in camp and on the battle-field,and a wide circle of friends in this City, who knew and appreciated his worth, mourn his loss.

abstract: INVESTIGATING THE ACTS OF THE ALDERMEN. --The Committee of the Councilmen to whom was referred the letter of Mr. KNAPP, ignoring his removal, and the notice from the Clerk of the Common Council of his removal, and also of Mr. TAPPEN's, with instructions to investigate the whole matter, held a meeting yesterday afternoon. Messrs. KNAPP and TAPPEN were sworn and testified that they had not been derelict in duty. Mr. KNAPP did not know why he had been removed, except that he would not use the patronage of the Street Department to help Alderman BOOLE become Comptroller. Mr. TAPPEN thought he had been removed because he did not feel himself under the necessity of obeying an Alderman. Alderman BRADY had intimated to him that he had him (Mr. T.) removed because he would not appoint a friend of the Alderman's on the Water Police. The notice of the Clerk of the Common Council, Councilman JONES thought, was informal, and could not be formal till it was sent by direct order of the Board of Aldermen. Councilman BARNEY said it was an assumption of power -- a trap -- designed to lead the Board of Councilmen into recognition of the removals. He was in favor of returning the notice to Mr. VALENTINE. Alderman HALL was the only member of his Board present, although all had been notified to be there. He testified that he knew nothing about the cause of the removals, but believed the assertion "for cause" was unsustained by any proof. The Committee adjourned till Tuesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

The notice of the Clerk of the Common Council, Councilman JONES thought, was informal, and could not be formal till it was sent by direct order of the Board of Aldermen. abstract: editorial on New Orleans secessionists taking oath of allegiance to Union to avoid effects of confiscation act
snippet: editorial on New Orleans secessionists taking oath of allegiance to Union to avoid effects of confiscation act
lead_paragraph: The last letter from our correspondent at New-Orleans, written a few days before the expiration of the season of grace preceding the putting in execution of the Confiscation Act, gave some very interesting details of the feeling and behavior of the wealthy Secessionists of the Crescent City, in view of that event. As the fated 23d of September drew ominously nearer and nearer, a corresponding desire was developed in hitherto recalcitrant rebel hearts to take the oath of allegiance; and it was observed that most of those who had been the noisiest in denouncing the Government then became the most clamorous to get in "and take a swear." But the most notable fact detected by our observant and reflective correspondent was that, as the portentous day approached, the responsibilities attached to taking the oath gradually lessened, until the general sentiment among the Secessionists became -- "It don't amount to much, after all, and saves us from the effects of the Confiscation law."

abstract: The rebel newspapers at Richmond are very indignant and no little frightened about the Emancipation Proclamation of President LINCOLN.
lead_paragraph: The rebel newspapers at Richmond are very indignant and no little frightened about the Emancipation Proclamation of President LINCOLN. They denounce its author as a "fiend," and portray with much vividness the horrors that will afflict the South if the Proclamation should lead to or instigate a servile revolt. Former attempts at insurrection are brought to mind, in which the negroes are said to have murdered women and children and "piled them in heaps." But the black insurgents were quelled and quickly and horribly destroyed.
