abstract: The wonderful success which has attended military operations by Stonewall JACKSON, and by the rebel STUART'S Cavalry, is attributable almost exclusively to the celerity of their movements.
lead_paragraph: The wonderful success which has attended military operations by Stonewall JACKSON, and by the rebel STUART's Cavalry, is attributable almost exclusively to the celerity of their movements. The fact at once illustrates and sustains the proposition that, with an otherwise well appointed army, success is in a great measure simply a question of transportation. Increase the mobility of a corps, and we add largely to its effectiveness, make it more confident and formidable in attack, more secure in retreat, and at all times safer from danger at the hands of an active foe. As an army is of little use unless fed, and supplied with suitable ammunition, it can move only so rapidly as its trains can be forwarded. Notwithstanding the vital importance of the transportation department, however, no other branch of the public service suffers so much for lack of system and practical business sense and experience in its administration. The same is true, indeed, of the entire Quartermaster's Department of the army.

abstract: THE WILL IS DISPUTE. -- The will made by CASPAR P. LURENS, a member of the Society of friends, has been left with the Register of Walls for probate, but it is contested on the ground of not being legally certified to. The will is written upon seven pages of letter paper, and the deceased's name is at the buttom of each page, except on the last, which has a blank, where the testators' and witnesses names should have been. The will, after naming a few private legacies, directs that George B. Wood, M.D., Wm. S. Price, William Biddle. H.S. Smith, M.D., Thos. Vaux, Michael Errickson, E.W. Bailey, Peter Rogers, W.H. French, T.E. Powels, and George W. Davis shall act as Trustees, to invest and make productive all the real estate, personal property, &c., of the deceased, and to invest the profits, interest, &c., until it shall amount to $350,000, and when this amount has been raised by interest upon interest, the Trustees are to purchase a lot of ground, the size of the one occupied by the hospital on Spruce and Pine streets.

abstract: editorial sees next battle war being fought in Kentucky between Buell and Bragg forces
snippet: editorial sees next battle war being fought in Kentucky between Buell and Bragg forces
lead_paragraph: The next battle of the war is to be fought in Kentucky. Any moment we may hear of the clash of arms between the forces of BRAGG and BUELL. And when the armies of these two Generals do meet, there will ensue the bloodiest duel that has been recorded since the rebellion began. Neither army has any amount of new or unskillful material in it. The soldiers of each are veterans all -- tried in the fire of battle, purged of all weakness of body by the regimen of prolonged camp service -inured to fatigue by unparalleled marches, and hardened to the work expected at their hands by the daily sight of suffering and death, and by their own hardships, blunting the sensibilities and pleasures of living. When Greek meets Greek, then comes the tug of war.

abstract: News of naval operations on Southern coast; further details on murder
snippet: News of naval operations on Southern coast; further details on murder
lead_paragraph: "In a council of general and held officers, held after night, it was unanimously resolved that if the enemy had not reoccupied, in strength, the position in front of Gen. PILLOW, the army should effect its retreat, and the order to assemble the regiments for that purpose was given by Gen. FLOYD. But as the enemy had, late in the afternoon, appeared in considerable force on the battle-field of the morning, a reconnoissance was ordered, I think, by Gen. PILEOW. under the instructions of Gen. FLOYD. The report of this reconnoissance, made by Col. FORREST, as been fully stated by Gens. FLOYD and PILLOW, and from all I have been able to learn since, I am satisfied the information was correct. Among other incidents showing that the enemy had not only reoccupied their former ground, but extended their lines still further to our left, is the fact that OVERTON'S cavalry, following after FORREST'S, was cut off from retreat by an infantry force of the enemy at the point where FORREST had crossed the stream on the river road. When the information of our reinvestment was reported, Gen. FLOYD, Gen. PILLOW and myself were the only members of the council present. Both of these officers have stated the views of the council, but my recollection of some of the incidents narrated differs so materially from that of Gen. PILLOW, that without intending any reflection upon either of those officers, I feel called upon to notice some of the differences between us.

abstract: Editorial says people backing Seymour aid and abet Confederates; editorials say those who vote for Seymour aid and abet Confederates
snippet: Editorial says people backing Seymour aid and abet Confederates; editorials say those who vote for Seymour aid and abet Confederates
lead_paragraph: There are three classes of men from whom votes may be expected to be cast for SEYMOUR. First and foremost are those whose secret sympathies are with the rebels, who would aid them if they could without danger to themselves. These men, who have exulted over every defeat of our armies, and have been downcast whenever the rebels have been defeated; who heartily hope to see the rebellion triumph, and who hang all the weight they can upon the nation to clog and embarrass it, are sure to vote for SEYMOUR. There is not one of them who could be got to vote against him on any consideration, be. cause they well know that every vote cast for him will be welcomed in rebeldom, and that his election would be as likely to be followed by an illumination in Richmond as a victory of LEE'S army. To these men we have no argument to address. They will go on in their course of wickedness. We only warn them not to go too far and commit themselves too openly.

abstract: From Kentucky, which is now the great point of interest, we have no later intelligence this morning. It is more than probable that a great battle was fought yesterday between BUELL and BRAGG. Our latest advices left the armies near each other, and it is hardly possible that a conflict can have been avoided--unless the rebels concluded to run, which they are said to have declared they would not do.

abstract: We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a letter from Gen. WADSWORTH  accepting the nomination for Governor. It is characteristic of the man clear, manly, bold and unmistakeable in its sentiments and style.
lead_paragraph: We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a letter from Gen. WADSWORTH accepting the nomination for Governor. It is characteristic of the man -- clear, manly, bold and unmistakeable in its sentiments and style. It defines, with distinctness, the issue which the coming election must decide, and leaves no room for doubt as to his position upon it. He is for supporting the Government in its effort to maintain itself, and in the proclamation of emancipation issued by the President, as a prominent means for accomplishing that end. He states with precision and emphasis the reasons which induce him thus to favor this measure. He believes it will be the most effective, the most humane, and the most beneficent method of crushing the rebellion; and he therefore commends it warmly to the support of the electors of this State.
headline: {'main': "Gen. Wadsworth's Acceptance.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Wadsworth's Acceptance.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Jura passed Cape Race on Race on Saturday morning, with European advices to the 26th ult. one day later than were received by the City of Washington. The news of the victory over the rebels at South Mountain, the prelude to the great victory at the Antietam, had reached...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Jura passed Cape Race on Race on Saturday morning, with European advices to the 26th ult. -- one day later than were received by the City of Washington. The news of the victory over the rebels at South Mountain, the prelude to the great victory at the Antietam, had reached England, and caused much rejoicing among those who sympathize with the North. An impetus was given to the Cotton market, which, however, was checked by large arrivals of Surats. The London Times, speaking of GARIBALDI, says it is not impossible that he may yet be seen crossing the Atlantic in the assumed character of an American citizen, and "fighting for the subjugation of a nation struggling to be free." The Morning Post thinks GARIBALDI, to be consistent, should fight on the side of the South, "where nine millions are lighting for the right of governing themselves." The sales of cotton for the week had been only ten thousand bales, at a decline of 1d. The market was firm on the reception of the American news, and a slight advance took place. Breadstuffs were quiet, and Provisions inactive. The latest quotation for Consols was 93 3/8@93 1/2 for money.

abstract: The Monitors, now in course of construction, have one weak point, notwithstanding the universal faith in their invulnerability. Water will do that which hostile shot cannot; it will slowly, but surelyeat its way through the iron plates which compose the hull so as to fataliy weaken or destroy them ultimately. A method of copper coating these plates has
lead_paragraph: The Monitors, now in course of construction, have one weak point, notwithstanding the universal faith in their invulnerability. Water will do that which hostile shot cannot; it will slowly, but surelyeat its way through the iron plates which compose the hull so as to fataliy weaken or destroy them ultimately. A method of copper coating these plates has been devised, however, which seems to afford effectual protection from corrosion. Copper is fused and heated to 1,600 degrees, when the iron plates, which are to be coated, are plunged into it and kept there until they are nearly white hot. Then partial fusion between the two metals takes place, and the plates, when withdrawn, are found to be much more effectually coated than is possible by the galvanic process, which has hitherto been employed. The severest tests which it has been possible to make of iron thus heated, have proved that it is perfectly protected from the action of the water, and as the cost of coating is comparatively small, it would seem as though the Government must follow the example of private builders, and adopt this method with the Monitors how in course of construction. Mr. EDWARD MILLS, No. 198 Broadway, is the general agent of the Copper Coating Company, which owns the right to use this method of copper coating.

abstract: What with sales of extras, , the Newsboys have been having an eye to the improvement of their lodging-house, and their guardians, willing to make  them as comfortable as possible, have censented to enlarge their quarters. Not only is the "Fifth-ave- nue Hotel" studded about with green painted iron bedsteads furnished with matresses and coverlets ...
lead_paragraph: What with sales of extras, , the Newsboys have been having an eye to the improvement of their lodging-house, and their guardians, willing to make them as comfortable as possible, have censented to enlarge their quarters. Not only is the "Fifth-ave- nue Hotel" studded about with green painted iron bedsteads furnished with matresses and coverlets accordingly, but the bath-room has been supplied with steam for heating water for cold Winter-night baths, and the "lecture-room" has been enlarged one-half its usual size, extending entirely around the corner of Fulton and Nassau streets. Many new paintings and engravings, all of an elevating tendency, adorn the walls of the enlarged apartment. Among these is noticeable a large-sized engraving of "The last days of Daniel Webster," also some well selected specimens from a friend to the enterprise, Mr. CHARLES MIXTER, of Boston. A must elaborate and curious work of art, simply framed in [???], consists of paragraphs from Scripture, so disposed as to display the highest perfection in chirography. It took the artist three years to accomplish the work, and it was presented to the Lodging-house by JOHN E. WILLIAMS, President of the Metropolitan Bank. The boys at their own expense have had the photograph of their popular President, Mr. WM. A. BOOTH, taken, and have it hang just above their gallery. This gallery is a study in itself. The Roger's Gallery may present different features, but certainly none more interesting. Here we have the [???] vendor natural as life -- rags and all. The likenesses of all distinguished members are framed and hold conspicuous place in this same gallery. JOHN SMITH, the tragedian, is here, represented under the umbrageous branches of a spreading oak -- lost, as it would seem, to all memory of newspaper trafficking and reveling in dreams of the drama. Paddy Beef also is here, looming up behind the glass as naturally as if he had never been a prisoner in a rebel jail. Paddy has evidently been taken as he stood, his red shirt in easy folds, his suspenders a though tighter than usual, and his pataloon-tops emulous of a position immediately under the arm pits. Such are the style of portraits in the News-boys' Gallery, and they proudly display it as one of their improvements.

abstract: The long threatened and expected draft in this State, will undoubtedly take place on next Friday or Saturday, as all the enrollments have been completed, and everything is now in readiness for the drawing. The Quartermaster-General states as his opinion that about 25,000 men are still wanted to fill up the quota of the State.
lead_paragraph: The long threatened and expected draft in this State, will undoubtedly take place on next Friday or Saturday, as all the enrollments have been completed, and everything is now in readiness for the drawing. The Quartermaster-General states as his opinion that about 25,000 men are still wanted to fill up the quota of the State. Therefore, that is the number to be drafted from the whole State. The number to be furnished by the City will be somewhere in the neighborhood of 6,000 men. By an order from Gov. MORGAN, last week, recruiting for the nine months men will be continued until the day of the drawing. It is decided that persons who have given fictitious places of resiidence will be drafted into the army immediately. We fancy quite a number of those young men who said they lived in Newark, Brooklyn, &c., when they were called upon by the enrolling officer, will find out they have committed a great mistake by giving in a wrong place of residence. They may possibly find that they have placed themselves in an unenviable position. There will be a camp of rendezvous established at East New-York for the drafted militia, under the command, it is understoood, of Brig.-Gen. BUSTEED.

abstract: The evacuation of Cumberland Gap by Gen. MORGAN, is a step, perhaps, to be regretted. If he could have held his position till the present time against the rebels in his front and rear, his day of danger would have been past; for to-day the rebel armies in Kentucky are on the retreat and on the defensive. By holding the Gap, Gen. MORGAN would have effectually closed to the rebels one avenue of their escape from Kentucky. But as the Gap is now unoccupied, and the road to its passes through a very broken country, affording many advantageous, passes and defiles in which effective stands can be made against a pursuing force, a portion of BRAGG's army, if they are to run away, could not ask a safer road out of the State, than that leading to Cumberland Gap.

abstract: The advantage of vocal gymnastics as an aid to physical development has induced the principals of our first-class private institutes to introduce it as a regular branch of their scholastic course. It was not at first accepted by the more ease-loving young ladies with avidity; it appeared eminently unlady like...
lead_paragraph: The advantage of vocal gymnastics as an aid to physical development has induced the principals of our first-class private institutes to introduce it as a regular branch of their scholastic course. It was not at first accepted by the more ease-loving young ladies with avidity; it appeared eminently unlady like to be throwing bean bags ever each others' heads, and talking loud enough to be heard half a block off; yet the work went steadily on. The Ferris and Packer Institutes can show classes of readers that can speak for themselves in behalf of elocution as an accomplishment second to none. Since it is so new a thing to teach grown-up girls and boys to talk -- to speak plainly, in fact -- it is found impossible to find competent teachers for the charge of such department, and a growing taste is observable among the, more refined to perfect themselves for professorships. A fine opportunity for such students is in store in the readings, dramatic and otherwise, which will be the fashion this Winter. The first of these takes place on to-morrow, Tuesday evening, at Dedworth's lower hall, and will consist of the characterization of the most thrilling passages in VICTOR HUGO's great romance, Les Miserables. It is a good idea in our master elocutionist, Mr. VANDENHOFF, to dramatize as it were, and give form and life to the creations of the novelist whose work is in everybody's hands, and in everybody's mouth both in this country and in Europe. We shall have rekindled the enthusiasm with which all must read the scenes so truly drawn. We shall have Monsteur Myriot, Jean Val Jean, Jabert, Marius and the rest to live and breath before us. It will be a study worth the while of those who clamor for a vocal gymnasium, which great necessity for each and all our schools, must shortly be supplied, but first we must have well qualified teachers.

abstract: REAL. -- The case of Mrs. MARY REAL will be brought to trial to-day in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Justice BARNARD. Mrs. REAL is indicted for the murder of her husband, PETER C. REAL, some months since, in his store on Broadway. The circumstances doubtless fresh on the minds of our readers, are simply these: Mrs. REAL feeling herself aggrieved by certain slights, misconduct and ill-treatment, called at Mr. REAL's store for the purpose of conversing with him. While there, the two having retired from the main room, Mr. REAL was shot. Whether the pistol was discharged accidentally, or whether under the influence of insane passion or whatever, the jury are to determine. Mrs. REAL appears at the bar with a previous unblemished character, and in addition to her able counsel, Messrs. EDWIN JAMES and DUNPHY, she has been tendered the aid and advice of many who sympathize with her in her misfortune.

abstract: -- On Saturday last, twenty-five recruits for the Brooklyn Fourteenth Regiment left for the seal of war. They were all stout, able-codied men. Some 200 more are wanted to fill up the ranks to the original standard, and as a number of prominent citizens having taken the matter in hand, the object will no doubt be accomplished. A meeting is to be held in the Lee-avenue Sunday School Hall (E.D.) this evening, with the view of raising money and recruits in that section of the city.

abstract: Messrs. Hiram Ketchum, Charles P. Kirkland Hiram Barney, M.H. Grinnnell, Abraim Wakeman A. Oakey Hall, Henry Hilton, C. Godfrey Gunther Joseph Hoxie, James Kelly, W.P. Disosway, E.G. Squier, Rufus F. Andrews, J.H. Steadwell, James T. Brady, Daniel E. Delavan, Jas. S. Carpenter, John Graham, and other prominent citizens, have issued a call to she people of this city, asking them to unite in efforts to recruit the gallant Excelsior Brigade, whose conduct has done so much honor to itself and to the city which sent it out. It is stated that the brigade, originally four thousand five hundred men strong, has lost, in the various battles on the Peninsula and before Washington -- in all of which it fought gloriously -- more than three thousand men in killed, wounded, missing and disabled. The shattered remnant is now stationed in the defences of Washington, waiting for recruits sufficient to enable it once more to take the field. It is hoped that our citizens will come forward with their means to help on recruiting. Contributions are to be sent to Mr. A.V. STOUT. The recruiting office is in the City Hall Park, under charge of Colonel CHARLES K. GRAHAM.

abstract: The old comedies are all very well in their way, but it is evident the public does not like them for their own sake so much as for the sake of seeing how well they can be played by Mr. WALLACK'S company. Attempts to revive them elsewhere have ended in disastrous failure, and Mr. WALLACK again...
lead_paragraph: The old comedies are all very well in their way, but it is evident the public does not like them for their own sake so much as for the sake of seeing how well they can be played by Mr. WALLACK's company. Attempts to revive them elsewhere have ended in disastrous failure, and Mr. WALLACK again finds himself, without further risk of competition, sole master of the field which they afford for the display of strongly characterized acting. At WALLACK's almost any piece is rendered enjoyable by the positive ability with which it is performed. Even the slowest example of the fossil standard-drama can be galvanized by Mrs. HOEY, Mrs. VERNON, Miss GANNON, Miss HENRIQUES, Mr. MARK SMITH, Mr. FISHER, Mr. GILBERT and Mr. LESTER WALLACK into liveliness and temporary brilliancy; and there are pieces of ancient origin, beside, which possess a good deal of inherent vitality. Other pieces, not new, but comparatively modern, (of the "standard class," though,) have attractions of their own; yet the public cannot be induced to regard them with favor, except when they are presented by Mr. WALLACK, with the completeness which he alone, of all managers, seems able to achieve and maintain. This fact has been proved, beyond dispute since the commencement of the present season, and, in all probability, the question will not be very soon agitated again. To a great many people novelty would not be unacceptable, if for no other reason than that of affording the admirable performers just named opportunities of appearing in original parts; but Mr. WALLACK cannot be expected to go to the trouble and expense of putting fresh pieces on the stage when those he has in stock are sufficient to fill his theatre every night. He indicates the preparation of something new, it is true, and we shall no doubt know what it is all in good time. For a week or two longer, however, a continuance of the old comedies is announced, and large enough audiences will be thereby influenced to warrant their repetition. This evening "A Cure for the Heartache" will be given; to-morrow, "She Stoops to Conquer;" Wednesday, "Money;" Thursday, "Love and Money," and Friday, "The Road to Ruin."

abstract: We announce another great battle and another great victory this morning, fought and won a Corinth, Miss. Information of an official character has reached Washington, to the effect that the Combined rebel forces, under VAN DORN, PRICE and LOVELL, on Saturday attacked our forces...
lead_paragraph: We announce another great battle and another great victory this morning, fought and won a Corinth, Miss. Information of an official character has reached Washington, to the effect that the Combined rebel forces, under VAN DORN, PRICE and LOVELL, on Saturday attacked our forces there, but were repulsed with great slaughter, and retreated, leaving their dead and wounded on the field. At last accounts our forces were in full pursuit, and it is to be hoped that this time the rebel campaign in the Southwest has received its finishing stroke.

lead_paragraph: The Street Commissionership difficulty is an interesting chapter in the history of a struggle between two factions of the Board of Aldermen, one headed by Mr. GENET and the other by Mr. BOOLE, The ultimate object of the strife is the Tammany nomination for Comptroller, GENET battling to secure it for Senator CONNOLLY, and BOOLE maneuvreing to obtain it for himself. The present object, however, is the control in the Tammany General Committee. The CONNOLLY party claim the Chairman, ELIJAH F. PURDY, and a majority of the Committee (which is composed of 121 members) as their supporters. They say the choice of delegates to Albany proved their superior influence. The BOOLE party say no contest was made on that point, but that they triumphed at the meeting of the Committee last Thursday night, by reversing, for the first time in the Chairmanship of Mr. PURDY, one of his derisions, and in deciding upon an enlarged and elected Committee of Conference instead of one appointed in the Committee on Organization.

abstract: HOMICIDE IN THE ELEVENTH WARD A MAN FATALLY STABBED IN THE STREET. The people in the neighborhood of Houston-street and Avenue B, were disturbed about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, by an affray between a party of colored men and some Irish- men who had been frolicking around town, and who were at the time considerably intoxicated.
lead_paragraph: HOMICIDE IN THE ELEVENTH WARD -- A MAN FATALLY STABBED IN THE STREET. -- The people in the neighborhood of Houston-street and Avenue B, were disturbed about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, by an affray between a party of colored men and some Irish- men who had been frolicking around town, and who were at the time considerably intoxicated. The affray resulted in the death of JOHN DONNELLY, who was stabbed in the breast with a dirk-knife, in the hands of some one of the party of colored men, but who the guilty one is, has not yet been ascertained. He died in a few minutes after the wound was inflicted, and before the Police could get him to the station-house. A man named FRANCIS LAMB, who was in company with deceased, was also stabbed seriously in the head at the same time. He was soon after taken to the Eleventh Precinct Station-house, where Police Surgeon KIMBARK dressed his wounds, and yesterday afternoon he was considered out of danger.

abstract: -- Mr. DISRAELI was good enough to observe in a recent speech to his constituents, that the great civil war in America had "increased his respect for the energy of human nature." It is pleasant for us to have been able to do human nature this service with the eminent advocate of all the Caucasians, the atra-bilious Prometheus of Toryism, whose liver no eagle could feed upon and survive. The operation has been rather expensive, so far as we are concerned, certainly, but we accept the result with gratitude.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. DISRAELI was good enough to observe in a recent speech to his constituents, that the great civil war in America had "increased his respect for the energy of human nature." abstract: -- The present State Assembly seems to be furnishing quite a number of candidates for Congress, Hon. C.T. HULBURD has been nominated by the Republicans and Unionists in the St. Lawrence District, and Hon. LEMUEL, STETSON in the Clinton County District. Both these gentlemen were among the ablest, most laborious and influential members of the last session. Both are staunch and unflinching supporters of the Government in its contest with the rebellion, and both, we trust, will be elected.

On more than one battlefield he was conspicuous for his gallant bearing."

abstract: -- If our readers wish to know the horrors of the battle-field, let them go to BRADY's Gallery, and see the fearful reproductions which he has on exhibition, and for sate. In all the literal repulsiveness of nature, lie the naked corpses of our dead soldiers side by side in the quiet impassiveness of rest. Blackened faces, distorted features, expressions most agonizing, and details of absolute verity, teach us a lesson which it is well for us to learn. The enterprise, the perseverance and courage, physical and pecuniary, which suggest to and encourage an artist in such work as this, establish for him forever a reputation such as no flattery, no claptrap can secure. The pictures, of a size convenient for albums, can be seen and bought at the National Gallery, corner of Broadway and Tenth-street.

abstract: -- The new ferry-boat recently constructed for the Roosevelt-street Ferry has been named the Superior, and will be put on-the fine either to-day or to-morrow. The Nebraska, which some weeks since was sunk in the East River, by coming in collision with the the Sound steamer City of New-York, has been rebuilt, and will soon be ready to resume her trips. She his been remodeled and much improved.

abstract: The completion of this stupendous work, which, had it not been for the overshadowing proportions of the rebellion, would have commanded a goodly share of public attention, has been permitted to be accomplished without any demonstration, or even a passing public notice.
lead_paragraph: The completion of this stupendous work, which, had it not been for the overshadowing proportions of the rebellion, would have commanded a goodly share of public attention, has been permitted to be accomplished without any demonstration, or even a passing public notice. The tunnel is excavated for double track, is 3,002 feet long, and penetrates the Oxford Mountain at Van Nest Gap, near the flourishing and beautiful village of Oxford Furnace, N.J. It was built for the Warren railroad, being part of the line of the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad, and was commenced in 1854, by RUTTER & DU PUY, contractors, and was finished some months since, by Messrs. MCALLISTER & WIESTLING, both of the latter having been interested in the work since the commencement. The rock is of a syenitic formation, and during the progress of the job almost every form of underground operations proved necessary. From the hard, seamless rock, offering the most stubborn resistance to construction, every degree of formation was encountered, to quicksand, with an unusual quantity of water. Almost one-half of the Tunnel is substantially timbered and arched with store masonry; the balance being carefully and skillfully excavated through the solid rock, requires no artificial support.
headline: {'main': 'The Van Nest Gap Tunnel.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Van Nest Gap Tunnel.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: editorial says Seymour election would aid Confederates; editorials say those who vote for Seymour aid and abet Confederates
snippet: editorial says Seymour election would aid Confederates; editorials say those who vote for Seymour aid and abet Confederates
lead_paragraph: The Seymourites make very wry faces when forced to swallow a little of their own medicine. Ever since the war began they have been calling the Republicans and other AntiSlavery men traitors; they have been denouncing them most vehemently as enemies of the Government -- as haters of the Constitution and the Union, and as seeking the overthrow of both. They have charged them with conspiring against our Generals in the field; with seeking to cripple the operations of our armies, and to give victory and conquest to the rebels. And they have been calling very lustily for their arrest and imprisonment, -- for the suppression of their Presses and the confinement of their persons in Fort Lafayette.

abstract: THE BOUNTY FRAUD CASE. -- The examination of Capt. KORTWRIGHT and Lieut. LAMBERT, of the Ironsides Regiment, on the charge of attempting to defraud the Bounty Committee of Kings County, was concluded before Justice PERAY on Saturday. The evidence proves that the accused came to the office of the Bounty Committee with six recruits, who falsely represented themselves as residents of Brooklyn. They were induced to make these representations on the promise of $12 each, which would leave quite a handsome profit for those who "roped them in" -- the amount of the bounty being [???] for each recruit. Some legal points being raised by counsel as to the nature of the offence -- if any there was -- the decision of the Justice was reserved until Wednesday. The defendants were committed to await the result.

abstract: the assassination of our soldiers wherever they may be stationed in the State, by dagger, by secret bullet, or by poison, but authorizes also the murder of all civil functionaries of the Union on Virginian soil, and doubtless also will be made to apply to all Union citizens and sympathizers wherever found; for it would be very easy to show that these, by upholding the Union, constructively, at least, aid and abet the Proclamation. It is the introduction of universal assassination throughout Virginia as a means of war. All that a man, or woman either, will have to do, on being seized with the mania for murder, will be to enter upon the work, and then show that the victims had, in some way or other, "aided or abetted" the Proclamation, -- which, in thousands of instances, will be easy enough done. Such is the point to which secession has reduced the high-toned gentlemen and ladies of Virginia.

abstract: Editorial on question of disposition of Negroes freed under Emancipation Proclamation as political issue in gubernatorial election
snippet: Editorial on question of disposition of Negroes freed under Emancipation Proclamation as political issue in gubernatorial election
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Well-meaning persons have been alarmed at the prospective emancipation of the slaves, from a belief that they would flood the North and bring their labor into direct and disastrous competition with our own. This has been a favorite argument with Pro-Slavery Democrats, who have used it very vigorously, first in opposition to the war and now in support of SEYMOUR's election. They aim especially to alarm the Irish laborers, who are naturally sensitive on a point which threatens to affect so nearly their own interests.

abstract: This distinguished military chieftain, whose triumphant services have raised him so high in the admiration and confidence of his country in this great crisis, was born in Hadley, Mass., in 1819, and is consequently forty-three years of age.
lead_paragraph: This distinguished military chieftain, whose triumphant services have raised him so high in the admiration and confidence of his country in this great crisis, was born in Hadley, Mass., in 1819, and is consequently forty-three years of age. His parents are not living. He has no brother. Two of his three sisters are married in Jefferson County, N.Y., and the other in Cincinnati. He is himself a bachelor. He entered the army from West Point in 1837, Second Lieutenant First Artillery and was promoted First Lieutenant in 1838. Adjutant Military Academy in 1841. Regimental Adjutant, 1841 to 1846. Throughout the Mexican War, in all its hard conflicts, he was well known as one of "the bravest of the brave," as he is now so well known in this struggle. He was brevetted Captain in 1846 "for gallant conduct in the several conflicts at Monterey on the 21st, 22d and 23d of September, 1846." Brevetted Captain Staff -- Assistant Adjutant-General -- 1847, and again in same year brevetted Major, "for gallant and meritorious conduct in the affair at the National Bridge. Brevetted Lieutenant-Colonel in same year, also "for gallant and meritorious conduct in the battle of Chepultepec." Thus much for his career in the Mexican campaign.

abstract: The next three months will test the firmness, the nerve, of the Administration, as it has never been tested before. The President has issued the Proclamation of Emancipation, which is to go into effect on the 1st of January next. There were those who fancied that it would be utterly without effect upon the...
lead_paragraph: The next three months will test the firmness, the nerve, of the Administration, as it has never been tested before. The President has issued the Proclamation of Emancipation, which is to go into effect on the 1st of January next. There were those who fancied that it would be utterly without effect upon the rebels; that they would feel themselves so secure behind the bayonets of their armies, so confident of the willing obedience of their slaves and of their power to enforce obedience among them, if necessary, that they would only laugh at the Proclamation as an impotent menace, and at the President for thus sitting as Giant Pope in Pilgrim's Progress sat, "grinning and biting his nails" at the pilgrims who went by in safety.

abstract: The Banner Club, of Kings County, have made arrangements for one of the grandest demonstrations freedomward ever seen in the City of Brooklyn. Maj.-Gen. CASSIUS M. CLAY, an orator by nature and culture, and a lover of truth and liberty by instinct, will address, to-night, at the Academy of Music, his fellow-countrymen and women upon the subject of the Proclamation. The old campaign banners, the Glee Club, with their grand chorus of "Free soil, free speech, free men, FREMONT and liberty," and the stirring music of Dodworth's Band, will lend their attractions to the gathering, and a refreshing season of the most orthodoxically Republican creed may be anticipated.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. The fourth of an interesting series of Mr. WM. H. HURLBERT's "Fifteen Months at the South," is given in this morning's issue. All official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Margaret Moncrief vs. John Moncrief. The argument on this appeal before the General Term has been before mentioned in the TIMES. The action was for a limited divorce on the ground of alleged cruel and inhuman treatment.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Moncrief vs. John Moncrief. -- The argument on this appeal before the General Term has been before mentioned in the TIMES. The action was for a limited divorce on the ground of alleged cruel and inhuman treatment. The cause was tried before Justice LEONARD in December, 1860, when the Judge found, as matter of fact, that the allegations of cruel treatment, &c., of the plaintiff, by the defendant, were not proven; and, as a conclusion of law, that the complaint should be dismissed, without costs.

abstract: The number of our sick and wounded soldiers "paroled" by the enemy's cavalry at Warrenton, last week, is 811. The proceeding can scarcely be recognized as a parole, from the information which has reached us. The Yankees merely took the names of the patients, giving few paroles in writing. The large majority were not required to take any oath or sign any paper.

abstract: Recruiting for the regular army in this vicinity is improving slowly. The officers at Chathain and Cedar streets get a few men each every week probably about a dozen between them, and as many or more music boys.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the regular army in this vicinity is improving slowly. The officers at Chathain and Cedar streets get a few men each every week probably about a dozen between them, and as many or more music boys. There are rendezvous open in Rochester, Buffalo and other town in the State, from which small detachments arrive periodically. It is said, however, that the present rate of recruiting would not keep the wants of the line supplied in time of peace. Whether the authorities have in contemplation any extra inducement for persons to join the regulars is not known.

abstract: Samuel Hallett ads. The People. -- This is a motion, on the par of the defendant, Samuel Hallett, to quash the indictments of the Grand Jury against him for forgery and false pretences in issuing forged and fraudulent certificates of the 5 per cent. stocks of the State of Indiana. The language of the indictment for forgery is, that Samuel Hallett, banker, &c., of New-York City, on the 23d day of May, 1862, did, with force and arms, feloniously, falsely make, forge and counterfeit a certain instrument purporting to be the act of the State of Indiana, by which instrument a pecuniary demand against said State was purported to be created, &c. The District Attorney raised the preliminary objection to the hearing of the motion, that defendant should demur to the indictment, and not move to quash, as from the Judge's decision on this last motion, whichever way it might be, it would be impossible for a writ of error to lie, and neither the people nor the defendant could appeal. The objection was overruled by the Judge, and the argument on the motion to quash, proceeded with. After very extended argument, the Judge took the papers and reserved decision.

The District Attorney raised the preliminary objection to the hearing of the motion, that defendant should demur to the indictment, and not move to quash, as from the Judge's decision on this last motion, whichever way it might be, it would be impossible for a writ of error to lie, and neither the people nor the defendant could appeal. The objection was overruled by the Judge, and the argument on the motion to quash, proceeded with. After very extended argument, the Judge took the papers and reserved decision.

abstract: Current scene, Savannah, Ga; report on building of harbor fortifications there
snippet: Current scene, Savannah, Ga; report on building of harbor fortifications there
lead_paragraph: Mr. A.G. SPENCER, formerly a merchant of this city, but for the last two years a resident of Savannah, Georgia, which place he left a week ago last Friday, arrived here two days ago in the United States transport George C. Collins, and has kindly favored us with the following authentic information with regard to the present condition of affairs in that rebel city. The population of Savannah, usually about 25,000, is at present something less than 15,000, and business is almost at a stand still. Two out of five of the stores and other places of business are closed, and those remaining open have a very meagre stock of goods, and are doing next to nothing in the way of trade. The blockade of the city he considers almost perfect, and does not think it worth while for the Government to spend another cent to make it more effective. All manufactured and imported goods are extremely high, and scarcely to be had at any price. Ordinary boots bring $30 a pair, and $20 is charged for footing old ones. Coats worth in New-York $15, bring from $40 to $50, and pants from $20 to $25. Tea is worth $10 per pound; coffee 75 cents; butter $1, and other things in proportion. Flour is $42 a barrel, with a limited supply on hand, as the wheat crop of that region has proved almost a total failure. The crop of corn, however, has been good this season, and it is now selling in Savannah at 50 cents a bushel; though, previous to the gathering of the new crop, it brought $2. There is great suffering among the poorer classes of the city, and their prospects for the future are daily growing worse, as the contributions of the wealthy for the support of the soldiers' families, which were freely given at the beginning of the war, are now greatly diminished, from the inability of the contributors, and from the fact that many of them have been themselves forced into the army through the conscription act. The conscription has been very thorough, and almost every ablebodied man, from 18 to 35, is now in the army. The second conscription, which is to include all between the ages of 35 and 45, had not been enforced when Mr. SPENCER left, but he thinks it will add one-third to the fighting force of the Confederacy, which he estimates at present to be about 400,000 effective men.

abstract: The two Committees, one from Mozart and the other from Tammany, met yesterday afternoon at the last-named Hall, and, with many sacrifices on each side, cemented the division which has so long estranged these factions.
lead_paragraph: The two Committees, one from Mozart and the other from Tammany, met yesterday afternoon at the last-named Hall, and, with many sacrifices on each side, cemented the division which has so long estranged these factions. SMITH ELY was the spokesman on the part of Tammany, and FERNANDO WOOD on the part of Mozart. A proposition was made by Tammany that Mozart should take four out of the six Congressmen from this City, and retain for themselves the Surrogate and Supervisor.

abstract: Editorial on Seymour views on war; Editorial on Seymour criticism of conduct of war
snippet: Editorial on Seymour views on war; Editorial on Seymour criticism of conduct of war
lead_paragraph: We have already more than once urged the fact that Gov. SEYMOUR devotes ten times as much space and labor to the condemnation of our own Government as he does to that of the rebellion. "But he does condemn the rebellion, nevertheless," say his supporters, -- "and that is all you have any right to ask." Perhaps it is -- and perhaps not. But let us see how he condemns the rebellion. "We charge," says Mr. SEYMOUR, "that this rebelbellion is most wicked, because it is against the best Government that ever existed." That starts off very well. It seems explicit and emphatic. But Gov. SEYMOUR proceeds to enlarge upon the point. "Rebellion," he says, "is not necessarily a wrong; it may be an act of the highest virtue." Possibly, then, there may be some extenuation for this rebellion. "To resist a bad government is patriotism, -- to resist a good one is the greatest guilt." Here, then, is the test which Mr. SEYMOUR proposes to apply. If our Government, in its actual and practical workings when the rebellion broke out, was a good one, then the rebellion was wicked. If not -- not. Now what has Gov. SEYMOUR to say on this point? "Our Government and its administration are different things; -- but in the eyes of the civilized world, abuses, weakness or folly in the conduct of affairs go far to JUSTIFY RESISTANCE." And then Gov. SEYMOUR comes back to the main staple of his speech, and proceeds to show that "abuses, weakness and folly in the conduct of affairs" have characterized our Government since its administration passed into Republican hands.
headline: {'main': 'How Gov. Seymour Censures the Rebellion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How Gov. Seymour Censures the Rebellion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Fifth Daily Session of the Episcopal Triennial Convention was held yesterday. The Special Committee of Nine on the Rebellion was announced. The Treasurer's and other reports were read and approved.
lead_paragraph: The Fifth Daily Session of the Episcopal Triennial Convention was held yesterday. The Special Committee of Nine on the Rebellion was announced. The Treasurer's and other reports were read and approved. Dr. GOODWIN proposed a new series of canons, prohibiting participation in the profession of arms by any Bishop, with evident reference to the case of the rebel Major-General POLK. After a lively debate, his proposed amendments were referred to the Committee on Canons. Rev. Dr. VINTON announced that he would to-day offer resolutions against uncanonical ordinations.

abstract: We suppose we may take it as true that Gen. ROSECRANS has won us a great victory at Corinth over the rebel forces of Gens. PRICE and VAN DORN. The dispatches so far received all go to confirm the first reports of the Union success.
lead_paragraph: We suppose we may take it as true that Gen. ROSECRANS has won us a great victory at Corinth over the rebel forces of Gens. PRICE and VAN DORN. The dispatches so far received all go to confirm the first reports of the Union success. The rebel Generals, it is alleged, attacked the Union army lying at Corinth, and made a most determined effort to drive them from their intrenchments. But they were repulsed with great slaughter, and withdrew, leaving their dead and wounded on the field. The facts of the pursuit are not sufficiently known to enable us to anticipate the probable future results of the fight; but Gen. GRANT seems to be hopeful of a complete annihilation of the rebels as a field force.
headline: {'main': 'Victory Again at Corinth.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Victory Again at Corinth.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- A patriotic clergyman of the Episcopal Church, yesterday introduced into the Convention of that highly respectable body a series of canons, (or, as the Express, perhaps with malice prepense, spells the word, cannons,) leveled against the seceding Major-General-Bishop LEONIDAS POLK, of the rebel army. That the course of this military prelate is a scandal to his Church, as well as a shame to his country, may be easily conceded, and we have no objection to seeing him exposed to a battery of every size and calibre. But when we reflect that the Convention meets in New-York, and that the Southern imitator of that rebellious Scottish Bishop whose "conscience rattled" under his surplice, is actually in Kentucky with the army of BRAGG, we cannot help suggesting that the offender is, just at present, rather "out of range." The only clause in the proposed ecclesiastical discipline which seems to us really practical in its character, is that which provides for certain action to be taken "whenever a Bishop shall be ipso facto suspended." Should BUELL succeed in capturing the crusader of Louisiana, this clause may perhaps come into operation with salutary effect.
lead_paragraph: -- A patriotic clergyman of the Episcopal Church, yesterday introduced into the Convention of that highly respectable body a series of canons, (or, as the Express, perhaps with malice prepense, spells the word, cannons,) leveled against the seceding Major-General-Bishop LEONIDAS POLK, of the rebel army. That the course of this military prelate is a scandal to his Church, as well as a shame to his country, may be easily conceded, and we have no objection to seeing him exposed to a battery of every size and calibre. But when we reflect that the Convention meets in New-York, and that the Southern imitator of that rebellious Scottish Bishop whose "conscience rattled" under his surplice, is actually in Kentucky with the army of BRAGG, we cannot help suggesting that the offender is, just at present, rather "out of range." The only clause in the proposed ecclesiastical discipline which seems to us really practical in its character, is that which provides for certain action to be taken "whenever a Bishop shall be ipso facto suspended." Should BUELL succeed in capturing the crusader of Louisiana, this clause may perhaps come into operation with salutary effect.

abstract: The United States steam gunboat Connecticut will sail from this pert on the 11th inst. for the Gulf, taking, besides stores and passengers, a mail for the squadron blockading the Southern coast en route. All letters, newspapers, parcels, &c., destined for any vessel of the fleet, left, free of expense, at the Brooklyn Naval Lyceum, and properly directed, will be forwarded cheerfully. The sailors of our navy value reading matter very highly, and their friends have now an opportunity to supply them. It is said the Connecticut will take out funds to pay our soldiers in Florida.

abstract: Whig of last Saturday discourses upon the chances of foreign recognition of the rebel Government. The prospects it concedes to be not very cheering, but it argues that the "imagined peril of the in institution of Slavery " has frightened the commercial classes of England, and that the favors the rebels receive from the English Press and Government must be owing to their desire to prop up that institution.
lead_paragraph: -- The Richmond Whig of last Saturday discourses upon the chances of foreign recognition of the rebel Government. The prospects it concedes to be not very cheering, but it argues that the "imagined peril of the in institution of Slavery " has frightened the commercial classes of England, and that the favors the rebels receive from the English Press and Government must be owing to their desire to prop up that institution.

abstract: -- The Committee having in charge the organization of the Ironsides Regiment, have unanimously recommended, as permanent Colonel of the regiment, MARK HOYT, Esq., of this City, and at their request, and in acquiescence with the earnest indorsement of Mr. HOYT by some of our most eminent citizens, Gov. MORGAN has made the appointment. Col. HOYT, therefore, occupies the position in place of CHARLES GOULD, Esq., resigned. The new commanding officer of the Ironsides Regiment is a gentleman of wealth, position, unblemished character and religious standing, and the regiment is fortunate in securing the sympathy and services of so suitable a commander. We are not informed as to his military capacity.
lead_paragraph: -- The Committee having in charge the organization of the Ironsides Regiment, have unanimously recommended, as permanent Colonel of the regiment, MARK HOYT, Esq., of this City, and at their request, and in acquiescence with the earnest indorsement of Mr. HOYT by some of our most eminent citizens, Gov. abstract: public rehearsal of the New-York Philharmonic Society takes place next Saturday afternoon at Irving Hall. This rehearsal inaugurates the Philharmonic's twenty-first season, and it is safe to say the Society was never in a more prosperous and promising condition than it is at present. It is the only musical association in the City which is distinctively American in character; other organizations -- the Arion and Liederkranz, for instance -- being almost exclusively German. Its object is the cultivation of American music; and its managers, whilst reproducing the best works of European masters, and offering engagements to foreign vocal and instrumental performers of acknowledged merit, desires especially to encourage the efforts of native artists and composers.
lead_paragraph: public rehearsal of the New-York Philharmonic Society takes place next Saturday afternoon at Irving Hall. abstract: Gen. BRAGG, commanding the invading rebel forces in Kentucky, inaugurated a rebel (Governor in Frankfort, the capital of the State, made a great speech on the occasion, burned the railroad bridge across the river, and evacuated the place with his entire force! It is to be hoped that BRAGG did not brag any in that speech of his -- for the fact that our army had got is his rear at Bardstown makes his retreat look amazingly like a skedaddle; and it is to hoped that the Governor he had just inducted to office was also inducted to the safe side of the Kentucky River before the bridge over it was burned.
lead_paragraph: Gen. abstract: day in supposing that Hon. F.A. CONKLING was a member of the Committee on Commerce in the House of Representative, and that he ought, therefore, to have detected the swindle by which a provision was smuggled through that Committee and the House, giving to the Collector, Surveyor and Navy Agent of this port one half of all the moneys resulting from the confiscation of rebel vessels in this port. Mr. C. was not a member of that Comtee. We understand, furthermore, that he opposed and defeated the same venal scheme when it came forward in a distinct shape, and that it finally passed by the indirect and dishonest means which we exposed the other day.

abstract: Union mass meeting held, Brooklyn; C M Clay and Stanton speak
snippet: Union mass meeting held, Brooklyn; C M Clay and Stanton speak
lead_paragraph: From pit to dome, in aisles, in lobbies, in private boxes, on the stage, peering in at all the doors, standing in all contiguous places where the proceedings could be heard, the crowded and brilliant audience at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn, last evening, testified to the thorough loyalty of our sister city, as well as to its appreciation of the necessity for sustaining the President and the Government in this hour of its trial. The audience comprised representatives of the wealth, the intelligence and the beauty of the City of Churches, rarely gathered within the walls of one building.

abstract: Editorial on current military movements in Kentucky sees no cause to fear for Nashville safety
snippet: Editorial on current military movements in Kentucky sees no cause to fear for Nashville safety
lead_paragraph: There is, we think, a wholly unfounded apprehension entertained in some quarters of the safety of Nashville, Tenn. It is assumed that Gen. BUELL, by marching his army to Louisville and getting in front of BRAGG, left the way open by which he entered, and that BRAGG had only to move back over the same road and fall with crushing force on Nashville, now stripped of its usual defensive force. It seems to be overlooked in this view of matters, that Gen. BUELL did not leave the road unprotected that he marched over. On the contrary, not only Nashville, but Munfordsville and Bowling Green, two very strong key positions on the road between Louisville and Nashville, are held in force by BUELL's men. From Bowling Green we had an account yesterday of reconnoissances beyond Glasgow, far cast of BRAGG's supposed route back upon Nashville, showing the Union troops to be masters of that line of travel.
headline: {'main': 'Safety of Nashville.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Safety of Nashville.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Alderman FARLEY presiding -- gave another hearing on this subject yesterday afternoon, when brief remarks were made by Hon. THEODORE E. TOMLINSON, Gen. HALL, Col. ROAME, and Mr. GEORGE W. MORTON, all favoring the idea that the Common Council should take steps to prepare the City against a surprised attack, and encourage local military organization. Mr. TOMLINSON thought it would be improper to leave arms permanently in the possession of the citizens, when not in legitimate use, but to store them where they could be readily obtained by the proper authorities, and yet be secure from the reach of violent mobs. The working model of a cannon, designed to concentrate a quadrupled fire upon the projectile, by connecting the latter with the charges by four rods, was exhibited and explained. The Artillery Inspector of Gen. FRANKLIN's Staff, who chanced to be present for a few minutes, and who was unknown to any of the other gentlemen present, privately remarked that the principle upon which the invention rests had so far failed to establish itself, but he believed it was worthy of further experiments. The Committee adjourned to meet at the call of the Chairman.

abstract: -- The Thirteenth Regiment New-Hampshire Volunteers, three years' men, which left Concord on Monday morning, arrived at Jersey City early on Tuesday morning in the steamer City of Boston, via Nashua, Worcester and Norwich. The regiment numbers about 1,000, mostly young, robust and temperate men, and is said to be the best regiment that has left that State. They are armed with Springfield rifles and equipped with everything necessary for the field. Upon arriving at Jersey City, the regiment were received by Maj. BROWN, and in a short time thereafter were furnished with breakfast by the New-England Relief Association. About 11 o'clock they took their departure on the cars for Washington. abstract: We have received a new map of the Washoe Silver region in Nevada Territory, published by H.H. BANCROFT & Co., of San Francisco. During this dearth of silver it is very pleasant to have spread before one's eyes a broad expanse of country, where the precious metal lurks in virgin coyness beneath the earth's green veil, throwing out shy indications of its presence, and only waiting to be wooed and won by some bold miner. It is rather an aggravation, however, to know that the silver is fenced in by proprietary claims, and stands to the public at large in the light of an "engaged" heiress, or, rather, an actual bride, -- preempted treasure which men may admire at a distance, but cannot "covet" without breaking a divine, commandment, cannot walk off with without becoming amenable to human law and vengeance --knowing, in fact, that all cradles in that vicinity must be rocked by the rightful proprietor alone. The map is for sale in this City, and may be had of Mr. J.H. COLTON, at No. 172 William-street.

MACDONALD, of Flushing, L.I., read a paper on "The Operations and Skirmishes of the British and American Armies in the County of Westchester, during the Autumn of '76, before the Battle of White Plains," at the meeting of this Society last evening. The Gallery of Art of this time-honored Society has recently been enriched by the deposit of several of the finest pictures of our best artists. Among them are CHURCH's "New-England Scenes," HUNTINGTON's "Counterfeit Note," and the gems of the last Academy exhibition -- GRAY's "Apple of Discord," KENSETT's "Indian Summer," CASSILEAR's "Swiss Lake," HUBBARD's "Head of the Lake," CROPSEY's "Study of Brambles," HENNESY's "Morning Prayer," S. JOHNSON's "Warming her Hands," GUY's "School Troubles," and others.

abstract: One of the largest and most interesting meetings in connection with the General Convention of the Episcopal Church, was that in behalf of the above above-named Society, held in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, on Sunday evening last.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest and most interesting meetings in connection with the General Convention of the Episcopal Church, was that in behalf of the above above-named Society, held in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, on Sunday evening last. The spacious church was filled to its utmost capacity by a congregation deeply interested in the proceedings of the society. The chancel was filled with bishops and clergy, including many officers of the Society and in the congregation were its friends, clerical and lay from many parts of the Church. The venerable and apostolic pioneer of the church in the Northwest, Bishop KEMPER, presided and with him were his successors and coadjutor, Bishops WHIPPLE, of Minnesota and TALBOT, Missionary bishop of the Northwest. Bishop WILLIAMS, of Connecticut was also present and opened the meeting with appropriate prayers. After the singing of a psalm, bishop KEMPER introduced the object of the meeting, and explained the charactor of the Society, which is an institution organized for the purpose of encouraging goodly and talented young men to enter the Ministry and to provide means for the education of such as need assistance.

abstract: No one who has attended the meetings of the Triennial General Episcopal Convention, now in session in this City, can have failed to perceive the singular omissions, inaccuracies, misstatements and absurdities contained in the reports of their debates in some of the City newspapers. As one of the Lay Deputies from this diocese, I have not hitherto been...
lead_paragraph: No one who has attended the meetings of the Triennial General Episcopal Convention, now in session in this City, can have failed to perceive the singular omissions, inaccuracies, misstatements and absurdities contained in the reports of their debates in some of the City newspapers. As one of the Lay Deputies from this diocese, I have not hitherto been inclined to attempt the correction of these numerous errors, preferring to await the full and authentic report, which will doubtless appear after the close of the Convention. The Evening Post of last evening, however, contains a misstatement so monstrous and so injurious, that I cannot allow it for a moment to go unnoticed.

abstract: This new, staunch, and beautiful steamer, belonging to Messrs. SPOFFORD, TILESON  Co., designed for the New-York and Havana trade, made her trial trip yesterday, sailing from Pier No. 4, North River, at 10 o'clock A.M. A very select party of gentlemen, friends of the above firm, were on board,...
lead_paragraph: This new, staunch, and beautiful steamer, belonging to Messrs. SPOFFORD, TILESON & CO., designed for the New-York and Havana trade, made her trial trip yesterday, sailing from Pier No. 4, North River, at 10 o'clock A.M. A very select party of gentlemen, friends of the above firm, were on board, and all expressed their delight at the admirable arrangements of the steamer, and the excellent manner in which she manifested her very superior sailing qualities. The Eagle was built by the well-known builders J.A. WESTERVELT & Son, and was launched June 21, 1862. She is two hundred and thirty-eight feet in length, thirty-seven feet breadth of beam, and twenty-one and a half feet depth of hold -- tonnage, one thousand five hundred and sixty two tons. Her machinery was built at the Allaire Works, and consists of a beam engine seventy-five inches diameter of cylinder, and twelve feet stroke of piston. She has two round flue boilers, with SICKLES' cut-off attached, iron wheels of thirty feet diameter, and ten feet face, a hoisting engine and independent boiler, and water tanks capable of holding six thousand gallons.

abstract: Robert B. Roosevelt et al. vs. Augustus J. Brown et at. This is an action on certain promissory notes and to foreclose a mortgage, and on a guaranty for the collection of the notes in suit. The defendant, Brown, interposes a demurrer to the complaint on the grounds, first, that he, the guarantor of the collection of the notes, is improperly made a defendant...
lead_paragraph: Robert B. Roosevelt et al. vs. Augustus J. Brown et at. -- This is an action on certain promissory notes and to foreclose a mortgage, and on a guaranty for the collection of the notes in suit. The defendant, Brown, interposes a demurrer to the complaint on the grounds, first, that he, the guarantor of the collection of the notes, is improperly made a defendant in this action. Second, that several causes of action are improperly united, namely, a cause of action arising upon the promissory notes, and on the mortgage described in the complaint, and a cause of action upon the agreement of guaranty on the part of defendant, Brown. The counsel for defendant cited the cases in 11 Howard Pr. R. 218; 17 Id. 183; and 23 Barb. 216.

abstract: a company of thirty well-dressed, fine-looking children from the Children's Aid Society, left the City for the West under the charge of Mr. H. FRIEDGEN. It is cheering to know that amid the horrors of the war the poor children, many of whom have been made orphans by it, are not forgotten. The kind-hearted people of the West still extend the warmest welcome to the proteges of the Children's Aid Society, and the numerous letters received from the boys and girls show how well they have been provided for in their new homes. Several young girls from the Girls' Lodging House, No. 205 Canal-street, accompanied the party, about the happiest of the happy family.

abstract: Dr. CHITTENDEN, Surgeon of the Sixteenth Regiment, returned from Kentucky yesterday, leaving Richmond on Monday and Lexington on Tuesday. He has been attending on our wounded, and in constant contact with the rebels, and is therefore able to speak intelligently of their strength, and the events of the past few weeks.
lead_paragraph: Dr. CHITTENDEN, Surgeon of the Sixteenth Regiment, returned from Kentucky yesterday, leaving Richmond on Monday and Lexington on Tuesday. He has been attending on our wounded, and in constant contact with the rebels, and is therefore able to speak intelligently of their strength, and the events of the past few weeks. He says that about three weeks ago our Gen. MORGAN, on his way from the Gap to the Ohio, near Manchester, captured KIRBY SMITH's ammunition train, and all the supplies he had there. He also seized all the salt and flour which had been stored there by the rebels. This news, which we have not heard before, was learned by Dr. C. from the rebels themselves, and is doubtless correct.

abstract: Editorial sees Seymour campaign hindered by war
snippet: Editorial sees Seymour campaign hindered by war
lead_paragraph: Our Seymour friends are not having quite as good a time with their canvass as they anticipated. They have encountered several unexpected obstacles. The changed condition of the country, and especially the altered aspects of the war, cause them considerable embarrassment. The fact is, they jumped into their partisan movement against the Government at a moment of disaster and discouragement. Reverses had overtaken our arms. Our armies had been driven back in their advance upon the rebel capital, and had been beaten in their attempt to defend our own. Discord prevailed among our Generals, -- hesitation and weakness seemed to characterize our Executive councils, -- and a feeling of profound despondency had seized upon the public mind.

abstract: HUDSON COUNTY COURT. -- The Fall term of the Hudson County Court commenced yesterday forenoon, Judge OGDEN and Assistant Judges POPE and CHAMBERS presiding. Judge OGDEN, in his charge to the Grand Jury, called their attention particularly to unlicensed liquor-selling in the county, and enjoined on them not to let a case of the kind pass their notice. He also called their attention to the general practice of selling liquor on Sunday, which was a violation of the State laws, and defined the nature of the crime -any person so doing was guilty of keeping a disorderly house, it making no difference whether the house was quiet or not. Until the Grand Jury have completed their labors the Court will be engaged on civil cases.

abstract: editorial holds Florida and Texas both suitable for colonization of Negroes to produce cotton
snippet: editorial holds Florida and Texas both suitable for colonization of Negroes to produce cotton
lead_paragraph: It has been proposed to send an expedition to Texas sufficiently powerful to hold that State, and then to colonize it with free labor for the production of cotton. A similar project has been suggested for Florida. Both deserve the earnest, prompt and practical attention of the Government. They involve consequences of very great permanent importance, as well as possess the highest value as immediate strategic movements.

abstract: A meeting of Californians was held at the Astor House yesterday, to make arrangements for the funeral of the late Col. MATHEWSON, of the California Regiment, who received his death wounds at the battle of South Mountain. Hon. F.F. Low was appointed Chairman, and HENRY THOMPSON, Esq., Secretary, Mr. STETSON read a note from Major-Gen....
lead_paragraph: A meeting of Californians was held at the Astor House yesterday, to make arrangements for the funeral of the late Col. MATHEWSON, of the California Regiment, who received his death wounds at the battle of South Mountain. Hon. F.F. Low was appointed Chairman, and HENRY THOMPSON, Esq., Secretary, Mr. STETSON read a note from Major-Gen. SANDFORD, stating that he had ordered out the Seventy-First Regiment as an escort to attend the funeral, and requesting that the funeral might be postponed till Thursday, the 9th inst., at 3 P.M. The meeting voted to postpone the funeral accordingly. Mr. MACOMBER appeared as the representative of the officers of the Greene-street M.E. Church, of which Col. MATHEWSON was formerly an honored and highly-respected member, and tendered the use of that church for the funeral ceremonies, which was accepted. The following gentlemen were then selected: Gen. John C. Fremont, Hon. C.K. Garrison, Gen. James S. Ellis, Hon. F.F. Low, Geo Wilkes, Hon. Samuel B. Smith, Hon. E.F. Burton-Henry Thompson and Dr. Eugene Crowell. A committee was appointed to wait upon the Board of Aldermen, then in session, and, through them, invite the Common Council to attend the funeral. A committee, consisting of Geo. Wilkes, Henry Thompson and Hon. S.B. Smith, was appointed to draft suitable resolutions, to be forwarded with the body to the family of the deceased (a wife and four children) now in California. A resolution was adopted, requesting the Rev. Mr. EWER, who was an intimate friend of the late Colonel in California, to assist in the services at the church.

abstract: Italian Opera is destined, as it seems to be, to lead a precarious and exciting life at the Academy during the war, German opera is making itself quietly comfortable in its snug quarters at Wallack's Theatre. It is not so long since Fashion followed Mr. WALLACK to Thirteenth-street that she can have forgotten her way to that charming little "temple of the muses" which was for years her favorite haunt. If she will but turn her steps that way at present we can assure her she will find her reward in the opportunity of hearing opera sung less for show than for love. The German must at least be admitted this musical merit, that they do with the heart whatever they do, and believe the divine art of BEETHOVEN, MOZART, MENDELSSOHN and MEYERBEER exist for more elevated purposes than to put lazy people agreeably to sleep or attract crowds to a bazaar. CARL ANSCHUTZ presides ever the orchestra of this Teutonic organization which is a sufficient guarantee that it is an orchestra and not an orgie of independent fiddlescrapers. The duties of prima donna devolve upon Mme. ROTTER, and those of tenor upon Herr WEINLICH. Naturally the strength of the company will not permit it to attempt grand opera, or even the higher range of strictly German composition -- but if it will but do well what it does attempt, we shall all be the gainers by this sensible and so far successful enterprise.
lead_paragraph: Italian Opera is destined, as it seems to be, to lead a precarious and exciting life at the Academy during the war, German opera is making itself quietly comfortable in its snug quarters at Wallack's Theatre. CARL ANSCHUTZ presides ever the orchestra of this Teutonic organization which is a sufficient guarantee that it is an orchestra and not an orgie of independent fiddlescrapers. abstract: Moses B. Taylor, et al. vs. The Ship Joseph Walker. This was a motion on behalf of the libel- ants for the repayment of money into Court. The libel was filed Oct. 29, 1855, to recover wharfage. Four different parties intervened in the suit, each contesting the libelant's claim and claiming prior and...
lead_paragraph: Moses B. Taylor, et al. vs. The Ship Joseph Walker. -- This was a motion on behalf of the libel- ants for the repayment of money into Court. The libel was filed Oct. 29, 1855, to recover wharfage. Four different parties intervened in the suit, each contesting the libelant's claim and claiming prior and superior liens and equities against the ship on their part. Shortly after the libel was filed an interlocutory decree was entered in the cause by consent of all parties appearing, that a venditioni exponas issue in the cause to sell the ship, "and that the proceeds of such sale be paid into the registry of the Court to await the further order of the Court in the premises without prejudice to any of the parties intervening therein." The venditioni was returned Feb. 28, 1858, with $3,063 made thereon, and three days after a written consent was signed by the proctors of the libelants, and all the claimants, "that those moneys be deposited by the Clerk of the Court in the United States Trust Company on thirty days notice to earn interest as accumulation, and that an order be entered accordingly of course," which was accordingly done.

abstract: Rumors and reports continue to come from all quarters that Gen. LEE'S army is retreating, or preparing to retreat, southward from Winchester; and the statement we obtain this morning from Washington by telegraph, to the effect that Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON is moving a...
lead_paragraph: Rumors and reports continue to come from all quarters that Gen. LEE's army is retreating, or preparing to retreat, southward from Winchester; and the statement we obtain this morning from Washington by telegraph, to the effect that Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON is moving a large rebel force over the Rappahannock in the direction of the Manassas Gap Railroad, and that he has already taken possession of Warrenton, Bristow and other points lately occupied by our troops, does not make it any less likely. It is probably his intention to attempt with his army to capture and hold Manassas, Thoroughfare Gap, and the whole line of the railroad to Strashurgh, which, if once effected, would render a rebel retreat from Winchester to Richmond comparatively easy. Or, if JOHNSTON fails to effect this, he can at least hold Warrenton and the line of the Rappahannock, by which action the rebels would be enabled to cross the mountains by way of Sperryville, and strike the railroad at a safe point south of the Rappahannock. It seems incredible, as some reports say, that the rebels are preparing to move their whole army up the Shenandoah Valley as far as Staunton. Either of the routes to Richmond which we have indicated, and others also, are infinitely more practicable; and if JOHNSTON has as large a force as is stated, it does not seem but that the rebels might conceive that either of them can be made effective. We had supposed, however, that we had men enough in front of Washington to prevent any such attempts on the part of JOHNSTON; and as SIGEL and HEINTZELMAN are, or were a short time ago, in command of them, we know that, so far as they are concerned, all that skill and courage can do will be done to prevent it. In case JOHNSTON attempts to advance any further on his present line, or even if he attempts to hold with force the positions he has just been permitted to occupy, we may soon look for an important action near the scene of our first great battle, and the scene of Gen. POPE's unstrategical manoeuvres. If he be allowed to seize the Manassas Gap road, drive our troops near there forward to Washington, and thus secure a comfortable rebel retreat from Winchester, we shall have to confess that our Washington strategy is sadly at fault.

abstract: The reputation of HINDMAN, of Arkansas, is well established. He is a knave, a tyrant, and a ruffian. It occasioned us some surprise, therefore, to learn recently, that he had lost his command in Arkansas, and been placed under arrest. If any conscription had to be forced rudely upon an unwilling people -- if any brutal revenge had to be wreaked on captive Union citizens -- if any murderous raid of bushwhackers into loyal districts were desired -- HINDMAN, of all villians in the South, was the man for the service. His disgrace was an enigma to us. How could the Confederates spare him?
