abstract: The rebels say that all the gains and victories of the North are won in the cool weather, while their triumphs are achieved in the warm weather. If the theory is correct this month and the ensuing one ought to find our army very active. October would be a pleasant month in which to capture Richmond. If our army do not enter it in that month, the rebel army probably will; end it would be much easier for our troops to enter and hold it before the rebels get there, than to capture it after that event. On to Richmond!

abstract: Editorial on able men Republicans have chosen as candidates for Congress
snippet: Editorial on able men Republicans have chosen as candidates for Congress
lead_paragraph: -- The Republicans and Union men throughout this State are putting forward very strong and able men as their candidates for Congress. We have already mentioned the nomination of Hon. LEMUEL STETSON, in the Clinton County, and of Hon. C.T. HULBURD, in the St. Lawrence District. We see that in the Auburn District Hon. T.C. POMEROY, the present member, has been nominated for reelection.

abstract: The Journal of Commerce says that if the "conservatives," meaning thereby Ex-Mayor WOOD, Captain RYNDERS and their supporters, carry the election this Fall, Mr. LINCOLN will find himself sustained as the Constitutional President of the United States, "by such a loyal body of men as he never dreamed of." We have no doubt of it. Mr. LINCOLN is not specially distinguished for his imaginative faculties, -- and we presume he never has dreamed of just such supporters as the Journal promises him. If he has dreamed in that line, then doubtless he was afflicted by a horrible nightmare; and, on waking, consoled himself by the interpretation usual for dreams, -- that they go by contraries.

abstract: -- The New-York special correspondent of the London Times has written a note to the Evening Post, protesting that he has, ever "given currency to any willful misstatement, great or small." He excuses himself for having sent off a forged extract from Mr. LINCOLN's letter to Mr. GREELEY, by saying that he copied it from the Caucasian. It is barely possible; that he may be ignorant enough of the City Press to suppose the Caucasian good authority for anything; and he may be too indifferent to current events to inform himself, accurately as to the tenor of a document published in every newspaper of the day.

abstract: trust, will fail to read the political speeches in our columns this morning. That of DANIEL S. DICKINSON on one side, and RICHARD O'GORMAN on the other, merit peculiar attention and comparison. Mr. DICKINSON is for war upon the rebels: Mr. O'GORMAN for war upon the Administration; and the burning language of the one in denunciation of the rebellion is not stronger than the words of the other in denunciation of the constituted authorities of the nation. If any one, after reading Mr. O'GORMAN's speech, can mistake the real aims of the Seymour party, or doubt which line of policy is likely to carry on the war vigorously, and bring it to a triumphant close, it must be because his mental and moral perceptions are rendered obtuse indeed by the virulence of Pro-Slaveryism and faction. A few more speeches like Mr. O'GORMAN's will compel every really loyal man to range himself at once under the banner of the party whose devotion to the War, the Union, the Government and the Administration, is unqualified. DICKINSON and O'GORMAN but lately acted with the same political party, but they are now wide as the poles asunder; and no man can doubt the fervid and entire devotion of Mr. DICKINSON, to the Union and the war against rebels.

abstract: Editorial says any action by McClellan forces should be taken shortly before winter weather sets in
snippet: Editorial says any action by McClellan forces should be taken shortly before winter weather sets in
lead_paragraph: -- We shall either have motion and action in the army of Gen. MCCLELLAN in a very short time, or we shall have -- winter quarters. In a few days it will be the middle of October, and by the middle of the succeeding month we shall begin to hear of that terrible mud, those horrible roads, and that fearful weather, of which we heard so much last fall and winter, and which render impossible any movement or action on the part of the National army. If LEE's army is really in the act of effecting, its retreat to Richmond or to its old quarters at Manassas, and if Gen. HALLECK does not propose that MCCLELLAN shall pursue it, or that SIGEL and HEINTZELMAN shall block its pathway, we shall take it as an inevitable indication that it is HALLECK's intention to maintain our army on the defensive before the Capital during the Winter. For if, holding the points our forces now do, at Harper's Ferryand at Centreville, it be considered impracticable? to attack with success a retreating army, it will certainly be much less practicable to attack that army when it is stationary and planted behind defensive works at Manassas or at Richmond. The present Autumn weather in Virginia is splendid weather for military work -- good roads, bracing air, bright skies. But, as we said before, it will presently come to a close. Our correspondent at Antietam wrote on Monday last: "This splendid Fall weather with its invigorating air and excellent roads inviting to activity, will soon give place to storms and muddy thorough fares, which will forbid us to move. By the time the Potomac has been swollen by rains, which will secure 'My Maryland' against another rebel raid, the roads, by the same natural agencies, will have been rendered impassable. We shall then be ready, I suppose, to go into Winter quarters, where the army will waste away by sickness and inaction, and be ready (?) for active operations in the Spring." We earnestly trust that this will not be the case, and that no such programme has been drawn up by Gen. HALLECK. The country demands action, the army demands it; and if it be delayed till next Spring, we may look forward to another Summer of disasters.

abstract: The army now, as  ever since the commencement of the war, is exceedingly anxious for active work against the rebels. There is nothing the soldiers dread so much as delay nothing they fear so much as inaction and Winter quarters. They leave worked hard during the hot months; they have fought splendidly, and achieved memorable victories.
lead_paragraph: -- The army now, as ever since the commencement of the war, is exceedingly anxious for active work against the rebels. There is nothing the soldiers dread so much as delay nothing they fear so much as inaction and Winter quarters. They leave worked hard during the hot months; they have fought splendidly, and achieved memorable victories. But they, as well as the nation, see and feel that their past triumphs have been indecisive; and they all believe that with brave and wise leadership they can speedily utterly conquer the enemy. "With them," writes one of our intelligent army correspondents, "time is everything; and with a certain class -- not, I hope, the best or largest -- every hour's delay makes them more and more indifferent as to how the fighting ends, so that it ends. Remove the legal restraint which holds the army together, and half of them would go home to 'see their parents' to-morrow -- the other half would vote to send Commissioners to Richmond, or to welcome propositions from the rebels for winding up the struggle -- rather than drag through another Winter campaign in the swamps of the Chickahominy, or in any other part of Virginia. But give them the word 'Forward,' and with the needful leaders and reinforcements, they will not stop until they have chased the rebels into the Gulf. I mention these things," continues he, "not willingly, but for the purpose of showing the temper of the army, and the absolute necessity of keeping their energies employed and their minds easy." We trust our gallant and splendid army will not be disappointed in its desires and hopes, but that it will at once be allowed to assume the offensive against a foe over whom, when on the offensive, it has always been victorious.

abstract: Samuel B. Haynes, the mate of the slaver Nightingale, was tried once before for his connection with her, but the jury disagreed. abstract: Ames & Barnes vs. Simmons & McKenzie. -- The facts in this case, as claimed by the plaintiffs, are, that in July, 1859, the defendants, wishing to purchase goods of the plaintiffs on a credit of six months, induced them to give such credit, on representations that they had ample means invested in their stationery business in Beckman-street, besides other representations of increase of custom, &c. It is alleged that after this sale, the defendant McKenzie, unknown to the plaintiffs, sold out to his partner Simmons, taking his note on such purchase, and that in January, 1860, Simmons sold out to one Messerole for his note, who closed the store and removed the goods to a basement in Pearl-street, where the plaintiffs attached them in this suit. The evidence of the fraudulent character of this sale to Messerole was conflicting.
lead_paragraph: Ames & Barnes vs. Simmons & McKenzie. -- The facts in this case, as claimed by the plaintiffs, are, that in July, 1859, the defendants, wishing to purchase goods of the plaintiffs on a credit of six months, induced them to give such credit, on representations that they had ample means invested in their stationery business in Beckman-street, besides other representations of increase of custom, &c. It is alleged that after this sale, the defendant McKenzie, unknown to the plaintiffs, sold out to his partner Simmons, taking his note on such purchase, and that in January, 1860, Simmons sold out to one Messerole for his note, who closed the store and removed the goods to a basement in Pearl-street, where the plaintiffs attached them in this suit. The evidence of the fraudulent character of this sale to Messerole was conflicting.

abstract: GENERAL SESSIONS. -- Owing to the trial of Mrs. REAL for murder in the Oyer and Terminer, there was not the usual crowd in attendance in this Court yesterday. A fair amount of business was got through with, however. RICHARD S. DOWNING was tried on an indictment for the killing of his wife ANN DOWNING, on the 24th of August, 1862, and was convicted of manslaughter in the second degree. He was remanded for sentence. JOSEPH MCCARTY pleaded guilty to an indictment for petit larceny, and GEORGE THOMPSON to an attempt at grand larceny from ULYSSES S. COURVOISSIER, No. 71 Nassau-street, of two gold watches valued at $100. Both prisoners were remanded for sentence.
lead_paragraph: GENERAL SESSIONS. -- Owing to the trial of Mrs. REAL for murder in the Oyer and Terminer, there was not the usual crowd in attendance in this Court yesterday. A fair amount of business was got through with, however. RICHARD S. DOWNING was tried on an indictment for the killing of his wife ANN DOWNING, on the 24th of August, 1862, and was convicted of manslaughter in the second degree. He was remanded for sentence. JOSEPH MCCARTY pleaded guilty to an indictment for petit larceny, and GEORGE THOMPSON to an attempt at grand larceny from ULYSSES S. COURVOISSIER, No. 71 Nassau-street, of two gold watches valued at $100. Both prisoners were remanded for sentence.

abstract: The trial of Mrs. Mary Real for the alleged murder of her husband, Peter C. Real, at No. 256 Broadway, on the afternoon of the 13th June last, commenced in the Oyer and Terminer, before Judge BARNARD, yesterday. The circumstances of this homicide are so fresh in the memory of most readers as to require no more detailed recapitulation than may be found in the opening remarks of the District-Attorney, and the testimony which follows.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Mrs. Mary Real for the alleged murder of her husband, Peter C. Real, at No. 256 Broadway, on the afternoon of the 13th June last, commenced in the Oyer and Terminer, before Judge BARNARD, yesterday. The circumstances of this homicide are so fresh in the memory of most readers as to require no more detailed recapitulation than may be found in the opening remarks of the District-Attorney, and the testimony which follows. A large concourse of spectators were in attendance at the opening of the Court, the popular interest in the trial, doubtless, being heightened by the fact, previously announced, that the celebrated English lawyer, Edwin James, Esq., had been engaged for the defence. The District-Attorney, A. Oakey Hall, Esq., appeared for the prosecution, and Mr. James was assisted in the defence by his associate partner, Thos. Dunphy, Esq. Mrs. Real entered the Court-room a few minutes before the opening of the trial, accompanied by three lady friends, all attired in deep mourning. Her friends, with the exception of one lady, who sat with her by the side of her counsel, occupied seats upon the platform, at the right of the Judge's desk. There were several other ladies seated in various parts of the audience, among whom we noticed the popular feuilletonist, Ada Clare, who occupied a chair within the railing. The brother of the deceased, Mr. Real, also occupied a seat within the bar. The appearance and bearing of the prisoner was that of unaffected, not to say shrinking, modesty, and her countenance bore the marks of much and long suffering. She is apparently about 25 years of age, of medium size, with brown hair and dark eyes, and a physiognomy denoting strong affections, and sincerity and earnestness of feeling.

abstract: ANTIETAM IRON WORKS, Md., Monday, Oct. 6, 1862. The rebels made their appearance yesterday, in  small force opposite this place, for the evident purpose of showing themselves. They were mounted, and numbered two hundred or less. As they seemed anxious to attract attention, a sectien of a Parrot battery was brought up, and a few shells were sent after them across the river. Of course, they made tracks.

abstract: The steamship Persia, from Liverpool on the  27th inst., and Queenstown on the 28th, arrived at this port last evening. Her advices are two  days later than those by the Jura, published on Monday. The news of Gen. McCLELLAN'S victory ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Persia, from Liverpool on the 27th inst., and Queenstown on the 28th, arrived at this port last evening. Her advices are two days later than those by the Jura, published on Monday. The news of Gen. MCCLELLAN's victory at Hagerstown Heights, or South Mountain, attracted much attention in Liverpool and London. The rebel policy of invasion is generally condemned. There is no change of consequence to report in the markets. Consols were quoted at 93 1/4@93 3/8 for money. The Paris Moniteur, in view of the discussions which are taking place on the Roman question, publishes a correspondence between the Emperor and M. THOUVENEL, to show what efforts have been made by the Emperor to bring about a reconciliation between the Holy See and Italy. We publish the letter in full elsewhere. The condition of GARIBALDI is reported to be much improved, and there is now no doubt that he will recover. Nothing is yet known as to what disposition will be made of him.

abstract: -- We desire to call attention to an advertisement in another column of a course of lectures upon "Human Mechanism, Physiology and Hygiene," by Dr. JOHN H. GRISCOM, of this City. The high standing of Dr. GRISCOM as a physician and sanitarian, and his familiarity with the subjects treated, will render his course of lectures very valuable to such as choose to attend them, and entirely unlike the quack harangues heretofore palmed off upon the public under the name of "lectures on physiology." The first lecture of the course will be delivered at the Home Chapel, No. 29 East 29th-st., at 11 o'clock to-morrow morning, and will be free.

abstract: foreign excerpts, this morning, will be found a very remarkable document, in the shape of a letter from the Emperor of the French to M. THOUVENEL, concerning the Roman question. It was written as long ago as May last, but has only now been given to the public, when the subject assumes a new and graver interest from the recent movement Of GARIBALDI.
lead_paragraph: foreign excerpts, this morning, will be found a very remarkable document, in the shape of a letter from the Emperor of the French to M. THOUVENEL, concerning the Roman question. It was written as long ago as May last, but has only now been given to the public, when the subject assumes a new and graver interest from the recent movement Of GARIBALDI. The letter, like every literary emanation of NAPOLEON the Third, is full of broad philosophical generalizations, great political liberalism, adroitness, indirection and skill in stating and balancing, without settling, the claims of opposing parties. His policy toward Italy, he avers, has always been the same: "to second the National aspirations, to invite the Pope to become their support rather than their adversary -- in a word, to consecrate the alliance of Religion and Liberty." At the same time the new Kingdom of Italy has enemies, and the Holy See also has enemies; the enemies of the new State are "all men of order;" the enemies of the Pope are "all that is liberal in Europe." It is necessary that the new Kingdom be reconciled with the Pope; and it is the interest of the Holy See that the Pope should be reconciled with Italy. "This double end would be attained by a combination, which, in maintaining the Pope master in his own domain, would lower the barriers which now separate his States from the rest of Italy." And the somewhat indefinite imperial conclusion of the whole matter is that on the one hand the Italians shall engage to recognize the States of the Church; and on the other, that "the Holy Sec. recurring to ancient traditions, should consecrate the privileges of the municipalities and the provinces in such a manner that they should, so to speak, administer their own affairs. Then the power of the Pope, soaring in an elevated sphere above the secondary interests of society, would disengage itself from that responsibility, always heavy, and which a strong Government alone can support."

abstract: Editorial doubts Confederates will again attempt invasion of North this fall; sees them retreating to Richmond for winter
snippet: Editorial doubts Confederates will again attempt invasion of North this fall; sees them retreating to Richmond for winter
lead_paragraph: It is very unlikely that the army of Gen. LEE will again attempt offensive operations, or the invasion of loyal territory, this Fall or Winter. The rebels threw their whole available strength into Maryland, and marched up to the very borders of Pennsylvania; but they were driven from Maryland soil and across the Potomac with great ignominy and loss, and without having achieved a single object of any importance. If ever an army entertained great expectations, or was stirred with glowing hopes, it was the rebel army when it entered Maryland. And if ever glittering prospects were utterly crushed, it was when that army turned its back upon Washington, upon Baltimore; upon Philadelphia, and turned its face toward the dismal deserts of Eastern Virginia. It owned itself disappointed, overmastered, repulsed and discomfited. It acknowledged that the Union army was too strong, its courage too great, and its leaders too skillful, to successfully cope with. It will not be likely to try the same thing over again, as if has already failed under the most favorable auspices and circumstances. It will not again leave Virginia soil to come northward, nor invite a contest on this side of the Potomac with the overwhelming masses that poured out from Washington and down from Pennsylvania to meet it.

abstract: A dispatch from Louisville, dated yesterday forenoon, informed us that reports had reached that city to the effect that heavy skirmishing was going on between the forces of BUELL and BRAGG, some fifteen miles southeast of Bardstown, with every prospect of a general engagement. By a...
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Louisville, dated yesterday forenoon, informed us that reports had reached that city to the effect that heavy skirmishing was going on between the forces of BUELL and BRAGG, some fifteen miles southeast of Bardstown, with every prospect of a general engagement. By a later dispatch we learn that an engagement of considerable magnitude has actually been progressing for the last two days, and will probably be continued to-day, at Perryville. The fighting is said to have been very desperate, and our losses thus far are estimated at two thousand killed and wounded.

abstract: ARREST OF A NOTORIOUS FEMALE THIEF.--Detective FARLEY, of this City, and Officer FROST, of Brooklyn, yesterday arrested a woman named ELLEN WAGNER, upon the charge of robbing the house of Mr. WELLS, No. 115 West Fifteenth-street, of jewelry and silver plate to the amount of several hundreds of dollars. The Police authorities allege that the prisoner ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A NOTORIOUS FEMALE THIEF. -- Detective FARLEY, of this City, and Officer FROST, of Brooklyn, yesterday arrested a woman named ELLEN WAGNER, upon the charge of robbing the house of Mr. WELLS, No. 115 West Fifteenth-street, of jewelry and silver plate to the amount of several hundreds of dollars. The Police authorities allege that the prisoner is, and has been for the last six years, one of the most shrewd and successful domestic thieves who have ever attempted to ply their trade in this City; and, although only about 21 years of age, she is already far advanced in crime, if all the accounts given by the authorities be true. Her general plan has been to obtain situations as nurse, chambermaid, &c., by means of advertising. She always had a large number of certificates of character from the first families in the City, and in this way she could generally secure situations whenever she desired them. Her plan was to stay in a place long enough to learn where the jewelry, plate, &c., were kept, and then, after taking all she could conveniently carry away, she would be found missing some morning when the family came down to breakfast. The Police have been upon her track for the last eighteen months, but not until yesterday were they able to effect her arrest. When she was taken into custody she had just robbed the wife of Lieut.-Col. DAVIS, in Bleecker-street, of $700 worth of jewelry. Col. DAVIS is at present with the Union army, and his lady was under the necessity of appearing at the Police Station yesterday for the purpose of making a complaint against the offender. ELLEN is a woman of good address and quite intelligent; she has consequently been admitted into some of our first families as a companion and an equal. All parties who have suffered through her operations are requested to call at Police Headquarters to-day, and take a look at the prisoner.

abstract: Editorial on Union need for adequate ambulance corps
snippet: Editorial on Union need for adequate ambulance corps
lead_paragraph: We have every reason to expect that the hardest fighting of the war will occur within the ensuing ninety days. We sometimes talk of a million of men in arms, and of the movements of such columns as have never before been seen in hostile array, as though so many complicated masses of inanimate machinery were about to be brought into collision, to settle some mooted question of physical force, merely. How many of us attempt to estimate the amount of human suffering that must ensue? How many realize the fact that in less than ninety days from this time sixty or seventy thousand of our friends and brethren may be stricken down in battle -- thousands to find soldiers' graves, and more, by their wounds and sufferings, to become the objects of an anxiety and solicitude which shall sadden thousands of households. When our relatives are about to go forth to the fight, we are clamorous in our demands that they shall be armed and equipped with all the appliances of sturdy soldiers. Government gathers its stores of food, clothing and ammunition, and distributes them by the usual avenue. Hospitals are erected at points more or less remote from the scenes of probable conflict in obedience to the dictates of sanitary science, and thousands of medical men are drawn from the pursuits of peaceful practice to contribute their skill upon the battle-field.

abstract: The fourth of the new Monitor fleet, the Montauk, the third iron-clad put afloat within six days, was successfully launched yesterday at Greenpoint, from the wharf at the foot of the Continental Iron Works. Extensive notification of the event having been given, a numerous assemblage was present.
lead_paragraph: The fourth of the new Monitor fleet, the Montauk, the third iron-clad put afloat within six days, was successfully launched yesterday at Greenpoint, from the wharf at the foot of the Continental Iron Works. Extensive notification of the event having been given, a numerous assemblage was present. We noticed, among others, Admiral HIRAM PAULDING, Commandant of the Brooklyn Navy-Yard, Commodore GREGORY, superintendent of iron-clads in this vicinity; Chief Engineer STIMERS, Mr. FRANK HALL, of the Commercial Advertiser, and quite a select congregation of New-York and Brooklyn people. Miss GREGORRY, daughter of the distinguished Commodore named, christened the ship, amid deafening cheers.

abstract: CLUB -- A meeting of the Democracy of the Twentieth Ward was held on Wednesday evening at Milliman's Hall, corner of Twenty-sixth-st. and Seventh-av. In consequence of the announcement which had been made that Hon. FERNANDO WOOD would address the meeting, the ball was very respectably filled. Considerable time having elapsed, however, without that gentleman appearing, a very perceptible thinning out of the assemblage took place. The meeting was presided over by P.G. MALONEY, Esq., President of the Twentieth Ward Club, and addresses denunciatory of the Administration were made by Messrs. Henry Radigan, George Peckham, Charles Davies, Edward S. Lawson, and Hon. R.C. Hutchins. Considerable disturbance was made at one time during Mr. HUTCHINGS' speech, and the obnoxious individual, who seemed disposed to controvert some of his assertions, was unceremoniously hustled out. Another individual in the audience created much excitement by his hearty denunciations, ever and anon, of "JEEMS" BUCHANAN, whom he stigmatized as a d -- d traitor, and wanted to be his hangman. He was silenced, however, and the speeches were proceeded with till 10 1/2 o'clock, when the meeting adjourned.

abstract: that there are still great delays and dilatoriness in paying to our troops the pittance they are promised by the Government. It is stated that requisitions to the amount of not less than fifty millions of dollars for their pay lie in the Treasury Department at Washington awaiting action; and that in Virginia, some regiments have not been paid since the 1st of June, while in the West there are regiments which have not received a cent for eight months. This is a grievous mistake on the part of the authorities. It will do more to discourage enlistments than all the substitute agents and traitors that ever were or could be put into Fort Lafayette. The soldier's pay ought to be sure and frequent. He ought to receive it at least once a month, if not once a fortnight, and he ought to receive it unfailingly. Most of the men, and particularly those from the large cities, have, previous to enlisting, been accustomed to obtaining their earnings every week; and the practice of keeping them waiting for months for their pay, and then giving it to them in large sums, does them great injustice and injury in many ways. Families and dependents suffer for want, of it; and when the soldier does get it, the temptations to squander are great. It makes less difference how much pay a soldier gets than that he get it often and certainly. In many of the European armies the soldiers receive less than a fifth of the sum given the American soldier, and there is no thought of complaint; but there is not a sovereign in Europe whose crown would be on his head at the end of eight months if he delayed for that length of time to pay his army. It is no doubt easy for the authorities at Washington to give excuses for not paying the troops promptly, but excuses are not what the men want -- they want their money. Whether the delay is the fault of the Secretary of the Treasury, or the Secretary of War, or their subordinates, or the army Paymasters, makes no difference. Whoever it is, President LINCOLN, who, no doubt in this as in other matters, shoulders the responsibility, should hold them to a rigid account, and should see that the soldiers are promptly paid, whoever else connected with the Government may have to go without their salaries.

abstract: The trial of Mrs. MARY REAL, for the murder of PETER C. REAL, was continued in the Oyer and Terminer yesterday before Judge BARNARD. Several witnesses were examined on the part of the defence to prove the disordered condition or the prisoner's mind after her marriage with Mr. REAL, confirmatory of the theory of insanity set up in her behalf. The Court adjourned at 2 P.M. till Monday morning next, at 11 o'clock.

lead_paragraph: They have been very slow in coming to the apprehension of this important reality, nor will it surprise us that such should have been the case, when we consider how obstinately certain men and certain parties in this country have clung to the delusion that the pending issues might be solved by other means than by the sword. At last, however, and at a most important moment for the interests of America, the few men in Europe who take the pains to study the problems of our position before offering to solve them, seem to have awakened to the real state of the case. We have yet to learn the effect produced in Paris by the intelligence of the victory of ANTIETAM, but we may safely infer from the tone of the best English criticism upon that intelligence, that in France as well as in England, the view which was taken in the TIMES of the bearings and importance of that victory will be substantially adopted.

abstract: We have startling news from Pennsylvania this morning. The rebels, notwithstanding their late expulsion from Maryland, and the consequent belief that an invasion of Pennsylvania was no longer to be feared, are actually now in that State, and have possession of Mercersburgh and Chambersburgh! Gov. CURTIN, last evening ...
lead_paragraph: We have startling news from Pennsylvania this morning. The rebels, notwithstanding their late expulsion from Maryland, and the consequent belief that an invasion of Pennsylvania was no longer to be feared, are actually now in that State, and have possession of Mercersburgh and Chambersburgh! Gov. CURTIN, last evening about 7 1/2 o'clock, received a dispatch from Chambersburgh informing him that Mercersburgh, was occupied by STEWART's rebel cavalry during the day, and that they were advancing or Chambersburgh. Subsequently he received information that a flag-of-truce party entered the latter town about 8 o'clock, and demanded to see the principal men, while the main rebel force, supposed to be three thousand strong, was about a mile distant, and expected to enter the town immediately. A deputation proceeded to meet the rebel commander, and it was supposed that the town would be surrendered at once, as there was no force there to resist. The deposits of the Chambersburgh Bank are at present in New-York, where they have been since the threatened invasion nearly a month ago. The rebels are said to have crossed the Potomac at Hancock, and crossed the country to Pittsburgh pike. Our latest dispatches from Harrisburgh state that Gov. GURTIN is pushing troops up the Cumberland Valley to meet this new danger.

abstract: The trial of this case was resumed yesterday at 11 o'clock. The attendance of spectators was larger than on either of the two previous days, and among them were many ladies. Indeed, all of the witnesses called by the defence thus far, have been ladies with whom Mrs. Real lived either before or after her marriage, and the testimony has been mainly as to the condition of her mind prior and subsequent to that event.
lead_paragraph: The trial of this case was resumed yesterday at 11 o'clock. The attendance of spectators was larger than on either of the two previous days, and among them were many ladies. Indeed, all of the witnesses called by the defence thus far, have been ladies with whom Mrs. Real lived either before or after her marriage, and the testimony has been mainly as to the condition of her mind prior and subsequent to that event. Several of the lady friends of Mrs. Real occupied seats by her side. There are said to be a large number of witnesses subpoened for the defence, and the trial probably will not be concluded before the middle of next week. Mrs. Real's health has not been so good for the past few days, owing partly to the intense heat, and the natural excitement of her position. The mockish sympathy which is often engendered by such cases seems not to have attached itself here, while in its place is a strong and normal upholding of a wife in trouble by an audience of more than ordinary respectability and intelligence.

abstract: Some time ago, says the Wheeling Intelligencer, Gen. Kelley and Staff were passing through a village up in the mountains, in pursuit of the rebels, when they stopped at a house to get something to eat.
lead_paragraph: Some time ago, says the Wheeling Intelligencer, Gen. Kelley and Staff were passing through a village up in the mountains, in pursuit of the rebels, when they stopped at a house to get something to eat. As the party was quite large, and as the General was in something of a hurry, his negro servant, Wilson, together with the servant of Capt. Geo. W. Harrison, called Granville, were sent into the kitchen to help the women of the house prepare the meal. It was not long before an abundant repast was placed upon the table and all of the officers, including the General himself, helped themselves heartily. After the meal was thus discussed the General walked out to the front part of the house and observing Wilson and Granvillle, told them to go back in the kitchen and get something to eat. The boys hesitated and made no reply, when the General assured them that if they were hungry there was no objection to their eating as much as they wanted. The boys then thanked him and said they had something in the wagon. An hour or so after the party got under way the General observed the two negro boys knawing ravenously at some hard crackers and flitch in the wagon. "Wilson," said the General, in a somewhat angry tone, "why didn't you and Granville get your dinners back at B.?" Well, to tell do God's trufe, General, it was too -- dirty." In consideration of the fact that Wilson had assisted to prepare the meal, he was not even reprimanded for his profanity.

abstract: The Republican primary meetings for the purpose of electing delegates to the Congressional, City, County and Assembly Conventions, were held in the several Wards of Brooklyn last night, and passed off in an orderly manner, with the exception of the Fifth Ward, where there was some disturbance, and a few ...
lead_paragraph: The Republican primary meetings for the purpose of electing delegates to the Congressional, City, County and Assembly Conventions, were held in the several Wards of Brooklyn last night, and passed off in an orderly manner, with the exception of the Fifth Ward, where there was some disturbance, and a few persons were rather roughly handled. The Second Congressional District Convention will meet at No. 9 Court-street, on the 14th inst., at 3 P.M. The Third District Convention at the same place, at 8 P.M. The County Convention will meet at the same place, on the 13th inst., at 3 P.M. The City Convention at the same place, at 8 P.M., and the Assembly Conventions at the different places designate in the call of the General Committee.

abstract: The United States iron-clad frigate Roanoke, one of the two frigates of that class in the navy, is now nearly ready for active service, and will probably be reported ready for her officers and men before the 10th of November. She is at present lying near the wharf of the Novelty Works, up town, and is covered from stem to stern with an iron armor, put on in the best manner. She will be the most formidable of all our master vessels, except perhaps the Puritan, Dictator and Dunderberg, (the latter is Mr. WEBB's ram,) and can bring a force against an opposing craft equal to that of two or three "Monitors." The floor is now being laid, and will soon be completed. Mr. EVERETT is superintending the Government work at the Novelty Works, and is of opinion that the Roanoke will be one of the most useful ships afloat.
lead_paragraph: The United States iron-clad frigate Roanoke, one of the two frigates of that class in the navy, is now nearly ready for active service, and will probably be reported ready for her officers and men before the 10th of November. abstract: Editorial urges women make warm clothes for soldiers
snippet: Editorial urges women make warm clothes for soldiers
lead_paragraph: -- The women of the United States have done nobly since the war opened, in working for the soldiers. They began by making havelocks, scraping lint, putting up delicacies and comforts for the sick and the well: they have volunteered for nurses, and for hospital service, and in every way conceivable they have served those who were suffering for their country. This work is still actively kept up all over the land; and to each appeal of the army medical authorities, or the Sanitary Commission for aid of any kind, a prompt response has always been made. Cold weather is now coming on in Virginia as well as here; and the Sanitary Commission makes a request that the energies of the patriotic ladies of the land be now turned to the knitting of socks and the making of underclothes for the soldiers. Of lint there is enormous quantities on hand, and havelocks have long been discarded. Warm socks, warm undershirts, and warm drawers, are the things that are now wanted. Let every fine lady, young and old, let every mother who has a son, every sister who has a brother, every maiden who has, or expects to have a beau in the army, let every woman in the country and in the city, who has days or hours or minutes to spare, and who loves her country, devote their spare time to this patriotic work. Our army is now somewhere between a half a million and a million strong; and every soldier in it should have at least two pairs of warm woolen socks. This, as will be seen, will require close on two million pairs --which is sufficient to keep active all the knitting needles in the country for a long time. Every man should have a couple of woolen undershirts, and a couple of pairs of drawers. A million of each of these articles are needed. Government will of course do what it can; but, if the soldiers have to depend entirely upon the Government, many of them will have to go without socks, or with poor cotton trash and hundreds of thousands of them will shiver all winter without underclothes. Ladies, women all knit and sew -- and great will be your reward. Chill November and freezing December are almost upon us.
headline: {'main': 'PATRIOTIC WORK FOR WOMEN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'PATRIOTIC WORK FOR WOMEN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

He said he would not criticise the acts of his superiors in the Government. The sentiment was a praise worthy one. But the remark was a significant cue; and it is in relation to its significance that comment is chiefly made.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, to appoint Inspectors of Registry. President PURDY was in the chair. The lobby was thronged with expectants for the appointments.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, to appoint Inspectors of Registry. President PURDY was in the chair. The lobby was thronged with expectants for the appointments. On proceeding to business the Board found that the Republicans had arranged their lists of nominees, and they were printed complete, but the Democrats had reported but very few of theirs. The division of the appointments was arranged the same as it had been in previous years -- two Republicans and one Democrat in one district, and a reversal of the order in the next district. As the Boards of Registry are to meet, by law, on next Tuesday, the appointments, it was concluded, could no longer be deferred. It was therefore decided to go on and make them, the Democrats to verbally announce their candidates as the vote proceeded.

abstract: Last Sunday, Bishops HOPKINS, McCOSKRY, WHITELEY and BURGESS, and Rev. Dr. CRAIK, all members of the Triennial Convention now sitting in this City, preached in our local churches, and their discourses were printed in the TIMES of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, Bishops HOPKINS, McCOSKRY, WHITELEY and BURGESS, and Rev. Dr. CRAIK, all members of the Triennial Convention now sitting in this City, preached in our local churches, and their discourses were printed in the TIMES of Monday. To-day, Bishop CLARKE, of Rhode Island, one of the most gifted sons of the Church, a man full of generous impulse and a devoted servant of his Master, will preach in the Church of the Ascension, at 10 1/2 o'clock A.M.; Bishop BURGESS will preach in the same place, at 4 P.M.; Bishop LEE, of Iowa, in St. Mark's Church, at 10 1/2 A.M.; Bishop UPFOLD, of Indiana, in Trinity Church, at 10 1/2 A.M.; and Bishop KEMPER, of Wisconsin, at St. Paul's, at 10 1/2 A.M. In the evening, at 7 1/2 , in Trinity Chapel, a meeting of the Sunday-School Union will be held, at which the above-named gentlemen and others are expected to speak.

lead_paragraph: The address that BRAXTON BRAGG published at Bardstown, Ky., on the 26th of last month, exposes in a remarkable manner the gross illusions of the Southern mind. The document is almost melancholy in its effect, even upon a loyal mind, presenting, as it does, in such close contrast, the vaunting policy and hope of the Confederate leaders with their utter and ignominious failure.

abstract: Editorial on European reactions to inventions shown at 1862 World's Fair, London
snippet: Editorial on European reactions to inventions shown at 1862 World's Fair, London
lead_paragraph: The hostility of the British Government to the development of domestic manufactures in the American Colonies, while they were yet British provinces, was manifested emphatically enough in the declared intention that "not so much as a wrought nail should be made in America." The world has moved since then. Notwithstanding all the wealth and power of the self-claimed mistress of nations, the once feeble and dependent Colonies have become a mighty nation; and the industry so contemned at the start is so potent now that Britain takes lessons from its triumphs.

abstract: Editorial lauds advances of Union forces in Southwest
snippet: Editorial lauds advances of Union forces in Southwest
lead_paragraph: Our armies in the Southwestern States have fairly begun work, after the long rest they have had during the Summer. The gallant and successful operations of Gen. ROSECRANS in Northern Mississippi, the march of Gen. BUELL northward to Louisville, and from thence southward in chase of the rebels, and his victory over them, -- the advance of Gen. SCHOFIELD into Southwestern Missouri, and his scattering of the rebels who had penetrated that State, -- these things show that the main columns of our army in the Southwest have all entered upon their work for the cool and cold weather. It is a very powerful army that we have in that section of the Republic. The forces under the commanders we have named -- those of BUELL, GRANT (including ROSECRANS), and SCHOFIELD -- actively engaged in service, number about a hundred and fifty thousand men; while, if we add the troops doing garrison and other duties at various points in the same great field of operations, we shall find that the Western army, with the new recruits it has lately received, will sum up its numbers to near two hundred thousand effectives.
headline: {'main': 'The Onward Movement in the Southwest.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Onward Movement in the Southwest.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We receive assurances from Washington that the rebel raid into Pennsylvania is not considered important there; that the disposition of the Na- tional forces will compel a hasty retreat of the enemy, and that their movements must be rapid to escape capture.
lead_paragraph: We receive assurances from Washington that the rebel raid into Pennsylvania is not considered important there; that the disposition of the Na- tional forces will compel a hasty retreat of the enemy, and that their movements must be rapid to escape capture. Gen. MCCLELLAN telegraphed to the War Department yesterday that not one of the rebels in Pennsylvania should return into Virginia. It is to be hoped that this promise will be fulfilled. Meantime we give elsewhere such facts relating to the movements of the rebel force as have reached us by telegraph. Yesterday morning they destroyed a large amount of property at Chambersburgh, including the machine shops railway and rolling stock of the Cumberland Valley Railroad Company at that place, and burned the railroad bridge at Scotland, five miles to the eastward. They also seized about five hundred horses, and a large amount of Government clothing -- exchanging the latter at once for their own dilapidated garments. At about 10 o'clock in the morning a portion of the force moved in the direction of Gettysburgh, with the intention, no doubt, of destroying a bridge at that place to prevent the approach of troops. The rebels, it now appears, crossed the Potomac near Clear Spring, early on Friday morning, and entered Pennsylvania by Blair's Valley. How they propose to get back again does not clearly appear, and Gen. MCCLELLAN's promise that they shall not escape is likely to be made good. From Frederick, Md., we learn that a prominent army officer made a locomotive reconnoissance in the direction of Chambersburgh yesterday morning, and discovered the fires set by the rebels, but no other signs of their presence. A considerable force of National cavalry and artillery passed through Hagerstown yesterday in quest of the rebels, and Gen. FRANKLIN was there.

abstract: There have been those at the North who have for a long time back declared, not only that Slavery was a "relic of barbarism," but that the practice of it had barbarized the entire South. The main body of our people had not accepted these statements as actual facts,...
lead_paragraph: There have been those at the North who have for a long time back declared, not only that Slavery was a "relic of barbarism," but that the practice of it had barbarized the entire South. The main body of our people had not accepted these statements as actual facts, and it was with a thrill of horror that the people of the North awoke to the knowledge that they were fighting a barbarous enemy; atrocity followed upon atrocity so fast, however that the fact could not be questioned. The rebels and their sympathizers threw railroad trains, carrying unsuspecting and peaceful citizens, into abysses prepared for them; they fired upon hospitals; they cut the throats of wounded men; they made rings out of the bones and drinking cups out of the skulls of our fallen heroes. And we have become somewhat accustomed to these practices of theirs, so that when we have heard of their murdering of wounded men in cold blood as Gen. MCCOOK was murdered, of the carrying off into Slavery negroes who had come within their lines under the protection of a flag of truce, as they did on the field of Manassas, of their refusing to give quarter to our soldiers who had surrendered, as that Louisiana regiment did to the two hundred Massachusetts boys during the fights before Richmond, or of their starving and maltreating our wounded who have fallen into their hands, or driving away with bayonets women who offered them water or food, as they did in the streets of Richmond, we say it is like them, and though our blood may boil when we hear of them, it hardly stirs when we hear a man talk of the wretches who committed them as "our deluded brethren," and urge such a course of political action as shall do most to encourage and cheer them.

abstract: CONWAY OF THE IRISH BRIGADE. -- To-day, at 1 1/2 o'clock, from No. 596 Broadway, the head recruiting office of the Irish Brigade, the remains of these two gallant soldiers, who fell fighting at the Battle of Antietam, will be borne to Calvary Cemetery. During last evening,and throughout the night, the bodies, encased in handsome metallic cofflins, and watched over by a guard of honor, were visited by hundreds of sympathizing admirers and sorrowing friends, from the lips of whom, as well as from the wounded men and officers, who also were among the crowd, one could hear but eulogies of the deceased.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Hibernian passed Cape Race on Friday evening, with advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 2d, and Londonderry on the 3d inst. Full accounts of the National victories in Maryland had been received in England, and the journals, in commenting upon them, paid high compliments to Gen. MCCLELLAN for his vigor and energy in defeating the rebels. The U.S. steam-frigate St. Louis had left Lisbon, supposed in search of the rebel steamer Alabama, or "290," before reported to be destroying American whaling vessels off the Azores. The Liverpool Cotton market was firmer, with an advance on American varieties. Breadstuffs were quiet and steady, and Provisions dull. Consols, 93 3/4@93 7/8 for Money.

abstract: The steamer Iberville, Captain ELFERT, arrived this morning from Iberville, reports that on Saturday last, about 2 P.M., was fired into from Mrs. VAUGHN's, plantation, about three miles below Bayou Goula, from a battery of four brass rifled 6-pound cannon. Forty or fifty shots were fired, ten of which took effect -- six passing through the upper cabin, and four between decks -- killing the watchman, a horse, also taking off the arm of the second steward. One ball fell in the ladies' cabin, smashing a marble slab table, and also doing slight damage to the steam drum and breaking the pump-rod on the doctor.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Iberville, Captain ELFERT, arrived this morning from Iberville, reports that on Saturday last, about 2 P.M., was fired into from Mrs. VAUGHN's, plantation, about three miles below Bayou Goula, from a battery of four brass rifled 6-pound cannon. Forty or fifty shots were fired, ten of which took effect -- six passing through the upper cabin, and four between decks -- killing the watchman, a horse, also taking off the arm of the second steward. One ball fell in the ladies' cabin, smashing a marble slab table, and also doing slight damage to the steam drum and breaking the pump-rod on the doctor.

abstract: FIFTH CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT REPUBLICAN CONVENTION. The delegates to the Fifth Congres-  sional District Republican Union Convention, comprising Hudson County and the City of Newark, met yesterday afternoon, at Commerical Hall, in Jersey City, for the purpose of nominating a canditate for Congress from that District.
lead_paragraph: FIFTH CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT REPUBLICAN CONVENTION. -- The delegates to the Fifth Congres- sional District Republican Union Convention, comprising Hudson County and the City of Newark, met yesterday afternoon, at Commerical Hall, in Jersey City, for the purpose of nominating a canditate for Congress from that District. Nearly all of the delegates were present. The meeting was organized by the election of ISAAC W. SCUDDER, Esq., of Hudson County, as Chairman, and O.B. WOODRUTH, of Newark, as Secretary. After appointing committees on resolutions and rules, the Convention took a recess, in order that the delegates from Hudson County could hold a conference.

abstract: THE BODY OF CAPT. SHANLEY The body of Capt. T.L. SHANLEY, of Company D, Sixty-ninth Regiment N.Y.V., will arrive here this morning.
lead_paragraph: THE BODY OF CAPT. SHANLEY. -- The body of Capt. T.L. SHANLEY, of Company D, Sixty-ninth Regiment N.Y.V., will arrive here this morning. Capt. SHANLEY served in the war from its commencement, and took part in eighteen engagements. He was with MULLIGAN in the famous fight at Lexington. At the battle of Malvern Hill he was wounded, and at Antietam met his death. He was shot by a rebel sharpshooter while in the act of rallying his men. The color-bearer of the company had been shot -- snatching the colors, the Captain was waving them aloft and calling on his men to follow him, when a bullet entered his breast. Capt. SHANLEY was an old member of Engine Company No. 40, of this City. The funeral will take place, to-day, from the house No. 132 Mulberry-street, at 2 P.M.

abstract: V Hugo toasts press of all lands, speech at Brussels banquet; He toasts press of all lands in speech at banguet, Brussels
snippet: V Hugo toasts press of all lands, speech at Brussels banquet; He toasts press of all lands in speech at banguet, Brussels
lead_paragraph: In reply to a personal toast, VICTOR HUGO, desiring, as he said, to embrace all his friends in one comprehensive speech of thanks, offered this sentiment: "To the Press in Every Land! -- To the free Press! -- to the Press powerful, fruitful and glorious!" "Gentlemen," he continued, dwelling upon the thought thus evoked, "the Press is the daylight of the world, and in all daylight there is something divine. Thought is more than a right -- it is the very breath of man. Whoever fetters thought attacks man himself. To speak, to write, to publish, are things, so far as the right is concerned, absolutely identical. They are the ever-enlarging circles of intelligence in action; they are the sonorous waves of thought. Of all these circles -- all these radiances of the human mind -- the vastest is the Press. The diameter of the Press is the diameter of civilization. Every diminution of the liberty of the Press is followed by a diminution of civilization. Wherever we see the freedom of the Press interfered with, there we see the nutrition of the human family interrupted. Gentlemen, the mission of our days is to change the bases of society, to create a real order, and to substitute everywhere truths for fictions. In this displacement of social foundations, which is the colossal labor of an age; nothing resists the power of the Press, applying its tractile force to Catholicism, to soldierism, to absolution to the most refractory blocks of facts and of ideas. * * * * * * The Press is the living clarion -- it sounds the reveille of the races, it announces aloud the dawn of right, it divines the coming day and rouses the world. Yet sometimes, strange spectacle! we see the Press itself receive a warning. This spectacle reminds one of the owl silencing the cry of the cock.

abstract: Editorial on campaign issues made more momentous by war
snippet: Editorial on campaign issues made more momentous by war
lead_paragraph: The steamship Hibernian passed Cape Race on Friday evening, with advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 2d, and Londonderry on the 3d inst. Full accounts of the National victories in Maryland had been received in England, and the journals, in commenting upon them, paid high compliments to Gen. McCLELLAN for his vigor and energy in defeating the rebels. The Times, however, insists that the cause of the North is not advanced one step by its "unexpected victory." The Paris correspondent of that paper states that a report is current in political circles that the British Government is no longer so entirely averse to the recognition of the Southern Confederacy, as it has heretofore been, and that there is a probability of the question soon becoming the subject of deliberation in Ministerial councils. Eminent men, of almost every European nation, assembled at the Social Science Convention at Brussels, are said to have signed an address to President LINCOLN in favor of a truce preliminary to negotiations for peace. The U.S. steam frigate St. Louis had left Lisbon, supposed in search of the rebel steamer Alabama, or "290," before reported to be destroying American whaling vessels off the Azores. The reports of her depredations are fully confirmed by an arrival in England. It was fully expected in Paris that by the 1st of November the French army would be in possession of the City of Mexico. The latest accounts of GARIBALDI's health are said to be satisfactory. Rumors were again current of an amnesty in his case. The Liverpool Cotton market was firmer, with an advance on American varieties. Breadstuffs were quiet and steady, and Provisions dull. Consols, 93 3/4@93 7/8 for Money.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington; editorial on battle
snippet: Dispatches from Washington; editorial on battle
lead_paragraph: We give elsewhere today such facts relating to the movements of STUART'S cavalry as have reached us by telegraph. On Saturday morning they destroyed a large amount of property at Chambersburgh, including the machine shops, railway and rolling stock of the Cumberland Valley Railroad Company at that place, and burned the railroad bridge at Scotland, five miles to the eastward. They also seized about five hundred horses, and a large amount of Government clothing -- exchanging the latter at once for their own dilapidated garments. At about 10 o'clock in the morning a portion of the force moved in the direction of Gettysburgh, with the intention, as was thought, of destroying a bridge at that place to prevent the approach of troops. They did not go to Gettysburgh, however, but when within three miles of that place turned to recross the South Mountain, striking the Cumberland Valley at Waynesboro, and proceeding toward the Potomac at Edwards' Ferry. They stopped at Monrovia, on the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, tearing up a small portion of the road to prevent the passage of troops. They then proceeded to Urbanna, through which place they passed, encumbered with, about a thousand horses, which they had captured during their progress, together with unknown quantities of boots, shoes and other necessary articles. They were soon followed through Urbanna by a large force of our cavalry, and afterwards heavy firing was heard on the line of rebel retreat, in the direction of Point of Rocks, indicating some opposition to the progress of the mauraders. Our latest dispatches, however, lead to the belief that almost the entire force escaped across the Potomac with their booty.

abstract: To-night at Cooper Institute there will be a grand mass meeting. It is called for several purposes. The ostensible ones are the ratification of the Democratic nominations, the rebuke of the Administration, and the glorification of sundry and divers aspiring politicians who hope to ride into place upon the current of popular uproar and disquiet. The Hon. HORATIO SEYMOUR will, it is said, positives address the meeting, as will also the Hon. FERNANDO WOOD. Minor lights are advertised by the score.

abstract: THE RAILROAD FARE QUESTION. The Joint Committee of the Board of Aldermen held a meeting on Saturday afternoon, for the purpose of receiving the statements of the Presidents of the Brooklyn City Railroad Companies in regard to the recent increase in the price of tickets.
lead_paragraph: THE RAILROAD FARE QUESTION. -- The Joint Committee of the Board of Aldermen held a meeting on Saturday afternoon, for the purpose of receiving the statements of the Presidents of the Brooklyn City Railroad Companies in regard to the recent increase in the price of tickets. Mr. PIERSON, President of the City Company, in the course of his remarks, justified the course the companies had pursued, and showed by an agreement entered into between the city and the Central Companies that they were authorized to charge five cents fare. He stated that the roads supported 2,500 persons, which he thought entitled the companies to some consideration. The Committees having the matter in charge will probably make their report to the Common Council to-night, when the matter will be ventilated.

abstract: editorial lauds Rosecrans for winning this battle
snippet: editorial lauds Rosecrans for winning this battle
lead_paragraph: -- Our late victory near Corinth, Mississippi, under Gen. ROSECRANS, appears to have been the most decisive, although not the greatest battle of the war. The enemy, indeed, seems to have suffered a complete rout. Gen. ROSECRANS, whose modest and soldierly dispatches have from time to time excited general admiration, reports that PRICE and VAN DORN's army is dispersed, demoralized, and incapable of further mischief. He had captured two thousand prisoners, including a hundred officers, and quantities of artillery, small arms, and ammunition. He desired to follow up the rebels to their utter destruction, and thus finish up work in that section, but Gen. GRANT strangely recalled him from pursuit, on the 9th inst.

abstract: An inside view of the rebellion is not so common with us as to warrant our turning and whistling to the wall when one is presented. BARNES  BURR have just published a little book entitled Thirteen Months in the Rebel Army, in whose behalf we challenge the attention of the public.
lead_paragraph: -- An inside view of the rebellion is not so common with us as to warrant our turning and whistling to the wall when one is presented. BARNES & BURR have just published a little book entitled Thirteen Months in the Rebel Army, in whose behalf we challenge the attention of the public. It is written by an impressed New-Yorker. Perhaps we should have said impressed volunteer, since the author volunteered in the rebel army owing to an intimation that he would be put in a way for joining the army of saints and martyrs if he did not. He is very modest and unpretending indeed, only making a 16-mo. book of some two hundred pages, when a man more given to words, -- more versed in the art of book-making, perhaps, -- would have furnished us a quarto. He tells in a straightforward way what he saw, what he personally experienced, not stopping to curse the rebels nor to weary the reader with any of the milder forms of invective that with the multitude go to prove a man's loyalty.

abstract: The expe-  rience of VICTOR HUGO justifies a new beatitude: "Blessed are the miserable, for they shall bring a man to a banquet." The tendency of our modern civilization to "resume" all its triumphs, as the French have it, in a dinner-party, is very remarkable. It is a tradition of the old regime; perhaps, as well as a tendency of the new, but it exists, and has become a part of history.
lead_paragraph: -- The experience of VICTOR HUGO justifies a new beatitude: "Blessed are the miserable, for they shall bring a man to a banquet." The tendency of our modern civilization to "resume" all its triumphs, as the French have it, in a dinner-party, is very remarkable. It is a tradition of the old regime; perhaps, as well as a tendency of the new, but it exists, and has become a part of history. At Versames and St. James in the olden day, to see the King eat his dinner, was a high and holy thing. In Paris, in London, in New-York/to-day, to see the latest hero of the hour perform the same necessary exercise, is a joy and a privilege coveted of all men.

abstract: Mr. FORREST, on Friday, made his first appearance, during his present engagement at NIBLO'S, as Richard the Third. The character is one in which he has always been severely criticised; yet there is no character he plays that he has tried more conscientiously to elevate from melo-dramatic energy to something like intellectual refinement.
lead_paragraph: Mr. FORREST, on Friday, made his first appearance, during his present engagement at NIBLO'S, as Richard the Third. The character is one in which he has always been severely criticised; yet there is no character he plays that he has tried more conscientiously to elevate from melo-dramatic energy to something like intellectual refinement. He has always taken a more philosophic view of the part than usual with tragic actors, making Richard politic and unscrupulous, rather than boisterous and cruel. He does not make Richard kill King Henry, and the infant princes out of sheer sanguinary malice, as very often apparently done; but he puts those victims out of the way because they are obstacles in his path to power. In short, he kills them from a self-imposed necessity, and not out of diabolical pastime. In his love making to the Lady Anne he also present a greatly improved version of that tender passage in the tyrant's turbulent career. It might be supposed that he really had such a passion for the lady as any man of ardent impulses could feel toward a woman whom he desired to marry; whereas the impression generally conveyed by other actors is that of an ogre, seeking to fascinate the unfortunate young woman for the sake of ultimately smothering or otherwise feloniously disposing of her. Mr. FORREST falls into the common mistake of too visibly betraying his agitation to his subordinates in the tent scene, but perhaps the situation would be less effective if it were rendered with more quiet naturalness. The last act Mr. FORREST plays with wonderful vigor, and with less tendency toward rant than even the language which he has to use would seem to warrant. "Richard the Third" will be repeated this evening. To-morrow Mr. HACKETT appears in his two famous parts of Rip Van Winkle, and O'Callaghan, in "His Last Legs."

abstract: MASSACRES. The recent massacres of white settlers in Southern Minnesota by the Sioux savages, have resulted in great distress and want among the survivors in that region. Many of those who escaped the tomahawk of the red men had their houses burnt down, their crops destroyed, and lost everything they had.
lead_paragraph: MASSACRES. -- The recent massacres of white settlers in Southern Minnesota by the Sioux savages, have resulted in great distress and want among the survivors in that region. Many of those who escaped the tomahawk of the red men had their houses burnt down, their crops destroyed, and lost everything they had. Fathers were slain, and their families are now, at the beginning of Winter, thrown upon charity. Hundreds of people in the vicinity of the massacres, fled to St. Peter and other towns, and are now dependent upon their fellow-citizens. Many women and children, left without means of support, and who have lost those who had always earned them a livelihood, will have to be helped to food and shelter during the Winter.

abstract: Maj.-Gen. Pope:  Yesterday I came to this point with my command, having been met by several half-breeds with a flag of truce. I encamped within five hundred yards of a large camp of about one hundred and fifty lodges of friendly Indians and half-breeds, who had separated themselves from Little Crow and the miserable crew with him, and had secured from them most of the white captives, awaiting my arrival.

abstract: The Louisville papers favor us with the information that "Nashville is completely surrounded by the rebels." This is undoubtedly true, and it has been thus surrounded since the day when secession became an accomplished fact in Tennessee. But if it be meant that Nashville is in a state of siege and likely to be captured by an organized rebel army now before it, we beg leave to dissent. The truth is, no doubt, that nine-tenths of all the people in the country surrounding Nashville are hostile to the Government. It is hard to find a Unionist outside of the city corporation. The withdrawal of BUELL's army from Middle Tennessee has emboldened the rebels. They are told by telegraph from Richmond that LEE is in Baltimore, and BRAGG in Louisville. They throw away all fear, therefore, and come up to the very gates of Nashville, pursuing forage trains and shooting Union soldiers. Nashville is besieged in one sense by a hostile country population, and its communications in every direction interrupted by active and desperate guerrillas.

abstract: -- By our latest advices from England, we learn that the London Press had got the details of the news of the rebel defeat and retreat from Maryland. They discuss the movements, as will be seen by the telegraphic abstracts given this morning, with varied intelligence and spirit. The fact of a substantial Union victory seems to be admitted on nearly all hands. The Times, of course, does not directly admit it, though it incidentally allows us a victory; but, as it cannot possibly claim a Confederate triumph at Antietam, it states the battle and its result in this oddly indefinite way: "The Confederate army measured its strength with the army under Gen. MCCLELLAN, and the former did not succeed in beating the latter." A great point, however, is made in our favor by the same journal when it admits that the contending armies have now, by this battle, been brought to an equality. We have been so long spoken of as hopelessly inferior to the rebels, and their continual and inevitable success in every engagement and movement has been so much harped upon, that it is comfortable to learn that it is now admitted that Antietam has brought us up at least to an equality with them. We have no doubt that, when Gen. MCCLELLAN shall make another movement as bold and rapid as the London Press admit his movement against LEE was, our army will demonstrate, to British satisfaction, that it is not only equal, but superior, to the rebels.
lead_paragraph: -- By our latest advices from England, we learn that the London Press had got the details of the news of the rebel defeat and retreat from Maryland. abstract: A dash  ing raid always excites applause, but it does not always prove the safest and most useful essay in war. The Virginia STUART made a dash around Gen. McCLELLAN'S army, between the Chickahominy and the White House. He also made an incursion into Gen. POPE'S lines, and secured the portfolio and other appurtenances of the General's headquarters.
lead_paragraph: -- A dashing raid always excites applause, but it does not always prove the safest and most useful essay in war. The Virginia STUART made a dash around Gen. McCLELLAN'S army, between the Chickahominy and the White House. He also made an incursion into Gen. POPE'S lines, and secured the portfolio and other appurtenances of the General's headquarters. In these cases the enterprise of the cavalry scout was successful, for the points invaded were left uncovered, because neither MCCLELLAN nor POPE thought so desperate a hazard would be made.

abstract: The Church of the Puritans was filled last evening, the very aisles being crowded, by a most intelligent audience, who were anxious to hear Rev. Dr. CHEEVER on his "Analysis of the Proclamation of Emancipation, and the way to make the most of it for God and Justice." Dr. CHEEVER selected as his text the 22d verse of the 15th chapter of I...
lead_paragraph: The Church of the Puritans was filled last evening, the very aisles being crowded, by a most intelligent audience, who were anxious to hear Rev. Dr. CHEEVER on his "Analysis of the Proclamation of Emancipation, and the way to make the most of it for God and Justice." Dr. CHEEVER selected as his text the 22d verse of the 15th chapter of I Samuel, and drew a parallel between the act of our President and the manner in which Saul acted when ordered by God to utterly destroy the Amelekites, and for refusing to fulfill the command to the letter he was told by the prophet Samuel that the Lord had decreed he should no longer reign over Israel. Coming to the Proclamation, he said it would be indeed glorious had it said that the slaves of those in rebellion "are now and forever declared free." He then took up the second part of the Proclamation, which, he said, was a relief from the penalties pronounced in the first part, if that be intended as a threat, and a hindrance to the first, if it be intended as a measure of right and justice.

abstract: our eminent fellow-townsman, Mr. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, before the Episcopal Convention now in session here, has been grossly misrepresented. He has been accused of sympathy with the rebellion, of denouncing the present struggle of the Government as a "wicked and unholy war," and of acting in the Convention in accordance with these sentiments and opinions. Of course no one who knew anything of Mr. RUGGLES' course in regard to the war, or of his strong and oft-expressed feelings in relation thereto, gave any heed to these absurd misrepresentations. Nevertheless, they were made and reiterated. Mr. RUGGLES took occasion, in a clear and able speech in the Convention on Saturday last, to define his true position, and to state what he conceives the wisest course for the Church in its action bearing upon the national crisis. He protests against the misrepresentations of his position, declares with emphasis that he justifies the war, and of our National Union he says in eloquent language:

abstract: -- It appears now, definitely, from the captured papers of BEAUREGARD, that the programme laid down for Gen. BRAGG was really nothing less than the capture of Louisville and Cincinnati, and carrying the war into the Northwest. BEAUREGARD even goes so far as to give BRAGG minute directions how to proceed, and points out the works that it will be necessary to construct at Louisville and Cincinnati, to hold those cities after their capture. But BRAGG has failed -- failed wofully. And now his chances of getting into Cincinnati are as dismal as were Adam's chances of getting into Paradise after it was guarded by the flaming sword.

abstract: It is announced that Gen. MCCLELLAN has taken his family to Harper's Ferry; and the inference has been drawn that he intends to make that place his headquarters for some time to come. We do not think the fact warrants the deductions drawn from it. If his family were to remain at Harper's Ferry, it might indicate a purpose on his part to remain there also. But a mere visit to the General's headquarters would have no such, significance. Indeed, it might mean exactly the opposite, and be a symptom of movement rather than rest.

abstract: A crowd collected in and about Cooper Institute, last evening, on the occasion of the Seymour Ratification Meeting. The interior of the building was filled long before the hour for commencing the proceedings, and the audience busied itself in cheering for "Rynders," "Harry Genet," "Richard O'Gorman," "Gen. McClellan," "Fernando Wood," "Seymour"' and "the Democracy." At length the music -- the Seventh Regiment Band -- appeared, and loud calls were made for "The Star Spangled Banner," "Garryowen" and "Hall Columbia." Capt. RYNDERS suggested that it would be well to commence with "Dixie."

abstract: We are very sorry that the news is confirmed that STUART's rebel cavalry have safely escaped from Pennsylvania "unbagged." We had them "completely surrounded," all their pathways of escape blocked up, and an official telegram was sent to Washington and communicated to the public, that "not one of them should get back to Virginia." But they went like the wind, wherever they listed, captured Chambersburgh, gorged themselves on the fat of Pennsylvania, mounted themselves on its best horses, produced apprehension throughout the State, destroyed public and private property, passed around our entire army, and now, after their long journey, are back in Virginia recounting their triumphs around the rebel camp-fires. The whole affair is infinitely disgraceful to our military leaders. We do not express any admiration for this feat of STUART's Cavalry; but if a small body of our cavalry will perform a like feat in passing round the rebel army, we will express for it an unqualified admiration.

abstract: The last advices received by the Government from Europe, in regard to American affairs, confirm the belief that no purpose of present interference is entertained by any of the Great Powers. The result of the battle of Antietam and the retreat of the rebel army into Virginia were well known, and regarded as important results in favor of the Union cause, giving increased stability to the non-intervention policy of England and France.

abstract: -- The Chenango Telegraph announces that HORACE G. PRINDLE, Esq., of Norwich, a staunch, eloquent and influential Democrat, refuses to support the nominees of the Seymour Convention. He agrees with Gen. DIX in the opinion that this is no time for "reorganizing the Democratic party," or for during anything to hamper and weaken the Government in its contest with rebellion. The Telegraph says that "Mr. PRINDLE's example will impel hundreds of Democrats in this county to carefully investigate the course they are asked to follow by the friends of JEFF. DAVIS, and the clear exposition which he is prepared to make of their plans, will show to the masses how near to the brink of ruin the Seymourites are pushing our beloved country."

abstract: Our regular mails from south and Central America, and from Bogota, are all due to-day or to- morrow, but the prospect now is, that none of them will arrive in time for the steamer. If they do, the telegraph from Panama will give me such items of importance as may reach there from the former States.

abstract: Ex-Gov. SEYMOUR made a speech last even- ing designed to aid his election. It was very long and very elaborate. We publish the essential part of it in another part of this morning's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: Ex-Gov. SEYMOUR made a speech last even- ing designed to aid his election. It was very long and very elaborate. We publish the essential part of it in another part of this morning's TIMES. That portion which we omit is devoted to proving that two years ago LYMAN TREMAIN and D.S. DICKINSON held opinions quite as favorable to the rebellion as Gov. SEYMOUR himself does now. As the fact is not denied, this elaborate argument in proof of it is quite superfluous. Both those gentlemen have since abandoned that position and are now Union men. Gov. SEYMOUR, unlike them, stands now exactly where he stood two years ago. This is the precise difference between them.
