abstract: A WELCOME EXAMPLE. We are glad that Mayor OPDYKE has at last effected what he and his predecessors so often threatened, viz: the arrest of a mockauctioneer under the mock-auction law of 1853. The case in point is the arrest of MOSES B. CHAPMAN, mock-auctioneer, and ZENO BURHAM, his agent.
lead_paragraph: A WELCOME EXAMPLE. -- We are glad that Mayor OPDYKE has at last effected what he and his predecessors so often threatened, viz: the arrest of a mockauctioneer under the mock-auction law of 1853. The case in point is the arrest of MOSES B. CHAPMAN, mock-auctioneer, and ZENO BURHAM, his agent. The former held the license, but the latter was known as the responsible party in carrying on mock-auction furniture sales, principally at No. 48 West Sixteenth street. Their mode of selling gaudy and glazed furniture belonging to "a family about to depart for Europe," is too well known to need description. BURHAM had long defied law, and had more than once blustered defiance to the officers of the law, in the Mayor's office. His last complaining victim was THOMAS D. GREEN, who was not so verdant as his name, as he set his his case before the Mayor, and showed so positively that BURHAM & CHAPMAN had cheated him of $360, that BURHAM was forthwith arrested, and gave bail for trial in the sum of $1,000. CHAPMAN could not be found, but his license was revoked, and his bond sent to the Corporation Attorney for prosecution and forfeiture of $1,000. Yesterday he was arrested and bailed. From the success that has so far attended the efforts to suppress the mock-auctions, it is quite probable that the case will slip through the courts on technicalities of some sort.

abstract: The Herald advises SEYMOUR to withdraw It sees nothing but damage and disgrace to the country from his continuing to distract the public mind by a party contest, while the nation is struggling for existence. It doesn't like WADSWORTH because it supposes him, (though very mistakenly) to be a radical; -- but it is for the vigorous prosecution of the war, the active and zealous support of the Government, and the effectual crushing out of the rebellion; and it regards the prosecution of the party strife which SEYMOUR'S nomination has stirred up in this State, as likely to divide public sentiment and seriously cripple the Administration in its efforts to maintain the Constitution.

abstract: The Granada Appeal of the 13th inst. makes the result of the Corinth battle even more disastrous to the rebels than our own reports. It is stated that the attack was opposed by all but one of the rebel Generals, meaning, probably, VAN DORN, against whom there is great indignation manifested.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO, Monday, Oct. 13.

abstract: the Pennsylvania papers have a theory that STUART's cavalry dash had a political object; and that his purpose was to draw off in pursuit of him a sufficient number of Pennsylvania Republicans to enable the Breckinridge faction to carry the election which occurs in that State to-day. This profound theory was, we understand, first broached by an intelligent contraband, and is said to have found several believers. If such was STUART's object, however, he has less sagacity as a politician than as a military leader; for, instead of taking fifty thousand away from the Republican ticket to-day, ho has probably by his raid contributed to it at least that number of votes.

abstract: The Episcopal Convention met, as usual, at 9 A.M. yesterday, at St. John's Chapel. Rev. Dr. MEAD presiding in the absence of the regular chairman Rev. Dr. CRAIE. The preliminary religious services were conducted by Rt. Rev. Bishop UPFOLD, of Indiana, and Rt. Rev. Bishop WHIPPLE, of Minnesota. Owing to the exceedingly inclement weather the attendance was unusually feeble, the ladies, who are generally in force, being almost altogether absent.

abstract: Our special correspondent at Harper's Ferry sends us the gratifying assurance that a forward movement of the Army of the Potomac has been determined upon, and that in a few days, at furthest, it will be on the Virginia side of the Potomac, engaged in offensive operations against the rebels. Our correspondent traces this promise of action directly to the late visit of the President.

abstract: Editorial on hardship and danger caused by Confederate destruction of Baltimore >amp; Ohio Railroad; urges Government act to preserve line
snippet: Editorial on hardship and danger caused by Confederate destruction of Baltimore >amp; Ohio Railroad; urges Government act to preserve line
lead_paragraph: The vital importance of the permanent and thorough occupation and protection of the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad has again been signally illustrated. This road, from the vicinity of Harper's Ferry to Cumberland, in Maryland, has been exposed, in consequence of the limited forces guarding it, to repeated attacks from the enemy. The success of these attacks has doubtless invited the late raid across that line into Pennsylvania and Maryland, and opportunity has thus been afforded Gen. STUART to accomplish one of the most brilliant and effective dashes which has ever been executed -- thus again reviving the depressed condition of the Confederates, and creating the greatest annoyance and mortification to the loyal people of the North.
headline: {'main': 'THE BALTIMORE AND OHIO RAILROAD.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE BALTIMORE AND OHIO RAILROAD.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The correspondence of BEAUREGARD with the rebel Adjutant-General and with Gen. BRAGG, regarding a plan of operations in the West, which was referred to by telegraph yesterday, is given to the public this morning. The documents may be genuine, and they may not. If they are genuine, we should imagine that BEAUREGARD after his illness dictated the main points to some scrivener, who gave them literary shape and form; for the style is hardly the style of BEAUREGARD, and some of the expressions we can scarcely conceive of his employing.

abstract: Prince JOHN has come back to us again. After a long retirement from the political stage, he made his reappearance at the Seymour benefit on Monday night. On the whole it was a success. He found some old friends glad to greet him again, and a good many new ones still more glad of his help in their extremity. It was hardly necessary to inform his audience that he had been put upon a very low diet for some months past; his speech showed that conclusively. Besides, Democrats out of office are very apt to make the same complaint.

abstract: Very few returns of the elections held yester day had reached us up to the time of going to press this worning. In Pennsylvania, so far as received, they indicate a Union triumph. THAD-  DEUS STEVENS is reelected to Congress from the Lancaster District, by about three thousand ma- jority. In the Fifth District, BAILY (Union) is probably elected.
lead_paragraph: Very few returns of the elections held yester day had reached us up to the time of going to press this worning. In Pennsylvania, so far as received, they indicate a Union triumph. THAD- DEUS STEVENS is reelected to Congress from the Lancaster District, by about three thousand majority. In the Fifth District, BAILY (Union) is probably elected. BROOMALL (Union) is elected in the Seventh District, and BIDDLE (Democrat) is defeated in the Second. Mayor HENRY, the Union candidate, is reelected in Philadelphia by an overwhelming majority. No returns from Indiana, Ohio or Iowa, had been received.

abstract: editorial notes many have volunteered for duty
snippet: editorial notes many have volunteered for duty
lead_paragraph: -- The Quakers, although debarred by the principles of their Society from taking part in wars generally, and although always heretofore exempted from military duty, have in many cases felt deeply the vital justice of the present struggle for national existence, and a respectable number of them have entered the ranks as soldiers. In Philadelphia, and elsewhere, the Quaker ladies, as well as those of the other sex, have worked very hard for the comfort of our soldiers, and we have heard of many instances where Quaker fathers and mothers have not objected to the enlistment of their sons who were not actual members of the body. The following patriotic and stirring note recently written by a very distinguished member of the Society of Friends, to his son in the army, has been handed to us for publication:

lead_paragraph: Herman Frost et al. vs. John Kelly, Sheriff, &c. -- This was an action of replevin for six packages containing crockery and glassware, shipped by the plaintiffs on board the ship Robert Center, in the Fall of 1860, marked "Philipp Runkel, New-Orleans, La." The Sheriff seized the property under an at tachment against Philipp Runkel. At the time of this seizure the plaintiff's held the ship's receipts for this merchandise, and sent to obtain a bill of lading which they were unable to obtain by reason of the seizure.

abstract: -- Mr. JOHN VAN BUREN told his Seymour friends at Cooper Institute, on Monday night, that he was living on spare diet, so as to be prepared for the scant prison fare of Fort Lafayette, where he expected soon to be confined. But immediately before, the distinguished speaker had shown to his own satisfaction, and to that of his audience, that he and they were the only sincere and earnest supporters that the Administration has. "For see," said he, "did not the Republican State Convention utterly fail to say a word in favor of Mr. LINCOLN in their resolutions, and did not the Democratic State Convention tender him unlimited money and men to carry on the war?"
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. JOHN VAN BUREN told his Seymour friends at Cooper Institute, on Monday night, that he was living on spare diet, so as to be prepared for the scant prison fare of Fort Lafayette, where he expected soon to be confined. abstract: editorial questions whether they are official lrs; Editorial notes many Quakers have volunteered for war despite religious beliefs; editorial notes Seymour attack on Adm. over wholesale arrests in violation of freedom of speech and press
snippet: editorial questions whether they are official lrs; Editorial notes many Quakers have volunteered for war despite religious beliefs; editorial notes Seymour attack on Adm. over wholesale arrests in violation of freedom of speech and press
lead_paragraph: The Seymourites set themselves up as the special champions of the habeas corpus and free speech. Evidently this is the ground where they mean to make their strongest stand. They fight very shy of the Emancipation Proclamation, which is really the key of the present position. They keep well aloof from every other important point. But around the habeas corpus they rally with a great show of devotion, and summon the people to the rescue. We are safe in saying that the people will not respond to this call. So far from its gaining their confidence, -- although quite as fond of habeas corpus as these partisan zealots, -- they will see in it but additional evidence of the disloyal spirit which actuates the enemies of the Administration.

abstract: Recently the Board of Councilmen adopted a resolution presented by Mr. JONES, inquiring of the Corporation Counsel what authority the city have for taking the business of the New-York. Manhattan and Harlem Gas Companies into municipal charge and control. In the Board of Aldermen the resolution ...
lead_paragraph: Recently the Board of Councilmen adopted a resolution presented by Mr. JONES, inquiring of the Corporation Counsel what authority the city have for taking the business of the New-York. Manhattan and Harlem Gas Companies into municipal charge and control. In the Board of Aldermen the resolution was referred to a Special Committee, consisting of Messrs. FARLEY, WALSH and BRADY, with instructions to investigate the subject, with the view of learning what the disposition of the people is in respect to having the City authorities take the gas business in hand. The Committee gave a hearing yesterday afternoon in the City Library room.

abstract: Harriet Adams vs. Matthew O. Farrel and John Anderson. -- The plaintiff is a lady of color, and the defendant, Mr. Farrell, was her landlord. The tenant was indebted to Mr. Farrell in the sum of three dollars, with interest, which he desired to collect, and gain possession of his premises. He accordingly procured a warrant to remove his tenant, and placed the same in the hands of John Anderson, who claimed to be the proper officer. Mrs. Adams, who is the mother of an interesting babe about one month old, alleges that the said officer and Mr. Farrell, in executing the warrant, used undue and unlawful violence, whereby she suffered to her damage to the amount of $500. No appearance was made by defendant on the call of the case for trial, and the evidence was taken on the case, when the jury brought in a verdict for plaintiff for $25.
lead_paragraph: Harriet Adams vs. Matthew O. Farrel and John Anderson. -- The plaintiff is a lady of color, and the defendant, Mr. Farrell, was her landlord. abstract: Editorial speculates on McClellan advance into Virginia
snippet: Editorial speculates on McClellan advance into Virginia
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Washington to the Philadelphia North American yesterday pronounces all the statements erroneous that indicate an early forward movement Of MCCLELLAN's army. The reason assigned is, that the condition of the roads is such as to render movement impossible, and that it will be necessary now to wait till the "hard frosts" come, unfortunately, persons without either information or judgment are in the habit of sending dispatches on this important subject; and the military censorship, which is bidden carefully to exclude from the wires all truthful indications of army movements, gives the utmost latitude to all romances of reporters. A most painful impression was made on all classes in our City yesterday when the substance of this Philadelphia dispatch was reproduced.

abstract: George Peabody et al. vs. Henry S. Leaaitt et al. -- This is defendant's motion to be discharged from an order of arrest made by Justice INGRAHAM, on the 26th of November, 1861, upon which defendants are held to bail in the sum of $35,000. The affidavits of James Tinker, on the part of plaintiffs, shows that plaintiffs are bankers in London, and defendants were, in 1860, engaged in mercantile business in the City of New-York. It is alleged that on the 10th day of February, 1860, the defendants applied to the plaintiffs for a credit, as such bankers, to the amount of £10,000, to commence on the 1st day of June, 1860, and to be granted by acceptances of defendants' drafts, from time to time, at four months from date. To induce such credit, it is alleged that the defendants stated that they had as their own capital $150,000, and had effected arrangements by which they had secured facilities or capital from their relatives to the additional amount of $250,000, which was then and would continue to be in their business. Relying on such representations, plaintiffs agreed to furnish the credit desired, and gave them the usual letter of credit for the amount named. The plaintiff from time to time accepted various amounts, making in the aggregate £10,000, upon which there was due Sept. 30, 1861, and is still due, $10,459, which the defendants, owing to the failure of their firm, have not paid. The confidential indebtedness of defendants amounted to about $205,000, and plaintiff allege that defendants [???], in consequence of the nature of plaintiff [???], to [???] that plaintiffs were first paid. The defendants, has ever, I [???] do so.

abstract: The declaration of the Louisville and Cincinnati papers that the Union forces had reoccupied the towns of Lexington and Danville, Ky., almost concurrently with the battle at Perryville, proves to have been incorrect. And these movements failing, the entire theory built upon them, that the rebels were flanked on the east as well as the south and could not escape from the State, fails also. We find it necessary, therefore, on the corrected reports from Kentucky, to recast our views of the position, and to confess that we now see little enough hope of "bagging" the army of BRAGG.
lead_paragraph: The declaration of the Louisville and Cincinnati papers that the Union forces had reoccupied the towns of Lexington and Danville, Ky., almost concurrently with the battle at Perryville, proves to have been incorrect. abstract: The trial of Haynes, the mate of the slaver Nightingale, is still continued. The testimony for the prosecution has been closed to-day. The prosecution has not examined all the witnesses whose testimony was taken on the former trial, in order to save time, as the District-Attorney said. Some new testimony has also been given. The Captain of the Saratoga, which captured the Nightingale, was examined as to the number of times that the vessel was boarded before the capture. He did not himself, however, board her. He stated, however, that if any one on board had stated that he thought the vessel was engaged in the Slave-trade, he should have seized the vessel at once.

abstract: It speaks well for Vermont, that her Legislature has just elected Senator FOOT to his third term, with almost entire [???]. The honor is the more marked in being the first instance of the kind, we believe in Vermont history. Senator FOOT has served his State and the country with eminent fidelity and efficiency. At no time have qualities like his been more required in the National Councils then now; and his retention in the Senate may well be hailed with pleasure.

lead_paragraph: The October elections in the great States of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Iowa, on Tuesday last, though the results are as yet but meagerly reported from some of the Northwestern States, are full of cheer for the supporters of the Government, and the advocates of a determined prosecution of the war. The returns, so far as they have reached us, will be found in our telegraphic columns, and will doubtless be carefully scanned by all who see the important bearing of these elections upon the course and issue of events, as well as by those who are accustomed to forecast the result in our own and other States in November from the indications of popular currents usually given in October.

abstract: -By the  steamer from Europe, whose news was published yesterday, we have an enlarged list of American ships destroyed by the rebel pirate Alabama, or "290," near the Island of Flores, one of the Azores. It comprises no less than ten vessels nine ships and a schooner some of which were large first-class vessels, and others smaller and less valuable.
lead_paragraph: -- By the steamer from Europe, whose news was published yesterday, we have an enlarged list of American ships destroyed by the rebel pirate Alabama, or "290," near the Island of Flores, one of the Azores. It comprises no less than ten vessels nine ships and a schooner some of which were large first-class vessels, and others smaller and less valuable. This new rebel pirate craft has but begun her exploits of burning, plundering, and slaughtering -- having sailed from England, where the rebels purchased her, only a few weeks since. She is the most formidable cruiser the rebels have ever had afloat, and bids fair to do more damage to American commerce than all her predecessors.

abstract: It having been announced that Mr. James would commence the summing up for the defence in this case yesterday morning, the opening of the Court found an immense throng of people eager for admit...
lead_paragraph: It having been announced that Mr. James would commence the summing up for the defence in this case yesterday morning, the opening of the Court found an immense throng of people eager for admittance, among whom was an unusual large number of ladies. All of the ladies were admitted, and supplied with seats within the railing, but the larger portion of gentlemen, including many members of the Bar, were necessarily excluded for want of found. Among the ladies present was Mrs. Edwin James, the wife of the distinguished Counsel for the defence, who occupied a seat near her husband during the delivery of his speech. Mrs. Thos. Dumphy, Miss Ada Clare, and several other ladies also occupied chairs near the Counsel. Mrs. Real was accompanied, as on the previous days, by two or three female friends, and maintained the same [???] demeanor as heretofore. She was considerably affected during portions of the address of her Counsel, and manifested more curiosity and anxiety during the opening remarks of the District Attorney than she had hitherto shown [???] of the case.

abstract: Somebody in authority told us at the commencement of this war, that cavalry was of no use to us. Whatever advantage it may or may not be to us, it is very certain that the rebels have hitherto proved its value to them. The aerobatic performances of STUART and his men, are really of a nature--if we could forget the seriousness of the subject and the insult conveyed--to excite a feeling akin to the ludicrous.

abstract: Staleybridge is one of those second-class interior towns of England's manufacturing districts, where the lives and souls of some fifteen thousand people depend upon the spinning of cotton. To say they must have suffered greatly, these fifteen thousands, from the withdrawal of American raw material, is needless. But Staleybridge, either because its mill-owners have declined to adapt their machinery to India cotton, or because no time at all has been preferred by them to half time, has suffered acutely from the war, and the appeals of its people for relief have rent the hearts of all England. The sorrows of Staleybridge have been only a degree less poignant than those of Blackburn. Starvation has not only looked into the windows of its poor, but has actually entered their doors; and to a community thus distressed and desperate, it seemed safe to go with the arguments with which the agents of secession are always ready to stimulate popular dissatisfaction with the American war, and urge the British Government to intervention.

abstract: We see that it is said that the Court-martial sitting to investigate charges preferred against Gen. MARTINDALE by Gen. PORTER will probably result in favor of Gen. MARTINDALE. Whether the charges are sustained or not, we do not hesitate to say that we are glad they are being examined by a Court-martial. Yet, we cannot help wondering why these charges should be the only ones which are investigated. They are not the only ones which have been made, and that, too, in positive terms and not in haste. Gen. POPE preferred charges against Gens. PORTER, FRANKLIN and GRIFFIN. Gen. MILROY made statements in his official report of the battle at Manassas against Gen. McDOWELL, which showed clearly that he ought to prefer charges against that General or be tried by Court-martial himself; and Gen. HOOKER, in his official report of the battle of Williamsburgh, makes the charge that some one, whose name he fails, however, to mention, was guilty of leaving him unaided through a long day's fight against superior numbers. Some one ought to have been Court-martialed for that. HOOKER says that, "History will not be believed when she states" that the case was as he states it. History may be believed in that statement, as she may have to be in some other most astonishing stories of inefficiency, or jealousy, or treachery in this most astonishing war. But it will be far more difficult for posterity to believe that such a statement as that of HOOKER's could be made in an official report, and no General be tried and shot for such action, and that months would elapse without any investigation into the matter, or the facts of the case being laid before the public. There was time enough for such an inquiry during all the long months spent in the trenches on the Chickahominy. There has, surely, been time enough, since the rebel army left our forces in safety on the banks of the Potomac, to have held investigations into the charges made by POPE and MILROY. We are glad to see a Court-martial held upon any General. We only hope that it may not stop with this me. We are quite inclined to think that our cause will only cease to suffer from miserable jealousies and petty rivalries and self-seekings among our Generals, when some one of them shall have been tried and shot for cowardice or incapacity.

abstract: Charles H. Fleming, Plaintiff in Error vs. The People, Defendants in Error. -- Fleming was tried in the General Sessions, on an indictment for bigamy. The indictment charged that on the 11th of November, 1855, Fleming married one Rowena Baldwin, and that on the 30th of December, 1861, he did "marry and take as his wife, one Jane A. Butt, against the form of statute, &c." On the trial, counsel for prisoner requested the Court to charge "that in order to justify a conviction, it was necessary to prove that at the time of the alleged marriage between the defendant and Jane A. Butt, the defendant did not come within any of the exceptions mentioned in Part 4, chapter 1, title 5, article 2, section 9 of the Revised Statutes." The Court refused so to charge, and charged that the statutory exceptions were matters of defence; to which counsel excepted.

abstract: The indignation aroused by the recent order of the Post-office Department has called forth an explanatory letter from the Postmaster in NewYork, published by us on Saturday, which practically nullifies the most objectionable feature of the order instructing Postmasters "to treat as...
lead_paragraph: The indignation aroused by the recent order of the Post-office Department has called forth an explanatory letter from the Postmaster in NewYork, published by us on Saturday, which practically nullifies the most objectionable feature of the order instructing Postmasters "to treat as unpaid any letter which may be covered with a stamp at all soiled or defaced," By the interpretation of our City Postmaster, this only applies to letters "covered by fraudulent stamps, or those so soiled or defaced or washed as to render it impossible to determine whether they are valid or not." This is all very well. No one can ask the Department to acknowledge a stamp which has already been used, but the only proper evidence of this is the mark of cancellation, or clear evidence that it has been removed. No amount of soiling is sufficient. No private person would dare refuse to pay his note on the ground that it had been handled by soiled hands. If the canceling has been properly performed, according to the regulations of the Department there is no possibility of successful erasure, unless in a single exceptional case. By the regulations the canceling is to be done "with printer's black ink, whenever that material can be obtained." Now there are very few offices so remote from a printing-office that this ink cannot be had with slight trouble. Twenty-five cents' worth will supply a small office for a year. If this is properly applied it cannot be removed without at the same time removing the colored ink with which the stamps themselves are printed.

abstract: One of the ablest of the Border State organs, the Baltimore American, in a recent moderate and thoughtful article on the President's Proclamation, predicted one result which deserves serious consideration...
lead_paragraph: One of the ablest of the Border State organs, the Baltimore American, in a recent moderate and thoughtful article on the President's Proclamation, predicted one result which deserves serious consideration Emancipation, it observed, would be no philanthropy to the negro: his fate was extermination. Free white labor would eventually expel free negro labor even in the South, as it had done in the North, and the inferior race would dwindle and disappear under the mysterious laws of races, before the superior race. This view is held by many economists in Europe and in the Free States.

abstract: The inquest in the case of HENRY L. WILLIAMS, Policeman of the Ninth Ward, who was murdered on Monday evening last, was held yesterday, by Coroner WILDEY, at the Station-house, in Charles-street.
lead_paragraph: The inquest in the case of HENRY L. WILLIAMS, Policeman of the Ninth Ward, who was murdered on Monday evening last, was held yesterday, by Coroner WILDEY, at the Station-house, in Charles-street. The testimony proved that the officer was murdered without any provocation whatever, while in discharge of his duty, and while assisting his murderer to his feet, after he had fallen over the shafts of a cart, as previously reported. The pistol was discharged at the moment that Officer WILLIAMS stooped down to raise the accused from the sidewalk. Immediately after the shot was fired some citizens came up, and found the deceased and his murderer, EDWARD MCCORMACK, upon the walk closely clinched, and MCCORMACK then had the revolver in his right hand. It was with great difficulty that the weapon was wrested from his grasp.

abstract: Editorial on J Van Buren remark on capturing Richmond and then letting Confederates go
snippet: Editorial on J Van Buren remark on capturing Richmond and then letting Confederates go
lead_paragraph: Take Richmond, and then, if they insist, let them go, argues Prince JOHN, next to Mr. SEYMOUR, the principal speaker at the Ratification Meeting. And yet these same leaders affect indignation when then loyalty is questioned. They seem to take it for granted that the people have neither the wit to discern, nor the spirit to resent. In ordinary times, such presumption would be incredible. But when rebels are so monstrously infatuated, it is not strange that rebel sympathizers should also display uncommon folly. Nobody can be deceived in the meaning of this speech. If we are to let the rebels go, after taking Richmond, why not before? What care we for Richmond, but as a vantage ground against the rebellion? Why spend blood and treasure in gaining the rebel Capital, if, when gained, we are to give the Confederacy option whether to keep its power or not? No man in his senses can believe that our encampment on Shockoe Hill would make the rebel leaders love us better than before. It would only humiliate and embitter. If option is to be the word, it had better be spoken on the Potomac. In either case it is certain that the rebel managers would not for an instant entertain the idea of returning to the Union. They know full well that such return would be their political annihilation. Every calculation and every instinct would impel them to stick to the Confederacy. Rebel option means national disunion -- nothing more or less. Mr. VAN BUREN's exhortation to "let them go if," is simply an exhortation to let them go anyhow. The locality where the alternative is presented is nothing. Whether at Washington, or Richmond, or Charleston, or New-Orleans, the offer would amount to a recognition of Confederate independence. It would give the rebels all they ask for. We say then that it is absurd for these men to protest adhesion to the war. Follow their counsel, and there is nothing left to fight for. It is just as absurd for them to claim loyalty. This language rivets and clinches every charge of disloyalty.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. The Movements in State Politics, with the Election returns from all the States so far as received, will be found in this morning's issue. All official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current, topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American readers, and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: A few weeks ago, when the President's Emancipation Proclamation was first promulgated, the rebel Congress was profoundly agitated. Violent philippics were hurled against the people of the North -- threats of an exterminating war were freely indulged in -- and the usual alarming apparition of a "black flag," with death's head and cross-bones painted in ghostly white upon it, flashed before our faces. Who of all the loyal millions of the loyal States would be spared, if the South, justly inflamed by the President's edict, should declare a war of extermination against us, and henceforth "give no quarter?" The Virginia Legislature, then in session, sympathized with this frenzy, and forthwith prepared to utter a decree that no person in that State should be held to have committed a crime who might kill soldier or citizen engaged in carrying out the President's Proclamation.

abstract: The annual New-York Trade Sale of Books opened yesterday at the spacious and elegant ware rooms of Messrs. GEO. A. LEAVITT  Co., Nos. 21 and 23 Mercer-street.
lead_paragraph: The annual New-York Trade Sale of Books opened yesterday at the spacious and elegant ware rooms of Messrs. GEO. A. LEAVITT & CO., Nos. 21 and 23 Mercer-street. The attendance was quite as large as in former years, though the South was not very largely represented among the buyers. Orders from the rebel States will probably be deferred until after the 1st of January next, when the Emancipation Proclamation of President LINCOLN will have gone into effect, and the rebels will have time to turn their attention from war to literature. If the opening day may be relied on as an indication of what is to be expected in the way of sales, a larger number of books will be disposed of than were last year. There is no reason why the sales should not foot up to a most astounding sum. True, books will probably command higher prices than hitherto, owing to the rise in paper, caused by Secretary CHASE's immense consumption of it in making Treasury notes. But the unimportant addition of forty or fifty per cent. to the price of books, or anything else, can scarcely be felt while the supply of money to the popular pocket is only limited by the supply of paper, the energy of engravers, and the power of the Treasury's presses. No indication of hard times can be found in the table which the liberal Messrs. LEAVITT & Co. provide for their customers at noon-time. For I must be known that book-buyers out as well as other men. Not as in the good old times, indeed, before [???] and exchange rose beyond the reach of the [???] and white imports were subject only to [???], is the table spread with chickens and champagne. But the more substantial indigenous viand and beverages, pork, beef, beans and coffee, abound. The sale and the dinner will continue for one week -- the former commencing daily at 9 in the morning, the latter at I in the afternoon.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: We have the pleasure to announce to our readers, to-day, the perfect safety of the Union. The existing war can last, at the furthest, but a week or two longer. The seceding States are about to return to our arms, under a general amnesty, guaranteed by the Czar of Russia and the Sultan of Turkey. Mr. LINCOLN has made arrangements to abdicate in favor of Mr. BUCHANAN, who has consented, for this time only, to make a positively last appearance upon the political stage.

abstract: At 9 A.M., yesterday, the members of the Episcopal Convention came together briefly at St. John's Chapel, and thence adjourned to Bellevue Hospital, at the foot of Twenty-sixth-street, on the East River. By 10 A.M., a goodly number of distinguished churchmen, both clerical and lay, had asembled at the hospital.
lead_paragraph: At 9 A.M., yesterday, the members of the Episcopal Convention came together briefly at St. John's Chapel, and thence adjourned to Bellevue Hospital, at the foot of Twenty-sixth-street, on the East River. By 10 1/2 A.M., a goodly number of distinguished churchmen, both clerical and lay, had asembled at the hospital. The little steamer employed in plying between the institutions on the adjacent islands was in readiness, and about 11 o'clock, the company of guests, preceded by the Right Rev. Bishop POTTER, of this Diocese, and the Hon. SIMEON DRAPER, Chairman of the Commission of Public Charities and Corrections, embarked. The party numbered in all 100 persons, including a fair representation of the ladles of the Church. The upper decks of the miniature steamer were densely crowded, and shortly after the craft got under way, a very serious accident was narrowly escaped. Right Rev. Bishop POTTER had, with a few pertinent remarks, introduced Mr. DRAPER officially to the company, and the latter had just replied and was proceeding to point out and describe the various institutions on the beautiful islands past which the boat was gliding, when, with a crash, a portion of the deck, some four or five feet in width, and reaching from side to side of the vessel, sank beneath the feet of the group crowded together to hear the Commissioner. In the first moment of alarm, all thought that the entire deck was giving way, and universal consternation prevailed. Had the weak shell, upon which scores of ladies and gentlemen were struggling, really broken through, loss of life and limb must have ensued. As it was, fortunately only a depression of some inches resulted, and the dangerous region was carefully avoided for the rest of the trip. This would have been gay and pleasant, had not a cold, drizzling rain marred the occasion. The same drawback existed throughout the greater part of the day and impaired its gratifications.

abstract: A NUMBER OF CHILDREN INJURED. Yesterday afternoon, as the children in Public School No. 20, in South Fourth-street, E.D., were engaged in their studies, smoke was discovered issuing from the flues of the heating apparatus.
lead_paragraph: A NUMBER OF CHILDREN INJURED. -- Yesterday afternoon, as the children in Public School No. 20, in South Fourth-street, E.D., were engaged in their studies, smoke was discovered issuing from the flues of the heating apparatus. An examination disclosed the alarming fact that the wood work was on fire, and in a few moments the greatest confusion prevailed. The children made a simultaneous and frantic attempt to escape from the apartment, numbers rushing to the windows for the purpose of jumping out, which one or two actually did. The teachers directed their efforts to getting the children out, and succeded in effecting the egress of nearly all of them uninjured. But in the desperate attempt to get out a number were trampled upon, crushed and more or less hurt. One boy named DAVIS, whose parents reside in South Fourth-street had his leg broken. A little girl named EMILY WASHBURNE, residing in South Eighth-street, sustained a compound fracture of the collar-bone. A boy, whose name our reporter could not ascertain, was suffocated with the smoke, and taken out of the building in an insensible condition. His recovery is considered doubtful. The above, it is believed, are all the casualties of a serious character that occurred. As soon as the alarm for the fire was given, it was responded to by the Fire Department in strong force. And when it became known that the school house was on fire, the greatest excitement, confusion and alarm prevailed. Mothers rushed to the rescue of their children, and hundreds of spectators were anxious to render aid. The firemen and the police rendered efficient and important aid, both in extinguishing the fire and rescuing the children. The origin of the fire is presumed to have been entirely accidental. The damage done to the building is estimated at $500. The building will not be fit for use for several weeks.

abstract: The popular interest in the protracted, but highly interesting trial, has continued unabated from the day of its commencement, and the last day witnessed no diminution in the throng of cigar specta-  tors who sought admission to the court-room. As on  previous days, the ladies had first to be accommodat-...
lead_paragraph: The popular interest in the protracted, but highly interesting trial, has continued unabated from the day of its commencement, and the last day witnessed no diminution in the throng of cigar specta- tors who sought admission to the court-room. As on previous days, the ladies had first to be accommodated, their number was so great that little room was left within the bar for male auditors, even though they urged their prior claims as members of the profession. It is to be hoped that the new Court-house now in process of construction, will contain at least one room capable of accommodating a reasonably large audience. Mr. Hall's address to the jury occupied five hours, and was an exceedingly able, thorough, masterly effort. The charge of Judge BARNARD was brief, concise, and to the point, and was admitted by all to be entirely impartial.

abstract: Editorial estimates Confederates lost some 60,000 slaves since war began
snippet: Editorial estimates Confederates lost some 60,000 slaves since war began
lead_paragraph: -- A recent Richmond paper, in speaking of the devastation caused to the State of Virginia by the invasion of the National armies, declares that 30,000 slaves have been lost to their owners. In the States of Tennessee, Kentucky, Arkansas and Missouri, so many have not been lost, but probably hall the number. In South Carolina, Georgia and Louisiana, we may safely assume that half as many more have been released from bondage. These calculations give a grand total of 60,000 slaves wholly lost to Southern masters by reason of the war. These slaves, at a valuation of $300 each, represent a wealth of thirty millions of dollars.

abstract: The Boston Courier of Tuesday invents or reports a conversation supposed to have been held on board of a Sound steamer, between some Down-Easter of an "inquiring mind" and a paroled Louisiana prisoner from Antietam, in which conversation the captive rebel is described as declaring that the election of SEYMOUR in New-York and of other Democrats throughout the North would bring the rebel cause to immediate ruin.
lead_paragraph: -- The Boston Courier of Tuesday invents or reports a conversation supposed to have been held on board of a Sound steamer, between some Down-Easter of an "inquiring mind" and a paroled Louisiana prisoner from Antietam, in which conversation the captive rebel is described as declaring that the election of SEYMOUR in New-York and of other Democrats throughout the North would bring the rebel cause to immediate ruin. A Democratic, victory at the North, this astute rebel is made to say, would give such tremendous force to the Union sentiment at the South that thousands of rebel soldiers would throw down their arms refuse to fight any longer, and go home to await the peaceful restoration of the "good old times."

abstract: The forward movement of the Army of the Potomac, promised a few days ago in our special correspondence, has commenced. A portion of the army advanced early yesterday morning and occupied Charlestown, after an artillery fight of about two hours duration with the outer force of the rebels. Gen. McCLELLAN was at Charlestown last night, and the indications were that the place would be held, even at the risk of a general engagement.

abstract: PUBLIC WORK. The bids awaiting opening at the Street Department, were deferred, for the fourth time, for five days, yesterday, till the 21st inst., the Comptroller declining to attend. The term of post- ponement is the least length of time specified by ordinance, and it is likely that the opening will continue to be deferred every five days till a Streat Commissioner is appointed.
lead_paragraph: PUBLIC WORK. -- The bids awaiting opening at the Street Department, were deferred, for the fourth time, for five days, yesterday, till the 21st inst., the Comptroller declining to attend. The term of post- ponement is the least length of time specified by ordinance, and it is likely that the opening will continue to be deferred every five days till a Streat Commissioner is appointed. At the Croton Department bids were opened yesterday for four jobs, and awards of contracts for them disposed of as follows: Laying crosswalks in One Hundred and Twenty-second-street at the intersection of Avenues A, and First and Second avenues; seven bids; lowest, CHRISTOPER KEYES and R. & J. CUNNINGHAM, (tie bids,) at $678 40. They are to settle the matter of the award between themselves, having mutually requested the privilege of doing so, and promising to report on the matter to-day. Laying trap-block paypment in Thirty-seventh-street, from Madison to Fifty-avenue; nine bids; to CHAS. GUIDET, at $1,632 90. Same in Forty-seventh-street, from Sixth to Seventh-avenue; ten bids; to MICHAEL DUNN, at $3,371 40. Same in Fifth-avenue, from Forty-second to Forty-ninth-street; eight bids; to WILLIAM A. CUMMINGS, at $13,900 08.

abstract: [???] has occupied seven days, and at midnight of yesterday was not yet concluded. A report of yesterday's proceedings is given on the second page. The case was given to the jury at 20 minutes past 4 o'clock, and the universal impression was that a verdict of acquittal would be brought in in fifteen minutes. Time wore on, and the long hours of the night were reached, when Judge BARNARD instructed the Sheriff that in case of a non-conclusion at 10 o'clock Mrs. REAL should be remanded to the Tombs Mrs. REAL spent the evening in the rooms of the District-Attorney, accompanied by several ladies and gentlemen, who were determined to remain with her to the end. She was perfectly calm outwardly, but gave occasional toxens of great mental anxiety. At [???] P.M., under charge of the Deputy Sheriff, he [???] to the Tombs.

abstract: The jury in the case of MARY REAL, for seven days past on trial for murder in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday morning brought in a verdict of manslaughter in the third degree, and recommended the prisoner to the mercy of the Court. She was sentenced to two years and six months in the State Prison, this being the shortest term allowed by statute. After receiving the sentence, the prisoner addressed the Judge in the most solemn and emphatic manner, saying "I'll never go; never go."
lead_paragraph: The jury in the case of MARY REAL, for seven days past on trial for murder in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday morning brought in a verdict of manslaughter in the third degree, and recommended the prisoner to the mercy of the Court. lead_paragraph: The diplomatic intellect of Europe is very much disturbed concerning our domestic troubles, and, thanks to the persistent reiteration of the statement, has finally persuaded its of that the delay which has occurred in the adjustment of our difficulties is altogether unparalleled in the history of civilization, and highly discreditable to us. The spectre o "intervention" is constantly evoked to accelerate our movements, and we are besought to admit that we cannot possibly settle our own affairs.

abstract: The jury in the case of the People vs. Mrs. MARY REAL, charged with the murder of her husband, came into Court yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, having been together all night, and announced that they had agreed upon a verdict. The prisoner was requested to stand up, and the usual question was put by the clerk -- "how say you, gentlemen, do you find the prisoner at the bar guilty or not guilty?" The foreman replied --" we find her guilty of manslaughter in the third degree, and in consideration of the mitigating circumstances of the case we unanimously recommend her to the clemency of the Court." On the announcement of the verdict, the prisoner appeared to be shocked; her lips quivered, and she shrunk back as if to sit down from nervous exhaustion; but shed no tears, and soon recovered her self-possession. She was requested to step forward to the Judge's desk, which she did, accompanied by the officer having her in charge. After being sworn, she was asked if she had any trade, to which she replied that she had learned the trade of a vest-maker. The question was then put to her what she had to say why sentence should not be pronounced upon her; whereupon her senior counsel, Mr. JAMES, arose and stated to the Court that since the adjournment of the Court Thursday new and important facts had come into his possession favorable to the accused, and which could hardly fail to induce the clemency of the Court toward his client. He therefore asked that the sentence be deferred until these facts could be brought to the attention of the Court in a proper form.
lead_paragraph: The jury in the case of the People vs. Mrs. MARY REAL, charged with the murder of her husband, came into Court yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, having been together all night, and announced that they had agreed upon a verdict. The foreman replied --" we find her guilty of manslaughter in the third degree, and in consideration of the mitigating circumstances of the case we unanimously recommend her to the clemency of the Court." On the announcement of the verdict, the prisoner appeared to be shocked; her lips quivered, and she shrunk back as if to sit down from nervous exhaustion; but shed no tears, and soon recovered her self-possession. She was requested to step forward to the Judge's desk, which she did, accompanied by the officer having her in charge. lead_paragraph: A writer in Richmond Enquirer assigns as a reason for expecting an early peace, that "the bitterness and animosity existing between the Northern political parties is daily increasing in intensity." He declares that "this state of things alone, without a conflict, must obstruct seriously, if not absolutely defeat, any efficient prosecution of the war." The view is a natural one, and the rebels have a right to take courage from it. Our great strength in time past has been the concentration of public feeling; and the distraction of this feeling threatens to be our great weakness in time to come. The conspirators would have never undertaken the rebellion had they anticipated a united North; it is not strange that now, in their desperate straits, they should hail the prospect of a divided North, and count upon a speedy recognition of their independence.

abstract: Eugene Hall vs. Henry G. Ely. It appears that one Benjamin Waterbury, in 1859, made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors to the defendant Ely. The plaintiff is one of the preferred creditors named in the assignment, and alleges that the defendant, as such assignee, accepted the trust and entered upon the execution thereof, and took ...
lead_paragraph: Eugene Hall vs. Henry G. Ely. -- It appears that one Benjamin Waterbury, in 1859, made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors to the defendant Ely. The plaintiff is one of the preferred creditors named in the assignment, and alleges that the defendant, as such assignee, accepted the trust and entered upon the execution thereof, and took possession of the assigned property for the payment of Waterbury's creditors; that the assignee has neglected to pay the plaintiff's claim, or to render any account of his trust. Also that Waterbury is still conducting business with the assigned property and in the name of the defendant, at No. 266 Broadway, and that defendant refuses to close the business and render an account of his trust.

abstract: The iron-clad vessel Weehawken, which was commenced about six months ago in Jersey City, by orders of the Government, is all but completed, and will be launched from the stocks positively early next week. In her completion the contractors. Messrs. SECOR. COLWELL & Co., of No. 68 West-street, New-York, have displayed much punctuality in adhering to their specification, and Mr. BIRKBECK, Jr., the General Superintendent of the works, has well acquitted himself in the faithful discharge of his duties.

abstract: -- JOHN VAN BUREN apologized for quoting, in his recent speech at the Cooper Institute meeting, certain private conversations, by saying that he stipulated, at the time of hearing of the conversations, for the privilege of repeating them. This apology argued a lingering sense of propriety on the part of the Prince, in the matter of betraying private confidence. We feel emboldened, therefore, to ask the distinguished orator by whose authority he read a certain letter to his audience on that occasion, purporting to have been written by Gen. SCOTT? There is a general feeling that there has been a gross breach of faith somewhere. Gen. SCOTT could not have given authority to publish what would be used to tarnish his fame. The President and Mr. SEWARD, to whom the letter was written, could not have betrayed a General they trusted so fully before and after the letter was written. The letter must, therefore, have been pilfered, or a copy made by dishonorable means before it reached the. Prince's hands. Will he name his accomplice?
lead_paragraph: -- JOHN VAN BUREN apologized for quoting, in his recent speech at the Cooper Institute meeting, certain private conversations, by saying that he stipulated, at the time of hearing of the conversations, for the privilege of repeating them. abstract: -- Advertising is in vain if the reader has failed to notice with interest the communications from Dr. ROBERT HUNTER, occasionally appearing in the TIMES, on the treatment of the leading disorders of the human system -- especially those of the throat and lungs. The method propounded is original and plausible. Many cases have been brought to our notice in which it has had apparent success and while we have not the presumption to pronounce upon its intrinsic merits, we certainly believe the consumptive will do wisely to give the remarks of Dr. HUNTER a careful hearing.

abstract: Gen. C.T. JAMES, who has just died in consequence of injuries received by a premature explosion of one of his own projectiles, was a native of Rhode Island. By profession he was an engineer, and for a time was engaged in superintending the construction of some of the largest manufacturing establishments in New-England. His leisure hours for the last thirty years have been devoted to the study of artillery, and the improvements which he claims to have made were the result and deduction of careful scientific investigations. Gen. JAMES represented his State in the United States Senate from 1851 to 1857. He derived his military title from having held the position of Major-General of the Rhode Island State Militia. At the time of his death he was about 51 years of age. He leaves a wife and four children.

abstract: Reliable information was received at this place yesterday, that Gen. STUART, with cavalry and artillery, was advancing and threatening this position. Thwarled in his attempt to cut off Gen. STAHL'S Command when a reconnoissance was made to Middleburgh, Snickersville and vicinity, last Monday, Gen STUART no doubt hopes to make amends for the lack of energy then displayed, by foreing this command to fall back from its present position.

abstract: Once more is the reality of war brought home to us. This morning while breakfasting, we were startled by the booming of cannon, not far away, but seemingly very near. Hastening to an adjoining hill, I could see wreathes of blue smoke slowly rising heavenward, from near Charleston, and distinctly hear the roar of our artillery. There have been several reconnoissances in that direction, but no such heavy firing as this.
lead_paragraph: HARPER's FERRY, Va., Thursday, Oct. 16, 1862.

abstract: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, indicate unmistakably that Gen. McCLELLAN is again about to measure strength with the rebel hosts under LEE. There appears to be no doubt that the latter intends to give battle at or near their present location, which is now well known to our Generals, through the thorough reconnoissances recently made.
lead_paragraph: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, indicate unmistakably that Gen. McCLELLAN is again about to measure strength with the rebel hosts under LEE. There appears to be no doubt that the latter intends to give battle at or near their present location, which is now well known to our Generals, through the thorough reconnoissances recently made. Simultaneous with the movement of Gen. HANCOCK's Division to Charlestown on Thursday, another movement was made across the Potomac, at Shepherdstown Ford, by Gen. WOODBURY's Division, which took the road leading to Smithfield, a small village half way between Charlestown and Bunker's Hill. This division encamped, on Thursday night, between Leetown and Kearneysville, having met with but slight resistance during the advance. Yesterday morning the cavalry attached to the division advanced toward Smithfield, and formed a junction with HANCOCK's cavalry, having meantime discovered the enemy in very heavy force. The object of the reconnoissance was thus attained without loss. To-day may bring us the news of another great battle.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN has broken the spell that has rested upon the two armies of the Upper Potomac since the battle of Antietam. On Thursday he threw forward division, well supported, to Charlestown, driving the rebel pickets before him; and rested at night on the hills two miles beyond the town, spending the night himself in the place.
lead_paragraph: Gen. MCCLELLAN has broken the spell that has rested upon the two armies of the Upper Potomac since the battle of Antietam. On Thursday he threw forward division, well supported, to Charlestown, driving the rebel pickets before him; and rested at night on the hills two miles beyond the town, spending the night himself in the place. The bulk of Gen. LEE's army is reported to be lying between Winchester and the Shenandoah. MCCLELLAN's advance is, therefore, a direct challenge of the enemy to combat; for the march is right toward the front of LEE's lines.

abstract: FIRE. -- Yesterday morning, about 4 o'clock, a fire broke out in the kindling wood establishment of Mr. W.F. GLEASON, Nos. 7 and 9 Adams-street, Brooklyn, resulting in the destruction of a number of sheds, including two horses; loss $3,000, insured for $1,500 in the Phenix Company, of Brooklyn. The adjoining premises of W.T. BURTON, iron pipe manufacturer, was damaged to the extent of $1,000. The stable of THOMAS HUNT, No. 11 Adams-street, was damaged to the extent of $150. The fire originated accidentally in the boiler room.

abstract: The chief product of South America is animal. The chief export is in bales of wool or cargoes of hides. abstract: One of the pleasantest bits of impudence characterizing the present State canvass is the assurance with which the blatant Democracy complain of the abridgment of the freedom of speech. Their orators and journals teem with abuse of the Government, and with all sorts of aid and comfort to the enemy; they are permitted to even openly advocate the recognition of the rebel Confederacy, to accuse the officers of the Government of imbecility, venality and treason; to load them with all the epithets that the virulence of disappointed office-seekers can concoct; and yet each fresh assault is wound up with the averment that the assailants are restricted in their freedom of speech. They have, in fact, not only freedom, but unbridled license.
lead_paragraph: One of the pleasantest bits of impudence characterizing the present State canvass is the assurance with which the blatant Democracy complain of the abridgment of the freedom of speech. They have, in fact, not only freedom, but unbridled license.

abstract: The case of HAYNES, the mate of the slaver Nightingale, was given to the jury yesterday afternoon. The defence gave little testimony except that of good character. Mr. BRADY summed up the case for the prisoner in a speech of three hours and a half long on Thursday. The District-Attorney spoke for five hours, commencing at the opening of Court yesterday morning. The Judge charged the jury briefly and clearly as to the law of the case, and the matter was submitted to the jury about 3 1/2 o'clock.

abstract: Eliza Malone vs. Benjamin M. Stilwell and Elizabeth Stillwell. -- This is an action for slander. The plaintiff alleges that in January, 1861, she was the domestic servant of the defendants, at their residence in Thirty-fourth-street. She alleges that on the 31st day of January, 1861, Mrs. Stilwell charged her with having stolen two diamond ear-rings of the value of $150, with a malicious and wicked intent, &c., and that Mr. Stilwell at the same time repeated the slander, and ordered her to leave the house. The plaintiff claims to have suffered great damage to her character for honesty, and her standing among the servant girls in the neighborhood, as well as her own peace of mind and conscience. She thinks, therefore, she ought to have about $2,000 damages. The defendants demur to the complaint on the ground that several causes of action are improperly joined; in that there is one cause of action against the husband, and one against the wife, requiring separate remedies. The demurrer was sustained, and all the allegations of the complaint touching slanderous words used by the husband were ordered stricken out.
lead_paragraph: Eliza Malone vs. Benjamin M. Stilwell and Elizabeth Stillwell. -- This is an action for slander. abstract: The movement inangurated a few evenings ince to raise in this city and State a fund in aid of the sick and wounded of the National army and navy, which should be as worthy of the cause as of the loyalty of the Golden State, is already as forward and successful as the most sanguine could reasonably expect.
lead_paragraph: The movement inangurated a few evenings ince to raise in this city and State a fund in aid of the sick and wounded of the National army and navy, which should be as worthy of the cause as of the loyalty of the Golden State, is already as forward and successful as the most sanguine could reasonably expect. The collections thus far are more than munificent, and make one feel especially proud of San Francisco merchant princes, whose wealth is only exceeded by their liberality and patriotism.

abstract: The United States steam transport United States, Capt. FULTON, arrived, yesterday, from Hilton Head, which port she left on the 14th inst., at 4 P.M. On the first day out she encountered heavy gales from north and east. She left the following vessels: Steamers Karnac and Trade Wind in distress; United States transports Ben De Ford and Boston; steamer Cosmopolitan sunk by running on her anchor in the St. John's River. On the 8th inst., the United States vessels of war Vermont, Wabash, Vandalia, Marble, head, Honsatonic, Conemaugh, Patron, Wissihicon-Dawn and Port Royal. The Pawnee and Lebago were at Nassau, all well.

abstract: Charles Weeks, Executor of Abraham Weeks vs. Obadiah Hopkins. -- This action, mentioned in the TIMES of Friday, is brought to recover several sums of money claimed to have been loaned from time to time to defendant, by the firm of A. & C. Weeks. The defendant answers that the firm of A. & C. Weeks and himself were in the habit of borrowing money from each other upon temporary loans, and of exchanging checks, and of assisting each other as their business necessities might require; that the sums of money I so loaned, and checks lent and exchanged by the said firm, were equal to the moneys loaned by this defendant. Plaintiff produced in evidence an old memorandum book, claimed to have been kept at the time the loans were made. The case involves the question how far these memoranda are admissible as evidence, without, other collateral proof tending in the same direction, and of plaintiff's right to bring this action as the executor of his father. The trial was concluded on Friday, and the jury rendered a verdict for defendant.

Plaintiff produced in evidence an old memorandum book, claimed to have been kept at the time the loans were made. abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: Hon. C.B. SMITH, Secretary of the Interior, addressed the citizens of Indianapolis at the Masonic Hall, on Friday evening, upon the condition of public affairs. He spoke hopefully of the future, thought we were much nearer the end of the war than a majority of the people imagined. He knew that we had suffered reverses and disasters, all of which were very discouraging and humiliating to loyal men; but even BUELL had accomplished something, and he now folt convinced that our Generals were learning, and that we would soon have the Mississippi clear, have possession of Vicksburgh and Jackson, and probably by the first of December would have six more from clad gunboats, superior to the Monitor, read. Two of them could pass Forts Sumter and [???] and destroy Charleston, on whose ruins he would erect a monument, upon which he would write the history of the rebellion, and allow it to stand as a terror to traitors for all coming time. He exhorted all to stand by the Government. All must suffer for the public good, and when the flag of the Union shall once more float over all parts of our country, we would stand forth the greatest, happiest and mightiest people on the face of the globe.

abstract: -- Rev. O.S. SENTER, of Berlin, Vt., has devoted much of his attention to the supply of religious reading far the use of privates in the army. Beyond furnishing a neat copy of the Testament and Psalms to each recruit of regiments within his reach, taking care to have the little volumes compactly bound in pocket-book form, he has compiled an extra fly-leaf of suggestions to the soldier, containing much that will contribute to promote his moral and physical health, and augment his chances of a wholesome longevity. The second volume, so supplemented, cannot be otherwise than a book of life to the bearer.

abstract: The heavy reconnoitering parties under Gens. HANCOCK and HUMPHREYS, which proceeded from the Army of the Potomac in the direction of Winchester on Thursday, returned to their positions again on Friday, as stated in our special dispatches.
lead_paragraph: The heavy reconnoitering parties under Gens. HANCOCK and HUMPHREYS, which proceeded from the Army of the Potomac in the direction of Winchester on Thursday, returned to their positions again on Friday, as stated in our special dispatches. The party under Gen. HUMPHREYS was followed by rebel cavalry and artillery to within a short distance of Shepherdstown, and one of our men was killed and six wounded. We captured a number of prisoners, and it is understood that the rebels had between forty and fifty men killed and wounded while disputing our advance.

abstract: Editorial laments delays in completing Union iron-clad vessels
snippet: Editorial laments delays in completing Union iron-clad vessels
lead_paragraph: -- We hear of great delays in the completion of our iron-clad vessels. Some which, according to the contract, were to be completed four or five months ago, will not, at present rates of progress, be finished for as many months hence. We were assured that fourteen or fifteen of them would be afloat by the 1st of this month; but our readers know how far the promise is from being yet realized. Of course, admirable excuses are made for this delay, and it is shown beyond dispute that it was quite impossible to do the work within the specified time. But we should have supposed that the contractors would have known all this before they undertook their jobs, and before the country had formed such hopes of a Fall naval campaign, which, it seems, is likely to be unrealized. We had hoped that our new-iron clad navy would give us all the rebel sea-coast cities worth taking before the setting in of Wintr, so that our civil and military Governors of those cities might spend the cool weather in pacifying the infuriated rebels. But if these hopes are to be even partially indulged, the Navy Department and its contractors will have to push night and day the work on each and all of the embryo iron-clads. We understand that a naval expedition, in which some of our new Monitors are to take part, is being gotten up now, and will soon be on its way. We hope it will be directed against a point on the enemy's coast of some value and importance, and that our other iron-clads will be finished and launched so quickly that the first blow may be followed up until the whole of the coast is in our possession. Then ships from every quarter of the globe, in approaching any part of our vastly extended sea-line, shall behold flaming against the sky, and floating from every fort and city, the glorious and blood-baptized emblem of the Republic.
headline: {'main': 'OUR IRON-CLADS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR IRON-CLADS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We congratulate the  A SILVER LINING. We congratulate the  country upon two results of the late elections the defeat of VALLANDIGHAM and of PETTIT. It would have been a very great disgrace if either of them had been allowed to pollute the Capitol for two years to come. It is bad enough that we have still to endure through the Winter the presence of the Ohio...
lead_paragraph: -- We congratulate the country upon two results of the late elections -- the defeat of VALLANDIGHAM and of PETTIT. It would have been a very great disgrace if either of them had been allowed to pollute the Capitol for two years to come. It is bad enough that we have still to endure through the Winter the presence of the Ohio copperhead, but we must still rejoice that he -- the man who was fitly honored by having a rebel camp named after him, whose praise is in the mouths of all traitors, whose name is an abomination to all loyal men, who has given no vote which would by any contingency be unpleasing to the rebels, or would give aid and comfort to his own country in her hour of need, the appropriate fellow of the traitor BRECKINRIDGE when he was glorified by the rebels of Baltimore, the man whose speeches ran through the whole scale of covert, cowardly treason, the whole Vallandigham set, as it may well be called, -- this man has been thoroughly defeated, and consigned to that oblivion to which all those sympathizers with rebellion are surely going.
headline: {'main': 'A SILVER LINING.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A SILVER LINING.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The auction rooms of Messrs. COBR, SINTON & BOND were filled with an anxious and expectant crowd yesterday, on the occasion of the sale of the extensive city real property owned by the late D.C. BRODERICK. The bidding was spirited throughout, and the aggregate of sales amounted to $170,350. The terms of sale, as announced, were 10 per cent. down, and the balance on confirmation of sale by the Probate Court and delivery of deeds. Portions of the Red House tract, on Mission and Howard streets, brought remarkably good prices, probably for homesteads. The water lots, too, sold well, and property on Market-street seemed especially sought after by bidders.

abstract: Editorial on plans for establishing well-supplied hospital corps
snippet: Editorial on plans for establishing well-supplied hospital corps
lead_paragraph: We have spoken recently with some earnestness of the importance of an organized "Ambulance Corps" in the national armies. We rejoice to near that the benevolent private organization which is filing up so many gaps in the medical administration of the Government -- the Sanitary Commission --- is about organizing a species of Ambulance Corps, or Camp Hospital, which must be productive of incalculable good to the army. The members and employes of the Commission have beheld the fearful evils from want of shelter and medical attendance for the wounded, immediately after the battle. Their three wagons, arriving days before the regular army medical supplies, after the battle of Antietam, were a blessing which hundreds of our poor wounded countrymen will never forget, and yet they were a mere drop in the bucket to what was needed by so great a multitude of wounded.
headline: {'main': 'A New Plan for a Camp Hospital.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A New Plan for a Camp Hospital.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are many shades of rebels in the South, and a General who deals with them should be what the Germans call a "manysided" man. Gen. BUTLER approaches very...
lead_paragraph: There are many shades of rebels in the South, and a General who deals with them should be what the Germans call a "manysided" man. Gen. BUTLER approaches very nearly to the required standard of a breaker-in of eccentric and calcitrant natures. What RAREY is among wild horses, this officer is among the rebels of New-Orleans. He is never at a loss when a "case" is brought before him; but, quick as thought, metes out the sentence, which the country approves for its aptness and justice.

abstract: Editorial on need to open up navigation on Mississippi River by taking Vicksburg
snippet: Editorial on need to open up navigation on Mississippi River by taking Vicksburg
lead_paragraph: -- The people of the North western States are loudly demanding that the Government open up to commerce the Mississippi River. They have been deeply disappointed, as indeed the whole country has been, in this matter. The great river was so nearly opened, apparently, in the Spring, that cargoes were put aboard steamers on the Upper Mississippi, to be taken down to the Lower Mississippi; and boats were cheerily advertised to leave "for New-Orleans and intermediate ports" as usual. But the rebels barred our passage at Vicksburgh, and by planting batteries at various points on the shore above and below that town, have shown the difficulties of navigation until the entire stream can be actively patroled by iron-clad gunboats, or the banks are in our hands.

abstract: The most terrible and fatal accident which ever fell upon this community occured on Thursday morning last, and was occasioned by the bursting of one of JAMES' projectiles during experiments in firing. Thirteen individuals were more or less injured, six seriously, two having already died.
lead_paragraph: The most terrible and fatal accident which ever fell upon this community occured on Thursday morning last, and was occasioned by the bursting of one of JAMES' projectiles during experiments in firing. Thirteen individuals were more or less injured, six seriously, two having already died. The instrument of death which opened such heartrending scenes of agony and death was a loaded shell such as is used in the James 12-pound guns, and the accident was the result of an attempt to draw the cap from the plunger with a pair of nippers.

abstract: editorial says Seymour's real issue is slavery question
snippet: editorial says Seymour's real issue is slavery question
lead_paragraph: The strenuous endeavor of the Seymourites is to win votes for their candidate on the ground of love for free speech. They claim for themselves to be its especial champions, and charge upon us that we are endeavoring to overthrow it. The claim comes with a wonderful grace from those who have, for years, relied upon threats and club law, rather than upon argument; who had no word of rebuke for that greatest outrage upon free speech perpetrated by "Congressman BROOKS, that terrible dialectician who refuted Mr. SUMNER by beating him," as says M. LABOULAYE. Capt. RYNDERS, the leader for years of the outrages upon free speech which have disgraced this City, is an appropriate mouthpiece of those who now seek, by appealing, on false pretenses, to this love of the people for freedom of debate, to drive the Republicans from power, in order to place themselves in office, who have systematically sneered at, and over-ridden it, wherever they could.

abstract: As the smoke clears away from the battlefield of Antietam, we have startling revelations of the conduct of men who appeared in response to the call of Surgeon-General HAMMOND for aid in the treatment of the wounded.
lead_paragraph: As the smoke clears away from the battlefield of Antietam, we have startling revelations of the conduct of men who appeared in response to the call of Surgeon-General HAMMOND for aid in the treatment of the wounded. The disclosures are frightful to contemplate -- and we could not give them credit did they not come from eye-witnesses of intelligence and undoubted integrity. It appears that the call of the Surgeon-General for volunteer surgeons, made under circumstances which did not admit long deliberation on his part as to mode and form, or hesitation on the part of those to whom it was addressed, while nobly responded to by numbers of accomplished surgeons, was made the excuse for the appearance on the field of carnage of another and very different class, who were not included in the language or spirit of the official invitation. The Surgeon-General only intended to summon skilled surgeons. He had no thought of asking the presence of the quacks who disgrace the medical profession. But these last flocked to the battle-fields of Maryland with a promptness only surpassed by their professional ignorance. Many of them were men who would have disgraced the medical profession in the days when barbers monopolized the skill and science of the healing and surgical arts. They seized with morbid avidity the opportunity to est their dexterity with the knife, where disgrace would not attend failure, because evidence of their wretched work would be buried in a soldier's grave.

abstract: A SCENE IN THE HARBOR. Yesterday afternoon at three o'clock, a very interesting and animating scene came off in the North River, opposite the Cunard Dock, on the Jersey side.
lead_paragraph: A SCENE IN THE HARBOR. -- Yesterday afternoon at three o'clock, a very interesting and animating scene came off in the North River, opposite the Cunard Dock, on the Jersey side. The French line-of-battle-ship, which has been lying at Quarantine for about a week, wended her way up from thence to the part of the river referred to. The French man of war mounts ninety guns, and closely in the neighborhood lay the Spanish frigate, which mounts fifty guns.
