abstract: -- Benj. F. Harding, who was a short time ago elected United States Senator from Oregon, is a native of Pennsylvania, whence he emigrated to his adopted State in 1819. He located a land claim within ten miles of Salem, at which place he was engaged in his profession of a lawyer. In 1852, he was appointed by President Pierce secretary of the Territory of Oregon, which office he held during the minority of that flourishing State. He was elected a member of the first State Legislature on the Democratic ticket, but was beaten for the Speakership by the candidate of the Lane faction -- W.G.T. Vandt. As a member of the Legislature he contributed much to prevent the reelection to the United States Senate of Delazon Smith, who had signalized his first brief term by selling himself to the support of the Lane faction, Harding was reelected to the Legislature, and was elected Speaker of the Lower House of 1860, with but slight opposition. He engineered the election of Baker and Nosmith to the United States Senate with so much success that many Republicans declared him their choice for Col. Baker's successor in the Senate. Mr. Harding is vet quite a young man. He is not more than thirty-five to thirty-seven years of age, while he has acquired a reputation as one the soundest lawyers and shrewdest politicians on the Pacific coast. His loyalty (as might be inferred from his birthplace) is beyond a doubt; and recently he was appointed by the Administration Quartermaster of the Oregon Volunteer Cavalry Regiment, in which his brother, E.J. Harding, holds a Captaincy. Mr. Harding has ever been a consistent Democrat -- of later years adhering to the Douglas school, finally abandoning party proclivities for the sake of a thorough Union organization.

abstract: Among the loyal general officers who fell in the late battle of Corinth, was Brig.-Gen. PLEASANT A. HACKLEMAN, of Indiana. Previous to the commencement of hostilities he was a lawyer and politician of much promise, and for nearly twenty years edited the Rushville Republican. In 1841 he was elected to the Indiana Legislature as a Whig, after which, for a number of years, he hold the office of Clerk of the Court in his county. In 1847 he was the Whig candidate for Congress, and in 1858 the Republican nominee, but in both elections was defeated. In the Chicago Convention he voted for Mr. LINCOLN, although his preferences were for CASSIUS M. CLAY, for whose character he had a, great admiration. In 1860 he was appointed by the Governor of Indiana a delegate to the famous Border State Peace Convention at Washington. On the outbreak of the rebellion he accepted the position of Colonel of the Sixteenth Indiana, although of Quaker parentage, and a man of Peace by conviction. Before the return of his regiment from the three months' campaign, he offered, in its behalf, to serve for the war, and the Sixteenth was at once accepted, and ordered to report to Gen. BANKS, then on the Upper Potomac. Col. HACKLEMAN himself was appointed Brigadier-General, and ordered to the West, where he served faithfully and with distinction until his untimely death. A learned, dignified and faithful advocate, an upright, well-informed politician, a courteous gentleman, he is regretted by a largo circle of friends, and his loss is severely felt by his native State.

abstract: The most surprising statistical information contained in the invaluable, directory of H.G. LANGLEY, now on the eve of issuance from the press, relates to our population. Of the more than thirty-four thousand names, thirty-two thousand are white males over 21 years of age. This is an increase over the number of last year of four thousand, or nearly nineteen per cent. For the consolation of old bachelors and widowers, we will inform them that the number of females in this city over 18 years is seventeen thousand five hundred; and of damsels "mostly" under this ripe age, over twenty-five thousand. This exhibits an increase of twenty-three hundred of maidens and matrons over 18, or upwards of fifteen per cent. Of girls under 18, the increase is nearly twenty per cent. The annual increase of children to our permanent population exceeds 5,000. According to the census returns of the compiler of the Directory, the total population of the City of San Francisco is set down at 91,825. These figures are founded on the most reliable data, and as the greatest industry and care has been taken to enumerate all the people living in our midst, we believe the returns are as accurate as could be obtained in any other way. The number of white males over 21 -- names in the Directory -- 32,000. The number of females over 18, 17,500. The number of males under 21, and females under 18, 25,000. Males, foreigners, and names refused, 4,200. Chinese, male and female, 3,250. Cofored, 1875. Besides these, there is our great "floating" population, larger, probably, than in any other city of this size in the Union. The number of transcient boarders, soldiers, fresh-water sailors, and others doing business on our Bay waters, besides some who live, like "Bummer and Lazarus," on the town, must amount to at least 8,000, which added to the above figures, gives the [???] of our population at 91,825. The only cities in the United States which can outnumber San Francisco are New-York, 813 668;Philadelphia, 565,531; Brooklyn, 266,661; Baltimore, 212,419; Boston, 177,[???]81; New-Orleans, 168,172; Cincinnati, 161,044; St. Louis, 151,780; Chicago, 109,263. The City of Pittsburgh, with its suburbs, numbers 115,000, but the place proper only, 49,465.Thus it appears that San Francisco, a town virtually but thirteen years old, already ranks as tenth amongst the cities of the United States. In another decade, it is probable, if no unforeseen untoward reverses occur, that this city will have outstripped eight of the ten that now surpass it in population.
lead_paragraph: The most surprising statistical information contained in the invaluable, directory of H.G. LANGLEY, now on the eve of issuance from the press, relates to our population. Of the more than thirty-four thousand names, thirty-two thousand are white males over 21 years of age. This is an increase over the number of last year of four thousand, or nearly nineteen per cent. For the consolation of old bachelors and widowers, we will inform them that the number of females in this city over 18 years is seventeen thousand five hundred; and of damsels "mostly" under this ripe age, over twenty-five thousand. This exhibits an increase of twenty-three hundred of maidens and matrons over 18, or upwards of fifteen per cent. Of girls under 18, the increase is nearly twenty per cent. The annual increase of children to our permanent population exceeds 5,000. According to the census returns of the compiler of the Directory, the total population of the City of San Francisco is set down at 91,825. These figures are founded on the most reliable data, and as the greatest industry and care has been taken to enumerate all the people living in our midst, we believe the returns are as accurate as could be obtained in any other way. The number of white males over 21 -- names in the Directory -- 32,000. The number of females over 18, 17,500. The number of males under 21, and females under 18, 25,000. Males, foreigners, and names refused, 4,200. Chinese, male and female, 3,250. Cofored, 1875. Besides these, there is our great "floating" population, larger, probably, than in any other city of this size in the Union. The number of transcient boarders, soldiers, fresh-water sailors, and others doing business on our Bay waters, besides some who live, like "Bummer and Lazarus," on the town, must amount to at least 8,000, which added to the above figures, gives the [???] of our population at 91,825. The only cities in the United States which can outnumber San Francisco are New-York, 813 668;Philadelphia, 565,531; Brooklyn, 266,661; Baltimore, 212,419; Boston, 177,[???]81; New-Orleans, 168,172; Cincinnati, 161,044; St. Louis, 151,780; Chicago, 109,263. The City of Pittsburgh, with its suburbs, numbers 115,000, but the place proper only, 49,465.Thus it appears that San Francisco, a town virtually but thirteen years old, already ranks as tenth amongst the cities of the United States. In another decade, it is probable, if no unforeseen untoward reverses occur, that this city will have outstripped eight of the ten that now surpass it in population.

abstract: The loyal people of Carter County have seen hard times during the past fortnight, On the 1st inst., Col. S. EIFORT received information that the town of Grayson had been taken by the rebels on the previous evening. Arrangements were speedily effected to guard all the roads leading from Grayson to Boone Furnace and Olive Hill; 200 men were posted on the State road from Grayson to Owingsville, 75 on the road leading to the Furnace, while about 100 were placed on another road, leading to the same point, and 60 held [???]. During the day it became known that the rebels [???] 1,000 strong were coming up, and, as [???] were not known, a close watch was [???] their movements. About sundown the whole party left Grayson by way of Olive Hill, and encamped some ten miles distant, at the Bull's Eye Spring. Their pickets advanced as far as Tyart Creek Bridge, within musket shot of the Home Guard pickets. In the morning the rebels advanced and commenced destroying property by burning houses, hay, and grain-stacks for a distance of ten miles along the State Road. At Olive Hill they burned the house and store of Hon. WM. C. GRIER, State Senator, taking his sick wife out of doors and making him a prisoner. The fight at this time had become general between the Home Guards and the rebels, the latter having been bushwacked from all sides, and losing some thirty killed between Olive Hill and Graver's Hill. From this point to the head of Tyart's Creek they fell into the hands of GEORGE UNDERWOOD, with another Home Guard, and he made them leave at double quick, killing forty or fifty of their number. Whenever the scoundrels would get surrounded, they would hoist a white flag, but this shameful trick was soon found out, and UNDERWOOD gave orders not to respect it. The rebels burned forty-five houses in a distance of ten miles, and all the forage and grain. We are hapsy to state that Mr. GRIER made his escape in the confusion.

abstract: -- About 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in some stables at the rear of No. 85 Pitts-street. The stables were owned and occupied by G.J. CRUMMELL. Loss, $1,000; no insurance. AUGUSTUS BUSH, who occupied the front premises, sustained slight damage to stock; insured for $800. ELIAS SHIRES of No. 208 Rivington-street, sustained a loss of $500 on tobacco; no insurance.

abstract: We gave on Saturday the particulars of the capture by KIRBY SMITH's rebel forces near Lawrenceburgh, Anderson County, of a number of wagons belonging to Gen. DUMONT's supply train, and a party of straggling soldiers. We have since met several gentlemen who fell into the hands of the rebel cavalry. The wagons captured belonged for the most part to sutlers, many of whom lost large amounts of goods, as their stocks had recently been replenished.

abstract: - A concert was given in Hamilton, C.W., last week, by the boy pianist, WILLIE BARNSMORE PAPE. The Spectator, speaking of his performance, says: "He is a wonderfully precocious lad. He led captive an appreciative audience in our good city, on Thursday evening, and entertained them with his extraordinary powers. The wonder is, how a mere boy of some twelve years could have obtained such a command of the instrument; and we are sure that none present were unmoved by the seeming talismanic influence he wielded. We have heard THALBERG and GOTTSCHALK, but WILLIE PAPE pleases us better, because he does not attempt any high flights, or mystify his audience. His 'Home, Sweet Home,' and 'Last Hope,' fairly electrified his hearers, and great was the applause that followed the rendition of them. WILLIE PAPE is truly a prodigy of no ordinary kind."

abstract: Although the recent rumors concerning winter quarters for the Army of the Potomac are beginning to be merged in appearances of a general forward movement, there is yet so much of disaster to our cause to be apprehended from possible delay, that we must again urge the intense desire of the people to see the enemy "driven to the wall."
lead_paragraph: Although the recent rumors concerning winter quarters for the Army of the Potomac are beginning to be merged in appearances of a general forward movement, there is yet so much of disaster to our cause to be apprehended from possible delay, that we must again urge the intense desire of the people to see the enemy "driven to the wall." We do not, indeed, suppose that our Generals in the field contemplate a state of inactivity for the Winter; we are certain the President desires nothing and expects nothing save the most energetic operations against the rebel army; -- nevertheless, past experience teaches us that delays come when least probable to the civilian comprehension. And now, when so much depends upon the quick pursuit, defeat, and disporsion of LEE's main army, we shall be excused for the expression of some anxiety as to the movements of our forces.

abstract: Among the  BEEF FOR THE REBEL ARMY. Among the  advantages which the rebels have gained by Gen. BUELL's permitting them so long to occupy Eastern Kentucky, is the large supplies of beef cattle they have obtained from that region.
lead_paragraph: Among the advantages which the rebels have gained by Gen. BUELL's permitting them so long to occupy Eastern Kentucky, is the large supplies of beef cattle they have obtained from that region. Previous to that time the rebels were very hard up for beef or flesh of any kind. Virginia, North Carolina and Tennessee were pretty much eaten out in this article, and supplies from Texas have latterly been exceedingly precarious.

abstract: John K. Imlay, by John Imlay, Guardian, vs. Thomas Fogge. -- This was an action of assault and battery. It appeared by the evidence on the part of the plaintiff, that the plaintiff, a boy, about seventeen years of age, was, on the 14th of June, 1861, employed at No. 72 Charles-street, when the defendant came upon the premises with a dog, and desired that it should have a fight with another dog which was then on the premises. Plaintiff objected, when some words ensued as to the fighting qualities of the two dogs, defendant insisting that his dog could whip the other. The proprietor uf the place ordered defendant to leave the premises. In the course of the conversation in response to an inquiry of the defendant, the plaintiff said he thought the dog belonging to the place could whip defendants dog and him too. Upon this, the defendant is alleged to have struck the plaintiff with his list, got him down, and kicked him with considerable violence. Defendant was taken away from the plaintiff by some of the bystanders.

abstract: Indian tragedies continue on the Northern Emi- grant route, as well as in Minnesota. Mr. W.H. GROVES and a party of seven dropped into this city on Saturday. Traveling by starlight and in by-paths or no paths, they managed to miss their Indian friends, and avoided delay and loss on that account. The party sighted about seven hundred emigrant wagons, whose destination was for the most part the gold-fields north.

abstract: Major JACK TRAINOR, of the Louisville Legion, with a detachment of six men from the Legion and six cavalrymen, arrived in the city last evening from Perryville with 131 prisoners, a portion of the rebels taken at Perryville on Wednesday last. There are five Lieutenants in the party, as follows: P.D. SAYRE, and EDWARD SCOTT, of Gen. ADAM's Staff. W.A. JAMES, of the First Alabama Cavalry; T.M. BLAIR, of the celebrated Washington Artillery, of New-Orleans, and F.G. HOLLIDAY, of the Twenty-fourth Mississippi Infantry. The whole number had been paroled by Gen. BUELL, and are subject to exchange. They were quartered at the Broadway Prison. The yarty marched on foot from Perryville to Bardstown, and were furnished transportation from Bardstown to this city. The officers speak in the highest terms of the treatment extended to themselves and men since their departure from Perryville.

abstract: photographs of Antietam battle dead on view at NYC gallery; on photographs of dead at Antietam now on display at his NYC gallery
snippet: photographs of Antietam battle dead on view at NYC gallery; on photographs of dead at Antietam now on display at his NYC gallery
lead_paragraph: The living that throng Broadway care little perhaps for the Dead at Antietam, but we fancy they would jostle less carelessly down the great thoroughfare, saunter less at their ease, were a few dripping bodies, fresh from the field, laid along the pavement. There would be a gathering up of skirts and a careful picking of way; conversation would be less lively, and the general air of pedestrians more subdued. As it is, the dead of the battle-field come up to us very rarely, even in dreams. We see the list in the morning paper at breakfast, but dismiss its recollection with the coffee. There is a confused mass of names, but they are all strangers; we forget the horrible significance that dwells amid the jumble of type. The roll we read is being called over in Eternity, and pale, trembling lips are answering to it. Shadowy fingers point from the page to a field where even imagination is loth to follow. Each of these little names that the printer struck off so lightly last night, whistling over his work, and that we speak with a clip of the tongue, represents a bleeding, mangled corpse. It is a thunderbolt that will crash into some brain -- a dull, dead, remorseless weight that will full upon some heart, straining it to breaking. There is nothing very terrible to us, however, in in the list, though our sensations might be different if the newspaper carrier left the names on the battle-field and the bodies at our doors instead.

abstract: The war is very nearly ended in the Southwest, and that, too, with the utter destruction of the rebels--if, (yes, if) our Generals and statesmen comprehend their true situation. I always feel mortified to put this if in--but you, as well as I, hare learned by hard experience, that an if lies in the way of all our Generalship.

abstract: FUNERAL CEREMONIES--Burial of a Soldier-- The remains of the late Corporal JOHN B. TOUHEY, of the Brooklyn Fourteenth Regiment, who died in the Union Hospital at Georgetown, D.C., from wounds received in the battle of Manassas Plains, were yesterday consigned to their final resting place in the Cemetery of the Holy Cross, Flatbush.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL CEREMONIES -- Burial of a Soldier. -- The remains of the late Corporal JOHN B. TOUHEY, of the Brooklyn Fourteenth Regiment, who died in the Union Hospital at Georgetown, D.C., from wounds received in the battle of Manassas Plains, were yesterday consigned to their final resting place in the Cemetery of the Holy Cross, Flatbush. The deceased was a member of Hose Company No. 7, and the members of that and several other companies escorted the body to the grave, preceded by a band of music playing the "Dead March." The furloughed members and new recruits of the Fourteenth, now in the city, acted as a guard of honor. The funeral services were conducted by Rev. Father MCDONALD, at the St. James Cathedral, in Jay-street, who spoke in high terms of the character of deceased, and his bravery as a soldier.

abstract: There is no word that so completely expresses the duty of the Government toward the rebellion as the word "crush." To conquer will not do; for a conquered spirit may gather new courage after the lapse of time, and fight again. It will not do to conciliate or appease; for such treatment involves no destruction of the principle of treason, but is rather a recognition of its rightful existence, entitling it to consideration and mercy. In the first case, or the last, the revolt is merely suspended, and may break forth again any time, involving the nation in the same horrible strife that now afflicts it. The rebellion must be crushed. There is annihilation in that phrase that implies no resurrection of the offending arm. An adder may be called conquered, if his aimless dart of poisoned fangs is rewarded with a blow that drives him writhing to his hole. But if his head be crushed by the club, there is an end of him. His carcass rots above ground, and his poison sinks harmless through the sod into Nature's alembic.

abstract: -- It was about this time last year that the public were comforted by the story that Gen. MCCLELLAN's army was waiting for the leaves to fall, so that our men might be able to see the enemy upon whom they were to bring to bear their musketry, artillery and bayonets. The story was a capital one, and relieved the popular impatience until such time as the leaves fell, which, in turn, was followed by that period of moral and material mud, in which the nation and the army stuck so long. We have not heard anything of the Virginia leaves falling this year yet as an excuse for delay; but a Washington telegram the other day solemnly announced that our army was waiting for shoes before it attempted to advance. That yarn is not near as good as the one of last year; for last year's left the time indefinite, inasmuch as it depended upon a slow natural phenomenon: but we suppose it car be demonstrated that, Lynn and Boston could shoe all MCCLELLAN's troops in three or four days, at the end of which time a bran new excuse will have to be invented. While the army, however, is waiting for new brogans, we suggest that Government examine, and see that each man of it is supplied with pantaloons; for the weather will soon be so cold, that if it is discovered they are without that article of clothing, it will be impossible for a single regiment to advance -- except, of course, the gallant Seventy-ninth New-York Highlanders, who go into battle without breeches. Let all these matters be attended to at once, and quickly; and then, let our army, with its new shoes, kick the rebels southward till they are beyond the furthest limits of the Confederacy.

abstract: -- More than once since the war began, the wavering courage of the nation has been rallied by the promptness and enthusiasm of the Empire State. Just after the outgoing of BUCHANAN's Administration, when the Treasury was exhausted by the sudden and enormous demands upon it, before any financial system was devised for the support of the war, and while the Government itself seemed bardly stable and coherent enough to justify any trust in its financial engagements, then it was that New-York City came forward, and, by a loan of fifty millions of dollars to Mr. CHASE, restored confidence at home and abroad. It is no exaggeration to say that this early negotiation did more to revive the spirits of the people, and restore their confidence in the vitality and ultimate preservation of the Union, than any victory in the field would then have done. And as it was reanimating to the loyal North, to an equal degree was it discouraging to the rebellious States, and to their allies abroad. It had been thought by them tha the United States would have to rely on foreign capitalists for money to carry on the war; and the London Times, of that day, contained frequent and earnest warnings to the British public not to take any of the loans that the United States would be anxious to negotiate! But the Bankers of New-York City renewed their faith in and their allegiance to the Government of the United States by pouring out their treasures in its service, and from that [???] the Republic lived again and draw to itself the support of the [???] of people.

abstract: --Mystery is the great staple of novel writers, especially of those of the female persuasion. These latter transfer the veil from their own faces to shroud the characters they invent.
lead_paragraph: -- Mystery is the great staple of novel writers, especially of those of the female persuasion. These latter transfer the veil from their own faces to shroud the characters they invent. At every turn and corner of their stories they mystify the reader by all manner of weak devices, pointing in a different direction from that they actually intend to take, flitting before you with simulated lameness, like the lapwing, to lead you away from the nest where their young brood of callow secrets lie. Of this art, Mrs. HENRY WOOD is the high handmaiden. She moves in a more mysterious way her wonders to perform than our own FERNANDO does. Her characters go through her stories as ships in crowded seas glide around in a fog, ringing bells to keep out of each other's way and carefully avoiding a meeting. Her last work, very properly christined The Mystery, is published by PETERSON & BRO., of Philadelphia, from advance sheets, for which a fabulous price is said to have been paid. The story is an ingenious one, and well managed in the main. A murder is committed, without any adequate motive on the part of the murderer, and the blood is sprinkled around in such a mysterious manner, that it is difficult to fasten it to the skirts of any one. A little girl, in a very innocent manner, manages to be everywhere where she should not be, and to hear everything that was least intended for her to hear. Were she not more retentive of talk than most young ladies are, she might set a great deal of doubt and trouble at rest in the early part of the story; but she preserves a most remarkable reticence, and permits the characters to go knocking their heads against each other, as awkward people do in dancing the Lancers. She is a very remarkable little girl, indeed, and eventually a most exceptional young lady. Truth compels the admission that Mrs. WOOD weaves quite an exciting and interesting chain of narrative from what seems at first glance to be rather slender material, though most readers will guess what is behind the mask long before the authoress removes it.

abstract: editorial says election of Seymour party, not European intervention in war, is what Union has to fear; editorial sees armies occupying relatively same positions as they did 1 yr. ago
snippet: editorial says election of Seymour party, not European intervention in war, is what Union has to fear; editorial sees armies occupying relatively same positions as they did 1 yr. ago
lead_paragraph: The election of Mr. SEYMOUR would do more to encourage the seceded States and prolong the war than their immediate recognition by Europe would. In the inception of the rebellion, Northern weakness was counted upon as an element of Southern strength. It was very lightly argued that a divided North could not stand against a united South. Nor could it. But hitherto there has been no division among our people. They have been a unit in their opposition to rebellion -- twenty million hearts have beat as one. The only chance for division has now occurred. The installation of a Republican Administration, a professed distrust of its supposed policy -- these were the pretexts the South offered in justification of its revolt. Were New-York to proclaim by its November vote that it too differed from the Administration and elected to oppose its necessary measures, it would be regarded by the revolted States as the first outcropping of Northern sympathy, the first indication of that disunitedness upon which they relied more than upon their armies when the skeleton of secession was first chalked out upon the cabinet walls of a Pro-Slavery President. It would be regarded by them as a virtual acknowledgment of the right of their rebellion -- for they only differed from the Administration in a slightly greater degree, and proclaimed that difference with more boldness, than New-York would in making such an election.

abstract: We have again a repetition of the reports that Winchester is being evacuated by the rebels--this time brought to Gen. SIGEL'S headquarters by deserters and refuges.
lead_paragraph: We have again a repetition of the reports that Winchester is being evacuated by the rebels--this time brought to Gen. SIGEL'S headquarters by deserters and refuges. These reports are given some plausibility by the fact that Leesburgh has already been evacuated, as ascertained by a reconnoissance on Friday and Saturday. Measures, we are assured, are being taken to ascertain the truth. The reports of the evacuation obtain considerable credence in Washington, though some of the military authorities are inclined to doubt them, and still believe that LEE intends to wait in the vicinity of the Potomac for an attack from MCCLELLAN -- believing that a retreat would prove more disastrous to the rebels than a battle.

abstract: Up to Saturday night there had not been, during the present season, a new piece produced at any of the leading theatres. Mr. WALLACK has pinned his faith entirely on the old comedies, whilst at Niblo's and the Winter Garden there has been no variety but that afforded by a judicious nightly change from one legitimate tragedy to another.
lead_paragraph: Up to Saturday night there had not been, during the present season, a new piece produced at any of the leading theatres. Mr. WALLACK has pinned his faith entirely on the old comedies, whilst at Niblo's and the Winter Garden there has been no variety but that afforded by a judicious nightly change from one legitimate tragedy to another. This is a very excellent and inexpensive species of success so far as the managers are concerned, especially when the public seems to be content as well as generously patronizing. Yet the interests of dramatic art demand the occasional production of original pieces, either native or imported -- the former in preference, of course, if they can by any possibility be obtained. Standard pieces are all very well in their way, but the drama, like all living institutions requires now and then an infusion of new blood to sustain its vitality and preserve it from stagnation. Mr. WALLACK, recognizing this fact, and, as usual, becoming the exemplar of an enlightened change of policy, this evening brings out a comedy never before acted in this country. Called "Friends and Foes" when first presented in London, it has here been rechristened "Bosom Friends," the alteration of name being justified by the remodeling which the piece has undergone at the lands of Mr. [???] WALLACK. The English chapter of the piece [???] not feel aggrieved at this [???] on his literary patent; at least until he has accounted to the author for the liberties he took with the French original. "Bosom Friends" is [???] to be a very charming comedy; a [???], of [???] and humor; of the [???] known to be so surely popular when placed by Mr. WALLACK's company. One reason why Mr. WALLACK has [???] "Bosom Friends" for his first novelty is the opportunity which is affords him of [???] in its performs [???] the test [???] in his company, Mr. [???], Mrs. [???] and Mrs. [???] WALLACK' Mr. FISHER, Mr. JOHN GILBERT, Mr. REYNOLDS, Mr. [???] and Mr. JOHN SEFTON all have parts in it. It is Mr. WALLACK's intention to alternate a few choice new pieces with the old comedies, until some new play that shall have stamina enough to fill his theatre upon its merits, shall chance to come into his hands.

abstract: Editorial on Union increase of cavalry
snippet: Editorial on Union increase of cavalry
lead_paragraph: Squadrons of light horse, well mounted, thoroughly disciplined, and officered by capable men, are useful under any circumstances; but in an offensive war, when the population is not actively friendly, the occasions for employing cavalry to advantage are innumerable. They occupy, as has been remarked by JOMINI, as important a place in an offensive campaign, as do corps of partisan rangers in a defensive war. They fulfill almost the same functions, hanging on the flanks or rear of the enemy, cutting off his supplies, deranging his combinations, harassing him night and day, discovering his weakest points, threatening his communications, and exhausting his forces by necessitating a strong convoy for every train of ammunition or provisions.

abstract: We are not informed in any order from Gen. ANTHON as to his intentions regarding the observance of the provisions established by the General Government for the protection of exempts. If we read those provisions rightly, it is expressly stated that a specified period is allowed all drafted persons who claim exemption from draft in which to establish their exemption, while Gen. ANTHON gives the public to understand that claims must be put in before the day of draft.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: The Seymourites of this State love to style themselves Conservatives. They are somewhat chary of the old appellation of Democrats. Seeing that the leading portion of the old party of that name are now in armed rebellion, and that its best portion are now staunch supporters of the Government in distinction from themselves, and mindful too of the prejudices of their old foes, and present allies, the Know-Nothings, they rather shun a designation so unpleasantly suggestive, and take to one of a little more attractive east. They fancy that they gain a point in adopting a name usually connected with respectability.
headline: {'main': 'Seymourism as Conservatism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Seymourism as Conservatism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: In behalf of a suffering National Treasury, we protest against the further consideration of schemes for sending the newly enfranchised blacks to foreign colonies. Every day we see the engineering appliances of these gigantic jobs peering through the Washington dispatches. They have been exposed and exploded, and it is time they were abandoned.

abstract: PERSONAL--Lord ERNEST VANE TEMPEST, bet  ter known as Capt. CHARLES STEWART, will leave today en route for home. Capt. STEWART has been in the United States service since the opening of the war. When Gen. STONE was appointed to his command Capt. STEWART was made his Adjutant-General, in which capacity he discharged with credit the onerous duties assigned him.
lead_paragraph: PERSONAL -- Lord ERNEST VANE TEMPEST, bet ter known as Capt. CHARLES STEWART, will leave today en route for home. Capt. STEWART has been in the United States service since the opening of the war. When Gen. STONE was appointed to his command Capt. STEWART was made his Adjutant-General, in which capacity he discharged with credit the onerous duties assigned him. His conduct at the battle of Ball's Bluff merited and received the personal thanks of Gen. MCCLELLAN, then Commander-in-Chief. At the time of Gen. STONE's removal, believing that officer to be unjustly dealt with, and unwilling to serve under another, he resigned his commission, and although tendered the Coloney of one of our finest infantry regiments, declined continuing in the service.

abstract: One hundred and fifty recruits arrived on the Baltimore boat this morning. They are for several different regiments in this vicinity. The same boat also brought down 224 rebel prisoners from Fort McHenry, who were taken at South Mountain and Antietam. They came in charge of A.H. LINDSEY, of the Eighteenth Connecticut Regiment. The prison  ers belong in Virginia and Louisiana, and left here for Aiken's Landing at 12 o'clock on the steamboat New--York.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. The Movements in State Politics, with the Election returns from all the States so far as received will be found in this morning issue. The Sixth of Mr. HURLBERT's Series of Letters appears in the current number. All official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic inter[???]. compiled from sources many of which, are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths or the week.

abstract: There are at present in this City some five or six gentlemen, from as many States now in rebellion against the Government, who are perfecting arrangements to hold a meeting of all Union-loving citizens, either at the end of this or the beginning of next week, at which they propose to give their views in relation to the conduct of the war. Gen. PRENTISS will probably be present, and Col. HAMILTON will certainly be. These gentlemen are all expatriated citizens, and may be understood to know whereof they affirm.

abstract: Editorial likens Harpers Ferry, Va, surrender to Confederates with siege of Grave during 16th century revolt against Spain; Editorial on types of guns used by Confederates
snippet: Editorial likens Harpers Ferry, Va, surrender to Confederates with siege of Grave during 16th century revolt against Spain; Editorial on types of guns used by Confederates
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe two days later are received by the steamship Bavaria, which passed Cape Race on Sunday afternoon. She left Southampton on the 8th inst. The President's Emancipation Proclamation had reached England, and of course received much attention. The London Times does not question the right of the President to issue it, but insists that he is without the power to enforce his decree. The North, it thinks, must conquer every square mile of the South before it can make the proclamation of more effect than mere waste paper. The Iowa, heavily laden with stores for the rebels, was run into by another vessel in the Clyde, and sunk. The French Gen. CHANGARNIER had taken the trouble to deny the truth of a rumor that he had been offered the command of the National forces by President LINCOLN. Letters have been received in Paris from Vera Cruz, which give different accounts of affairs in Mexico from those published in the French papers. According to these accounts, the French will not have an easy road to travel to the Mexican Capital. JUAREZ is preparing for a desperate resistance; the City of Mexico is strongly fortified, and the advance from Orizaba will be disputed inch by inch. GARIBALDI and his followers, as we were led to expect by previous advices, have been granted an amnesty by King VICTOR EMANUEL, exception being made in the cases of deserters from the royal army. The Liverpool Cotton market was buoyant, and an advance had taken place on all varieties. Breadstuffs were steady, and Provisions dull. Consols were quoted at 94 1/8 for Money.

abstract: rioting reported at Hyde Park, Eng, pro-Garibaldi meeting
snippet: rioting reported at Hyde Park, Eng, pro-Garibaldi meeting
lead_paragraph: Hyde-park yesterday was the scene of a riot far exceeding in magnitude and in its serious consequences that which took place on the previous Sunday. In consequence of the interruption there was to the meeting of sympathy with GARIBALDI by a body of Irish roughs, and who succeded in thwarting the object of its conveners, large bodies of working-men had given notice to the committee that they intended being present in the park yesterday and supporting them at all [???]. The committee, not feeling justified in incurring the responsibility of calling a second meeting for yesterday, when a collision was likely to ensue, determined to abandon their intention to hold the meeting, and during last, week issued a notice to that effect. The publicity given through the Press to last Sunday's proceedings, however, combined with the fact that the abandonment of the meeting had not become generally known, caused an immense assemblage in the park yesterday. Before 2 o'clock all the principal thoroughfares lending to Hyde Park were crowded with persons proceeding toward it, many of them carrying thick sticks, and by 3 o'clock the police on duty estimated that at least 100,000 persons had passed through the park gates. As on the previous Sunday, the mound of earth near the marble arch was the centre of attraction, and at an early hour of the afternoon it was taken possession of by a body of about three hundred Irish laborers, armed with bludgeons, who at once raised the cry of "Three cheers for the Pope, and down with GARIBALDI." immediately surrounding this mound were stationed about 500 more of the same class similarly armed, and who openly expressed their intention to oppose by force any meeting being held in favor of GARIBALDI. It soon became rumored through the crowd that the Committee did not intend holding any meeting, and while many approved of this decision, by far the the greater number expressed much disappointment. On its becoming known to the Irish party on and about the mound, they set up a loud shout, and began taunting the Garibaldian party for their cowardice. A working man who, unperceived by the Irish, had made his way on to the mound, here rushed to the front, and, waving his hat, and holding aloft a board with the name of GARIBALDI painted upon it, called upon the vast mass of people in front and around the mound to give three cheers for the Italian patriot, which appeal was responded to by a tremendous burst of cheering from the assembled thousands. In an instant a dozen of the Irish bludgeons rattled about the head of the Garibaldian champion, and he was hurled from the mound bleeding profusely. This was the first act of violence committed, and was followed by a desperate rush of the Garibaldians upon the Irishmen, who, from the advantageous position they held, their determination, and the free use of their gudgets, succeeded in beating back their assailants, but few of whom had anything but Nature's weapons at their command. Just at this time a body of powerful Irish laborers and others came upon the ground, all armed with sticks, and ought their way up to their country [???], who, thus reinforced, and emboldened by their recent triumph, with loud hurrahs for the Pope, made a desperate [???] the crowd, knocking down indiscrimination, men, women, and children, amongst others two or three soldiers of the [???] who seemed in especial object of dislike to the Irishmen. The Garibaldians, irritated at this [???] and ruffianly attack, and headed by about twenty soldier, who had [???] to the aid of their [???] fought their way up to the [???] did after a severe straggle with the Irishmen ranged [???] succeeded in obtaining a [???] upon [???] now became one of great excitement. The soldiers, who were armed with sticks supplied [???] the crowd, amid the cheering of the Garibaldians and the yells and shouting of the Irish, laid about them with unsparing vigor. The blows from the sticks [???] blood began to flow [???] from the leads of both parties. Each soldier had at least a dozen assailants to contend with [???] of whom were evidently expert at the use of their weapons, and possessed of sufficient bulldog ferocity to make them most formidable opponents. At least a dozen men were lying at this time bleeding and senseless on the top of the mound, and the soldiers were on the point of being overpowered by numbers, when about half a dozen of the Life Guards, about the same number of the Third Buffs, followed by a body of at least fifty working men with sticks and umbrellas, rushed on to the mound and turned the tide of victory. After a terrific melee of about five minutes the Irish gave way, and made a precipitate retreat from their position. One soldier of the Third Buffs, a short thickset man, armed with a piece of park rail, knocked down six of the Irishmen in succession, receiving in return a severe wound in the forehead. As the Irishmen were beaten from the mound, the people below seized upon those who had made themselves must conspicuous, and dragged them to the outskirts of the crowd, and gave them in charge to the policemen, several of whom were there stationed, but with orders not to interfere unless under the personal orders of the Commissioner. Those who were identified as having taken an active part in the first onslaught upon the people were at once taken off to the Station-house. The Garibaldians and the solders being now in possession of the mound, one of the soldiers was hoisted on the shoulders of his comrades, and said if any of the Committee were present who called the meeting last Sunday, and wished to propose a resolution in favor of GARIBALDI, the soldiers would form a circle around the mound, and guarantee them a hearing. No one, however, responded to this appeal, but it gave rise to one of the greatest bursts of cheers that ever resounded in Hyde Park, followed by more cheers for the army. The Irish, now driven from the mound, and rendered perfectly infuriate by their defeat in that quarter, formed themselves into several detached bodies of about 200 each, and forcing their way into the crowd in different directions, began striking at all within their reach. It was estimated that there was at this time 200,000 people assembled, and the wishes of one portion of the crowd to escape the blows of these ruffians, the determined stand made against them by other portions, the shouts of the men, the shrieks of the women, and the cries of the juveniles, presented a scene of the most alarming description. Sticks were being used, and stones were flying in all directions, and at least 2,000 people were battling in different parts of the park. In some cases knives were used, and several persons were taken off the ground who had been stabbed. About 500 soldiers were now mixed up in the crowd, great numbers of whom were fighting against the Irishmen, who at last were overpowed, and fled in all directions, many of them meeting with knots of Garibaldians, by whom they were severely maltreated. Sir R. MAYNE and Capt. HARRIS, the Commissioners of Police, now came upon the ground, and it getting dusk, and seeing the alarming state of affairs, dispatched a constable to the Wellington Barracks for a strong picket of the Fusileers, about fifty of whom, under the command of an officer, but without arms, speedily attended, one party taking cossession of the mound, and the other ordering the soldiers into barracks. A strong body of the Division of Police, who had been kept in reserve in the Marble-Arch, were also brought on the ground under the command of Capt. HARRIS. These measures combined with the retreat of the Irishmen, and the approach of dusk, put a stop to the proceedings, and the people gradually left the park, which became quite cleared by 8 o'clock. A large number of persons were severely injured during the afternoon, and the various surgeries in the neighborhood were crowded with parties waiting to have their wounds dressed. It is to be hoped the authorities will take measures to prevent any repetition of these disgraceful doings next Sunday.

abstract: Editorial on armored ships and artillery used to penetrate them
snippet: Editorial on armored ships and artillery used to penetrate them
lead_paragraph: The cheapest way of solving a problem is, undoubtedly, to pronounce it insoluble, and as intellectual fatigue is a leading characteristic of the present age, we ought not to be surprised at seeing this royal road to repose adopted all over the world, in regard to questions which would tax the brains of the now traditional statesmen, and which naturally, therefore, appeal to the actual politician. In matters social and economical this method of dealing with difficulties may not, perhaps, be absolutely ruinous, since man's incapacity may well prove, after all, to be Heaven's opportunity. But material science is a remorseless prosecutor of impossibilities. The abstract love of truth, the artistic passion which grows with practice, mere personal ambition, and the thirst for wealth -- all conspire to make acquiescence hopeless at any stage of scientific achievement. We may be certain, therefore, that, nothing being yet absolutely settled by the long duel between artillery and armor, everything put at issue in that duel must be regarded as absolutely unsettled, and we must be careful not to suffer ourselves to be lulled into the delusion that the astonishing results of our recent experience with the Monitor, the Merrimac, and the Arkansas, have done anything more than communicate a new impulse to the ancient conflict.

abstract: Intimations too numerous and reliable to be disregarded, come to us daily, that the rebels are straining every nerve to equip and arm powerful steamers to prey upon our commerce, and a foretaste of the results likely to follow their endeavors, is given us in the exploits of ...
lead_paragraph: Intimations too numerous and reliable to be disregarded, come to us daily, that the rebels are straining every nerve to equip and arm powerful steamers to prey upon our commerce, and a foretaste of the results likely to follow their endeavors, is given us in the exploits of the Alabama, which has been destroying defenceless whalers and merchant vessels in the neighborhood of the Azores. As we have already urged, the English shipbuilders to the Confederate Government do not make and execute contracts out of sympathy with the "struggling republic." John Bull does not do business in that way; "cash down" is the basis of all his transactions, particularly when the credit of his customer is not first-rate. But Confederate bonds do not appear upon the lists of stocks sold in the English market, and it is therefore clear that cotton must be the sole medium of exchange between Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS and his "neutral" allies in the British isles. By preventing the shipment of this staple, then, the growth of the Confederate navy will be suddenly checked.

abstract: THE SIXTH SENATORIAL MILITARY COMMITTEE, COL. ETHAN ALLEN.--This Committee, to whom the Governor of the State has delegated the control of he military matters of this Senatorial District, met on Monday at their rooms at the City Library, City Hall.
lead_paragraph: THE SIXTH SENATORIAL MILITARY COMMITTEE, COL. ETHAN ALLEN. -- This Committee, to whom the Governor of the State has delegated the control of he military matters of this Senatorial District, met on Monday at their rooms at the City Library, City Hall. There were present, Geo. W. Blunt, Senator Bradley, Peter Copper, Alex. T. Stewart, Geo. Opdyke, John A. Foster, Gen. P. N. Wetmore, Brig.Gen. Spicer, James W. Farr, and others. It was debated how the number of volunteers could be increased and the prospects of the draft diminished. This Committee has subscribed thousands of dollars to the war, and raised and placed two regiments in the field. It was unanimously resolved that ETHAN ALLEN, Esq., as Colonel, be requested and authorized to raise a regiment, to be added to the Mercantile Brigade. In the hands of a young and enthusiastic officer, there is time and opportunity to fill a regiment yet before the draft; and if by that time the regiment should not be filled, all the men recruited, whether few or many, can be turned over to new regiments.

abstract: There have been rumors  for some days, both here and at Washington, that JEFF. DAVIS had made certain proposals for peace, or, at least, for a truce, to our Government; and it has even been put forth by a semi-secession organ, that the reason of...
lead_paragraph: There have been rumors for some days, both here and at Washington, that JEFF. DAVIS had made certain proposals for peace, or, at least, for a truce, to our Government; and it has even been put forth by a semi-secession organ, that the reason of Gen. MCCLELLAN's delay at Harper's Ferry was, not that-his army was waiting to be shod, but that the result of the negotiations might be ascertained. The rumor of rebel proposals for peace receives a sort of confirmation from recent debates in the Confederate Congress at Richmond, as well as from the words of the rebel officer who sent in a flag of truce to Gen. BUELL, on the 9th inst., asking "a suspension of hostilities until they should hear the result of the mission of the Pence Commissioners, whom the Confederate Government was about to send to Washington."Statements of this kind have abounded of late, and the rebel newspapers, also -- allowing Confederate Senator FOOTE -- have claimed that so complete was the humiliation of the Union Government and army, that they were only too glad to have such offers made.

abstract: The late  unauthorized publication by JOHN VAN BUREN of Gen. SCOTT'S letter to Mr. SEWARD has called forth from the illustrious old soldier a vindication of his position on the secession movement in its early days.
lead_paragraph: The late unauthorized publication by JOHN VAN BUREN of Gen. SCOTT'S letter to Mr. SEWARD has called forth from the illustrious old soldier a vindication of his position on the secession movement in its early days. The document will be found in full in the TIMES of this morning, and will undoubtedly attract universal attention. Gen. SCOTT shows clearly, by documentary proof, the extraordinary and untiring efforts he made as early as October, 1860, to put the nation and the Southern forts in such a position of military strength that the rebellion would be crushed out as soon as it reared its head. He He rose from a sick bed in December when South Carolina was about to secede, and went to Washington, where he personally urged his views upon FLOYD, (" who," says Gen. SCOTT, "did not concur in any of my views.") He begged FLOYD to procure him an early interview with the President, that he might make one more effort to save the forts and the Union; and with Mr. BUCHANAN he also unavailingly discussed the same topics. For months Gen. SCOTT continued persistently and earnestly to reason in person with the authorities, and to send them correspondence and memoranda, urging the placing of the forts and arsenals in such a condition that the rebels could not hope for success; for as the Richmond Examiner (quoted by Gen. SCOTT) said: "The Southern States are full of arsenals and forts, commanding their rivers and strategic points; and had SCOTT been able to have got these forts in the condition he desired them to be, the Southern Confederacy would not now exist." But Gen. SCOTT's long and earnest labors were all ineffective -- the treason of FLOYD and the mingled treachery, imbecility and vacillation of the old knave BUCHANAN defeating nearly every one of his great and far-reaching plans. We will not attempt to give an epitome of the document, for we doubt not it will be read by every one, as it will assuredly take its place in history as a paper of the first importance.

abstract: Yesterday was the big day of the trade sale. The invoices of Messrs. APPLETON  Co.; LITTLE,  BROWN  Co.; WM. RADDE; MOORE, WILSTACH  Co.;  BLANCHARD  LEA, and JAS. HOGG  SONS, of London, were disposed of. Almost without exception, the books offered have thus far brought better prices than they did last Fall, and a marked improvernent since the spring sale, is particularly noticeable.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was the big day of the trade sale. The invoices of Messrs. APPLETON Co.; LITTLE, BROWN & CO.; WM. RADDE; MOORE, WILSTACH & CO.; BLANCHARD & LEA, and JAS. HOGG & SONS, of London, were disposed of. Almost without exception, the books offered have thus far brought better prices than they did last Fall, and a marked improvernent since the spring sale, is particularly noticeable. An invoice of Bibles, offered by Mr. HARDING, of Philadelphia, on Monday, netted that gentleman $500 more than a similar invoice did at the previous sale. The demand for religious books is very marked, indeed, and indicates that serious preparations are being universally made for death. There also seems to be a great demand for miscellaneous books, novels and stories that move the mind to mirth. In this we recognize tne different dispositions and habits that go to make up a novel. There are people who become pious under the pressure of circumstances, to whom trouble brings thought, who, when the star of death rises grimly and terribly above the horizon, betake themselves to prayer-books. And again there are those who attempt to shake off care by shaking their sides, who seek a refuge from thought and dismiss death as though he were simply a dun. Thus it is that theatres, con- cert saloons, and gin shops, are doing a better busi- ness just now than they did in times of peace, when death seemed distant from every one as the stars -- a possibility but not a probability -- a nebulous uncer- tainty rather than a fixed and surrounding fact. Were it announced that the world would end at a certain hour on any particular morning, we would engage that, while half its inhabitants went to church and shrived themselves, the other would seek a dance house and dance till the earth began to crack, and the skies rolled back their flaming gates.

abstract: We
lead_paragraph: -- We give to-day the articles of the London Tunes and London Star greeting the President's Proclamation. These papers represent the extremes of English opinion on the American war -- the Times being arrant Secession, and the Star intensely Anti-Slavery in sentiment. As happens elsewhere, so in England, the gravest public documents are seen in widely variant lights, and are wise or foolish, beneficent or pernicious, just according to the interests, prejudices or passions of those who give judgment upon them. It will be found that the Times regards the Proclamation as a futile assault upon the Confederacy, which will have no force except where the National arms penetrate to give it efficacy; while the Star considers it well calculated to make good men the world over pray for the success of the Union cause, besides being an effective war agency in arousing the blacks against the rebels. A very few brief months will give both Europe and America, North and South, light on this great subject, and until then it is hardly worth while arguing about it with our foreign foes.

abstract: IRVING HALL.--It has been maintained by experienced managers and artists of long suffering that the days of popular concerts were at an end; that three-decker programmes, with fantasias all over them like buttons on a page's coat, were no longer attractive to the public.
lead_paragraph: IRVING HALL. -- It has been maintained by experienced managers and artists of long suffering that the days of popular concerts were at an end; that three-decker programmes, with fantasias all over them like buttons on a page's coat, were no longer attractive to the public. Mr. HARRISON, in his admirable series of entertainments, goes far to upset this theory. In reviving the palmiest days of miscellaneous music, he has also restored to the concert-room its ancient reputation of being the most harmless place where worldly delights can be enjoyed. Profuseness and excellence were combined with admirable discrimination in last evening's programme. Mr. GOTTSCHALK has seldom been heard to greater advantage, being received, of course, with the usual fervor. A fragment from a Fantasia on "Somnambula," by the Cuban pianist ESPADERO, was the principal novelty, but it hardly justified the expectations excited by its announcement. The composer is said to be a remarkable man, and certainly owes a reputation to Mr. GOTTSCHALK, who never hesitates to speak with enthusiasm of his gifts. The fantasia is sufficient to excite interest, but not to call for further remark. In his own pieces, Mr. GOTTSCHALK was, as usual, Inimitable. Mr.THEODORE THOMAS played a couple of solos with superb elegance and clearness, especially a Tarantette, by VIEUXTEMPS. Mr. EDEN was excellent in his flute pieces, and Mad. Dr. LUSSAN sang with her accustomed tact and skill. Not the least interesting event of the evening was the debut of Mr. WM. CASTLE, a young American tenor, who possesses an admirable voice, and is evidently destined to assume a leading position in musical circles. In a romanza by MERCADANTE, and a pleasing ballad by Mr. A. WOOD, ("Things that Never Die,") the best qualities of his voice were displayed; both pieces were encored -- "La donna e Mobile" being substituted for the first, and "My Pretty Jane " for the second. The latter was the least successful of Mr. CASTLE's efforts, being somewhat too florid and inconsequential for the earnest outpourings of a balladic swain. The gentleman's success, however, was none the less marked and merited. His voice is fresh, powerful, and of good quality, and his future clearly rests with himself.

abstract: The  Seymourites are even more indignant at the proclamation of the President, declaring the existence of a modified martial law, than they are at the proclamation of prospective and conditional emancipation.
lead_paragraph: The Seymourites are even more indignant at the proclamation of the President, declaring the existence of a modified martial law, than they are at the proclamation of prospective and conditional emancipation. They try to make out that it means the complete abrogation of free speech -- even while their own loud enjoyment of that right shows their falsity; they, at- tempt to show that it involves the arbitrary arrest of all who are politically opposed to the Administration -- although their own immunity from arrest shows that it signifies no such thing; they struggle to prove that it contem- plates a complete destruction of the liberties of both loyal and disloyal citizens -- although, of course, they cannot show that a single right of the loyal citizen has been invaded since its promulgation.

abstract: While the United States are happily emancipated from the political dogma that "Cotton is King" by virtue of which the Cotton States were wont to practice much arrogance toward...
lead_paragraph: While the United States are happily emancipated from the political dogma that "Cotton is King" -- by virtue of which the Cotton States were wont to practice much arrogance toward the rest of the Union -- it must not be understood that the people of the North do not consider cotton an element of vast importance in their future political and commercial relations. We wish to destroy the infatuated belief of the Gulf States that in them only, of all lands of the world, cotton can be profitably produced. But we do not wish to lose cotton from the list of American products. From that source has been drawn many millions of the wealth that, in its suddenness and vastness, has made the United States a marvel of material prosperity. It has furnished the bulk of foreign exchange to us for over a quarter of a century. It has freighted American bottoms --set running millions of American spindles --clothed and fed millions of American laborers, and shall we dash away the agent of so much prosperity, merely because, in the downfall of slave cotton culture in America, the rebel States get an annihilating blow?

abstract: Our special correspondent at Harper's Ferry sends as the particulars of the reconnoissance toward Leesburgh, from the Army of the Potomac, which started on Tuesday, and returned yester-...
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent at Harper's Ferry sends as the particulars of the reconnoissance toward Leesburgh, from the Army of the Potomac, which started on Tuesday, and returned yesterday. Our forces were under the command of that dashing officer Gen. GEARY. The expedition, which embraced cavalry, artillery and infantry, proceeded as far as Lovettsville, encountering on the way a party of rebel cavalry, which was effectually broken up -- several of them being killed and wounded, and a large number, including the commander, taken prisoners. We had but one man killed, and three or four wounded.

abstract: The Seymourites had another "tall" demonstration at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, yes- terday evening. The concourse inside and out-...
lead_paragraph: The Seymourites had another "tall" demonstration at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, yes- terday evening. The concourse inside and outside of the building was large and vociferous and quite revived the stirring recollections of old-fashioned campaigns. Within, the speakers were Hon. HORATIO SEYMOUR, JOHN VAN BUREN and Hon. DAVID R. FLOYD JONES; SAMUEL SLOAN, Esq., presiding, assisted by a host of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. Outside, Messrs. Moses F. Odell, Judge S. D. Morris, Edmund Driggs, E.O. Perrin, Ex-Alderman Wilson, J.L. Douglass, and others, all of whom indulged in the usual Anti-Republican strain, but more mildly than heretofore.

abstract: CERTIFICATION OF VALUE. -- The Common Council of Jersey City, at their meeting on Tuesday night, adopted an ordinance for the issuing of certificates of value of the denominations of 5, 10, 25 and 50 cents, to the amount of $25,000. These certificates are to be deposited with the City Treasurer, and will be paid out to persons holding city warrants, and are redeemable in one year. They will be ready for use in about three weeks.

abstract: -- The friends of the Administration are working with stirring energy in New-Jersey. The disadvantages they have to contend with are formidable. The State has a strong secession leaven, the product of ignorance on the one hand, and of a mistaken notion of self-interest on the other; and the not result is an open and shameless sympathy with rebellion, not at all below the mark of VALLANDIGHAM and the WOODS. In the northwestern counties the Breckinridge Democrats are still faithful to the South. At the east, the long connection of the leading manufacturing capitalists with the Southern trade, and their severe losses in consequence of the war, have not endeared the cause of the Union to their hearts; and very gladly would they make any concession to procure peace and the restoration of their business. These causes create a numerical strength as a basis of the Democratic Party, which is, as elsewhere, augmented by Democrats who are loyal to the Union and the Constitution, and mistakenly believe that they are giving a new impulse to the war by voting for Democratic candidates. Add to these influences the absence of a preponderating vote in the shape of the volunteers in the army, -- for her volunteer soldiers are true to the Union and to the only Administration which can redeem if, -- and we have some measure of the force the Secession Democracy are in a condition to exert in the contest.

abstract: The most dismal piece  of literary composition we have read for many a day is the account of the manoeuvres of Gens. BRAGG and BUELL in Kentucky, ...
lead_paragraph: The most dismal piece of literary composition we have read for many a day is the account of the manoeuvres of Gens. BRAGG and BUELL in Kentucky, which we publish in another column. The telegraph has been strangely reticent regarding affairs in that State ever since the day when it was announced that BUELL had the whole rebel army in a "trap." We have had glimpses now and then of the rebels retreating and "closely pursued;" but we had no hints furnished of the state of affairs as now revealed. The manoeuverings of BUELL are quite marvelous, and are certainly altogether inconsistent with the existence of the generalship which has heretofore been so widely accorded him in army and official circles.

abstract: Seymour political rally held at Academy of Music, Brooklyn; Seymour, Van Buren, others speak
snippet: Seymour political rally held at Academy of Music, Brooklyn; Seymour, Van Buren, others speak
lead_paragraph: The "unterrified" of Kings Connly turned out an masse last evening, or rather turned into the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at a rate that suggested the inquiry where they could all have come from. However, there they were, and for numbers, noise and vehement approbation of the sentiments uttered by their speakers, the concourse was certainly an imposing one.

abstract: The "Wadsworth and Tremain Association," of the Eighteenth Ward, met Thursday evening at the Republican headquarters, near the corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, to ratify the recent State ...
lead_paragraph: The "Wadsworth and Tremain Association," of the Eighteenth Ward, met Thursday evening at the Republican headquarters, near the corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, to ratify the recent State nominations of their Party -- JAMES M. THOMPSON, Esq., the President of the Association, in the Chair. Mr. WM. DRUMMOND read a series of resolutions indorsing all the Republican nominees for the State and District, which were adopted nem. con. In the absence of some leading speakers announced by the call, RICHARD WARREN, Esq., addressed the audience in exalted commendation of Mr. ELLIOT C. COWDIN, their Congressional nominee, and good-humoredly satirized Mr. NELSON J. WATERBURY, his Democratic opponent. He was very bitter against the Southern aristocracy, blamed Slavery as the sole cause of the war, the Abolitionists who were accused of it, "never having cast a vote for any one," and denounced the Northern Democrats in unmeasured terms. The latter, he declared, would not have ventured one year ago, to put up a ticket like the present one headed by HORATIO SEYMOUR. But, times had changed, and they now felt bold and confident. Mr. WARREN had the assent and applause of his audience throughout.

abstract: On the Montague-street side of the Academy two stands were erected, and an immense crowd of citizens gathered around them to listen to the lesser orators. At Stand No. 1, Mr. D.T. BROWN presided, and FREDERICK W. KALBFLEISCH and JAMES HOWE, Jr., were appointed Secretaries. At Stand No. 2, WM. BEARD, Esq., was called to the Chair, and DEWITT BOGARDUS and JAMES B. MURTHA acted as Secretaries. The usual addenda of calcium lights, flags, banners, &c., were used in profusion, and the aid of music was brought in to inspire the masses assembled. Cheers for SEYMOUR and Gen. MCCLELLAN were loud and frequent; and each speaker, on being introduced, was received with huzzas and "tigers." Young America, as usual, scattered himself throughout the swaying crowds, and cheered vociferously for anybody and everything that was proposed. Pyramids of gas-lamps were tastefully arranged near the stands, and these, in addition to the calcium lights which had been extemporized for the occasion, made everything in the vicinity as bright as day. Numbers of ladies, notwithstanding the coolness of the atmosphere, accompanied by their husbands, fathers and brothers, helped to swell the crowd, and seemed to take a deep [???] the proceedings. Delegations from various Wards made their appearance soon after the proceeding [???] and [???] was loudly hailed [???] of the [???]. As was the case at the Cooper Institute mass meeting, a large number of Republicans were "lookers-on in Vienna," and extemporized [???] were gotten up between them and their Democratic friends touching the platforms and policies of the two opposing parties, the chances of success for their favorite candidates, &c., all of which, though carried on with carnestress, were characterized by good feeling. A rumor that RICHARD O'GORMAN, Esq., would speak from Stand No. 1 having obtained circulation among the crowd about 3 1/2 o'clock, caused a hurrying thither of a large number of persons, who were listening to Hon. MOSES F. ODELL, at Stand No. 2. The expectants were, however, doomed to disappointment, Mr. O'GORMAN not being present. Couriers arrived every few minutes at the stands from the meeting inside the building, and reported the progress of operations there, much to the satisfaction, apparently, of the outsiders. The announcement that Mr. SEYMOUR had closed his speech with a declaration that the Union should never be dissolved, brought forth hearty applause for the gubernatorial candidate, and the statement that JOHN VAN BUREN, Esq., had commenced his speech gave rise to three hearty cheers for the "Prince." The crowd about the door leading to the back part of the stage button-holed every one who emerged from there as to Mr. VAN BUREK's speech, the anxious inquiry being, "Did he tell where and how he got possession of Gen. SCOTT's letter?" The negative reply which was always given to this query seemed to disappoint the questioners, who evidently had got the idea into their heads that Prince JOHN was on this occasion going to make a clean breast of the whole affair. The speaking at the stands having been concluded, the crowd tell into line, bearing illuminated banners, on which were inscribed the names of the candidates and devices usual among the Democracy on all campaigning occasions, and marched down Fulton-street, headed by a band of music. Before the inside meeting had adjourned, the outsiders had closed their proceedings, and the stands were deserted, save by a few of the young Democracy who were explaining their views regarding the issues involved in a manner at once striking and peculiar. The speakers at the outside meetings were Hon. MOSES F. ODEL, Judge S.D. MORRIS, Hon. EDMUND DRIGGS, E.O. PERRIN, Ex-Alderman WILSON, J.L. DOUGLASS, and others.

abstract: In spite of the war and of the (so called) high [???], our importations continue to be heavy, [???]. Money seems to [???] its [???] for [???] which [???] that [???] produce [???] demand [???] to the [???] certainly decrease. It may be found in a few weeks, however, that the price of demand notes has had the effect of causing orders to be countermanded, and that the importations will consequently be smaller. The high price of demand notes has not affected our large importing houses unfavorably, after all. On the other hand it has been the means of adding to the profits of many of them. A good many of them in anticipation of the rise in the value of these notes, which was certain, as they daily became less abundant, procured very large quantities of them when they commanded a premium of but five or ten per cent., or less. They also invested largely in gold, which they reserved through all the fluctuations in its value, as compared with that of legal tender notes. These demand notes they have had at hand when duties were to be paid. But with the rise in the comparative value of gold, and in that of Custom-house demand notes, the price of every commodity has increased correspondingly. Those who have been compelled to buy demand notes with which to pay duties, giving therefor a premium of twenty or thirty per cent., have been, of course, compelled to add this sum to the selling price of their merchandise, thus raising its market value. In selling, those firms which paid but five per cent., for notes with which to pay duties, receive as much for their goods as those who paid twenty-five. In this way it is evident that the unsteady state of our currency and the high price of notes have acted favorably to the moneyed importing houses, and unfavorably to those of small means; giving to the former the power of underselling the latter, at the same time that they realize a very high profit. When the case is examined in this light, it is not so difficult to see how it has happened that, in spite of the war and the derangement of our currency, the importations have been and still are so great. That they will continue so as long as the condition of the money and merchandise market remains as at present, is not at all improbable, for many houses have sufficient notes with which to pay duties for a long time. Our exports, too, continue very heavy, and contribute largely toward the payment of our foreign debts.

abstract: editorials on Seymour speech
snippet: editorials on Seymour speech
lead_paragraph: Mr. SEYMOUR is laboring very hard for his election as Governor of the Empire State. He delivered another speech last night in Brooklyn; and there was a large crowd present to listen to him. On this occasion, the Ex-Governor seems to have rather changed his tactics, and made an effort to plant himself on the platform occupied by the successful Democracy of the Western States. He avoided, in great measure, the semi-secession utterances which characterized his Cooper Institute speech. He has discovered that this great and loyal State will not sustain him in making war upon the Administration while it is engaged in fighting for its life and the life of the nation. But his real sentiments came out very legibly in some of his remarks, and more especially in the spirit in which they were uttered. It was quite evident that he is as much an enemy of the Administration, and as bitterly opposed to its policy of using "all means to crush" the rebellion as he was ten days ago. His buncombe phrases and hollow rhetoric will deceive no honest and determinedly-loyal voter.

abstract: The Major, , of New-York vs. John Kerret al. The argument on the motion for a perpetual injunction in this case, before mentioned in the TIMES, was proceeded with yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Major, &c., of New-York vs. John Kerret al. -- The argument on the motion for a perpetual injunction in this case, before mentioned in the TIMES, was proceeded with yesterday. The Corporation Counsel on behalf of the City commenced an action against the defendants to recover $100,000 damages for injuries sustained by the City by reason of the unlawful occupation of the streets by the defendants in building what is known as the Seventh-avenue Railroad. The plaintiffs claim and declare that they have from time immemorial possessed and enjoyed, and under their charter have and own the expensive eight and property of controlling and licensing all those who use the said streets for carrying thereupon persons and property for hire. The plaintiffs further show that they have at great expense paved and regulated said streets and made them convenient for travel and that in violation of these rights, the defendants have broke and entered on the Seventh-avenue and Broadway for the purpose of building a railroad.
