abstract: A NEW-YORK MERCHANT ROBBED IN THE STREET.?For the last two weeks we have had accounts of highway robberies committed in this City, by a genteelly dressed colored man. His usual plan ...
lead_paragraph: A NEW-YORK MERCHANT ROBBED IN THE STREET. -- For the last two weeks we have had accounts of highway robberies committed in this City, by a genteelly dressed colored man. His usual plan was to approach men passing through unfrequented streets, at a late hour of the night, suddenly draw a dagger, and threaten them with instant death unless they delivered to him all their money and valuables. Large amounts of money, and quite a number of watches have, in this manner, been obtained by him from his victims, who valued their money less than their lives. The last man who is known to have suffered from this footpad, is Mr. FERNANDO ESTRADO, a merchant, doing business at No. 483 Broadway. A few evenings since Mr. E. was met by this colored desperado, on the corner of Mott and Broome streets. With a terrifying threat, and a flourish of his steel, he demanded Mr. E.'s money and watch, and in default of which he said he would take his life. Mr. ESTRADO having no money with him, gave the robber his gold watch and chain, with which the latter at once made his escape. The victim applied at Police Headquarters, where he gave a description of the villain's person to Sergeant YOUNG, and by this means Detective FARLEY was yesterday enabled to effect his arrest. The prisoner, upon being taken to the Station-house, gave his name as ANTONIO ISMAGO BARTOL. Upon being confronted by Mr. ESTRADO, he was instantly identified as the man who robbed him. The accused says he was born in Cuba, has been 18 months in this country, but only about six weeks in this City. He says he is a waiter by occupation, and resides at No. 100 Hester-street. He was committed by Justice CONNOLLY for trial. Persons who have lately been robbed in the manner above described, are requested to call at Police Headquarters and take a look at the prisoner.

abstract: A few day since a young man of South Boston, accompanied by five Southern rebels, with passes from our own Government, frandulently obtained, visited Boston for military purposes. The young man ...
lead_paragraph: -- A few day since a young man of South Boston, accompanied by five Southern rebels, with passes from our own Government, frandulently obtained, visited Boston for military purposes. The young man visited his mother in South Boston, and the rebels remained one night at the Parker House. They have all since gone to Washington.

abstract: Our readers will recollect the outburst of rage with which the Emancipation Proclamation was greeted by the rebels, and the various schemes, differing only in the degree of brutal.
lead_paragraph: -- Our readers will recollect the outburst of rage with which the Emancipation Proclamation was greeted by the rebels, and the various schemes, differing only in the degree of brutality and barbarism that they exhibited, which were introduced into the rebel Congress as proper to be adopted in reference to it. It would seem from a recent article in the Richmond Whig that the final decision of the rebel Congress was to leave the whole matter to the discretion of JEFF. DAVIS, and as it is left to him, the Whig calls upon him to do something about it. And the measure which the Whig would have him adopt is to issue a proclamation -- not a proclamation of counter emancipation, as some of our friends have seemed afraid would be done, not a proclamation that the whole thing was nugatory and might be utterly disregarded, as those few among us who hate emancipation have so loudly declared would be the view the rebels would take of it -- not a proclamation quieting the apprehensions of the inhabitants and assuring the soldiers that they need have no fear of insurrections. None of all these things meet the views of the Whig. It is to be a proclamation "demanding that LINCOLN's Emancipation Proclamation be rescinded," and "declaring that unless this is done, we shall send forces into the North to burn, ravage, desolate and destroy everything in their path."

abstract: Editorial sees attitude towards Adm. main issue between Union Party and Seymour party in NYS
snippet: Editorial sees attitude towards Adm. main issue between Union Party and Seymour party in NYS
lead_paragraph: English journals have predicted the reign of license and disorder in this country as the result of our civil war. The mob was to rule, and civil authority must give way to anarchy or despotism. The character of the people and the nature of our Government seem to be alike an enigma to our British cousins. Here are massed nearly a million of people in this single City. We have passed through a year and a half of war. Hundreds of thousands of troops have been enlisted or temporarily quartered here. The intensest excitement has prevailed. Political agitation has been unrestrained. Yet there has not been a riot or a serious disturbance of the public peace. Our cities have been more quiet and orderly, for the most part, than during any similar period before the war. The records of crime show a steady diminution of arrests. Property and life were never more secure. Law was never more respected. So much for New-York.

abstract: The Aldermanic Railroad Committee met yesterday afternoon without a quorum. The first paper taken up was the resolution directing inquiry to be made as to the number of cars run by the Sixth
lead_paragraph: The Aldermanic Railroad Committee met yesterday afternoon without a quorum. The first paper taken up was the resolution directing inquiry to be made as to the number of cars run by the Sixth-avenue Company, the number they pay license for, and by what right they have extended their track into Fifty-ninth-street. The Clerk, Mr. E.W. TAYLOR, reported that the Company had paid license fees for 34 two-horse and 21 one-horse cars. The subject was then deferred till the next meeting, to give the officers of the Company notice to appear.

abstract: Thomas B. Stillman vs. Samuel L. Milchill.  The trial of this case was continued yesterday. Ex-Judge Dean, for the defendant, put in the depositions of Secretary Welles and others.
lead_paragraph: Thomas B. Stillman vs. Samuel L. Milchill. -- The trial of this case was continued yesterday. Ex-Judge Dean, for the defendant, put in the depositions of Secretary Welles and others. Mr. Welles states that he recollected Mr. Stillman, who came to Washington as a candidate for the office of Civil Engineer in the Navy-yard, Brooklyn, but did not recollect whether Stillman spoke to him on the subject of his appointment. He had no recollection of a negotiation with Mr. Stillman in relation to the purchase of the vessels in question. The purchase was made through George D. Morgan, of the New-York and Savannah Steam Navigation Company. The bill of sale being executed by the defendant, the President of the Company.

abstract: Editorial says emancipation in US must be universal
snippet: Editorial says emancipation in US must be universal
lead_paragraph: No one believes that Slavery can exist in the Border States after it stall have been abolished in the South. However earnest the desire of the National Government to preserve to the loyalists in those States the rights which they have never forfeited -- and among these the right to hold slaves -- it will be found impossible, in the nature of things, to do so, in regard to this particular class of property. Slavery and freedom cannot exist in such contiguity. Long since, it became apparent that no slave could be held in any county bordering on a Free State, provided the slave had spirit enough to aspire to be a freeman. Hence, Slavery has not practically existed for years in all that belt of country comprising the northern parts of Delaware, Maryland, Virginia and Kentucky. Now, surround those States with free territory, in which thereafter no Fugitive Slave law can be enforced, and what will be the result? With the moral excitation on the subject that the war has brought, added to the causes that have thinned the slaves heretofore from the Northern border, it is clear that the institution must die -- as quickly and surely as a man dies who is set a-bleeding at every pore.

abstract: Last night, a few minutes past 9 o'clock, a fire was discovered on board the schooner Elener, Capt. D. TOWNSLND, in the employ of the Government, which was lying at anchor in the North River, in ...
lead_paragraph: Last night, a few minutes past 9 o'clock, a fire was discovered on board the schooner Elener, Capt. D. TOWNSLND, in the employ of the Government, which was lying at anchor in the North River, in front of and a short distance from the Cunard Dock. The deck being loaded with hay, the flames spread with great rapidity, and in a few moments the vessel was enveloped in one entire sheet of fire. The Fire Department of Jersey City and or the lower districts in New-York turned out, but were unable to render any assistance, and for some time no information could be gathered as to the name of the vessel, or whether there were any persons on board. Several small boats from vessels in the vicinity were seen plying around, and finally one of them came ashore, with the Captain, first and second mates, the steward and one of the crew -- the latter badly burned about the lace, hands and feet. The injured man, whose name is LEWIS R. HICKMAN, was taken to MERCEIN's drug-store, in Montgomery-street, where his wounds were dressed, after which he was conveyed to the New-York Hospital.

abstract: In our article yesterday we brought the reader to the threshold of the mighty problem before the country what to do with the four million slaves in the South who will shortly
lead_paragraph: In our article yesterday we brought the reader to the threshold of the mighty problem before the country -- what to do with the four million slaves in the South who will shortly be enfranchised through the President's Proclamation. We have shown that they will be abject paupers, all without land, money, clothing, food, friends or home. Was ever a race of peope, in all the world's history, found so utterly poor, helpless and hapless as they? How will they live a month, a week or a day? By charity? By whose charity? The Southern whites will have neither means nor charity for them. The Government, if it had both means and charity, could not reach to help one destitute in a thousand. Shall they subsist by thieving and plunder? Cod forbid! For, although an ingenious casuistry might argue such conduct no crime, as the slave's labor had produced what he now took to supply his necessities, the practical effect on the slave of such licensed brigandage would be fearfully demoralizing and disastrous.
headline: {'main': 'The Problem Solved.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Problem Solved.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial expresses concern that Bragg forces will march on Nashville
snippet: Editorial expresses concern that Bragg forces will march on Nashville
lead_paragraph: -- Now that BRAGG has got into Tennessee with his whole army, there is very great danger that he may suddenly march it to Nashville, and make an effort to capture that beleagured city. Our readers know that the city has been in a critical condition for some time, with a rebel force in its vicinity small, but sufficiently impudent to have sent in a flag of truce demanding its surrender. Our army of defence, however, is quite able to hold it, so far as fighting is concerned, unless the rebel force is greatly increased; but the enemy seem rather to be making an effort to starve it into terms. The city is cut off from all communication with the North, and is seriously straitened for supplies. If now BRAGG's army advance against it, it will be in an almost hopeless condition. BRAGG will undoubtedly do something soon, and this is the work nearest to his hand. One of the rebel newspapers says that the Chattanooga railroad is in full running order to within fifteen miles of Nashville, which will make BRAGG's movement thither easy.

abstract: Our special correspondent at Harper's Ferry, it will be seen, insists that the late movement upon Charlestown was the preliminary of a general advance of the Army of the Potomac, not withstanding the assertions that it was simply intended as a reconnoissance in force. In proof of this he cites the fact that the baggage and commissary trains accompanied the troops.
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent at Harper's Ferry, it will be seen, insists that the late movement upon Charlestown was the preliminary of a general advance of the Army of the Potomac, not withstanding the assertions that it was simply intended as a reconnoissance in force. In proof of this he cites the fact that the baggage and commissary trains accompanied the troops. he retrograde movement was determined upon through fear of a counter movement on the part of the enemy, which they might have executed before a sufficient body of our troops could have been moved across the river to render the advance secure.

abstract: The trial of John Reynolds for killing Pat Matthews was concinded in this Court yesterday. Mr. Whitehead closed the summing up for the prosecution, after which Recorded HOFFMAN charged the jury,
lead_paragraph: The trial of John Reynolds for killing Pat Matthews was concinded in this Court yesterday. Mr. Whitehead closed the summing up for the prosecution, after which Recorded HOFFMAN charged the jury, reviewing the evidence in detail, or such parts thereof as bore directly upon the question of the guilt or innocence of the accused. He said that in this case there was a direct contradiction in the testimony of witnesses for the prosecution and for the defence, upon material points; and the principal question for the jury to decide was which of the witnesses was entitled to belief. Two witnesses for the defence testified positively that Matthews had a dirk-knife in his hard when he attacked the accused, while two witnesses for the prostitution swore that they saw no knife, and the policemen who was called to the scene of the homicide both swore that they found Matthews lying on the ground with no knife in his hands, and that when he was taken to the Station-house the dirk was found sheathed and attached to a belt under his vest. The question whether Matthews used a knife in his attack upon the accused was of great importance, as showing whether the accused was in such imminent danger of his life from the attack as to justify the use of his own knife against his adversary. The Recorder laid down with great clearness the law governing justifiable homicide, and said it was for them to decide whether the facts in this case came within the rule. The prisoner was entitled to the benefit of any doubt resting upon their minds, but such doubt must be a reasonable one, and sufficiently strong to create such a balance in their minds that they could conscientiously find a verdict either way.

abstract: editorials on Seymour speech
snippet: editorials on Seymour speech
lead_paragraph: This speech was anticipated with a good deal of interest, as it was hoped that the candidate of the malcontents would at least respond to the public desire for an explicit statement of his real sentiments respecting the rebels, and the policy of the Administration against the rebels. This statement was particularly incumbent upon him, inasmuch as he stands charged with faint-heartedness, if not false-heartedness in relation to the war. This charge has gained color from the undisputed fact, that up to the very time the war began, Mr. SEYMOUR publicly denounced coercion in the strongest terms, and from the fact, which we believe is equally undeniable, that, since the war began, he has steadily held aloof from all practical furtherance of it, either by gift of money or encouragement of enlistments. His antecedents bear very much against him. If they give him a position that is not really his, there was urgent necessity that he should right himself by defining his real position fully and precisely. This just expectation of the public was not met.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. The Movements in State Politics, with the Election returns from all the States so far as received, will be found in this morning's issue. The Sixth of Mr. HURLBERT's Series of Letters appears in the current number. All official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMIWEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: SOME  Some of the Southern journals have hit upon an ingenious device for making the world believe that they care nothing for the President's
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the Southern journals have hit upon an ingenious device for making the world believe that they care nothing for the President's Proclamation of Emancipation. They are urging the formation of negro regiments, to serve in the field, and the conscription of negroes to act as camp followers. Now, we do not doubt that the masses of the Southern people are firmly convinced that no power can make their slaves rise upon them, so long as they retain the control of their own territory; and we are not unwilling to suppose that multitudes of the negroes ignorantly hate the Yankee white man, whom they don't know, more than they hate the Southern white man, whom they do know.

abstract: [???] SOLDIERS -- One of our correspond[???] that a number of officers and [???] with the National army [???] Asylum for the Insane, [???] Washington. He adds, that the Surgeon in charge refuses to give the names of these unfortunates. Our correspondent is apparently surprised at this [???]. We are not so; for it is quite plain that the soldiers and officers in question must belong to that numerous class of lunatics in the army who think that war means fighting, and who are obstinately bent on keeping out of Winter quarters. Of course, it is highly proper that the more extravagant of these maniacs should be confined, because, if they were left at large, it is evident that the whole army might at any time be exposed to be led against the enemy, and might, perhaps, incur the irreparable disgrace of winning a victory without waiting to put on its shoes, or even -- dreadful thought -- some still more indispensable portion of its wearing apparel. Fortunately for the general peace of mind, it is believed that few rabid cases of this insanity have as yet developed themselves in the highest ranks of the service.

abstract: It so rarely happens that we  appreciate the modest gifts which the God's vouchsafe to us, that the success of so pleasant a trifle as the German Opera may be regarded almost as phenomenal. The World clamors for Opera Without
lead_paragraph: -- It so rarely happens that we appreciate the modest gifts which the God's vouchsafe to us, that the success of so pleasant a trifle as the German Opera may be regarded almost as phenomenal. The World clamors for Opera without seeming to know that other lands than italian have done something in the cause of art. There are hundreds of works in German and French that could be transplanted successfully to this latitude, were managers more enterprising and the public less wedded to what is fashionable. Mr. ANSCHUTZ in his venture at Wallack's theatre, has thrown himself upon the genuine appreciation of the public. With a company, which all things considered is amply sufficient for his purpose, a good orchestra and a well selected chorus, he has offered from week to week a choice of works popular in German theatres but unknown elsewhere. No better musician exists in this country, and this circumstance accounts for a degree of completeness in the representations which could hardly be predicated from the known material of the establishment. The critic, who is not cramped by prejudices, detects in every performance something which raises it above the average of ordinary performances, whilst the amateur listens with pleasure to the careful interpretation of works that are, perhaps, entirely new to him. "Johann von Paris," which was produced at the German Opera house on Wednesday, is a work that no longer possesses the bloom of youth, but so agreeably was it performed, and so pleasantly were its charming melodies offered to the ear, that it obtained a success such as the composer in his palmiest days might have envied. The principal parts were intrusted to Mme. JOHANNSEN and Mme. ROTTER, both of whom were more than equal to the demands made on them. HERR GRAFF, a respectable basso, was excellent also as the Seneschal, and HERR KROUFELD, an admirable comedian, kept the house in constant merriment as the overwhelmed innkeeper. The minor parts were cared for in the best manner, and a terpsichorean scene in the third act by Mile. THELEUR and Mons WIETHOFF brought down the house by its excellence. We have seldom, indeed, listened to an opera that in its manner of performance and placement on the stage, gave more genuine satisfaction, or merited greater praise. BOILDIEU's music is full of graceful, case and melodic charm. It is written with the freedom of a master, and with none of that over wrought effort which now passes muster for effect. The third act, which, displays the master's best characteristics, was received with a tumult of applause, and insured a triumphant success to the performance. Both Mm. [???] and [???] were encored in the [???] The opera is so pleasant, and the performance so good, that we shall be greatly disappointed if it does not crowd the cosy quarters of the Germans for many evenings to come.

abstract: The Criminal Term of the Hudson County Court commenced yesterday, Judge OGDEN and Associate Judge POPE on the Bench. The day was occupied in the trial of GUSTAV BERLIN, charged with manufacturing and passing bogus ten-cent and three-cent pieces, at Guttenberg. At the time of his arrest, last Summer, dies, crucibles and other articles used for coining, together with a lot of the bogus coin and metal, was found on the premises. The case was not concluded. There were sixty-one bills of indictment found by the Grand Jury the present Term.

abstract: The letter of Gen. SCOTT to Mr. SEWARD will go far to redeem the reputation of the old soldier for mlitary wisdom and judgment, and to place his character is a more amiable light than it has recently occpied.
lead_paragraph: The letter of Gen. SCOTT to Mr. SEWARD will go far to redeem the reputation of the old soldier for mlitary wisdom and judgment, and to place his character is a more amiable light than it has recently occpied. This letter, written March 3, 1861, is, in its sagacity and general tone, far above anything that we ever conceived Gen. SCOTT to be capable of, and proves him to have been, at the time of its writing, both a statesman and a soldier.

abstract: Editorial on too many soldiers being on leave when McClellan needs them in Virginia
snippet: Editorial on too many soldiers being on leave when McClellan needs them in Virginia
lead_paragraph: -- There is an immense number of soldiers, both officers and privates, now in this City; and there are more of them to be seen in the streets on sunny days than at any time since the war began. They are generally fine-looking, hearty, well-behaved, and seem to be bountifully supplied with shinplastere. They are mostly of three classes: first, new volunteers, who have not been sent forward to the seat of war; second, those who are on leave of absence from their regiments; and thirdly, paroled officers and soldiers who, though exempted from active service, are entitled to wear their uniforms and draw their pay.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer of the 20th contains [???] extracts from the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 17th last. It admits that "Gen. BEAGG has fallen back from his late position a distance of forty miles, for the purpose of securing subsistence. The combinations of the enemy, who had been strongly reinforced, doubtless rendered such a step absolutely necessary. It is surmised, also, that Rosecrans had commenced a strategic movement to form a junction with Buell, and cut off our army entirety."

abstract: --The  The English Press, as a body, are extremely anxious to impress upon the world the truth that Mr. GLADSTONE'S remarks about "Southern nationality" have no bearing upon the question of action by the British Government; but English politicians in the rural districts have not been so wisely thoughtful.
lead_paragraph: -- The The English Press, as a body, are extremely anxious to impress upon the world the truth that Mr. GLADSTONE'S remarks about "Southern nationality" have no bearing upon the question of action by the British Government; but English politicians in the rural districts have not been so wisely thoughtful. In Surrey, for instance. Mr. ALCOCK and Mr. LOCKE KING, the former remarkable for nothing in particular and the latter remarkable for bringing up in Parliament a yearly motion on the ballot, which is every year defeated, have just made little after-dinner speeches, not altogether unnoticeable as straws revealing the flow of opinions and of sentiment in England. Mr. ALCOCK elicited cheers from the bumpkins, his constituents, by asserting that "in England all sympathized with the people of the Southern states in their heroic struggle for liberty," while his colleague, Mr. KING, made an earthquake among the wine-glasses by saying that England had borne too much from the North, since, if she had gone to war on the Trent affair, she "would never have desisted until she had obtained that to which she had a right, Portland harbor and the State of Maine!"

abstract: --Gen. BUELL has  been removed from the command of the forces in Kentucky, and Gen. ROSECRANS ordered to assume the position. This is the sequel of the late campaign in the West, around which so much interest has hung, North and South. It is not a little singular that the campaign for which Gen. BUELL receives the marked displeasure ...
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. BUELL has been removed from the command of the forces in Kentucky, and Gen. ROSECRANS ordered to assume the position. This is the sequel of the late campaign in the West, around which so much interest has hung, North and South. It is not a little singular that the campaign for which Gen. BUELL receives the marked displeasure of his Government, excites likewise on the part of the rebels the utmost disgust for Gen. BRAGG. Neither General has done the work that was expected at his hands, and they will probably share the same fate.

abstract: Union mass meeting held, Brooklyn Academy of Music
snippet: Union mass meeting held, Brooklyn Academy of Music
lead_paragraph: A very large audience assembled at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening to witness and hear the demonstration of Southern Union feeling promised by several of its leading champions who have come up to us from the land of rebellion. Unfortunately, no precise hour for the commencement of the meeting had been fixed by the call, and the assemblage, among whom were many ladies, consequently manifested no little impatience during the long period of waiting that preceded the organization.

abstract: Editorial on number of idle soldiers in NYC and vital jobs they could be doing
snippet: Editorial on number of idle soldiers in NYC and vital jobs they could be doing
lead_paragraph: -- The large number of officers and soldiers who are now in and around this city are not wanted, we suppose, in the army of Gen. McCLELLAN. If they were, so many of them would not be here on leaves of absence from that army. Let them, then, be all massed together and sent on other work. Let them be quickly coneyed from here to the James River, up that stream as far as possible, landed on its South bank, and then march into Richmond while the rebel army is far away from it and the city is guarded by only a few regiments. There are enough idle troops in and around New-York to do up this work in ten days.

abstract: The Expedition to "London," of which I sent you a full account by telegraph last evening, proved highly successful. Farmers from that section have been coming in daily with accounts of the robberies and outrages committed by Capt. GRUBB'S Rangers, a new cavalry company recently raised in London County, and attached to Gen. STUART's command.
lead_paragraph: The Expedition to "London," of which I sent you a full account by telegraph last evening, proved highly successful. Farmers from that section have been coming in daily with accounts of the robberies and outrages committed by Capt. GRUBB'S Rangers, a new cavalry company recently raised in London County, and attached to Gen. STUART's command. So near have they at different times approached the Ferry, as to frighten away the market men and women, and thus cut oil our vegetable supplies.

abstract: What will the South think of this? The South will answer with a hiss [???] But what will [???] North think of it? What will Pennsylvania say -- Pennsylvania, which is already unquiet under the loss of her best customers, and not easy under the absolute despotism of the present Government at Washington? What Boston may say or think is not, perhaps, of much consequence. But what will New-York say? It would not answer the purpose of any of these cities to have the South made a howling wilderness. They want the handling of the millions which are produced by the labor of the black man. Pennsylvania desires to sell her manufactures in the South; New-York wishes to be again broker, banker, and merchant to the South. This is what the Union means to these cities. They would rather have a live independent State to deal with than a dead dependency where nothing could be earnt. To these practical persons President LINCOLN would be, after his black revolution had succeeded, like a dogstealer who should present the anxious owner with the head of his favorite pointer. They want the useful creature alive. The South, without its cotton and its sugar and its tobacco, would be of small use to New-York, or even to Philadelphia; and the South, without the produce of its rice and cotton, and its sugar and tobacco, would be but a sorry gain, even if it could be obtained. If President LINCOLN wants such a conquest as this, the North is, perhaps, yet strong enough to conquer Hayti. A few fanatics, of course, will shout, but we cannot think that except in utter desperation and vindictiveness, any real party in the North will applaud this nefarious resolution to light up a servile war in the distant homesteads of the South.

abstract: The steamship Australasian arrived at this port yesterday morning, from Liverpool on the 10th inst., and Queenstown on the 11th, with advices from Europe two days later than were received by the Kangaroo. The news is interesting and in some respects important. The English Press continued its comments on the Presidents Emancipation Proclamation, and managed to find a good deal of fault with it. It was reported that the "Southern Association" in Liverpool had agreed to a proposition which has for its objectthe memorialising of the British Government for the recognition of the Confederate States. This movement was chiefly caused by the remarks of Mr. GLADSTONE at Newcastle. It was also said that the members of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce were about to petition Government as to the necessity of recognizing the South. There appears to be no danger of recognition however. The Liverpool Post, of the 11th, says: "Two of the highest class Liverpool houses received yesterday evening telegram from headquarters in London that the British and French Governments have lost no time in announcing that they are resolved on persisting in a policy of perfect neutrality." The city editor of the Times asserts that the feeling among the commercial classes of London is as strongly opposed as ever to any action on the part of the Government toward a formal recognition of the dissolution of the Union, and he says that there is a suspicion that the desire for such a recognition comes rather from the North than the South. The London Commercial Daily List says it is enabled to state that there is no likelihood of an immediate recognition of the Southern Confederacy. Advices from Italy say that GARIBALDI is about to issue another manifesto, and that he will endeavor to carry out his project of taking Rome. This can hardly be true at present. The Liverpool Cotton market was rather flat, with no change in prices. Breadstuffs were easier, and Provisions steady.

abstract: Editorial says election of those in NYS not in sympathy with Adm. would betray soldiers; Editorial says election of those not in sympathy with Adm. would betray soldiers
snippet: Editorial says election of those in NYS not in sympathy with Adm. would betray soldiers; Editorial says election of those not in sympathy with Adm. would betray soldiers
lead_paragraph: Yes, betray is the word. To put men in power who oppose the war is to play false to the men who prosecute the war. What did our soldiers volunteer for but to fight? What impelled these million men to take upon themselves the hardships of military life, but the stern conviction that the rebellion must be put down by the strong arm? What has sustained them in pouring out their blood like water, but the assurance that every drop of it was a necessary and an effective sacrifice for the redemption of the Union. They went to the battle-field, not simply because they were themselves devoted, but also because they believed the people so. Every dollar that was contributed for their own comfort or that of their families, every bright flag that was given to inspire them, every waving handkerchief and every exultant cheer, was a pledge that the people were with them, and would stand by them to the end. Had the people sworn with uplifted hands before high Heaven to be true to the cause for which their noble brothers and sons went forth to bleed and to die, the obligation could not have been more sacred.
headline: {'main': 'Shall We Betray our Soldiers?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Shall We Betray our Soldiers?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Reports on Union pursuit of Bragg in Kentucky
snippet: Reports on Union pursuit of Bragg in Kentucky
lead_paragraph: Exciting and [???] events have characterized the movements of the central advance of the Army of the Ohio since the date of my last. We had then just entered Danville, and encamped in its immediate suburbs. The brilliant dash of Gen. SMITH into the town resulted in driving MORGAN and his cavalry out,and pursuing one of our wagon trains, to capture which was one object of the noted brigand chief. A number of prisoners were taken from MORGAN by the movement. In the capture of Danville we took between three and four Hundred prisoners, the larger part of whom [???] dispersed and scattered themselves through the vicinity foraging purposes. Ninety-two were taken from the hospitals, the Theological Institute having been taken for that purpose. At Danville, as at other places, the citizens suffered severely by the rebels, having been robbed and driven from their houses, and even prevented from getting water from their own wells by rebel guards stationed around them. The demonstrations of joy shown by the citizens at [???] appearance among them would have thrilled any heart alive to the impulses of a noble patriotism.

abstract: FOUND [???]. -- Coroner F.W. BOUNSTEDT of Hoboken, held an inquest Thursday on the body of an unknown man found drowned. Deceased was about 38 years of age, dressed in army pants, vest and overcoat; had a canteen and haversack. In his pocket was found a bible and pack of cards, and few Poughkeepsie shinplasters. The overcoat was marked "J.T. MARTIN, N.Y." and on the sleeve, "U.S. Hospital, for H.W. MARSH, N.Y." No marks of violence were found, and the cury rendered a verdict of death by drowning, whether by accident or otherwise, unknown to the jury.

abstract: -- FERNANDO WOOD ratified himself last night, in a speech, before the Seymourites of the Fifth Congressional District. We call attention to his remarks. They are very significant, and show how rapidly the front of treason is rearing itself in our City. The hope now is that others will follow FERNANDO WOOD's example, and that all who do really desire a "splendid tyrant," (JEFF. DAVIS,) instead of a Constitutional President, (Mr. LINCOLN,) will, like WOOD, have the boldness to say so. When the position of Mr. SEYMOUR and his friends is as sharply defined on all hands, as Mr. WOOD defines his, the labor of patriot speakers and journalists will be over.

abstract: The Northern allies of the rebels are uttering a daily untruth in declaring that the President has issued a proclamation emancipating the slaves of rebels. He has done no such thing. He has called on them to refrain from their treason, and admonished them that unless they do so by the beginning of next year, he will then, as a military measure, assail their strongest entrenchment by freeing their slaves. The Seymour party, therefore, stand on this dilemma when they denounce the proclamation, that they thereby declare their preference that the Union shall be dissolved and the Government destroyed, sooner than the slaves of rebels shall be freed. This is a serfdom to Slavery exceeding that of the slaves to their masters.

abstract: As to the bare fact, it is stated, not that JEFFERSON DAVIS has made a nation of the South, but the South is a nation already, and JEFFERSON DAVIS has given it a form and a name. Mr. GLADSTONE has, therefore, only made a statement considerably within the truth, He has, however, only stated what we all of us see, and cannot but see.
lead_paragraph: As to the bare fact, it is stated, not that JEFFERSON DAVIS has made a nation of the South, but the South is a nation already, and JEFFERSON DAVIS has given it a form and a name. Mr. GLADSTONE has, therefore, only made a statement considerably within the truth, He has, however, only stated what we all of us see, and cannot but see. The Federals do not see it, because they will not see it. The greater the truth, the greater the libel. They are exasperated because there is so much substance and solidity in a disagreeable fact. We old stagers of the Old World have so many, such bitter experiences, we have been so schooled by adversity, that we know how to take things that cannot possibly be helped. Our wisdom runs largely on the folly of trying to mend what cannot be helped, of crying over split [???], and the like. By this time we have learnt to eat humble pie with a good grace, both at home and abroad, as Washington can testify. Thy Americans are as yet in their political boyhood, and cannot brook the dry lessons of experience and the stubborn logic of facts. As Mr. GLADSTONE says, they have noble instincts and generous emotions. They can feel and talk well -- a little too well; but they have not yet drunk the cup of bitterness as England has. They thought it was never to come to them. They are mistaken, but will not acknowledge it.

abstract: ADELAIDE IRWIN was indicted for petit larceny from the person of Mrs. HELEN McNAUGHT. This case occupied considerable time, and in its consideration a question of no slight importance was suggested. The case, as presented by District-Attorney ...
lead_paragraph: ADELAIDE IRWIN was indicted for petit larceny from the person of Mrs. HELEN McNAUGHT. This case occupied considerable time, and in its consideration a question of no slight importance was suggested. The case, as presented by District-Attorney STEWART, and testified to by Mrs. MCNAUGHT, is this: As the lady was riding in the omnibus, in June last, the prisoner, who was a fellow-passenger, pulled the strap, got out, and walked hurriedly off. The complainant mechanically placed her hand upon her pocket, and ascertained that her wallet was gone. Suspecting the departed girl as the thief, she left the stage, pursued, caught and collared her, being rewarded therefor by the discovery of the wallet and its contents in her possession.

abstract: From Lancashire to America the transition was easy. Mr. GLADSTONE has never concealed that he is favorable to Southern independence. From so impartial a mind we should have been glad to hear what best could be said for that cause. He does not think that the special interests of England will be served by the disruption; he rather thinks it was for the interest of England that the Union should continue. One, and one only, reason for approving the separation he venturesto name. It will leave the negroes with less compression on them than before -- the compression of their own masters, instead of that of the entire Union. But can Mr. GLADSTONE think that it makes any practical difference to the slaves whether they are kept down by the Southern army which fought at Bull Run and Antietam Creek, or by that and the Northern army added to it? We do not find fault with him for recognizing the progress which the South has made in establishing its independence. It is the proper business of a statesman to look before all thihings at the facts. Mr. Jefferson Davis has probably made a nation of the South, and in the place of a group of communities, with various pursuits, characters, and civilization, developed in peace and freedom, we shall see "nations," which in Mr. DAVIS' sense were previously unknown, with standing armies, standing navies, standing debts, and undying national enmities. It will be a poor day for England that ratifies this change in the character of her heretofore prosperous customers. Mr. GLADSTONE spoke of the South. But he knows that North and South are not all. Could not he have said one word in favor of saving from the curse of Slavery the vast countries which must fall to one or other of the combatants, but whose destiny is at present undecided? Since he spoke of British counsel as a possible element in the final settlement, he might have touched on that topic. But we must do him the justice of acknowledging that his references to the North, were most kindly and honorable.

abstract: Nathaniel S. Bouton vs. Charles B. Phillips. -- The facts of this case are these, as appeared on the trial. The defendant advertised for proposals for the iron work of a building in Chicago, intended to be used as a continuation of the Richmond Hotel in that city. In answer to the advertisement for proposals, the firm of Stone, Boomer & Bouton, iron manufacturers, of Chicago, made a proposal, as defendant claims, to do the whole work for $3,200. The plaintiff, however, who sues as assignee of Stone, Boomer & Bouton, alleges that they made three bids, each for specified portions of the work, which were accepted by the defendant, and on the first of those bids, viz.: the one for $2,950, the action was based. The defence further set up that Stone, Boomer & Bouton had not complied with the terms of their contract; but had delayed the work so that it ultimately proved of no value to him.
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel S. Bouton vs. Charles B. Phillips. -- The facts of this case are these, as appeared on the trial. The defendant advertised for proposals for the iron work of a building in Chicago, intended to be used as a continuation of the Richmond Hotel in that city. In answer to the advertisement for proposals, the firm of Stone, Boomer & Bouton, iron manufacturers, of Chicago, made a proposal, as defendant claims, to do the whole work for $3,200. The plaintiff, however, who sues as assignee of Stone, Boomer & Bouton, alleges that they made three bids, each for specified portions of the work, which were accepted by the defendant, and on the first of those bids, viz.: the one for $2,950, the action was based. The defence further set up that Stone, Boomer & Bouton had not complied with the terms of their contract; but had delayed the work so that it ultimately proved of no value to him.

abstract: The nature of our dispatches from the Army of the Potomac leads us to believe that if a general advance of our lines has not already taken place, it will take place very soon--probably to-day. Orders were issued on Thursday night to the various commands to be ready for an advance yesterday morning, and Gens. PORTER, MORELL and GRIFFIN returned from Washington and resumed their respective positions.
lead_paragraph: The nature of our dispatches from the Army of the Potomac leads us to believe that if a general advance of our lines has not already taken place, it will take place very soon -- probably to-day. Orders were issued on Thursday night to the various commands to be ready for an advance yesterday morning, and Gens. PORTER, MORELL and GRIFFIN returned from Washington and resumed their respective positions. It is reported that the rebels, in considerable force, occupy a position about three miles beyond Shepherdstown.

abstract: Editorial sees election of Seymour party as end of Northern unity; Editorial sees election of Seymour party causing end of Northern unity
snippet: Editorial sees election of Seymour party as end of Northern unity; Editorial sees election of Seymour party causing end of Northern unity
lead_paragraph: The Richmond papers are jubilant -- and they are apt to be so when the cause, of the Union has received detriment. They rejoiced over the first battle of Bull Run. There were those among us who rejoiced also. They rejoiced over Ball's Bluff, over the days before Richmond, over the days in Northern Virginia -- and the same parties among us rejoiced over them all. Loyal men met their exultant smiles amid the gloomy faces of those who loved their country, and could hardly resist the impulse to smite back the traitorous rejoicing which thus had broken forth from the depths of traitor hearts. And now again the Richmond papers exult, and again we see among us that baleful exultation upon those traitor faced. Both rebels in Richmond and rebel sympathizers here rejoice together. Surely it is not that they think that our cause, the cause of the nation, the cause of freedom, the cause of the Stars and Stripes has advanced and been prosperous.

abstract: My name, I see, is again used in connection with a political office, without my know- ledge or consent. I shall remain at my post, doing all I can to sustain the Government in putting down the rebellion; and at a moment when the existence of the nation is hanging by a thread, I cannot leave my duties here to be drawn into any party strife.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Oct. 22, 1862.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, the Recorder passed sentence upon the following persons, previously convicted: ANNA SINGLETON, for grand larceny, State Prison for two years; WM. HENRY, for attempt at grand larceny, State Prison two years and six months; JOSEPHINE WILSON for keeping a disorderly house, fined $175. In the case of ADELAIDE IRWIN, convicted of petit larceny from the person, the Recorder, in consideration of the youth of the prisoner, suspended sentence, and informed her that he would give her one more chance to reform her habits. He cautioned her against continuing the associations she had heretofore kept, and told her that if she was herafter found committing any offence against the law she would be brougtht up and sentenced under this conviction to the full term allowed by law -- five years in the State Prison. The Court also suspended sentence in the case of JOHN O'CONOR, who, in a drunken frotic, stole a horse and wagon, and gave the prisoner similar warning and advice.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, the Recorder passed sentence upon the following persons, previously convicted: ANNA SINGLETON, for grand larceny, State Prison for two years; WM. In the case of ADELAIDE IRWIN, convicted of petit larceny from the person, the Recorder, in consideration of the youth of the prisoner, suspended sentence, and informed her that he would give her one more chance to reform her habits. He cautioned her against continuing the associations she had heretofore kept, and told her that if she was herafter found committing any offence against the law she would be brougtht up and sentenced under this conviction to the full term allowed by law -- five years in the State Prison. The Court also suspended sentence in the case of JOHN O'CONOR, who, in a drunken frotic, stole a horse and wagon, and gave the prisoner similar warning and advice.

abstract: Of all the pursuits in which men engage, war is emphatically a game of destruction. To consume is the business of armies. How exhaustive it is of human life all have considered, but it needs the startling figures which remain in the documents of the War Departments, when peace ...
lead_paragraph: Of all the pursuits in which men engage, war is emphatically a game of destruction. To consume is the business of armies. How exhaustive it is of human life all have considered, but it needs the startling figures which remain in the documents of the War Departments, when peace has returned, to enable one to comprehend to what extent war absorbs the products of peaceful industries, and uses the labor of those who never see the field.

abstract: A library has been established upon the island for the use of the invalid soldiers. Contributions of books and magazines are requested. As there are many Germans, and some French and Italians, in the hospitals, works in either of these languages will be acceptable. Experience has shown that books of travel, memoirs and histories are quite as desirable as works of fiction, and that philosophical works are valued by many inmates of the hospital, as there are among them minds capable of appreciating the highest literary productions. The hospital is a United States institution. Contributions must be delivered free of charge, and may be sent to

abstract: Time presses. Yet a few weeks and the services of WM. CORNELL JEWETT may be for- ever lost to the United States and to Colorado Territory. Our only hope of averting so direful a calamity lies in the prompt action of the President. WM. CORNELL JEWETT has published a second letter upon American affairs in London. It differs from his first letter in certain particulars of slight importance, but in ...
lead_paragraph: Time presses. Yet a few weeks and the services of WM. CORNELL JEWETT may be for- ever lost to the United States and to Colorado Territory. Our only hope of averting so direful a calamity lies in the prompt action of the President. WM. CORNELL JEWETT has published a second letter upon American affairs in London. It differs from his first letter in certain particulars of slight importance, but in that great quality of style, which, as BUFFON justly observed, "is the man," the two epistles are identical. Each is JEWETT -- pure, perfect and unadulterated. This time, however, JEWETT addresses his remarks, not to the "Governments of Europe," but simply and majestically, in huge capitals, "To THE EDITOR." What editor? The ideal editor, we presume -- the " able editor," in whatever clime, and of whatever hue. JEWETT, let us also observe, no longer dates from "Morley's Hotel." Whether from some difficulty as to the rates of exchange upon bills drawn against Colorado Territory, or from whatever causes, it would appear that JEWETT has left Morley's. Perhaps, he has gone to stay with " the Governments." Nothing more probable, when we consider the solemn decision to which JEWETT is sadly tending in respect of this hapless Republic.

abstract: Editorial compares provisions for Union and Confederate soldiers
snippet: Editorial compares provisions for Union and Confederate soldiers
lead_paragraph: All other things being equal, those men will fight best who are best fed, best clothed and best armed. It is for this reason that the people of the United States have relied so surely on an carly success against the rebels. They knew the latter to be illy prepared to feed large bodies of men in mass; that they had no manufactories for clothing equal to Southern wants, and no arms save what they had taken from the United States in the early seizure of Southern arsenals.

abstract: Eighteen sick and discharged Soldiers engaged passage to come North, of Mr. PRATT, of the firm of PRATT, DAVIS,  SCHAUS, corner of New-Levee and Gravier-streets, New-Orleans, on the steamer Cumbria, Forty-five dollars per man was demanded, for which they were promised good fare, and good accommodations.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen sick and discharged Soldiers engaged passage to come North, of Mr. PRATT, of the firm of PRATT, DAVIS, & SCHAUS, corner of New-Levee and Gravier-streets, New-Orleans, on the steamer Cumbria, Forty-five dollars per man was demanded, for which they were promised good fare, and good accommodations. They agreed to these terms, although twentyfive dollars is the proper price for the passage, and good fare, and gave Mr. PRATT, as security for the payment of the passage money, their certificates, which were demanded, for payment, averaging five months' pay, and mileage, which were payable in New-York, and are now in the hands of Mr. J.B. GAGER, agent for Mr. PRATT, at No. 104 Wall-street.

abstract: The country is gratified with the news of a new victory on the famous field of Pea Ridge. Gen. SCHOFIELD accomplished a movement, very much like a surprise, against the enemy, encamped on the old battle-ground. Gen. BLUNT was sent to make the attack from one direction; Gen. SCHOFIELD attacked from another.Gen. BLUNT, after "a hard night's march" -- whether with or without entire personal comfort is not stated -- " came to time," and the enemy was badly beaten, losing all their artillery and considerable quantity of transportation equipments, which it will be hard for the rebels to replace west of the Mississippi. The rebel General, HINDMAN, exhibited the speed of a well-trained courser in running away from SCHOFIELD.

abstract: Thos. B. Stillman vs. Samuel L. Mitchell. -This is the suit to recover $27,000 on the sale of certain steamers. The case has taken three days to try, and has been before mentioned in the TIMES. The defendant, it will be remembered, was the President of the New-York and Savannah Steam Navigation Company, who sold the vessels Augusta, Alabama and Florida to the Government for $276,500, of which plaintiff claims ten per cent, as commission for negotiating the sale. The defence was that plaintiff had no authority to act in the matter, and that the sale was effected by another party, namely, George D. Morgan, who had been handsomely paid for the work.
lead_paragraph: Thos. B. Stillman vs. Samuel L. Mitchell. -This is the suit to recover $27,000 on the sale of certain steamers. abstract: The Seymourites have set themselves up as the champions not only of Free Speech but also of Decorum in Debate. They were unanimously horrified that CASSIUS M. CLAY should say that there would have been less chance of the rebellion if some men like FERNANDO WOOD had been hung.
lead_paragraph: The Seymourites have set themselves up as the champions not only of Free Speech but also of Decorum in Debate. They were unanimously horrified that CASSIUS M. CLAY should say that there would have been less chance of the rebellion if some men like FERNANDO WOOD had been hung. Such a remark shocked them, and they proclaimed far and wide how much they abhorred such things, how dreadful it was that any one, should have so unchristian a temper as to make such a speech, and how plainly it was the duty of every man to set his face against those who could be guilty of such an outrage upon Decorum.
headline: {'main': 'Democratic Decorum.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Democratic Decorum.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The memorable battle-field of Pea Ridge, in Arkansas, has been made further memorable by another battle and another victory of the National arms. Gen. CURTIS telegraphs from St. Louis to Gen. HALLECK, that Gen. SCHOFIELD, finding the enemy had camped at Pea Ridge, sent Gen. BLUNT.
lead_paragraph: The memorable battle-field of Pea Ridge, in Arkansas, has been made further memorable by another battle and another victory of the National arms. Gen. CURTIS telegraphs from St. Louis to Gen. HALLECK, that Gen. SCHOFIELD, finding the enemy had camped at Pea Ridge, sent Gen. BLUNT with one division westward, and himself moved toward Huntsville with the rest of his forces Gen. BLUNT, after a hard night's march, attacked a rebel force from five to seven thousand strong, on the morning of the 22d, at Maysville, and after an engagement lasting an hour, totally routed the enemy, capturing all their artillery, a large number of horses, and a large portion of the transportation and garrison equipments. At last accounts Gen. BLUNT's cavalry and light howitzers were still in pursuit of the flying rebels. Meantime Gen. SCHOFIELD pursued the rebels under HINDMAN beyond Huntsville, and coming close upon them, they precipitately fled beyond the Boston Mountains. The mission of the Army of the Frontier has thus been gallantly and successfully accomplished.

abstract: It appears after all, that the main body of Gen. BUELL'S army has not been beyond Crab Orchard, Gen. abstract: The last accounts from Vera Cruz received in Havana mention the arrival in the former place of a Spaniard, proceeding from Mexico City, who brings accounts of the enthusiasm displayed in the capital and other places to resist the French invasion.
lead_paragraph: The last accounts from Vera Cruz received in Havana mention the arrival in the former place of a Spaniard, proceeding from Mexico City, who brings accounts of the enthusiasm displayed in the capital and other places to resist the French invasion. Several forts have been built, and every one in the City of Mexico has been obliged to take up arms. According to accounts received from Vera Cruz, Gens. URAGA and COMONFORT were expected in the capital, and it was publicly reported that Gen. ORTEGA, who has been appointed Commander-in-Chief on the death of ZARAGOZA, would be relieved of his office. The [???] Mexico General, who held the supreme command of the Mexican Army, died of typhons fever on the 9th of last month. BERRIGZABAL, [???] and DORLADO were said to be likewise sick. The correspondent of the Havana newspaper, the [???] Vera Cruz, inquires sarcastically, whether there had been administered a soup a la Julienne, but there is nothing to warrant a similar accusation.

abstract: The second trotting-match between Gen. Butler and Rockingham took place on Friday afternoon, Both horses went to sulky, and the race was from the commencement to the end of the fourth heat when it was too dark to finish the contest one of the fastest, ...
lead_paragraph: The second trotting-match between Gen. Butler and Rockingham took place on Friday afternoon, Both horses went to sulky, and the race was from the commencement to the end of the fourth heat -- when it was too dark to finish the contest -- one of the fastest, closest and most exciting races that has ever taken place on the Long Island courses; not excepting the best doings of Flora Temple or Patchen. Previous to the start, $100 to $70 was current in favor of Butler, and after the first heat the betting was even. Some delay occurred in scoring on the first heat, which drew from Capt. RYNDERS the threat that, if any further delay took place, he and the other judges would leave the stand, and other judges might be selected.

abstract: The friends of the President holding official Fede- ral positions in this city, together with the United States naval officers belonging to the Navy-yard, ten- dered Mrs. LINCOLN the compliment of a serenade at the Metropolitan Hotel, at 10 o'clock last evening.
lead_paragraph: The friends of the President holding official Fede- ral positions in this city, together with the United States naval officers belonging to the Navy-yard, ten- dered Mrs. LINCOLN the compliment of a serenade at the Metropolitan Hotel, at 10 o'clock last evening. The Navy-yard Band, comprising twenty-eight pieces, JAS. MALE, leader, was engaged for the occasion. Fully three thousand persons had assembled in front of the hotel, awaiting the commencement of the exercises, and the balcony and front parlor were filled with ladies and gentlemen. Precisely at 10 o'clock the band struck up the National airs, after which Hon. Mr. LOWE, of California, introduced Col. A.J. HAMILTON, of Texas, who spoke as follows:

abstract: The trial of Albert Horn, charged with fitting out the steamer City of Norfolk as a slaver, was con- tinued. The witness Beaufort was still examined, and testified I never saw Horn on the vessel but once, but was at this office a number of times; Tilton ...
lead_paragraph: The trial of Albert Horn, charged with fitting out the steamer City of Norfolk as a slaver, was continued. The witness Beaufort was still examined, and testified -- I never saw Horn on the vessel but once, but was at this office a number of times; Tilton was Captain of the vessel from here; Crawford was mate; I was second mate; Schomberg had general management of fitting her out; he was aboard nearly every day; I went to see Horn once about coal and he asked me when Schomberg had been there; he told me to go and order coal, and I did; I saw Schomberg pay money to the men; 26 or 27 persons left New-York in the vessel; we went to St. Thomas; Tilton left the vessel there, and Crawford took command; Curvelo and Mandillo went in the vessel from New-York; they went ashore at St. Thomas; I was ashore there 12 or 15 times; the vessel was there 12 or 15 days; I saw Curvelo ashore there; I was supposed to be first mate after we left St. Thomas; Flores acted as second mate; we took out six Spaniards from New-York, besides a Spanish steward; at St. Thomas we discharged part of the cargo; kept on board bread, beans, rice, bacon, mackerel, 60 or 70 barrels of bread, 25 or 30 barrels of beans, 25 tierces of rice, 1,500 pounds of bacon, 75 or 100 boxes of herrings, one barrel of palm oil, which was afterwards mixed with the negroes' food; we took on board cargo at St. Thomas; there was no change of crew at St. Thomas; no new persons went from St. Thomas; Tilton and Curvelo stayed in St. Thomas; we went from St. Thomas to Barcelona, in Venezuela; on our way there shooks were put up into casks; we took a few cabin stores there, and some water; from Barcelona we went directly to the coast of Africa, and made land near Cape St. Paul, on Tuesday, Aug. 7, 1860; we hoisted a flag as we ran within two miles of the coast -- a private signal; then we ran down the coast a short distance, and a canoe came on board with a man in it; this was in the Bight of Benin; we took on board between 500 and 900 negroes at Whydah; took them as soon as we let go the anchor; remained there from about 8 A.M. till about 8 P.M.; no one went ashore; one passenger came aboard -- a Portuguese, I think; the vessel sailed that evening, and came back to Cuba; at Cuba the negroes were landed; after that we got the ship under way and took her out to sea; ran out into 16 or 17 fathoms of water; I told the men to lower the boats and get into them; we stopped the ship, we got into the boats and abandoned the ship; Crawford and Mandillo were aboard and went ashore in one of the boats; the vessel and part of the crew were taken by a Spanish man-of-war; the men were afterward liberated by the Spanish Government, and were sent to Key West; I came in a steamer from Havana to New-York; I called on Horn next day after my arrival; he asked me about the ship, how many negroes we had on board, and how the ship came to be taken; I told him all the particulars, and he said it was a sorry job; he paid me $25 then, and $200 in all; I arrived here about Oct. 15 or 16; a year or so after I came back I was sick in the country; I was in Horn's office a dozen times; went into the country in May; I was informed by note from Mr. Horn's clerk that there was a warrant out for me; I was not at home when the note came; I saw Horn after I came back from the country; I met him on Broadway; he said, "What are you doing here? don't you know you will be arrested?" I said I was going back in the country: he said I had better go, and stay there; I saw him again on my return from the country the second time; he told me he had been arrested, and that I had better clear out, and not stay in New-York; Horn told me, after I came back from Havana, that he had lost a great deal of money by the ship, somewhere about $9,000; he read me a letter from Mandillo; he stated that he had paid the crew who were not taken some small sum of money; Horn stated that Mandillo said he would send me some money through Horn -- $600; it was to be paid to Horn's brother, in Havana; Horn said Mandillo said that for the negroes taken to land he had received the money for; about April I went to Horn, and asked him if the money had been sent from Havana, and he said "No"; I went again and he said it had not come, and he did not think I would get it, as the merchants were failing there; he offered to buy my claim, and paid me $200 for it; he asked me to leave the City three or four times; I talked with Capt. Tilton before we left here about fitting out the ship; we were talking about the coast of Africa; he said he thought she would carry so many negroes; I differed from him; we spoke of what she would make if she did carry as many negroes -- some $300,000 or $400,000. Nothing was said about Horn's buying the vessel, nor of her being transferred to Crawford; on the voyage out to St. Thomas, I heard of her being sold from Tilton; he did not say what kind of a sale it was to be; at St. Thomas I heard that Curvelo and Mandillo were to purchase her and take title in Crawford's name.

abstract: An unfortunate accident occurred, at East Newark yesterday morning. As the 8 o'clock train for New-York, from the Morris and Essex depot, was passing that place, a soldier from a troop train which was temporarily detained there, foolishly attempted to cross the track in front of the locomotive. The train was going at the rate of only ten or twelve miles an hour, but the engineer was unable to cheek its speed until it had struck the unfortunate soldier and thrown him from the track. At first it was feared that he was fatally injured, but a careful examination showed that besides a few bruises he only sustained the fracture of one of his legs. Mr. JERE. COUNSELLOR, the conductor in charge of the Morris and Essex train, with characteristic humanity, did all in his power for the sufferer, and sent him promptly to the Newark Hospital, where he now lies. He blames no one but himself for the unfortunate occurrence.

At first it was feared that he was fatally injured, but a careful examination showed that besides a few bruises he only sustained the fracture of one of his legs. Mr. JERE. COUNSELLOR, the conductor in charge of the Morris and Essex train, with characteristic humanity, did all in his power for the sufferer, and sent him promptly to the Newark Hospital, where he now lies. He blames no one but himself for the unfortunate occurrence.

abstract: FATAL FLUID ACCIDENT. Coroner COLLIN yesterday held an inquest at Beilevue Hospital upon the body of JAMES McCORMICK, a boy four years of age, who died from received by the accidental fall of a lighted fluid lamp.
lead_paragraph: FATAL FLUID ACCIDENT. -- Coroner COLLIN yesterday held an inquest at Beilevue Hospital upon the body of JAMES McCORMICK, a boy four years of age, who died from received by the accidental fall of a lighted fluid lamp. The deceased, with the mother and another child, were asleep in the cabin of a canal-boat, of the Hudson and Delaware line, when one of the boatmen came in with a lamp. By some mishap it fell to the floor, and almost instantly the entire interior of the cabin was in flames. The mother, in her efforts to save her children, was burned in a shocking manner, and she and her other child are now in the hospital, but no hopes are entertained of their recovery. The deceased was so seriously burned that he survived but a few hours. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.

abstract: Organized and Authorized Parlisan Rangers.  Under the provision of an act of Congress, approved April 21, 1822, and by authority of the War Department, I am raising and organizing a regiment of partisan rangers, to be under my command as Colonel, ...
lead_paragraph: Organized and Authorized Parlisan Rangers. -- Under the provision of an act of Congress, approved April 21, 1822, and by authority of the War Department, I am raising and organizing a regiment of partisan rangers, to be under my command as Colonel, C.S.A., for immediate and very active service in the military department (west of the Blue Ridge) now under the command of Maj.-Gen. TROS. J. JACKSON. The corps will be of a mixed character, mounted and on fool, adapted to the peculiar features of the country. The officers, except myself, will be elected as in other arms of the service; myself will be appointed and commissioned by the President.

abstract: REV. MR. CONWAY AT THE CAMP OF THE "IRONSIDES." Rev. Mr. CONWAY preached to the "Ironsides" in their beautiful camp at Jamaica, Long Island, yesterday.
lead_paragraph: REV. MR. CONWAY AT THE CAMP OF THE "IRONSIDES." -- Rev. Mr. CONWAY preached to the "Ironsides" in their beautiful camp at Jamaica, Long Island, yesterday. The services were held in the large building occupied by Quartermaster BALLARD. The exercises were commenced by singing and prayer, after which Mr. CONWAY proceeded to address his attentive audience from this text: "Be thou faithful unto death." After dwelling upon the importance of personal faith in God on the part of the soldier, he dwelt upon the value of faith in our country, and in the good cause in which we are engaged, and said in this connection: "There is too little faith in our country, especially here at home. The soldiers in the field believed sincerely that the enemies of our land are yet to be overthrown; this I am convinced of after eighteen months' experience among them. It is the duty of every man and woman to have faith in our country, and to have faith in no one who has not faith in the country, for such as have no faith are demagogues. God is always with those who are fighting for justice and liberty; and I believe we are more right in these respects than our enemies. No person should doubt that it is God's intention to overthrow the slave-power of this country; and whatever be our misfortunes, we should never allow ourselves to doubt this."

lead_paragraph: On the 26th of October, l826, the water of Lake Erie was admitted into the Canal, and a flotilla set out from the harbor of Buffalo, conveying the Governor, the Canal Commissioners, and numerous distinguished persons, bearing the symbols of the junction of the waters of the lake and the ocean. The flotilla was increased at Albany by an escort of steamboats, and when the aquatic procession entered the boundaries of the City of New-York, the corporation and public authorities joined it, while signal cannon thundered out the tidings of the event from the harbor of Buffalo to the shores of the ocean.

abstract: November
snippet: November
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's Magazine for November is as crisp and cheerful as one of the brilliant Fall days which we are now enjoying. During the sleepy Summer months it dragged heavily now and then, for Harpers, as well as Homers, must sometimes nod; but the Twenty-fifth Volume, of which this number is the finis, closes with a rush and flourish such as marks the advent of a stage-coach into one of the towns along its route, where the horses are changed and the passengers fed. J. ROSS BROWNE opens the number with one of his graphically written and illustrated papers. This time he discusses Poland Over-Ground. December will bring us the antithesis, Poland Under-Ground. Mr. BROWNE bears the same relation to the present generation of travelers that BAYARD TAYLOR did to that now passing off the stage. The latter described countries which few had seen, and was interesting in spite of himself; the former goes over and under ground which has been written of for the last quarter of a century, and surprises the most blasc tourist by showing him how much he has left unseen. "A Notable Congress" tells us much that very few people know regarding insects which are nearly omnipresent. Dr. GUERNSEY condenses Capt. GRONOW's interesting hook, "The Last of the Dandies," in a manner which will not diminish the desire to read the work itself. To be sure, it is no compliment to the members of a tribe which throngs Broadway on a pleasant afternoon to intimate that they are but imitators, and that the last of a race which they are feebly trying to perpetuate has passed from earth, or is very soon to take his conge, but Capt. GRONOW demonstrates the fact completely. Mr. LOSSING's sketch of the 'First Colonial Congress" embodies no new facts and might as well have been written by anybody else; and nearly the same might be said of W. PARKER SNOW's paper on "Arctic Explorations;" but these articles will both be read with interest by those who insist on having the historical department of the magazine sustained. Miss PRESSCOTT's story of "Madeleine Schaeffer" is concluded. "Romola," "Orley Farm," "Mistress and Maid," and "The Small House at Allington" we regard with more liking, as they nearer approach their respective end. It is a manifest improvement, however, to allow them to usurp but one-third the entire number of pages in a single issue; sometimes, when nothing better was at hand, they have been assigned one half of the whole number. It needs the genius of a MORPHY, or some one who can play half a dozen games of chess blindfolded, to keep distinct the thread of four or five serials in a monthly magazine, nor should the mental capacity of readers be taxed so cruelly. Of the Editor's Drawer not much can be said. Some jokes, which are not jokes at all, find a place. Those who feel an interest in the Drawer should drop into it a few grains of wit. The two illustrations. "The Regatta on the Steamer" and "The Regatta on the Yacht," seem a little like an after-thought, for the scenes which they represent transpired more than four months ago, and will not recur until next June, but the excellence of the sketches, which are the best that have appeared in Harper's for a long time, makes this anachronism pardonable. The poetry of this number is very good. "Non Respondet," by CLARENCE STICKNEY, is a nervous and spirited production; and Mr. SHEPARD's poem. "Autumn," contains some very line descriptive lines.

abstract: The entire success of the musical and dramatic season has encouraged Mr. GRAU to complete the organization of a good company for the Academy of Music, which will be opened on the 10th of November, under his management.
lead_paragraph: The entire success of the musical and dramatic season has encouraged Mr. GRAU to complete the organization of a good company for the Academy of Music, which will be opened on the 10th of November, under his management. The stockholders of the Fourteenth-street establishment, as well as the artists engaged there, have modified their terms to the standard of the times, and it is likely, therefore, that Mr. GRAU's season will extend through the whole Winter season. Something like an important effort at management is absolutely necessary to restore the Opera to its old position, as the leading fashionable amusement of the Metropolis. The brief and desultory seasons of last Winter, with their small excitements about smaller things, leave nothing to be remembered with pleasure. They were conducted with a strict view to economy, and under the conviction that a more important adventure would certainly fail. Just as surely would a repetition of the same sort of close management lead to disaster now. New-York has long since passed the rudimental state of opera, and, except under extraordinary circumstances, will be content with none but the perfect thing. Mr. GRAU is thoroughly alive to this fact, and his arrangements indicate an intention to restore, as far as possible, the palmiest days of operatic management. The season will be remarkable for the introduction of several new artists, and the production of MEYERBEER's latest opera, "Le Pardon de Ploermel." The impresario is singularly rich in prime donne, having a good half dozen of more or less reputation. Mme. GUERRABELLA, an American prima donna, who has achieved much success, will in all probability, open the season, followed by Mme. LORINI WHITING, another American, in dramatic roles, such as "Norma." Several of the best works of the Italian repertoire will be revived for these artists. About the second or third week of the season MEYERBEER's new work will be submitted to the public, the principal part -- Dinorah -- being sustained by Mll'e CORDIER. This is necessarily the great event of Mr. GRAU's season, and will attract the particular attention of the musical community. There is hardly a question about the success of the opera, unless it should be New-York's unenviable privilege to reverse the unanimous verdict of Europe. Wherever "Le Pardon de Ploermel" has been brought out, it has been received with the greatest enthusiasm by the public, and this notwithstanding the fact that the music is of a singularly reticent character. Like other works by the same master, it requires very ample resources, and we are glad to hear, therefore, that Mr. GRAU has no intention of economising with respect to the orchestra and chorus, both of which have heavy work to perform in the opera. In addition to the artists we have named, it is hinted that Miss KELLOGG, Miss CARLOTTA PATTI, and Madame STRAKOSCH will also belong to the company. There are no fresh names among the male artists, but it is only right to add that a better trio than BRIGNOLI, AMODIO, and SUSINI could not very easily be found. The company promises, indeed, to be one of the best we have had for many years, and the season one of the most interesting. If only a reasonable portion of the patronage which is showered on other places of amusement be extended to the Academy of Music, there can hardly be a doubt about the issue of Mr. GRAU's experiment. Signor MUZIO will be the conductor.
