abstract: Editorial on report Confederates are blockading NY ports with steamer at Azores, compelling ships from Europe to arrive via Greenland
snippet: Editorial on report Confederates are blockading NY ports with steamer at Azores, compelling ships from Europe to arrive via Greenland
lead_paragraph: The clipper-ship Dreadnaught, of this port, yesterday arrived in safety from Liverpool, after making a long detour to the northward, in order to avoid the attentions of Capt. SEMMES and the rebel steamer Alabama. It is somewhat humiliating for us to chronicle such a fact as this, and to admit that whereas we have been blockading Charleston and Savannah by fleets, at the very mouths of their harbors, for eighteen months, with the grand net result of sending into those ports more large foreign steamers than ever entered them before, the Confederates have succeeded in so thoroughly blockading New-York, by a couple of steamers at the Azores, as to compel our ordinary transatlantic commerce to coast the icy shores of Greenland for safety.

abstract: New edition of O W Holmes poetry reviewed; English translation of Les Miserables reviewed; Rev. H W Beecher's Eyes and Ears reviewed; English translation of Les Miserables reviewed
snippet: New edition of O W Holmes poetry reviewed; English translation of Les Miserables reviewed; Rev. H W Beecher's Eyes and Ears reviewed; English translation of Les Miserables reviewed
lead_paragraph: Of Les Miserables we may write, finished. The American rendering is also completed. VICTOR HEGO now has permission to commence another story equally good -- his translator is at liberty to resume the study of French in which he evidently was rather rudely interrupted. Gavroche, the phenomenal gamin, to our great sorrow, is dead, and the life-shade of that amiable convict, Jean Yaljean -- pronounced by ambitious beginners in French, Jaw Valjaw -- have run out beyond the reach of the most retired physician. The smoke has lifted and drifted away from the fatal barricades of June, and the men who fought so bravely and died so grimly behind them are swept away out of sight-buried anywhere but in Pere le Chaise. The daughter of the wretched Fantine, by the transmutation of favorable circumstances, becomes a happy wife and mother. One way or another, by marriage or by death, the misery of the miserables is ended, and the inexorable curtain rings down on all the characters, good and bad.

abstract: Editorial questions why Army of Potomac is delaying attack
snippet: Editorial questions why Army of Potomac is delaying attack
lead_paragraph: The representation made in some quarters that the public debt has reached $2,000,000,000 is a gross exaggeration. On the first day of the present month, we learn authoritatively, it was only $620,000,000, and is now less than $660,000,000. This amount includes the entire circulation and every species of notes and between $70,000,000 and $80,000,000 debt of the late Administration; but excepts claims for which no requisitions have yet been made. The claims adjusted and unadjusted cannot exceed $20,000,000.

abstract: The late experiments of the English Government at Shoeburyness will be found full of instruction, if we are willing, at last, to modify our wonted belief in the inevitable supremacy of whatever is American.
lead_paragraph: The late experiments of the English Government at Shoeburyness will be found full of instruction, if we are willing, at last, to modify our wonted belief in the inevitable supremacy of whatever is American. The fact that Mr. WHITWORTH (who has made a battery of guns for the rebels) drove through the "Warrior" target, at 600 yards, an explosive shell, which blew the debris of the plates and backing into what represented the vital parts of a ship; and the fact that Mr. CLAY, of the Mersey Iron Works, burst a hole as large as a barrel-head through the same target, at 200 yards. with his 13-inch wrought-iron gun and 74 pounds of powder; and the fact that Sir WILLIAM ARMSTRONG destroyed a similar target with his coiled "[???]-pounder," which, although the breesh-screw blew out with 90 pounds of powder, from an obvious delect in construction, did not burst in the barrel; and the fact that Mr. KRUPP has forged his wonderful east-steel into guns of 9-inch bore, without seam or weld, while the heaviest charge of powder known to our practice is [???]0 pounds, and that for a ball of 425 pounds weight, and, therefore, low velocity, and while the strongest material found in our ordnance, excepting only the light wrought-iron hoops of PARROTT, is cast-iron; these things, we remark, are worthy of very serious consideration.

abstract: Editorial on report New England soldiers returning from New Orleans by ship were swindled and ill-treated in passage
snippet: Editorial on report New England soldiers returning from New Orleans by ship were swindled and ill-treated in passage
lead_paragraph: Everybody remembers the howl of indignation which was raised in England four years ago over the hideous brutality of the East Indian Government's contractors to soldiers returning from Hindoostan to England. Brave men, who wore on their breasts the medals of Delhi and Lucknow, -- men whose stout arms and true hearts had been England's bulwark in her extreme hour of peril, -- men who had thrown their lives between the Sepoy and his prey, rescuing English honor from the dust and English mothers from despair and death, -- these men were packed away on board of leaking vessels, supplied with poisonous and tainted food, crowded in unventilated holds, and landed at last on the shores of the country they had covered with glory, half naked and more than half dead, wan, wasted, fever-smitten, to perish of disease, or to live as memorials of England's neglect and wrecks of England's honor. The pen of DICKENS was consecrated to their wrongs and to the branding of those by whom such wrongs had come. We read his eloquent outburst of righteous wrath, and shuddered at his terrible photograph of patient misery and heroic endurance. How little did we then dream that in our own country, and in our own city, we should be called to witness scenes as dark almost and as discreditable as those which gathered in gloom over the closing history of so many of the saviours of British India?
headline: {'main': 'The Penalty of Patriotism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Penalty of Patriotism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on need for NYC cavalry squadron; Editorial on various makes of guns and damage they can inflict
snippet: Editorial on need for NYC cavalry squadron; Editorial on various makes of guns and damage they can inflict
lead_paragraph: Our readers will bear witness to the earnestness with which we have urged the necessity of setting in the field a cavalry force commensurate with the other arms of the service, and equal to the requirements of campaigns carried on in a country as broad as ours. We are pleased to see that the Common Council of this City is awakening to the importance of the subject. A series of resolutions relating thereto were introduced in the Board of Aldermen on Saturday, which will be found among the proceedings of that body published in this issue; and further action in the matter will be taken speedily.

abstract: The Washington  Star publishes a plea for the quietude in the Army of the Potomac. which we transter to our columns. It opposes the policy of attacking the rebels at present, or for some time to come; and instead of seeing disasters, perceives naught but advantages in delay. The argument is old enough, and pretty well worn, but is restated as if it were quite a refreshing novelty.
lead_paragraph: -- The Washington Star publishes a plea for the quietude in the Army of the Potomac. which we transter to our columns. It opposes the policy of attacking the rebels at present, or for some time to come; and instead of seeing disasters, perceives naught but advantages in delay. The argument is old enough, and pretty well worn, but is restated as if it were quite a refreshing novelty. The gist of it is that it is unwise to assail the rebels, as their army is stronger now than it will be at any future time; while if we wait till the Northern conscription is enforced, our army will be greatly stronger than it is at present. Their supplies of arms and clothing are giving out, while ours is increasing; and we shall soon have a fleet of iron-clads to attack Charleston and Mobile -- though the Star says nothing about the fleet of iron-clads the rebels are likely to have if we give them plenty of time. Besides all this, the position of LEE at Winchester is very strong; and if he should be beaten there, he would retire to certain mountain passes and fight a succession of battles which may cost us 50,000 men, while one thousand rebel cavalry can compel MCCLELLAN to employ 50,000 more soldiers to watch them. But, on the other hand, if our Young General "elects to keep the rebels shivering in nakedness in the Valley for but a month" -- we shall see what we shall see.
headline: {'main': 'THE PLEA FOR DELAY', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE PLEA FOR DELAY', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The new building intended for the accommodation of the Plymouth Church Sunday-school is now nearly completed, and will soon be ready for occupation. The building fronts on Cranberry-street, and extends to the church edifice in the rear.
lead_paragraph: -- The new building intended for the accommodation of the Plymouth Church Sunday-school is now nearly completed, and will soon be ready for occupation. The building fronts on Cranberry-street, and extends to the church edifice in the rear. The first floor is 66 feet long, by 58 feet wide, with a ceiling 20 feet high and is divided into lecture-room, parlor, reception, and Trustee's rooms. Two stairways lead to the school-room on the second floor, which is to feet long, feet wide, and 20 feet in height, with a gallery at the side for the infant and Bible classes The former is 43 feet long, by 14 wide, with raised seats. The latter 22 feet long, by 14 feet wide -- both opening to the main room by movable sashes. A fountain is introduced in the centre of the school-room. An organ, by STUART of New-York, has been procured. The building is heated by two furnaces, one at each end. It is ventilated by three shafts from the ceilings and floors, a current of air being produced by gas burning in the shafts. The lecture-room is lighted by a row of small jets round three sides, at the bottom of the cornice, and the school-room by five circular reflectors, placed in the ceiling. The lecture-room is ornamented with a heavy cornice of three feet, running down to the top of columns, which are five feet from the sides; that space forming a beautiful colonade round three sides of the room. The entire cost, without furnishing, is $10,000.

abstract: The Louisville Journal of Oct. 23, has the following particulars of MORGAN'S performances at Cox's Creek and subsequently:  After the teamsters and guard, to the number of three hundred, were paroled, they were marched in...
lead_paragraph: The Louisville Journal of Oct. 23, has the following particulars of MORGAN'S performances at Cox's Creek and subsequently: After the teamsters and guard, to the number of three hundred, were paroled, they were marched in front of a cavalry company in the direction of Lebanon Junction, and were required to perform the journey on foot, the greater portion of the way in double-quick time. On the route three of the paroled Federal prisoners were wantonly shot and killed upon shallow pretexts. A youth who belonged to an Illinois regiment, who had been captured and formally paroled Gen. KIREY SMITH, was thus murdered, simply because he exhibited his parole and claimed the rights which belong to a paroled prisoner.

abstract: Yesterday was an occasion of remarkable interest to the congregation of the old John-street Methodist Episcopal Church, of which Rev. W.H. MILBURN, known more generally as "the blind preacher," is now the officiating pastor. It was the ninety-fourth anniversary of the establishment of the organization and of the edifice now represented by the improved structure still in use as a place of worship. In the lapse of nearly a century the old altar has not been removed from its original site, and the improvements have consisted merely in the adaptation of modern ideas of comfort and convenience.

abstract: This ship, about whom some little anxiety has been expressed, as it was said the commander of the rebel privateer Alabama had taken a fancy to her, and was looking after her, arrived yesterday morning, after a very boisterous passage of 24 days. Capt. SAMUELS had heard of the intention of the commander of the Alabama while in England, and although admiring his taste, determined to disappoint him, and in consequence, came out of the North Channel and made an extremely northern passage, coasting along Greenland, Newfoundland and Long Island, experiencing much heavy westerly weather. When in lat. 48° lon. 46° 05, passed a large iceberg. She has a full and valuable cargo, with 165 passengers, all well.

abstract: BEN. WOOD IN DANGER. -- The Jeffersonian Democracy of this District, indisposed to let "Love and Secession" have their own way, have nominated as an opponent of BEN. WOOD, Mr. WILLIAM L. ELLSWORTH, formerly under Mr. BUCHANAN, the United States Consul-General for Cyprus. Mr. ELLSWORTH is highly popular with his party, and unlike Mr. WOOD, is a war Democrat, not at all tainted with treason, and sure to support the Administration with energy so long as it prosecutes with vigor the contest against traitors. There is no doubt of Mr. ELLSWORTH's election.

abstract: The promises of a forward movement of the Army of the Potomac are at last likely to be fulfilled. Gen. PLEASANTON, with his cavalry and four pieces of artillery crossed a new pontoon...
lead_paragraph: The promises of a forward movement of the Army of the Potomac are at last likely to be fulfilled. Gen. PLEASANTON, with his cavalry and four pieces of artillery crossed a new pontoon bridge at Berlin, six miles below Harper's Ferry, on Sunday at daylight, and proceeded direct to Lovettsville, in Loudon County, from which point he subsequently proceeded toward Leesburgh. Shortly after the crossing of the cavalry, Gen. BURNSIDE, with his Second Army Corps, commenced crossing at the same point, and occupied nearly the whole day in passing over. He occupied Lovettsville at night, and was expected to move forward yesterday morning -- in what direction is not yet known. Other divisions of the army were prepared to follow from Bolivar Heights and other points higher up. The reports from the front announce that the rebels have drawn in their pickets at Charlestown, abandoned Martinsburgh, after completing the destruction of the railroad property, and fallen back toward Winchester. Whether they have retreated beyond that point or will give battle there is the great point to be developed by the movements of our army.

abstract: Patriotism is not the last refuge of the scoundrel, old Dr. JOHNSON to the contrary notwithstanding. FERNANDO WOOD is not a whit nearer this so-called last shift than be
lead_paragraph: Patriotism is not the last refuge of the scoundrel, old Dr. JOHNSON to the contrary notwithstanding. FERNANDO WOOD is not a whit nearer this so-called last shift than be fore the late decision of the Court of Appeals in the MARVINE case. Instead of hiding his shame in mock devotion to his country, he makes himself more at home in faction and sedition than ever. The same spirit which impelled him to resist the Metropolitan Police Law by force -- to instigate the bread-riots -- to telegraph to TOOMBS to stick to the muskets -- to recommend, by official message, that New-York should join the South in seceding -- to threaten, at the Academy of Music, that Congress should be broken up and dispersed, still cleaves to him. In fact he never was on quite so fierce a rampage as just now. In his speech at his ratification meeting as nominee for Congress, he declares what he is going to do when he gets to Washington. "I am going to the President, and I will tell him that without we have a change of measures, so help me God! we will make a change of men." If Old ABE don't listen to his dictation, what then? Why he soon says, in a connection that cannot be mistaken: "A despotism has come upon us; and if a despotism has come, if we are to have a tyrant, I want a splendid, brilliant ruler, one that has nerve and brain, and is equal to the emergency." In other words, the President must do the bidding of the Fernando Woods of the country, or somebody shall be put in his place who will.
headline: {'main': 'Fernando Wood.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Fernando Wood.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: are looking with greater interest than ever for news from our army on the Upper Potomac. The telegraph has been permitted to announce that the movement of the army has already begun; and as the late heavy rains have undoubtedly raised the water in the Potomac so as to permit the whole of MCCLELLAN'S force to advance, we shall probably have news of a rebel retreat or of a battle, before the end of this week. It has generally been thought that, when Gen. MCCLELLAN moved from Harper's Ferry, he would march directly down upon LEE's army at Winchester, and fight the rebel leader and his bests in their chosen position. An article we published yesterday, however, showed how satisfactory a battle must be, even if [???] the rebels in a general engagement, at Winchester, as there were innumerable mountain passes which small bodies of the enemy could hold, and thus prevent our following up a victory. There are other and better lines of advance for our army than would be that up the Shenandoah Valley; and Gen. MCCLELLAN will very likely first compel the rebels to leave their stronghold before he attacks them.

abstract: Last evening, at No. 410 Grand-street, a meeting was held for the purpose of ratifying the nomination of Gen. JAMES S. WADSWORTH for Governor, and Capt. JOHN DUFFY, of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, for Congress. Mr. ANDREW CRAFT was in the Chiar. Mr. ABRAM WAREMAN was to have addressed the meeting, but was prevented by previous engagements, and Dr. JAMES C. JACKSON, of Livingston County, spoke in his behalf. A series of resolutions, pledging the meeting to the support of the candidates, were adopted, Speeches of the most enthusiastic and patriotic nature were then made by Messrs. JOSEPH HOXIE, CHAS. SPENCER and LAMBERT. To-morrow evening a special meeting will be held.

abstract: The U.S. steam transport Honduras, Capt. CLIFFORD, arrived at this port last evening in eight days from Pensacola, bringing a mail and passengers. She left at Pensacola the U.S. steam transport St. Mary's, for New-Orleans; also, U.S. flagship Hartford, U.S. steamers Brooklyn and Susquehanna, and U.S. ships Preble and Potomac.

abstract: There are those at present in the rebel army guilty of a very great crime, it must be admitted, against their country, but yet possessing ability equally great to serve the cause of freedom, if they will repent and come back to duty. Among these we may name STERLING PRICE, of Missouri, as conspicuous. PRICE was a Union man long after the war of rebellion was commenced. He was President of the Union Convention of Missouri, and when he took up arms it was in the name of the State of Missouri, and to vindicate State laws against what he deemed unauthorized military interference. For months in the field PRICE was not recognized by the Confederate rebel Government, and he refused to recognize or obey them.
lead_paragraph: There are those at present in the rebel army guilty of a very great crime, it must be admitted, against their country, but yet possessing ability equally great to serve the cause of freedom, if they will repent and come back to duty. abstract: J T Brady speaks, Democratic rally, Brooklyn; favors vigorous prosecution of war; J T Brady favors vigorous prosecution of war, speech at Democratic rally, NYC
snippet: J T Brady speaks, Democratic rally, Brooklyn; favors vigorous prosecution of war; J T Brady favors vigorous prosecution of war, speech at Democratic rally, NYC
lead_paragraph: A large audience was assembled at the rooms of the Union Democratic Association, No. 927 Broadway, to listen to an address by JAMES T. BRADY, Esq., upon the issues of the day. Shortly after 8 o'clock, the President of the Association made his appearance on the platform, accompanied by the orator of the evening, who was greeted with loud cheers. He was at once introduced to the audience, and proceeded to say that instead of calling them fellow-citizens and fellow-Democrats, he perhaps ought to follow the example of a distinguished orator who, on a memorable occasion, in addressing the residents of this City, called them "Fellow-traitors." He was happy to have the honor of addressing them at that particular juncture in our history, and was glad to see the old and the young men assembled together to give free and fearless expression to the sentiments which the Democracy entertained, and sentiments which were not only entertained by them, but were silently and secretly cherished in many a bosom of conservative Republicans in the land. [Applause.] The young men who had banded themselves together in that Association, to disseminate their principles and sustain their doctrines, would not only cover their own names over with glory, but the names of all who love them with glory and prosperity. That was the first time for a long period that he had made a political address. It had been his misfortune during a year past to suffer from an affection of the throat, which had led him to be cautious in speaking before large bodies of men; but the very last public address that he made he could recur to with just pride in view of the aspersions cast upon the Democracy in reference to their loyalty to the flag and arms of our country. The very last speech that he made in public, and one that seriously aggravated the illness under which he was laboring, was when he had the honor of presenting a flag to a regiment of Massachusetts soldiers, on its way to the war. [Cheers.] He was glad to have the opportunity of addressing his fellow-citizens in New-York, as he was wont to do on the eve of an important election. He began to do so when there was no danger of any species of treason in the land, at a time when that party, which, after different mutations was at last presented in the form of a species of republicanism, to which he would allude again, was engaged in opposing that great man who stirred the profoundest depths of every young man's heart in the time when he began his life -- JACKSON, whose name is a tower of strength. But was he not mistaken in saying that there was going to be an election? He had always understood an election involved the idea in some way of a choice between two sets of principles and two sets of candidates, but he had seen instructed, from what he had seen in the papers emanating from some of the so-called distinguished orators of the fanatical and rabid portion of the Republican Party, that there was to be no election at all -- [laughter] -- that there was to be but one candidate -- and that, as the lawyers would say, the whole of this must go by default. He was informed by them that the only choice left for them was that which the man gave his wife on the occasion of a severe domestic feud, when he said to her, after a great deal of altercation: "My darling, you can stay in this house or not, exactly as you please, but I am determined you shan't stay." Mr. BRADY then alluded to the resolution proposed some time ago by GEORGE W. BLUNT, who informed the people of this intelligent City, that the man who voted for WADSWORTH gave a vote for patriotism, and the man who voted for SEYMOUR was equivalent to a traitor. He (Mr. BRADY) should be sorry to believe, like Mr. BLUNT, or any man who entertained the same narrow, illiberal, despicable and prescribing principles. He should be sorry to think that the State in which he was born after the close of the next canvass should present such a number of traitors, as he designates them, as will be found at the close of the next election. [Applause.] On the subject of being permitted to have a choice in the sanction of rulers, he would call a witness in his favor, and he believed there was not a Republican throughout the land that would quarrel with the nature of the testimony he was about to adduce. He had read, when he began to study the rudiments of political science, in the Declaration of Independence, that "Government derived its just powers from the consent of the governed." He found that doctrine stated a little more strongly by a gentleman who said, in a speech at Peoria, ill., on the 16th of October, 1854, when speaking of the political right of negroes to political equality with while men, these words: -- " What I do say is, that no man is good enough to govern another man without that other's consent. I say this is the leading principle and sheet-anchor of American republicanism." He (the speaker) thought that was a little too strong, and thought that the doctrine there promulgated, in a republican form of government, that no man had a right to govern another in any sense without his consent, was a little unpleasant, because if that was so none of the Democracy consented to the election of Mr. LINCOLN, and in that sense none of them would owe him allegiance. He thought, therefore, in view of that testimony, that it was no particular offence on the part of an American citizen that he purposed in an election in the great State of New-York to give his vote to one or the other of the two opposing candidates, unless in the expression of his opinion, he should be found guilty of that thing they call treason. Treason! the flippant folly, the atrocious audacity of a set of men who had never stood by the wars of this country. [Applause.] Mr. BRADY alluded to the war of 1812, when the Democratic Party, with its usual proclivity to a fight, [laughter.] was battling for the rights of our young country against that lower which was now basely threatening to do its injury. He would like to know what was the position of a certain set of gentlemen in New-England -- a country of which he spoke with respect, because he admired its energy and its intellect, and was happy to number among his most intimate friends some of its sons. In one of the States of New-England, while that war was progressing, they refused the occupancy of their prisons by the Federal Government for the detention of enemies taken in war; and when the Federal Government undertook to enforce its power and authority, there broke out a certain Convention, in which the doctrine of secession, for the first time in the history of this country was clearly, distinctly and openly advocated in a preamble, address and resolutions written by one of the most distinguished men that ever gave lustre to the intelligence of any part of our country -- ROGER SHERMAN. And when he mentioned that name, it was not that he would lend the slightest sanction to any such doctrine as secession, in the modern acceptation of that term, but quite the reverse, as they would see in the subsequent portions of his remarks. He merely sought to vindicate the Democratic Party, at a period so far back as 1812, against the idea that it ever opposed any war for the greatness, the prosperity and the renown of this country, and so to vindicate it against the men opposed to the Democratic Party, who, even in that eventful struggle, sought to bring disgrace upon our arms and give triumph to our foes. How was it in regard to the war with Mexico, during the Administration of JAMES K. POLK? Was it not always charged by the opponents of the Democratic Party that that was a war of conquest, set on foot for the acquisition of territory, that the Slave Power might be extended, and that new States in which Slavery was permitted should be brought under, the protection of the Federal Constitution, and that the Slave Power should be increased at the expense of freedom? And when war was declared against the strong opposition of that party which had the impudence to charge the Democracy with a want of patriotism, in what paper was it that you read that the American flag was a flaunting he? ["The Tribune, followed by hisses for GRESLEY."] From whose mouth did they hear the wish expressed that on the soil of Mexico -- their brothers and sons, who went there to sustain the honor of our country and got victory to our arms -- would meet at the hands of the Mexicans with hospitable graves? ["That horrible monster, GREELEY."] He invited the Republican Press that either of them would make between now and election, to name the first time in the history of our century when the Democratic party, or any portion of it, in [???] in private, has even [???] practiced upon any principle indicating any desire, when a war broke out, except to sustain it, [???] at every expense, until there could [???] honorable peace and additional glory to our Government. [Cheers.] Mr. [???] of the [???] the London Times [???] to the war in Mexico, when [???] of the Yankees ever to [???] encounter, and said that [???] Vera Cruz, was [???] which, if [???] by [???] for the American [???] holding a high position [???] subsequently the Republican [???] office, a man of very inferior [???] who, [???] tiny, disobedience, and [???] was [???] from the service of the United States. He [???] JOHN C. FREMONT. [???] JOHN C. FREMONT, was the darling of a certain portion of the Republican party, and most unfortunately for our army, and for the [???] in which we are all engaged, he was given a high command, and they sought to cover him over with glory and renown, in view of this historical fact, with which they were all acquainted, at the same time that in the most dastardly and assassin-like manner, they sought to do injury to that gallant young man, whom he had never seen nor corresponded with, and who was a perfect stranger to him, but with reference to whom he was glad to avail himself to say, that the time would come, when all his enemies would be compelled to shout in his praise. He meant MCCLELLAN. [Loud cheers.] Mr. BRADY then paid an eloquent tribute to RICHARD O'GORMAN, who had delivered an address upon the crisis, and said he hoped he would be excused from saying that when he read in the columns of any journal an aspersion upon Mr. O'GORMAN's loyalty, it was another instance of that detestable audacity to which he had previously referred. He thought at a time when the whole country was wringing with the praises of those gallant sons of the Emerald Isle, who had gone forth to battle after battle, Democrats as they were all, [applause,] to fight for our success and for increased glory to the country in which their fortunes were cast; in view of the sublime developments thus made by men eager to shed the last drop of their blood, to apply to them, by any species of suggestion, by hint or inuendo, the insinuation that they could be guilty of treason to this country, ought to damn to eternal infamy the source from which such a charge came. They were, as he and as all the Democrats he knew of, in favor of prosecuting this war, but for what purpose and to what end? In favor of prosecuting it vigorously, with all the power that can be applied to it, that through the presence of an honorable peace the Union might be restored, perfected and continued, so that our general Government is preserved, to use the language of JEFFERSOM, "in its entire constitutional vigor." [Cheers.] To show the sincerity of the Democratic party, and to illustrate his position in regard to that, he would take the liberty to state that at no time did anything emanate from him that was not designed to secure to every portion of this country under the Constitution of the United States every claim of right to which it might make a just claim. And he would state to them in public what he had never before disclosed, except in the relations of private confidence, (and he blushed to do it because it was for the moment seeming to give him an importance which he did not feel,) that when he assumed the position of the candidate for Governor on the Breckinridge ticket with a perfect certainty that that ticket would be defeated, and against the remonstrances of some personal friends, and against the censure of old political associates, determined to adhere to that nomination and follow the fortunes of that little army, though it should be dwindled down to as few as were the signers of the Declaration of Independence, it was to say in public that he did not leave the State of New-York in such a condition that the South, when it claimed the right to secede, should say that it had no political organization to represent it in the State of New-York. He nurtured that thought close to his heart, for he knew it would have been egotistical to have avowed it at the time, and he knew also, what events were occurring in the South calculated to disturb the relations of this Union to its various members, and if that secret thus hugged here, said he, had eaten out my heart, as the stolen fox did which was hidden under the folds of the young Spartan's garment, I think I could have died without making an avowal of the purpose by which I was actuated. He was desirous that no Southern statesman, nor any of the Southern people might find in the election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN an excuse for the division of the Union, and he would be unjust to what he believed if he did not say that the act of the South in leaving those who stood so manfully by them in years of trial and minority was one without the slightest pretence of justification or excuse; and if there be in the South any man who loved the Union, now, when the time was approaching that the shock of the fiercest battle which had ever yet occurred, and which was soon to disturb the present tranquility of the land, and bring anguish to the hearts of new thousands afflicted by the loss of those they love -- if there be any Union men in the South, he called upon them to trample their leaders under their feet as dust in the balance, come forward, and reestablish this Union, lay down their arms, and give us a chance. [Cheers.] The vote for LINCOLN in the Presidential election stood as follows: In the Free Status, 1,810,430; vote for the Democratic and Union tickets 1,706,339, making the majority against the Democratic Party in all the Free States of this Confederacy the poor sum of 104,901 votes, and that, too, at a time when both branches of Congress were Democratic, and at a time when LINCOLN obtained a large majority, the vote against negro suffrage was thousands upon thousands, indicating that there were men in this State perfectly willing to vote for LINCOLN, intelligent, patriotic and pure members of the Republican Party, who never meant that the time would come when the negro should have political equality with the white man. [Applause.] One of the greatest pieces of jugglery, and one of the most miserable illustrations of hollow-hearted hypocrisy ever exhibited in the annals of the human race, was the pretended affection of the fanatical portion of the Republican Party for the class of beings called negroes. There was no man on the face of the earth to whom he would admit for an instant that his love of the thing called freedom, be it possessed by the most exalted on earth or the most debased or degraded, could transcend his. He knew that the love of liberty pervades the hearts of all the Democratic Party, and their mission ever had been to give liberty to all people, but not to destroy Constitutions and wreck nations. [Applause.] Did they know what become of the immense treasures expended by the great Powers of the earth to abolish Slavery on the Coast of Africa? What became of the poor negroes who were taken on board the slavers and then the slavers captured? If they were taken by an English vessel they were carried, under the form of apprentices or something akin to that away from their homes, or if they were taken by our Government that were carried to Liberia. Thus the treatment which the poor African received resulted in their still being made exiles. The particular causes which produced such a state of things, nor would he seek for a moment to justify so vile and damnable a traffic as the slave-trade, nor had the Democratic Party ever justified it in the history of the country. But when the negroes were found here, when in virtue of the inalienable right to freedom, of which the orators of a particular portion of the Republicans were so fond of prating -- what was done with them? If he believed it was the design of Almighty God that every man, of what color or complexion he might be, should enjoy precisely the same rights politically with himself and others, he did not see how he could refuse him the priviledge, and he did not understand how the Republican party, which gave a maturity for the electoral ticket that secured the choice of Mr. LINCOLN as President, could say in one breath, "this is a man and a brother," (that was their sterotyped phrase,) and yet refuse to their brother the slightest exercise of any high political right. He was talking with an intelligent colored man a short time ago in this City, and on asking him if he felt a great interest in this war, he said he felt none. He (the speaker) was surprised, first at the observation, but he was not when he informed him of the conclusion which he had just stated - that he did not see how the condition of the colored race was to be benefitted if, although they were rescued from bondage, they were kept in hopeless inferiority. The State of Illinois, where they recognized the principal of freedom as the basis of their constitution, made it a criminal offence for any man whose blood was fainted as a mulatto, or a negro, to come within their territory. Mr. BRADY quoted the words of Mr. LINCOLN, delivered in Peoria to the effect that if all earthly power were given him, he should not know what to do with the existing institution of Slavery. But he had some bad instructors at Washington, who suggested to him what he had the physical though not the moral right to do. He issued a proclamation which had been the means of more injury to our cause here and abroad than almost any event which has transpired. [Loud cheers.] He did not propose to discuss that, but he would refer any gentleman fond of the study of political science to the unanswerable discussion of the proclamation by BEN. S. CURTIS, of Massachusetts, late Judge of the Supreme Court of the United States.

JAMES BROOKS, and EDWIN JAMES,  Esq., in the strain of denunciation and boastfulness which has of late become fashionable with the so-called "Conservatives" when speaking of the Administration and the impending State election. The audience was neither very large nor very enthusiastic.

abstract: Democrat J K Porter defends Adm, against Seymour attacks; Glen Falls Democrat J K Porter defends Lincoln Adm. against Seymour attacks
snippet: Democrat J K Porter defends Adm, against Seymour attacks; Glen Falls Democrat J K Porter defends Lincoln Adm. against Seymour attacks
lead_paragraph: Hon. JOHN K. PORTER, an old Democrat, delivered an exceedingly able speech at the Union ratification meeting at Glen's Falls, on the evening of Oct. 21. He commenced by calling attention to the fact that the Democracy of the North was divided; that in all the recent elections in which it had nominated anti-war candidates it had been defeated; that the Republicans were united upon this issue, and that in New-York the lines were clearly drawn, HORATIO SEYMOUR standing as the anti-war candidate, and Gen. WADSWORTH as the war candidate. Mr. PORTER then discussed the pretext alleged by the rebels as justification for commencing the war, showing their falsity, and proceeded to review at length the positions held by Mr. SEYMOUR, showing that he first announced at Tweddle Hall the proposition of submission to the rebels, which JOHN VAN BUREN again urged at the Cooper Institute. In discussing this position of the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Mr. PORTER said:

abstract: editorial sees danger to Nashville
snippet: editorial sees danger to Nashville
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the frequent revival of the story of Nashville being surrounded, cut off, besieged and ordered to surrender, we continue in the faith that it is not in imminent danger. Undoubtedly there is intense desire on the part of the rebels to take it, especially the Tennessee rebels. Their pride is aroused on the subject.They would give more for Nashville than for all the other points our army holds in the State. They quarreled with BRAGG for leaving Nashville behind and marching into Kentucky. It is not unlikely that they will -the Tennessee rebels - under the lead of Gov. HARRIS, DE FORREST, and others, improvise an attack of their own upon Nashville, as a reproach to the Confederate Government which fails to give them back their capital. But such attack will fail, we believe.

abstract: question whether loyal men can honestly elect him
snippet: question whether loyal men can honestly elect him
lead_paragraph: In the outburst of patriotism which followed the fall of Sumter, our people gathered indignantly round the offices of certain newspapers in this City, whose loyalty they instinctively suspected, and compelled them to show their colors. Those papers now, every one of them, support SEYMOUR, and every one feels it to be appropriate that they should do so. Can any loyal man fail to see why they support him, and why that support is appropriate?

abstract: The United States iron-clad steam gunboat Sangamon was launched yesterday at Chester, Penn., in presence, a private dispatch says, "of a party more select than numerous." The Sangamon is 844 tons burden, Government measurement, about 200 feet long, 45 feet wide, and 12 feet deep. She has only one turret, in which two 11-inch guns will be placed. These will constitute her entire armament. There is hardly any difference between this ship and the Monitors, of which she is one. The Montauk, Passaic, and Nahant, all afloat, have been described at length. The Sangamon is a fac simile of them. The turret is 21 feet inside, 9 feet high, and 11 inches thick. Orders have been received by the contractors to prepare her for her crew and guns as speedily is possible. The Sangamon weighs actually, 1,300 tons. When finished, she will weigh 1,800 tons. The Lehigh, sistership to the one launched, is rapidly approaching completion, and will be ready to be floated out in a few days. There will then be but the Weehawken, which will be launched at Jersey City this week, the Nantucket, at Boston, and the Catskill, at Greenpoint, to be finished, of the nine Ericcson batterries.

abstract: TWO PERSONS  DROWNED. -- On Saturday last, Misses EMMA and ANNA A., daughters of JESSE M. CHRISTOPHER, Esq., formerly Commissioner of City Property, left this city, in company with Mr. HARVEY RITCHIE, to visit some friends in Port Deposit, Md. On the arrival of the train at Havre de Grace, the party took the steamboat for Port Deposit, a town on the banks of the Susquehanna, a few miles above Havre de Grace, and when near their destination the sad accident occurred. It appears that Miss ANNA A. CHRISTOPHER and Mr. RITCHIE were standing on the hurricane deck of the boat, near the guards, which were very low, and the boat making a sudden lurch, both were precipitated into the river. Mr. RITCHIE, it is stated, was a good swimmer, and by great exertions kept Miss CHRISTOPHER's head above water for ten or fifteen minutes, but his strength failed him before any efficient means were resorted to to rescue them, and both sank to the bottom. The bodies have not yet been recovered. Mr. RITCHIE, who lost his life in attempting to save that of Miss CHRISTOPHER, was a clerk in the office of the Philadelphia and Wilmington Railroad Company. He resided in Front-street, near Wharton. Miss CHRISTOPHER was in her twentieth year. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Oct. 27.

abstract: News has just reached me through a source in which I place full credence, that the rebel Gen. Wise is advancing on Yorktown with twenty thousand men! His main body has reached New-Kent Court House. His army is composed entirely of conscripts. I do not think they can be depended on, or they would have been sent to the assistance of LEE or JOHNSTON.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the Philadelphia Press.

abstract: It is a strange spectacle. Southern slaveholders, fresh from the rebel States, here in the face of our people, solemnly declaring that Slavery must perish if Liberty is to live, and conjuring us to support the President's proclamation as the sure means of destroying the rebellion: Northern demagogues, on the other hand, contending that Slavery has inviolable rights beyond the reach of military law, and denouncing the President's Proclamation as a blunder and a crime. Southern men substantiating, beyond all possibility of doubt, that the rebels have staked their all upon the Confederacy, and protesting with impassioned earnestness that overtures of compromise would be alike futile and ignominious: Northern men holding out that the rebels still long for the Old Flag, and that they may be, and ought to be, won back by conciliation. Southern men reprobating the rebellion, in unqualified terms, as the most unprovoked, wanton, faithless and heinous conspiracy that ever disgraced the earth, and invoking us, in the name of country, humanity and God, to combat this crime of crimes to the very last: Northern men excusing and extenuating it, pretending that it was instigated by Northern wrong, that we have no right to push it to an extremity, that it has rights and interests which we are bound to respect even while we fight it, and that, as soon as possible, we must quit fighting it altogether! And yet it is this spectacle which has just been presented to us. We have seen, in the last week, HAMILTON of Texas, BOYNTON and FRAZIER of Florida, HOYE of Mississippi, CASTER and ROGERS of Tennessee, and BOSSERMAN of Virginia, engaged in the one work: HORATIO SEYMOUR, JOHN VAN BUREN, FERNANDO WOOD, and ISAIAH RYNDERS, engaged in the other.

abstract: A most enthusiastic meeting of Republicans and Union men of the Twenty-first Ward, was held at Lincoln Hall, corner of Thirty-third street and Eighth-avenue, last evening, under the auspices of the Ward Club. The speakers were Judge FRAZIER, CALVES L. ROBINSON and JOB, REMINGTON, of Florida, and Mr. J.C. PAGE, of this City, Mr. ROBINSON gave a very interesting account of the manner of his escape from rebellion, and was accordingly bitter in his denunciations of the "[???] compromise men" of the North, for whom he said the [???] of the South entertained no [???] had of contempt and detestation. All the speaker can [???] in welcoming the President's Proclamation as being to surest and quickest means of undermining the temple of treason that the cotton trailers had erected, and predicted that the leaders of secession would be [???] to atoms by its fall. Judge FRAZIER proclaimed "the old public functionary" either [???] or an imbecile, and desired the friends of that official to take their choice of these designations. He warmly urged the election of Gen. WADSWORTH, in which he was healthy indorsed by Mr. ROBINSON and Mr REMINGTON, The most intense enthusiasm was mane fesfed by the audience, and the applause for the President and the Proclamation was frequent and hearty.

abstract: GARD has such an ill repute for veracity, that we do not feel called upon to accept without qualification, his report of the affair that took place midway between Charleston and Savannah on last Thursday. We doubt whether both Pocotaligo and Coosawhatchie were attacked in force; we doubt whether the Abolitionists were required to their gunboats -- whether they came in thirteen gunboats and transports -- whether they left the railroad uninjured -- whether they left their dead and wounded on the field -- and whether BEAUREGARD's cavalry were in hot pursuit; and if there be anything else beyond these six assertions stated or involved in BEAUREGARD's ten-line report, we doubt its truth. The only thing in this connection which we credit -- and this we credit because it has proof outside of BEAUREGARD's report -- is that Gen. MITCHEL made a naval reconnaissance up the Coosawhatchie River. in the direction of the Savannah and Charleston Railroad, with the object probably of cutting the communication between these two cities [???] for its result we must await the reports [???] Gen. MITCHEL and our own correspondent [???] We have no doubt that Admiral [???] and Gen. MITCHEL did whatever they should to do; and if that was to cut the railroad from Charleston to Savannah, we think likely that the movement was preparatory to an attack on one of these cities.

abstract: During the Summer vacation, the Lecture-room and Sunday School-rooms connected with Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, have been greatly enlarged, beautified and rendered commodious. Though not entirely finished, it is so far in readiness as to warrant the Sunday-school to hold this week their Annual Festival. The new school-room will be used during the festival as a gallery of art, in which is collected a large number of rare and beautiful pictures. In the Church, which will be thrown open on the occasion, the celebrated Germania Band, of the Twenty-second Regiment, conducted by HELMSMULLER, will give a concert, commanding at 6 o'clock to-night. Refreshments will also be provided, and addresses made by Rev. HENRY WARD BELCHER, Rev. THEO. L. COYLER and others. As usual, the children expect to have a jolly good time.
lead_paragraph: During the Summer vacation, the Lecture-room and Sunday School-rooms connected with Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, have been greatly enlarged, beautified and rendered commodious. abstract: A Washington telegraphic correspondent recently made certain charges against Gen. VIELE, Military Governor of Norfolk, and added that the Norfolk Secessionists had "presented him with a magnificent carriage, as a token of their approval of his official course as Governor of that city." Facts have been submitted to us which prove that the charges against Gen. VIELE were unjust, and that the statement of the presentation to him of a carriage or any other testimonial from rebels was false. Complaints against this General have been very plentiful from certain partisans since his appointment as Military Governor of Norfolk; but, on examination being made into them by his superior officer, they have been discovered to be either trivial or unfounded. Gen. VIELE's course at Norfolk has been conciliatory but firm; and he has discharged his duties to the entire satisfaction both of Gen. DIX and the authorities at Washington, who have full opportunities of knowing all the facts and incidents of his administration.
lead_paragraph: A Washington telegraphic correspondent recently made certain charges against Gen. abstract: The Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, held their nineteenth annual meeting in the Court of Sessions Room, City Hall, last night. The president, Hon. GEORGE HALL, occupied the chair. The annual report of the Board of Managers shows that 2,300 families, including over 5,000 individuals, have received assistance from the Society during the past year. This year there will be greater demands, in addition to the wants of the widows and orphans of those fallen in battle. The receipts last year were $6,245.45, and the expenditures $6,131.72, leaving a balance on hand of $113.72. The officers of the previous year were reelected, and the meeting adjourned.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. The Movements in State Politics, with the Election returns from all the States so far as received, will be found in this morning's issue. All official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The following dispatch has been received from the Times Special Correspondent at Centreville.  Capt. DAHLGREN, of Maj.-Gen. SIGEL'S Staff, with about one hundred men, left last evening at 11 o'clock on a scout toward Warrenton Junction, having the double object in view of ascertaining the force of the enemy in that direction, and the fate of Capt. ANGER, an account of whose fight with the rebels on Friday appeared in Saturday's TIMES.

abstract: The City Inspector reports that 340 persons died in New-York last week -- 12 men, 72 women, 106 mortality of the corresponding week of 1861. Of the deceased 180 were children under 5 years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as fol-boys, and 92 girls -- a decrease of 13 from the mortality of the previous week, and of 61 as compared with the lows: Consumption, 58; infantile marasmus, 29; infantile convulsions, 25; croup, 18; cholera infantum, 13; diphtheria, 12; dropsy in the head, 9; hooping cough, 8; typhoid fever, 6. Deaths from external causes, 36 -- among which are reported 9 premature births, 6 deaths from old age. 2 drowned, and 8 killed by accidents. There were 25 interments in Potter's Field, and 35 deaths in institutions.

abstract: A MAN ROBBED OF HIS BAGGAGE. -- PRENTICE G. ALDEN, a messenger and door-keeper of the Senate at Washington, appeared before Justice QUACKENBUSH, yesterday afternoon, and made a complaint against two young men named WASHINGTON LEWIS and GEORGE LEVY, whom he charges with having been guilty of robbing him of his baggage in the following manner.Mr. ALDEN came down on the Hudson River Railroad yesterday morning, and when he arrived at the depot in Thirty-first-street the two young men above mentioned came aboard the cars, and represented themselves to Mr. ALDEN as licensed expressmen. Upon this representation, ALDEN told them he wished his baggage, which consisted of a large trunk and a valise, taken to the Girard House, and gave them the checks for the purpose of obtaining them. The pretended expressmen promised to have the baggage there in an hour, instead of which they took it to the Putnam House, in Fourth-avenue. There they told the book-keeper that they were travelers, just arrived by the cars, and desired a room for the purpose of changing their dress. A room was furnished them, and the trunks taken to it. About half an hour after the two came down with new and clean suite on, and LEVY, as he passed out of the hotel, was observed to have a bundle under his arm. The suspicions of the hotel-keeper were thus aroused; the room was examined; the trunk was found broken open, and nearly everything taken away. The Police were soon notified, and the result was the arrest of both of the guilty parties. A small portion of the stolen property has been recovered, but Mr. ALDEN says that a new suit of black, valued at about $75. is missing, and also some other valuable articles. The prisoners were committed for trial, in default of bail.

The majority report, signed by Alderman TERNAN, WALLACE, and FISHER, recommended the adoption of reso-...
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen last night, the Joint Railroad and Law Committees, to whom was referred the matter relating to the refusal of the city Railroad Companies to sell tickets at the rate of $4 per hundred, presented two reports. The majority report, signed by Alderman TERNAN, WALLACE, and FISHER, recommended the adoption of resolutions, directing the Counselor to agree with the several Railroad Companies upon a proposed case, which shall contain the facts upon which depends the controversy respecting the various issues between the City and the Companies, with the view of having the same submitted to some Court of competent jurisdiction; that the Counselor, before submitting the same to the Court, or entering into any agreement or stipulation therefor, report the same to the Board for its approval, and that he ascertain at once whether said Companies will enter into such an agreement, and if they refuse or neglect to do so, that he report that fact to the Board without delay.

abstract: We are glad to learn that our military authorities are considering the subject of establishing a corps of reserves in the vicinity of the Capital to be held in hand for such service as the emergency may require. The importance of forming such a corps has been urged upon the Government by officers high in military authority and experience, and it is surprising that so little heed should have been given to their recommendations. Our evident departure from the plainest principles of warfare in this particular has, very justly, subjected us to the criticism of foreigners, who have a notable prejudice in favor of the rules of strategy, established by long experience in the art of war, under the ablest commanders of history. The Paris Moniteur is particularly satirical at the idea of risking a great cause upon an army which fights without reserves.

abstract: The French residents of Mobile, Ala., a few days ago presented M. PORTZ, the French Vice-Consyl there, with a cane. In a speech acknowledging the complement, the Mobile Tribune says that "he regretted that the South had not been recognized by his Government; but from his full conviction that France would always be found in support of a rightful cause, he was satisfied that this act of justice would not be long delayed, and that this hope was now stronger than ever in his mind, from the tenor of his recent advices."

abstract: The different Precinct Station-houses have been so crowded since Saturday, with applicants for exemption from the coming draft, that the Commissioners have found it utterly impossible to accommodate the throng. The Station-houses have not only been filled, but long lines have extended beyond the sidewalks, and there are numerous instances where persons have been compelled to wait for hours and then be obliged to leave because they could not be attended to. In view of this state of affairs the Adjutant-General has ordered evening sessions to be held from 6 1/2 to 9 o'clock P.M. until (and including) Friday evening. This will afford an opportunity for those who are unable to attend in the daytime, to come at night. The Commissioners had as much as they could attend to on Monday and Tuesday, and the prospects are that they will be kept busy during the remainder of the week. Last week about 5,000 persons were exempted in the Western District. This week will only be limited by the ability of the Commissioners and Surgeons to pass upon the claims of the applicants.

abstract: There was unusual bustle at the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, in consequence of the arrival from New-York of the steamship Vanderbilt, now thoroughly converted into a man-of-war. She eclipsed everything in the stream, looking even more formidable than the line-of-battle ship North Carolina. Frigates, corvettes, and gunboats looked like fishing smacks beside her. All the paraphernalia of a mail and passenger steamer has been removed from the spar deck, the cabins, "galleys," and baggage gangways having been used for the last time. Portholes have been bored, and all the weak points of the splendid ship made sound and solid. She is as strong in every part as a regular navy-built vessel, and is swifter than any of those in our navy. The deck beams are as firm as the Monitor's, and the spars are equally invulnerable. Orders have been received from the Navy Department to fit her out for sea at once. Men will be kept working night and day on board until this is done. She will be manned and equipped in a few days, and will then go to do some fighting. In compliance with orders from Secretary WELLES, the following officers have reported for her: Acting-Lieut. BALDWIN, Commander; Acting-Masters, J.D. Daniels, W. McGleven, Albert M. Keith; Acting-Masters' Mates, Geo. Baker, Geo. R. Griswold; Ensign, A.C. Alexander; Acting Ensigns, E.D. Keyser, Geo. Masters, A.K. Jones, Jas. E. Tolfree; Acting Assistant Paymaster, John B. Hamilton; Assistant Surgeon, Thos. R. Wilson.

abstract: Last night was a gala night for the attendants at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, being the first of the three days' Annual Festival. The particular object which drew together a most numerous audience composed of the elite of our sister city, was the opening of the new sabbath school hall and lecture-room which have just been erected.
lead_paragraph: Last night was a gala night for the attendants at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, being the first of the three days' Annual Festival. The particular object which drew together a most numerous audience composed of the elite of our sister city, was the opening of the new sabbath school hall and lecture-room which have just been erected. The building in which these are situated is the new addition in the rear of and adjoining the church proper, and is beyond all doubt the finest in the country for the purposes intended. The building (or more properly the addition) is about ninety feet long by one hundred feet in width, having most excellent facilities for ventilation, lighting and heating. The lower floor is to be used as a lecture-room, and has a raised platform at the westerly end, from which the speaker can address his auditory. This room is lighted by a number of gas jets running entirely round the room in front of the cornice work. The upper flooring is supported by six cast-iron columns. One peculiar and noteworthy feature of the new addition is the social parlors, running the entire length of the building, the flooring being raised about four foot from this lecture-room floor, and divided from that room by a glass framework partition. Should an audience be too numerous to find accommodations in the lecture-room proper, this parlor can be used, and will comfortably seat two hundred persons additional.

abstract: GREAT RUSH TO THE EXEMPTION OFFICES. Yesterday there was a great rush to the various Stationhouses, where the Commissioners of Exemption are in daily session. So large was the crowd seeking exemption in the Seventeenth Ward that the Police were almost powerless in keeping it orderly.
lead_paragraph: GREAT RUSH TO THE EXEMPTION OFFICES. Yesterday there was a great rush to the various Stationhouses, where the Commissioners of Exemption are in daily session. So large was the crowd seeking exemption in the Seventeenth Ward that the Police were almost powerless in keeping it orderly. Some of the windows were broken, but beyond that no damage to property or person was done. Every Station-house where this business is transacted, in the upper Wards of the City, was literally packed with impatient candidates for exemption, and it necessitated great powers of patience and fortitude in the Commissioners to perform their duties systematically. Since the Commissioners appointed to decide upon the claims of persons who apply for exemptions have been in session in this City and Brooklyn, many have been unable to obtain a hearing, owing to the immense crowd of applicants who rush to the Station-house, and the inability of the officers to dispose of every ease. The term of fen days which the Commissioners were to devote to this business in this City will expire on Thursday, and in Brooklyn on Friday, but Gen. ANTHON has wisely determined to continue the service until Saturday.

abstract: The arrival of the steamship Ericsson from Port Royal has put us in possession of the facts respecting the attack by Gen. MITCHEL'S forces, on Wednesday last, upon the Charleston and Savannah Railroad, a brief account of which, from rebel sources, we published yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the steamship Ericsson from Port Royal has put us in possession of the facts respecting the attack by Gen. MITCHEL'S forces, on Wednesday last, upon the Charleston and Savannah Railroad, a brief account of which, from rebel sources, we published yesterday. The expedition was one of some magnitude, consisting of the commands of Gens. BRANNAN and TERRY. The main body of the troops was landed under cover of gunboats at Mackey's Point, distant about fifteen miles from the railroad, and marched seven miles inland, where the enemy was met in force. A sharp fight of an hour drove him from his position, and making a second stand at a point two miles beyond, he was again compelled to retreat by our closely-pursuing troops. The rebels made a third stand at the village of Pocataligo taking she precaution to destroy the long bridge over the Pocataligo River, thereby effectually preventing further pursuit. This victory was not achieved without serious loss on our side, and the light appears to have been as hotly contested as any on a more extended scale. While these events were happening with the main body, Col. BARTON, with 350 men, penetrated to the railroad at Coosawhatchie, actually tearing up a few of the rails and cutting the telegraph wire, besides tiring upon a train filled with troops, killing several and capturing a stand of regimental colors.

abstract: It is a matter of daily bitter regret with patriots that the Union Army has become so much demoralized by the rivalries and jealousies of Generals. The failure of numerous important operations, and especially the failure of POPE to repel the rebel army at Manassas, is charged to this cause. At the present moment, arraignments are on file at Washington against Major-Generals of the Army for offences which, if sustained, will require them to be shot. And other Generals (MCDOWELL, for example,) are held to answer, by an irresponsible but inexorable popular indictment, offences no less grave and unpardonable. Military jealousy is undoubtedly at the bottom of much, if not all, of the trouble involved in these cases.

abstract: To-morrow night the Republican Ward and other political clubs are to hold a grand convocation at the Cooper Institute. It is intended to have a universal ratification of the Wadsworth State ticket, and to present such an exposition of the great issues now before the people as will reestablish the faith of every loyal voter, and convince the wavering that the cause of the Union the Constitution, and the enforcement of the laws, can best be served by the hearty support of the Union nominations.

abstract: Puig, Mir  Co. vs. The ship James Guthrie.  The libel in this case was filed to recover the amount of a Bill of Exchange, drawn by the master of the vessel. The facts were, that the vessel was chartered by Stewart  Murrell, of Mobile, in October, 1854, for two voyages from that place to France or Spain.
lead_paragraph: Puig, Mir Co. vs. The ship James Guthrie. The libel in this case was filed to recover the amount of a Bill of Exchange, drawn by the master of the vessel. The facts were, that the vessel was chartered by Stewart Murrell, of Mobile, in October, 1854, for two voyages from that place to France or Spain. She went on the first one to Toulon, the master paying the disbursements of her outfit by draft on his consignees at Toulon against the freight. She then returned to Mobile, and was loaded for a voyage to Ferrol, Spain. Her master had no funds to meet this second outfit, and Stewart & Murrell could not make him a loan for it, but on their advice he drew a draft on his consignees against the freight, which Stewart & Murrell procured to be negotiated for him by the libellants, who did business in New-Orleans, making a temporary loan to the master, until they received the proceeds of this draft. The vessel sailed on her voyage, but met with accident, and was prevented from delivering her cargo, so that the freight was never paid, and the master's draft was protested. The libelants in this suit endeavored to collect it out of the ship, as being a loan to her. The Court below dismissed the libel, and the libelants appealed.

abstract: THE BATTLES IN SOUTH CAROLINA. -- In yesterday issue we published BEAUREGARD's brief report of the battle in South Carolina, and expressed our doubt of the truthfulness of its averments. Our correspondent, who was present at the battle, arrived in the City last night, and proves our doubts to have been correct. The truth is that instead of the rebels gaining a victory, our troops defeated them in the three very hard-fought engagements which took place a week ago to-day, drove them from both their chosen positions, and compelled them to retreat in haste across the Pocotaligo River, at which they destroyed the bridge in their rear, to prevent further pursuit. And although Gen. MITCHEL did not, on this occasion, succeed in carrying out the magnificent programme which he had conceived, he did make a complete reconnoissance of the region between the Island of Port Royal and the Charleston Railroad, and administered to the rebels a thorough chastisement.

And although Gen. MITCHEL did not, on this occasion, succeed in carrying out the magnificent programme which he had conceived, he did make a complete reconnoissance of the region between the Island of Port Royal and the Charleston Railroad, and administered to the rebels a thorough chastisement.

abstract: "THE COMPANY HE KEEPS." -- There may be some who suppose that if Mr. SEYMOUR is elected, he will urge on the prosecution of the war, not only till Richmond is taken but till the rebellion is quelled. Do they suppose they know SEYMOUR better than those who nominated him? Do they not know that the WOODS, that Capt. RYNDERS, that BROOKS, VAN BOREN, and all of that stripe, would not support any man heartily if they thought be would thus push on the war, and that his election would not hamper the Government? Some one is going to be cheated by Mr. SEYMOUR if he is elected. Which is it most likely to be, the knaves or the honest men?

abstract: After the most strenuous exertions on the part of its officers, the State finds it impossible to clothe and shoe our soldiers without again appearing to that overflowing fountain of generosity, the private contributions of our people. The rigors of Winter are approaching, our soldiers are already suffering, and...
lead_paragraph: After the most strenuous exertions on the part of its officers, the State finds it impossible to clothe and shoe our soldiers without again appearing to that overflowing fountain of generosity, the private contributions of our people. The rigors of Winter are approaching, our soldiers are already suffering, and must suffer more if our sympathies are not practical and active. The Quartermaster's Department is laboring faithfully to provide for them; but owing to speculation and extortion, will fall short. The deficiency must be supplied by the people. We shall have an active Winter campaign, and how can our troops, if ragged, cold and barefoot, contend with the splendidly equipped columns of the enemy.

abstract: Reports from Confederate States; Democratic city and county ratification meeting, City Hall Park; speakers noted
snippet: Reports from Confederate States; Democratic city and county ratification meeting, City Hall Park; speakers noted
lead_paragraph: The grand Democratic City and County Ratification meeting announced with so much flourish came off last evening in City Hall Park. The weather was clear, cool and beautiful, the bright sunshine of the day having completely dried the soil and left a cloudless sky. Between 6 and 7 P.M., the usual crowd of lookers-on and idle people began to assemble around the three platforms which had been created -- one in front, and one on either wing of the Municipal edifice. The Committee of Arrangements assembled at Tammany Hall, the facade of which was decorated with a brilliant transparency of huge dimensions bearing the names of the Democratic State and County nominees. In the Park, calcium lights, emblematic banners, rockets and Roman candles amused the throng until 7 o'clock -- the appointed hour for the commencement of the evening exercises.

abstract: editorial sees Army headed for advance on Confederates at Winchester
snippet: editorial sees Army headed for advance on Confederates at Winchester
lead_paragraph: We presume there is no longer a doubt that the Army of the Potomac is to be put immediately in action against the enemy at Winchester. Gen. BURNSIDE is already on the advance, having crossed the Potomac six miles east of Harper's Ferry with all his artillery and army equipage. The troops, we are told, hailed the event with cheers, and shouted with joy as they put the waters of the Potomac behind them and trod the soil of Virginia once more. Gen. MCCLELLAN's entire army, we are assured, is now fully prepared for an onward movement -- fully clothed, fully shod, and completely armed. The advance of BURNSIDE is taken as the precursor of an "advance along the whole lines," and if so, the day of final trial between the two greatest armies of the age may be at hand.

abstract: The trial of Albert Horn, charged with fitting out the City of Norfolk as a slaver, was continued.  Henry C. Crawford, for the prosecution, testified: I have followed the sea since 1839; was born in Denmark; have known Mr. Horn since December, 1859; had then been mate on a brig called the Cygnet; saw Horn three or four days after my return at his office,...
lead_paragraph: The trial of Albert Horn, charged with fitting out the City of Norfolk as a slaver, was continued. Henry C. Crawford, for the prosecution, testified: I have followed the sea since 1839; was born in Denmark; have known Mr. Horn since December, 1859; had then been mate on a brig called the Cygnet; saw Horn three or four days after my return at his office, and was introduced there to Schomberg; I called on him at his office about a dozen times; saw Mandillo there; first heard of the City of Norfolk from him; I went with him, and he showed her to me; about a week after I went to Horn's office; he asked me if I had seen her, and how I liked her looks; I said she would do very well for that trade; he had asked me how she would do to go and get negroes; saw Horn again about three weeks after; he asked me how Mandillo was acting as to drink while on the Cygnet, as he was going on the Norfolk, he wanted to know; I told him that any one who told him Mandillo got drunk was mistaken; Horn told me that he had some interest in that vessel, and, if Mandillo did not act right, he would not have him aboard; I next had talk with Horn the day of the trial trip; he told me if Mandillo should not do as he ought, for me to take charge of the vessel and bring her home, as he had about $18,000 interest in her; I had made an agreement with Mandillo; he told me I was to have $120 a month, and $6 a head for every negro that was landed; Horn told me he and Schomburg had concluded to send the vessel to Cuba first, so there would be no suspicion where she was going; I did not go in her to Havana; saw Horn white she was gone; he said when she came back, she was going to be fitted up a little more, and take in a cargo for St. Thomas, and then go to the Coast for negroes; I saw the vessel when she came back; Horn told me that Tilton was going as her master; that she was going to be transferred in St. Thomas, and, if any papers were to be signed, I was to sign them; we went to St. Thomas direct; lay there about ten days, and discharged part of our cargo; kept the bread aboard, 70, 80 or 100 barrels, lot of rice, 20 or 30 tierces or more, 200 or 300 boxes of herrings, meat, beef and pork in barrels; the cargo that was to be left aboard was by itself; there were a lot of shooks'; there was a lot of coal aboard; also a large medicine chest; took aboard there 12 of 15 hogsheads of beans; there were kegs inside of them which were all sawed in two, and made info kits for the negroes; there were handcuffs in one of the hogsheads, 100 or more; there was a box, with the place for the coppers and everything to fasten them up; the British Consul was our consignee there; he sent these things aboard; Tilton had charge of the vessel till the last day; he went ashore in a boat just as the vessel started; he was with me when I cleared the vessel; the day before, Tilton came aboard in the forenoon and told me to come with him to the American Consul; I did, and he introduced me as being Mr. Crawford, the master of the vessel; the Consul asked me if I was a citizen; I told him I was; the Consul told Tilton he would have the papers ready next day; I went next day with Tilton; the Consul asked me how much money was to be paid for the vessel; I did not know; Tilton said $35,000; the Consul filled in the papers; he read the bill of sale to me; I signed my name to it; the Consul asked me if I had a dollar to give Tilton to bind the bargain; Tilton gave me a gold piece, and I gave it back to him; the Consul asked him if he had got his money; he said he had; the Consul said to me, you must be a rich man to buy the whole vessel, cargo and all, and he told Tilton to come there every month and sell a vessel like that, and Tilton laughed, because he knew exactly what kind of a sale it was; when the Consul was going out with me, he said -- "I would like to have a dozen niggers;" from St. Thomas we we went to Barcelona, to fill up with water; it was too dear there; it took three or four days to run down there; lay there eight or ten days, and then went to the coast; the same persons went in her who went out from New-York, except Tilton and Curvelo; I got back to New-York in October, 1860; went next day to Horn's office; I told him that we landed the negroes, and how many were not captured -- about seventy-five -- and what was done with them; Horn blamed me for the loss of the negroes; he said I ought to have taken charge of the ship, and seen the negroes landed safe, as long as I was master; I said I was not master, but Mandillo.

abstract: "A THIEF TO CATCH A THIEF." -- The Seymourites proclaim that the Republicans have shown themselves incompetent to the task of quelling the rebellion, and claim that on this account that work should be confided to them. This is as if it should be urged that because the police failed to suppress robberies, we should appoint prigs to be policemen. It is as if because the bremen were slow in putting out a fearful conflagration, we should be called upon to put the engines into the hands of the incendiaries.
