abstract: The Democracy of this City and County held a "grand" ratification meeting yesterday evening in the City Hall Park. Calcium lights, rockets. Ward processions, music and huzzas were not wanting, but argument and oratory were we fully deficient. There were three stands erected one in front and one on either side of the City Hall. At the main platform, Capt. ISAIAH RYNDERS called the assemblage to order and Ex-Mayor ANDREW H. MICKLE presided. Characteristic speeches were made by Hon. S. S. Cox, ofOhio; Hon. ELI P. NORTON, Hon. LUKE F. COZANS, Dr. R. B. BRADFORD, IRA C. HUTCHINGS and Capt. RYNDERS. Stands Nos. 2 and 3 had their share of City speakers, and about 10 P.M. the entire concourse dispersed.

abstract: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONICS. -- The third and last preliminary rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society will take place, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, this afternoon, at 3 o'clock. The attractions offered are the same as those which will be presented at the concert on Saturday night, Mme. Comte BOROHARD (soprano) and Mr. WM. CASTLE, the new tenor, will rehearse with the orchestra. The orchestral pieces are SCHUMANN's Symphony in B flat CHERUBINI's Overture to "Medea," and WEBER's Overture to "Oberon."
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONICS. -- The third and last preliminary rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society will take place, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, this afternoon, at 3 o'clock. The attractions offered are the same as those which will be presented at the concert on Saturday night, Mme. Comte BOROHARD (soprano) and Mr. WM. CASTLE, the new tenor, will rehearse with the orchestra. The orchestral pieces are SCHUMANN's Symphony in B flat CHERUBINI's Overture to "Medea," and WEBER's Overture to "Oberon."

abstract: Under an order from the President of the United States it national system has been established by the Sanitary Commission for the safe transmission and judicious distribution of articles contributed by the people for the sick and wounded of the Army and Navy. The system, after being well tried, has been formally approved and recommended by the President, the General-in-Chief and the Surgeon-General. The security it offers against misappropriation is practically perfect until the contributions are delivered in the hospitals, where they necessarily pass from the control of the Commission. Of more than a million articles sent through one of the largest of its channels of supply, it has been ascertained that not one hundred have miscarried or been dishonestly used. Discreet and trustworthy agents are constantly employed in visiting all divisions of the army, including those on the Southern coast, the Mississippi and the Western frontier, to observe their wants, to direct supplies where they are most needed, and to secure, as far as practicable, their honest use. The Commission does not undertake to deliver articles to individuals, and declines to receive contributions with any restriction as to their destination within the limits of the force employed in the service of the Nation, it being one of its secondary objects to strengthen the sentiment of National unity wherever it can come in antagonism with State or local pride. The distribution of hospital supplies is but a branch of the work of the Commission. It employs the best professional talent which can be obtained in the country to aid its larger purpose -- to do all that is possible for the health and vigor of our fighting men, to lighten their burden, and to sustain their spirits under the privations and hardships which are an essential part of successful warfare. For this purpose contributions to its treasury are solicited. They may be directed to the Treasurer, G.T. STRONG, Esq., No. 68 Wall-st., New-York.

abstract: Another important blow at the Slave-trade was dealt yesterday in the United States Circuit Court in this City, in the conviction of ALBERT HORN-for fitting out the steamer City of Norfolk for that traffic. The evidence, as given in Court, showed that the case was a most flagrant one. It showed that HORN...
lead_paragraph: Another important blow at the Slave-trade was dealt yesterday in the United States Circuit Court in this City, in the conviction of ALBERT HORN-for fitting out the steamer City of Norfolk for that traffic. The evidence, as given in Court, showed that the case was a most flagrant one. It showed that HORN bought the vessel, paying $20,000 for her; that she was run on one voyage to Havana and back, and then was sent to St. Thomas, having had some $25,000 more of repairs and outfit put on board of her. At St. Thomas the transfer, which is an almost universal accompaniment of these cases, took place, and the vessel, after running to Barcelona, (Venezuela,) to get water enough, sailed for the African coast, and on arriving in the Bight of Benin, took in eight hundred negroes in broad daylight and sailed for Cuba, where she arrived with them. Having discharged them into boats, the steamer was abandoned by her crew, but was shortly afterward captured by a Spanish man-of-war, which. also captured most of the negroes.

abstract: Yesterday was a grand gala day at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. It having been known that the wife of the President intended to visit the receiving-ship North Carolina, an immense crowd of persons congregated at the gate and several hundreds obtained admission. About noon all the wharves were crowded with spectators. At 1 1/2 o'clock the Police harbor boat arrived off the yard with Mrs. LINCOLN, Gen. ANDERSON, Gen. BANKS and a lady, said to be Mrs. GOLDSBOROUGH. The distinguished party were waited on by Admiral PAULDING, who took his private barge alongside the steamer. All the North Carolina's boats were lowered, the crews being uniformed in whitefrocks, blue pants and blue collars. The marines were in full uniform on the quarter-deck, and the full band, also in full uniform, on the poop. At 2 o'clook the "side boys' were piped, and the visitors entered the ship, amid cheers from the crews of the North, the Savannah, Vanderbill and other men-of-war in the stream. An army General's salute was then fired from the cobdock. The party was then shown through the vessel, and partook of Capt. MEAD's hospitalities. Having spent some two hours at the yard they left in the steamboat, well pleased with their visit.

abstract: "ElectSEYMOUR," said NORTON at the Park meeting, "and you choose a statesman whose election would throw over the South a gleam of hope." Precisely so. The rebels will take comfort from it unquestionably. They will understand that the North is no longer a unit -- that the peace policy is bound to prevail here -- and that they have only to persevere to be soon in a position to dictate terms in the Union, or maintain their independence out of it, just as they may please. Of course they associate SEYMOUR -- and hope. Not so with WADSWORTH. That name means no hope short of unconditional submission. They fear it, and for that very reason, above all others, we shall cleave to it. As we intend to use our iron-clads and our field batteries to crush the rebellion and not to court it, to bring despair and not hope to the Confederacy, so ought we to use our ballots. It is senseless and suicidal to make two policies -- one in the field and another out of it. All the power of the Nation, military or civil, material or moral, ought to converge to the same end. That end is the destruction of the rebellion. Votes are weapons, as well as muskets or cannon. They are formidable, too -- none more so. Could our Northern ballot boxes send forth an absolute unanimity of thorough war sentiment, it would strike upon the rebels like a very thunderbolt from the skies, scattering confusion and dismay in a style that we have long looked for in vain. Moral power in this struggle is even more potent than material. The two combined would be irresistible. We should see to it that so far as depends upon us, they act together, and that thus the rebels shall be deprived of their last hope; instead of giving the rebels hope, as this Seymourite demagogue solicits.

They fear it, and for that very reason, above all others, we shall cleave to it. As we intend to use our iron-clads and our field batteries to crush the rebellion and not to court it, to bring despair and not hope to the Confederacy, so ought we to use our ballots. It is senseless and suicidal to make two policies -- one in the field and another out of it. All the power of the Nation, military or civil, material or moral, ought to converge to the same end. That end is the destruction of the rebellion. Votes are weapons, as well as muskets or cannon. They are formidable, too -- none more so. Could our Northern ballot boxes send forth an absolute unanimity of thorough war sentiment, it would strike upon the rebels like a very thunderbolt from the skies, scattering confusion and dismay in a style that we have long looked for in vain. Moral power in this struggle is even more potent than material. The two combined would be irresistible. We should see to it that so far as depends upon us, they act together, and that thus the rebels shall be deprived of their last hope; instead of giving the rebels hope, as this Seymourite demagogue solicits.

abstract: Editorials on issues and candidates
snippet: Editorials on issues and candidates
lead_paragraph: But four more working days before the election. Make the most of them. The canvass has been far too brief, considering the tremendous interests involved. The Seymourites were earliest in the field, and sowed falsehood broadcast, which has poisoned tens of thousands of honest minds. They have taken great pains, too, to screen the prime issues of the contest, and to push forward others in their place of merely secondary account, or of no account whatever. Misapprehensions still prevail to a very mischievous extent. These need to be cleared up, and it can be done, too, if every true patriot, in his own sphere, will make himself a missionary in the work. Processions, flags, multiplied meetings, and all the other material means of stimulating energy, have figured less in this canvass than in any other for years back, owing doubtless to the comparative looseness of party organization and discipline. But energy is needed more than ever. The party questions which have ordinarily appealed to the public judgment have, been insignificant in comparison with the stupendous issues now presented. At best, but poor justice can be done to those issues. But it is every patriot's business to see to it that he and his neighbors apprehend them as justly as possible, and to be sure that all shall vote, and vote right.

abstract: Capt. DUFFY, of the gallant Sixty-ninth, has been nominated by the loyal men of the Fifth Congressional District as their candidate, in opposition to the submission candidate, ex-Mayor, ex-merchant FERNANDO WOOD. Capt. DUFFY is well known as a tried man, an upright citizen, a loyal countryman, and a gallant soldier. Upon him, as such, the columns of a cotemporary has seen fit to pour the contents of their bilious souls, and to make his honest endeavor in a long career of Honorable usefulness a subject of reviling and scoffing.

abstract: Virgil Whitcomb vs. Walter M. Hungerford. -- The plaintiff sues the defendant for an alleged unlawful conversion of a certain chestnut mare called Parsy. The plaintiff complains that on the 24th day of September, 1860, the defendant sold and delivered to the plaintiff, and the plaintiff received from the defendant a chestnut mare at an agreed price of $1,000, and the plaintiff paid $100 down on account; but that prior to the commencement of this action, the defendant, without the knowledge of consent of the plaintiff, took the mare and converted her to his own use, in consequence of which the plaintiff has sustained $1,000 damages.

abstract: At the great gathering of the Union and Wadsworth Clubs at the Cooper Institute to-night, Gen. WADSWORTH, the candidate of the party for Governor, will be present, and Hon. LYMAN TREMAIN will give especial importance to the proceedings by responding at length, and with his usual spirit, to the attacks made upon him by Mr. SEYMOUR, Mr. JOHN VAN BUREN, and other Democratic orators. The meeting will also be addressed by Hon. J.W. FORNEY and Hon. Judge KELLY, of Philadelphia; by Hon. GEORGE S. BOUTWELL, of Massachusetts, and by Messrs. GREELEY, EVARTS and NOYES, of this City. The occasion will, doubtless, be one of the highest interest.

abstract: GENTLEMEN OF THE JURY Your intelligent and patient attention to the testimoney, and to the learned and elaborate arguments of counsel in this case, has enabled you to comprehend the facts, and will ren
lead_paragraph: GENTLEMEN OF THE JURY Your intelligent and patient attention to the testimoney, and to the learned and elaborate arguments of counsel in this case, has enabled you to comprehend the facts, and will render it unneccessary for me to do more than submit the legal principles which should guide you in coming to a conclusion. It is a well-settled rule of law that, before you can convict a prisoner charged with crime, you must be satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt of his guilt. The burden of proof to establish that guilt is on the Government. This principle rests on the well-known role that a man is to be presumed innocent until he is proved guilty. If the evidence offered in support of the charge is circumstantial evidence, that evidence, when taken together, should, in order to warrant his conviction, be inconsistent with any other hypothesis than that of his guilt. These are familiar principles, applicable to the trial of all persons charged with crime. The Judge then read the statute upon which the defendant stands indicted. The first count in the indictment charges, in substance, that, on the first day of June, 1860, the defendant did, at the port of New-York, with force and arms, for himself as owner, fit out, equip and load, and otherwise prepare, a certain steamship called the City of Norfolk, and did cause said steamship to be fitted out, equipped and loaded and otherwise prepared, with intent then and there to employ her in the trade and business and, for the purpose of procuring negroes, mulattoes and persons of color from a certain foreign country -- to wit: Africa - to be transported to a certain place -- to wit: the island of Cuba -- to be held and sold and otherwise disposed of as slaves, and to be held to service and labor, against the peace and contrary to the true intent of the statute of the United States, in such case made and provided. The second count charges that the defendant, on the day aforesaid, and at this port, did, as owner, send away and cause to sail said vessel from this port, with like intent. The third count charges that he did, on the day aforesaid, not as owner, but for some other persons, as factor, fit out, equip, load and otherwise prepare said vessel, and did cause her to be fitted out, loaded and otherwise prepared, with like intent. The fourth count charges that on the day aforesaid, for some other person or persons, he sent or caused her to be sent away and sail from this port, with like intent, she having before that time been fitted out, equipped and loaded by him (the defendant) for that purpose. The fifth count charges that he aided and abetted, for himself, as owner, in fitting out, equipping and loading her for that purpose, with like intent. The sixth count charges that he aided and abetted the fitting out, loading and equipping this steamer, as factor, for others, with like intent. I give only a brief summary of the charges in the several counts, omitting the technicalities, for greater simplicity. The day on which the acts are charged is the 1st of June, 1860; but the precise day, as it may appear in the proofs, is not material. There can be no difficulty on that point, as the acts proved were done, if done at all, about that time. The acts charged, or either one of them constituting the offence, must have been done at the time of their commission with the guilty intent of the defendant, as charged in the indictment, in order to justify a verdict of guilty. The jury will then inquire whether or not the defendant did, for himself, as owner, or for others, as factor, fit out, equip and load at, and send away this steamship from this port, with the guilty intent of employing her in the unlawful business as charged in the indictment, if he did, he is guilty; if he did not, he is not guilty. There are some leading facts that are not controverted, which I will recall to the minds of the jury. This steamer was purchased by the defendant at Baltimore, and brought to this port after finishing a trip for which she was engaged to Savannah. She was sent on a voyage to Havana, in the island of Cuba. She was fitted up and improved in various ways in this port, while she continued to be owned by the defendant, and a cargo put on board of her, and in June, or about that time, she sailed from this port for the island of St. Thomas, in the West indies, in charge of Captain Zadoc A. Tilton, who was then her [???] and the acknowledged agent of the defends. After remaining at that island a few days, an alleged transfer of the steamer took place. Crawford, the first mate, who sailed in her from New-York, taking the title in his own name, and, as she was about to cast off her moorings, was delivered by Capt. Tilton into Crawford's hands, and [???] for the coast of Africa, where she arrived, took on board a large number of negroes and landed them on the Island of Cuba. She was then abandoned by her officers and crew. Now the first question that will naturally suggest itself to the Jury is, [???] the defendants thus prepare, fit out, equip and load this vessel in the port of New-York, with intent to employ her in a voyage of this character? You have heard the testimony of Beufort and Crawford, who sailed in her as officers from New-York, the latter of whom nominally owned and commanded her after she left St. Thomas, and both of whom performed, as it would seem, the entire voyage to Africa and Cuba in her. They swear that the defendant knew the purpose of the voyage at the time she was being fitted here and at the time she sailed. You will remember the details of their testimony. I am requested by the defendant's counsel to instruct you that Beufort and Crawford are accomplices, on their own confession, and that, therefore, you should not convict the defendant on their testimony, unless they are corroborated as to the material facts to which they testify. That they are accomplices there can be no doubt, and while the jury have the power, if they see fit, to convict the defendant upon the testimony of accomplices alone, it is proper, and the only safe course to require corroboration in some material points in their testimony. In weighing their testimony the jury will look at the probability of their story, at their appearance on the stand, and manner of testifying, see how far their statements agree with the undisputed facts in the case, and then say to what degree of credit they are entitled, and what degree of corroboration the jury will require in order to give their testimony full credit. They will then look to the facts disclosed in the case by the other witnesses who are not accomplices, and see if they materially and satisfactorily corroborate their testimony. I say the jury will look to the facts disclosed by others than accomplices, because one accomplice cannot be said to corroborate another. What I have here said as to the necessity of corroboration of an accomplice, will apply to any other witnesses in the case who may also be accomplices. Itwill be recollected that Mrs. Crawford testified todeclaration of the defendant, which, if true, lead to show that he had a knowledge of the guilty object of this voyage before she sailed from New-York, Mrs. Crawford is not, upon the evidence before us, an accomplice, and so far as she testifies to facts not testifies to by her husband, her statements must rest upon her personal credibility, subject to any inconsistency in, or contradiction of her story. Although she cannot in law, as the wife of an accomplice, corroborate and strengthen his particular statements, she is a competent witness, if believed by the jury, to prove any other and independent facts not sworn to by her husband, and not forming part of his acts; although those facts, if believed by the jury, fasten a guilty knowledge on this defendant. The jury will carefully weigh all that part of her testimony which details facts which took place in the absence of her husband, especially the alleged declarations of the defendant to her, or in her presence, and say whether they believe her and are satisfied from her testimony that the defendant had, at the time he fitted out, loaded and equipped this vessel, a guilty knowledge of the purpose of her voyage. If they are satisfied that he knew that this vessel was to be employed in the business which she was afterward engaged, and fitted her out and sent her away with his knowledge, the jury can have no difficulty in determining whether he did thus fit her out, equip and load her at and send her away from this port, with the guilty intent charged in the indictment. As to the extent of the fitment, it is not necessary that it should have included everything required for a successful slave voyage. If she was partially fitted here, and her equipment completed at St. Thomas, and the partial fitment here was done by the defendant, or by his directions or procurement with intent to employ her in this unlawful business, then the crime was committed, and you should find defendant guilty. It is contended by the defendant that the fitment of the vessel here, so far as he was concerned, had no connection, or was not intended by him to have any connection, will the voyage upon which she finally sailed from St. Thomas. And support of this claim Tilton's testimony and Cubelo's deposition are offered, in connection with a letter of instructions to Tilton, and some other evidence, which you will recollect. You have heard the statements of Capt. Tilton, and seen him on the stand. You will recollect that he stated that he had very little to say to Cubelo or Mandillio on the voyage out to St. Thomas, (both of them being on board,) as they talked Spanish. You have heard his statement, that he never talked with Cubelo at all at St. Thomas; and also his account of the alleged sale at St. Thomas. You will have before you also the letter of instructions of the defendant to Tilton, and the deposition of Cubelo, and the letters and papers annexed to it, and von will say whether the extraordinary transaction at St. Thomas, which is termed a sale of this vessel, was a bona fide transaction on the part of Tilton, or whether it was a device to cover a guilty enterprise and conceal the guilty projectors of it. If you are satisfied that the transaction was a mere pretence and cover, and that it was so understood by Tilton, who is an old and experienced shipmaster, then you will say how far he is entitled to credit in the other parts of his testimony. If you are satisfied that this transaction at St. Thomas was a sham, it does not necessarily follow that the defendant authorized it. But you will look further, and see what was the conduct of the defendant when this transaction of his agent, Tilton, was made to known to him. Did he dissent from it, and call Tilton to an account for it? Or did he approve it, or silently acquiesce in it -- in this transaction, in which he had so large an interest? If you find that the defendant did approve or silently acquiesced in this transaction, after its true character became known to him, you will say whether or not it was part of an original scheme in which the fitting out of this vessel at this port was included, and in which the defendant was a participator, with a guilty knowledge and intent. On this point you will consider the facts in connection with the defendant's conduct after the capture of the vessel was known to him, after Crawford and Beaufort returned to this City. If this was a sham sale, and this vessel in which the defendant had so large an interest, had, by thee fraud or recklessness of Capt. Tilton, paused into the hands or under the control of Mandillio, who was guilty of a crime against the defendant, Crawford was an accomplice and Beaufort a tool of Mandillio. The jury should then inquire, from the evidence, what the conduct of the defendant was toward Crawford and Beaufort after they returned to this City. Did he approve or silently acquiesce in what they had done? If the Jury find that he approved or silently acquiesced in their acts after the vessel arrived at St. Thomas, and after she sailed on her unlawful voyage, they will say whether the whole circumstances of the case taken together, which they find proved beyond a reasonable doubt, are consistent with any other hypothesis than that the defendant fitted out this vessel at and sent her from this port, with intent to employ her in the unlawful business in which she engaged. If the whole conduct of the defendant, taken together, from first to last, as the jury shall find it proved beyond a reasonable doubt, is consistent with any hypothesis that admits of his innocence, then he should not be convicted; but if that conduct is inconsistent with any other hypothesis, except that of his guilt, then their verdict should be guilty. The whole case is with the jury. If they are not satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant is guilty, he is entitled to the benefit of a doubt and to an acquittal. If they are satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt that he is guilty, they will render a verdict accordingly.

abstract: -A paragraph found a place among our Washington dispatches yesterday, to the effect that Mr. JOHN W. MCCLURE, of this City, recently appointed to a position in the Quartermaster's Department, was formerly noted for his sympathies with the rebellion. We cheerfully yield to Mr. MCCLURE's request to say that this statement he emphatically denies; and asserts that he has been unwavering in his support of the war from the outset, and has heartily sustained the administration of Mr. LINCOLN.

abstract: Six to one of theIowa soldiers, in the late election, voted for the Union Republican candidates. So would it be through the army, could the men vote, who have pledged their lives to the war. And yet the rebel sympathizers boast over successes due solely to the disfranchisement of hundreds of thousands of our bravest find truest. The late developments ought to confound them. They fix the charge of unsoundness. They prove that these malcontents, who are agitating the [???], are seeking for something which the army is not. They force the conclusion that while the soldiers meets fight, these factious demagogues mean [???]. Every Congressional candidate, who, as a supporter of the Administration, has been overthrown by a Cox, or a Voorhies, is a living testimonial that his district has done its duty in draining itself of its best blood for the war. A defeat, under such circumstances, is an honor, it is only the cow-boy victors, who should beabashed.
lead_paragraph: Six to one of theIowa soldiers, in the late election, voted for the Union Republican candidates. So would it be through the army, could the men vote, who have pledged their lives to the war. And yet the rebel sympathizers boast over successes due solely to the disfranchisement of hundreds of thousands of our bravest find truest. The late developments ought to confound them. They fix the charge of unsoundness. They prove that these malcontents, who are agitating the [???], are seeking for something which the army is not. They force the conclusion that while the soldiers meets fight, these factious demagogues mean [???]. Every Congressional candidate, who, as a supporter of the Administration, has been overthrown by a Cox, or a Voorhies, is a living testimonial that his district has done its duty in draining itself of its best blood for the war. A defeat, under such circumstances, is an honor, it is only the cow-boy victors, who should beabashed.

abstract: There have been auctionsales of works of art almost every day this week; and, notwithstanding the hard times, many fine pictures have sold readily at good prices. To-morrow morning, as will be observed from the advertisement, MINEL & SOMERVILLE will sell from their gallery the admirable collection of oil paintings which has been on exhibition for some time past, and has attracted the attention of connoisseurs. Besides the works of the French, German, and English schools, there are some of the best productions of American artists -- bright gems of genius by EUGGLES, admirable and brilliant glimpses of nature and life by CREESEY, HART, SHATTUCK, CORMAN, NICHOLS, HILL, BROWN, VAN BERST and DANA, and other works by other truthful and loving workers in our native school of art, which really, in many features of conception and execution, is surpassed by no school in the world.

abstract: Isaac Thacher et al. vs. Alexander McAndrew et al. -- This case was brought to recover an amount claimed of the defendant as general average. The ship Rachel, bound from Liverpool to New-York, passed Sandy Hook, and on Sept. 22, 1859, struck on the West Bank. Efforts were made to get her off by tugs, but in vain. The agent of the underwriters came down with steam pumps and other apparatus, and her cargo was discharged into lighters, almost entirely. The cargo belonging to the defendants was discharged with lighters by Sept. 25, and was delivered to them on their signing an average bond. The efforts to get the ship off were then continued, and the vessel was finally got off on Nov. 11. The expense of thus getting her off exceeded the value of the ship when brought to the port. The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants should contribute to this expense.
lead_paragraph: Isaac Thacher et al. vs. Alexander McAndrew et al. -- This case was brought to recover an amount claimed of the defendant as general average. The ship Rachel, bound from Liverpool to New-York, passed Sandy Hook, and on Sept. 22, 1859, struck on the West Bank. Efforts were made to get her off by tugs, but in vain. The agent of the underwriters came down with steam pumps and other apparatus, and her cargo was discharged into lighters, almost entirely. The cargo belonging to the defendants was discharged with lighters by Sept. 25, and was delivered to them on their signing an average bond. The efforts to get the ship off were then continued, and the vessel was finally got off on Nov. 11. The expense of thus getting her off exceeded the value of the ship when brought to the port. The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants should contribute to this expense.

abstract: The delegates to the Republican Convention for Hudson County met yesterday afternoon at Commercial Hall, Jersey City, to make nominations for County offices. Capt. JOHN SIMMS was chosen Chairman, and A.D. BROWER, Secretary. The following nominations were made: For Sheriff, Hon. SAMUEL A. FRENCH, Democrade Union nominee. Coroners -- Dr. WALTER J. HADDEN, Jersey City; JOHN REINHART, Hobokeo, and Dr. JOSIAH HORNBLOWER, Hudson City. A considerable discussion ensued in reference to the nomination of State Senator. The Convention was divided, a portion, favoring the adoption of THEODORE F. RANDOLPH the Democratic nominee, and others advocating denomination of a Republican. Finally, a motion was adopted deeming it inexpedient to nominate a State Senator at the present time, and the Convention adjourned.

abstract: The defeat of a political party from the fact that its members were engaged in defending their country with their lives, is not likely to impair it seriously. The Western Democrats who sent their brethren and friends to the war and then "betrayed them at the polls," will not, probably, enjoy their dishonorable victory...
lead_paragraph: The defeat of a political party from the fact that its members were engaged in defending their country with their lives, is not likely to impair it seriously. The Western Democrats who sent their brethren and friends to the war and then "betrayed them at the polls," will not, probably, enjoy their dishonorable victory any great length of time. The cause of the Union can bear many such defeats and yet be just as strong.

abstract: The German Democrats of New-York had a large ratification meeting last evening at the Cooper Institute, with the usual accompaniments of music, banners, rockets, lights. Ward processions and cannon. In the hali, C. GODFREY GUNTHER presided, and addresses were delivered in English by Hon. S. S. Cox, of Ohio, and Capt. ISAIAH RYNDERS, and in German by Messrs. FICK-LER, MERKLE, OTTENDOERFER, BERGMANN and BUCHSWEILER. An outside concourse listened to the German speeches of Messrs. WEIL VON BUHL, Dr. FRECH, Dr. JULIUS KORN and others. Anti-Administration resolutions were passed, and the throng continued until a late hour.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, the trial of JACOBWELLER for the murder of his wife by shooting with apistol, on the morning of the 26th of August last, wascontinued. Messrs. HOWE and PHILIPS summed upthe case for the defence, and Mr. STEWART, AssistantDistrict-Attorney, made the closing argument for theprosecutor. The Recorder delivered a very ableand impartial charge to the jury, reviewing the wholetestimony in the case, and laying down the law applicable thereto. He said that their verdict must be either murder or acquittal, as there was no evidence that would bring the case under either of the degrees of manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, the trial of JACOBWELLER for the murder of his wife by shooting with apistol, on the morning of the 26th of August last, wascontinued. Messrs. abstract: The difficulty between the caulkers and the bosses is not yet settled. The men demand $3, and the bosses think $2 50 enough. One man offered $2 75, but it was refused. Messrs. SPOFFORD & TILESTON, who had the ship Calhoun upon the large sectional-dock, decided upon lowering the ship and having her repaired in Liverpool.The steamer Ella Warley, on the small balance-dock, foot of Pike-street, was also ordered to be lowered by the owners, and several other vessels waiting to be docked, it was decided upon by the merchants should be taken to foreign ports for repairs. Messrs. E. BUCKNAM & Co., the carpenters employed to strip the ship Calhoun, offered the strikers $2 75, but it was refused. The caulkens in the Navy-yard are still at work at the old price, and are anxiously awaiting the result of the City strike.

abstract: IRVING HALL. -- The success of Mr. HARRISON's third concert (second GOTTSCHALK series) was so marked that the fourth and last -- which takes place to-night -- will probably draw forth one of the largest and most fashionable audiences ever seen in Irving Hall. On Tuesday night, there was only standing room, a condition of things which did not in the slightest degree interfere with the pleasure of the audience, if we may form an idea from the inordinate number of encores which occurred. Miss FANNY STOCKTON was the vocalist of the occasion, and acquitted herself with distinguished honors. Mr. THEODOR THOMAS on the violin, Mr. EBEN on the flute were, as usual, admirable. Mr. CASTLE, the new tenor, improves so rapidly on acquaintance, that he is already a great favorite with the public. These are the auxiliary artists of Mr. HARRISON's really fine entertainments. Mr. GOTTSCHALK is, of course, the principal attraction; on the present occasion he was assisted by Miss BARNETCHE, a young lady who possesses much power and precision as a pianist, and who in the "Trovatore" duet divided the house with Mr. GOTTSCHALK.

abstract: The friends of the sailor will be pleased to know that another society has recently been formed in this City, to promote the temporal and spiritual welfare of seamen. It takes the name of the New-York Seamen's Friend Society. The officers are: Hon. DANIEL, F. TIEMANN, President; Rev. C.K. TRUE, D.D., First Vice-President; JOHN FALCONER, Second Vice-President; A.V. STOUT, Treasurer; Rev. W.H. DIKEMAN, Recording Secretary; Rev. D. TRACY, Corresponding Secretary and Financial Agent. The most prominent object the Society has in view, is the erection of another Sailors' Home, having more particular reference to our navy, which has so suddenly changed from eight to thirty thousand. The great City of New-York has less accommodation of this kind than Boston. The two Homes in this City cannot accommodate more than 250 boarders. We may ask: "What are these among so many? We purpose to erect a building costing about $50,000, and we shall soon be calling on the ship-onwers and Marine Insurance offices and others, to aid in the work. Any one preferring to do something without the personal call, can send the money they wish to contribute to A.V. STOUT, President of the Shoe and Leather Bank, Broadway, corner of Chambers-street.

abstract: We do not learn from our correspondents that any further movement of the Army of the Potomac has taken place since Gen. BURNSIDE crossed the river and proceeded to Lovettsville. A dispatch from Harper's Ferry states that the movements of the enemy are "very mysterious," and reports in regard to them are conflicting. One report states that the whole force under HILL and
lead_paragraph: We do not learn from our correspondents that any further movement of the Army of the Potomac has taken place since Gen. BURNSIDE crossed the river and proceeded to Lovettsville. A dispatch from Harper's Ferry states that the movements of the enemy are "very mysterious," and reports in regard to them are conflicting. One report states that the whole force under HILL and JACKSON has moved from Bunker's Hill to Charlestown, occupying the whole of that village and the roads a mile this side. Another large force had occupied a declivity half a mile beyond the village. The beating of the rebel drums can be distinctly heard at Halltown.

abstract: The result of the contest in the Second Congressional District will be looked for with peculiar interest. The Seymourite candidate, Mr. ODELL, has done a good deal for the soldiers and voted for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. With such antecedents, it has excited some surprise that he should be found now running on the same ticket with Mr. SEYMOUR, who did not favor the giving freedom to the District, and whose election would be as bad for our soldiers as a defeat by the rebels. But since Mr. ODELL has chosen to show himself thus inconsistent, and to place himself by the side of FERNANDO WOOD and Capt. RYNDERS, and the rest of the sympathizers with treason, no man who desires to support the Administration or to help on the war can consistently vote for him. His opponent, Mr. HUMPHREY, is too well known in both cities to need any praise from us. No man can say aught against him, and he should carry the votes of every loyal man in his District. The election of Mr. ODELL will be claimed to be a victory for those who oppose the Government and favor the rebels. It will therefore be a comfort to the rebellion. No such result can in any contingency follow the election of Mr. HUMPHREY.

abstract: This is the war programme of the Seymourites; and under it they expect to delude "war Democrats" into their support. Isn't it a terrible war blast, to be sure? Doesn't it breathe intense hatred of the treason of SUMTER. Doesn't it glow with the patriotic fire of 1776, and 1812? Doesn't it seem like the voice of ANDREW JACKSON, the iron Democrat of 1832, calling the people to arms in defence of his motto -- "The Federal Union, it MUST be preserved?"

abstract: Wednesday evening the Nineteenth Ward Wadsworth and Tremain Clubs held a meeting at No.932 Thirdavenue, for the purpose of ratifying the nomination of JAMES S. WADSWORTH AND LYMAN TREMAIN as...
lead_paragraph: Wednesday evening the Nineteenth Ward Wadsworth and Tremain Clubs held a meeting at No.932 Thirdavenue, for the purpose of ratifying the nomination of JAMES S. WADSWORTH AND LYMAN TREMAIN as Governor and Lieutenant-Governor; also, to ratify the nomination of Col. MCLEOD MURPHY for the Ninth Congressional District, and DENNIS MCCABE for the Sixteenth Assembly District, Mr. C.H. BRAMHALL was elected President of the meeting. A series of resolutions were then read and adopted, pledging the meetings to the support of the nominees. Speeches of the most patriotic character were made by Mr. CHARLES E. WHITEHEAD, Hon. WM. T.B. MILLIKEN, Dr. BERGMANN, and Col. SHANNON, of the First Mississippi Regiment. The meeting then adjourned till this evening, at 7 o'clock, when it will march down to Thirty-fourth-street, join the Clubs of the Twenty-first Ward, and march in a body to the Cooper Institute.

abstract: There can hardly be a doubt of Mr. ORISON BLUNT'S intention to withdraw from the contest in the Sixth Congressional District. A sterling Republican and devout lover of the Union, he certainly will never consent to promote the election of Gen. WARD, the fellow in politics of BEN. and FERNANDO WOOD; and yet it is absolutely certain that, for Mr. BLUNT to remain in the field, would be to elect WARD. By no possibility can Mr. BLUNT secure his own election; he could only secure the defeat of Mr, CONKLING. We submit to Mr. BLUNT whether he may not be postponing his retirement too long, and whether the cause he is anxious to serve may not be damaged by the delay.
lead_paragraph: There can hardly be a doubt of Mr. ORISON BLUNT'S intention to withdraw from the contest in the Sixth Congressional District. By no possibility can Mr. BLUNT secure his own election; he could only secure the defeat of Mr, CONKLING. We submit to Mr. BLUNT whether he may not be postponing his retirement too long, and whether the cause he is anxious to serve may not be damaged by the delay.

abstract: The Union and Wadsworth demonstration last night in and around Cooper Institute was probably the largest and most imposing political gathering that this City has ever seen. The doors of the great hall were no sooner open than it was filled to repletion, and thousands were besieging it for admission; and...
lead_paragraph: The Union and Wadsworth demonstration last night in and around Cooper Institute was probably the largest and most imposing political gathering that this City has ever seen. The doors of the great hall were no sooner open than it was filled to repletion, and thousands were besieging it for admission; and these latter swelled in volume until the whole space from St. Marks-place to the old Astor-place Opera House and Broadway was densely crowded with patriotic American citizens. A fair and, we think, tolerably accurate estimate of the numbers present made them fall not short of twenty-five thousand. This is twice, if not thrice, the number present at the Seymourite assemblage in the City Hall Park on Tuesday night. On this occasion, too, it was not merely a crowd of idle people who had sauntered out in the evening, attracted by the torches and speeches; but it was a patriotic, enthusiastic, whole-souled demonstration on the part of the unflinching supporters of the American Union. The grand outbursts of applause which followed the loyal and warlike sentiments expressed by the various orators showed the extraordinary unanimity of opinion which pervaded the entire mass of voters present.

abstract: Hon. JAS. T. BRADY told a secret to a party of Seymourites whom he addressed at the corner of Twenty-second-street and Broadway, the other night. He told them why he had consented to be a candidate for Governor of the State of New-York, on the Breckinridge ticket,  in 1860.
lead_paragraph: Hon. JAS. T. BRADY told a secret to a party of Seymourites whom he addressed at the corner of Twenty-second-street and Broadway, the other night. He told them why he had consented to be a candidate for Governor of the State of New-York, on the Breckinridge ticket, in 1860. It was, he said, because he foresaw that the Southern States would secede from the Union in consequence of Mr. LINCOLN's election, and he was determined that they should not say that "they had a right to secede because they had no political party to represent them in New-York."

abstract: The audience that crammed to suffocation thespacious hall of the Cooper Institute, large as it was,may be set down as merely a private tea-party, com-pared with the immense [???] of people whocrowded the open space in front of that building and the streets adjacent. If the in-door meeting numbered its thousands, it is safe to say that the out-door meeting numbered its tens of thousands. Even before the meeting in the hall had been called to order, the overflow therefrom had filled the space immediately fronting the north end of the Institute; and by the tune the various Ward Clubs had arrived upon the ground, the entire area extending from the Mercantile Library Building to the east side of the Third-avenue Railroad track, was [???] with one dense mass of human beings. The immensity of the rally was a surprise even to the most sanguine friends of the Wadsworth and Tremain ticket; and the verdict was unanimous, that it was one of the largest, if not the largest night-gathering ever assembled in NewYork. It was past 8 o'clock before the Wadsworth Clubs began to arrive, and, meantime, the crowd listened to inspiring music from a band stationed upon the balcony of the Con, [???] Institute, and watched the course of the sky-rockets that momentarily shot upward, piercing the sky, and letting out from the blue vault a shower of variegated stars. At length the Ward Clubs began to arrive, with their long trail of banners, Chinese lanterns, and blazing Roman candles. First came the Wadsworth and [???] Club of the First Ward, followed by the Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Wards. Then came the Twenty-first, Eighteent, Seventh, Thirteent, Tenth, Ninth, and so [???], until every Ward was represented, and there was no room felteven for that legendary individual known as the "Al-derman of the Twenty-third Ward. [???] Nearly all ofthe deportations were accompanied by a band ofmusic, and the banners consisted mainly of the sim-ple inscription. "Wadsworth and Tremain Club ofthe -- Ward," and the American flag, the most ex-pressive banner of all. There was a total absence ofthose vulgar [???], and [???] banners,with which the Seymour parts attempts to catch theeyes and [???] (no prejudices of the ignorant and[???] but instead of these was the simple name ofthe [???] its candidates, carried side by [???] withits waving stars and stripes. The Ninth Ward Club [???] preceded by a car driven by six white horses and surrounded by a banner inscribed: " Robinson's employers are for the Union" and " the Empire State must do its duty and support the President." This delegation also bore a banner inscribed with the famous words of ANDREW JACKSON -- "The Union, it must and shall be preserved." There were numerous banners inscribed with the name of Capt. JOHN [???] the candidate for Congress in opposition to FERNANDO WOOD, and there can be little doubt that he will poll the larger share of the vote of the working, men of the Ward.

abstract: I go for sustaining the Government in crushing this rebellion." Thus says Col. MCLEOD MURPHY in his letter accepting the Congressional nomination of the Union Republicans for the Ninth. That's the talk! Sustain the. Government, and not drag it down as SEYMOUR advocates. Crush the rebellion, and not bargain with it, as the WOODS and all their tribe hope to do. Col. MURPHY, though a Democrat, has sterling stuff in him. He shows it in his acts, as his splendid discipline and as his riddled banners testify. He shows it in his words, as is evinced in his patriotic appeals for the Government and his protests against faction. He belongs to the highest style of manhood, and every Republican in the Ninth should work for him with a will. He can be elected, and must be.
lead_paragraph: I go for sustaining the Government in crushing this rebellion." Thus says Col. MCLEOD MURPHY in his letter accepting the Congressional nomination of the Union Republicans for the Ninth. That's the talk! Sustain the. Government, and not drag it down as SEYMOUR advocates. Crush the rebellion, and not bargain with it, as the WOODS and all their tribe hope to do. Col. MURPHY, though a Democrat, has sterling stuff in him. He shows it in his acts, as his splendid discipline and as his riddled banners testify. He shows it in his words, as is evinced in his patriotic appeals for the Government and his protests against faction. He belongs to the highest style of manhood, and every Republican in the Ninth should work for him with a will. He can be elected, and must be.

abstract: It is extremely hard for an American community to believe that it is in any real danger. We have indulged in exaggerations so long that simple truth does not arouse us.
lead_paragraph: It is extremely hard for an American community to believe that it is in any real danger. We have indulged in exaggerations so long that simple truth does not arouse us. At every local election for petty offices, during the last twenty years, we have heard the cry that revolution was at hand, and that one party or the other was aiming to destroy our liberties. The choice of a Town Clerk or County Commissioner produced enough terrific oratory to have heralded a second French Revolution. The Federalists, and next the Whigs, were always about to sell the whole United States to the tyrant, England, and then erect a monarchy; and the Democrats were preparing the populace for anarchy and Red Republicanism. When, at length, two years ago, the real wolf came which had been cried so long, and no one believed in it. We could not, for a time, conceive it possible that there could be genuine conspirators against the glorious Republic. We thought the Southern threats a part of the usual heroics which accompany an election defeat. In our simplicity we allowed the traitors and plotters to disarm us and equip themselves for a terrible struggle, without ever believing that they were in earnest. 80 confirmed was this scepticism in the Northern mind of any real danger to the country that but for the keen sense and resolute will of an eminent military man, we should have been aroused from our unbelief by the capture of Washington and the inauguration of a revolutionary Southern administration. The national mind had fed on bombastic oratory and exaggerated rhetoric so long, that it almost lost the sense of reality and simplicity when they were at last presented to it. We never imagined that all our grand figures of Treason assailing the palladium of Liberty, and CATALINE betraying the Republic, and the fair fields of America drenched in civil blood, were ever to be fully realized in our own experience. We said, up to the very last moment, till the thunders of Sumter fell on our incredulous cars, "Oh, this is an election trick! The South will never secede. They will all come in again in sixty days!" And even now, when Treason has stained half a continent with brothers' blood; when the pillars of the Republic tremble to the base, and another year may see anarchy and civil war extended even through the Free States, and the Southern Confederacy triumphant and unassailable, we cannot make thousands of our best citizens see that there is any danger at all. They only say, "Oh, that is an election trick of the Republicans! It will be all right when SEYMOUR is in, and the Democracy have the power. The liberties of America can never be stricken down by her own sons."

lead_paragraph: Amid the conflicting reports which reach us from the Army of the Potomac and from the Army of Virginia, it is impossible yet to determine the whereabouts of the main rebel army under LEE. A special dispatch from Berlin, where Gen. MCCLELLAN now has his headquarters, asserts that it is definitely ascertained that the main body of the rebels is still between Banker's Hill and Winchester: while our correspondent with the Army of Virginia states that Gen. SIGEL and Gen STAHL both believe that LEE has already commenced falling back toward Richmond -- the unusually large rebel forces known to be at the different passes being indicative of this. LONGSTREET, HILL and STUART have been gradually placing their respective forces so that they can stop the gaps in the mountains whenever necessary, to prevent a flank movement against the retreating rebel host. The mystery of the rebel movements it is to be hoped will soon be cleared up.

abstract: It has required a long time to put the tax law in operation. Though the bill was passed by Congress last July it was not placed in effect, in any of its details, until the 1st of September, and although it did not require that its provisions relating to stamp duties should be complied will until Oct. 1, it has been found impossible, as yet, to enforce them.
lead_paragraph: It has required a long time to put the tax law in operation. Though the bill was passed by Congress last July it was not placed in effect, in any of its details, until the 1st of September, and although it did not require that its provisions relating to stamp duties should be complied will until Oct. 1, it has been found impossible, as yet, to enforce them.

abstract: The Court has directed the following arrangement of its business for next week: There will be no calendar made up for Monday or Tuesday in any of the branches, Tuesday being election day. The Courts will simply open on Monday and adjourn to Wednesday, with the exception of Chambers, in which ex parte business will be attended to from 10 A.M. to 12 P.M., on Monday. The General Term commences its business on Wednesday with the non-enumerated calendars. It will be held by Judges Ingraham, Leonard and Barnard. There will be two Circuits, Part I including the Oyer and Terminer, held by Judge Mullen, and Part II by Judge Potter. The latter branch will be held in the new rooms in Duane-street. There will be but one Special Term, held by Judge Clerke, in Duane-street. The Chambers will be held by the Judges holding the General Term, from 10 to 11 A.M. Judge Barnard will hear ex-parte business in the usual room. Judge Ingraham will call the first, second, third and fourth classes of preferred motions in the Special Term Room. Judge Leonard will call the other preferred classes and the General Calendar in the General Term room.

abstract: The public hall over the Hamilton-avenue Market in the Twelfth Ward of Brooklyn, was last evening the scene of a disgraceful disturbance, which doubtless, is to be taken as a foretaste of the kind of free speech which Mr. SEYMOUR tells us conservative ascendancy is to restore to us. The hall had been engaged for a meeting to ratify the Union and Republican nominations for Congress and for the State Legislature, but was early taken possession of by a gang of Democratic rowdies with a predetemined purpose to prevent the holding of the meeting. For more than an hour the atmost confusion prevailed, and amid the din of cheers for SEYMOUR and *ï¿½ [???] WOOD," and groans and hisses for WADSWORTH, the "Wooly-heads," and "Nigger-worshipers." speaking and hearing were alike impossible. The Union men, however, persevered, and after the arrest by the Police of a few of GOV. SEYMOUR'S special friends of the new conservative school, order was at length established, and the speaking proceeded. A very effective speech was made by Mr. BARBER, a prominent citizen of South Brooklyn, who was followed by JOS. G.E. LARNED, from the Novelty Iron Works; WM. II. BURLEIGH, Esq., and others, who gave to the deluded victims of negrophobia some new ideas in regard to the effect of opening the South to free labor by the abolition of Slavery. On the whole, the meeting was a decided success.

abstract: TheRichmond Dispatch published JOHN VAN BUREN'S speech in favor of HORATIO SEYMOUR, in which Mr. VAN BUREN proposes, after Richmond is taken, to let the Southern States "go," and asks the following question: "If the seceded States are to be dismissed in the end, why attempt to take Richmond first? It will only cost thousands of valuable lives. Better let us go now, and save the shedding of so much flood."

It will only cost thousands of valuable lives. Better let us go now, and save the shedding of so much flood."

abstract: SOCIAL MEETING OF INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL CHILDREN. There was a large meeting of the children of the German Industrial School, No. 439 Grand-street, on Wednesday evening, Oct. 29.
lead_paragraph: SOCIAL MEETING OF INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL CHILDREN. There was a large meeting of the children of the German Industrial School, No. 439 Grand-street, on Wednesday evening, Oct. 29. The event of the evening was the presentation of a birth-day bouquet to Capt. P.B. MACY, a gentleman to whom the children, appear warmly attached, for the interest he had shown in the school by his frequent attendance and kindness to the scholars. It was very cheering to witness the scene that took place, and no greater moral evidence could be given of the progress in improvement of the school, and the value of the influences brought to bear upon them. There was much sweet singing during the evening, and the effect was heightened by the addition of some little members of the Cottage place Boys' Meeting, who formed a separate choir, under the superintendence of Mr. A.L. SMITH. Refreshments were distributed to the children in the course of the evening.

abstract: Gilhon Freres vs. Santiago Lindo. The plaintiffs are manufacturers of wines in Bordeaux, whose agents in this City are J. Fassin  Co. It is alloged by the plaintiffs that their agent in New-York...
lead_paragraph: Gilhon Freres vs. Santiago Lindo. The plaintiffs are manufacturers of wines in Bordeaux, whose agents in this City are J. Fassin Co. It is alloged by the plaintiffs that their agent in New-York during the past winter, discovered that large quantities of spurious wine were offering for sale in this market under the name of their principals. They succeeded in tracing its origin to a dwelling-house in Crosby-street, where large quantities of liquor were secretly manufactured and put up by the defendant, Santiago Lindo, in boxes and bottles, bearing their names. They immediately obtained from the Superior Court a preliminary injunction against the use of Messrs. Guilhon's name and trade-mark; a motion to dissolve which was denied.

abstract: The Seymourites havestarted frightful stories of the imminence of foreign intervention, and will doubtless multiply them before the election. The object is plain. It is hoped that the fear of foreign attack upon us will impel the faint-hearted to vote for the candidate who favors compromise and peace. Well, let those who canhe so easily scared go for him. He is their man.

abstract: -The Union refugees from the South unanimously favor WADSWORTH's election. They do not favor the peaceful departure of the "wayward sisters," even after Richmond is taken, which, we believe, is the extreme limit of our prosecution of the war as proposed by the Seymourites. They have been robbed, their companions murdered, shot, hung, and they hope to see these outrages punished, and their own safety and that of their families secured for the future. Hence, they oppose Mr. SEYMOUR, and his friends, who call this war an[???] war upon our Southern brethren."[???] "if we elect [???][???] Shall we stand by the Southern Union men or the rebels and their Northern sympathizers?

abstract: SEYMOUR AND SUBMISSION. -- Such is the true way of putting it. The only war worthy of the name is that which WADSWORTH supports -- war that hesitates at no effective means, and that knows no other limit than the utter prostration of the rebellion. All short of that, call it by what name you may, is simply submission. Whether qualified or unqualified, whether an absolute surrender of every thing which the rebels demand, or a bargain with them to leave some things and take the [???] it is a yielding, a giving in, a tree. [???] which is [???] it all cost [???] this [???] this [???] and [???] breath? Then vote for WADSWORTH. Are you for fighting it not because you hate it, but to meet the pressure of the hour? -- for fighting it tenderly and considerately, so that it shall not be hit in its vital parts? and for ceasing to fight it just so soon as you can come to a parley and make terms with it? Then SEYMOUR is your man.
